EVENT_NARRATIVE: Newspaper accounts showed flash flooding across roads in Punxsutawney and along SR 199. Several roads in Punxsutawney closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a strong cold front moving across the Ohio Valley, producing large hail and wind damage across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Isolated flash flooding also occurred across western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on SR 910 and Grubs Rd with homes flooded on Ramsgate rd. Deer Creek out of it's banks and flooding Gibsonia Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front that helped end the heat wave across the region also triggered thunderstorms that caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain produced poor drainage flooding and flooding along streams in a narrow axis from Fleetwood in Berks County into Upper and Lower Macungie Townships and South Whitehall Township in Lehigh County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches  within this band.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a strong cold front moving across the Ohio Valley, producing large hail and wind damage across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Isolated flash flooding also occurred across western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with several roads and basements flooded in Uniontown with SR 51 also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Bucks and Montgomery County border on the evening of the 4th. The runoff from the heavy rain later caused flooding along the Neshaminy Creek. Precipitation event totals reached around two inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as roadway flooding in southeastern Montgomery County. The flooding was centered in and around Horsham Township. Keith Valley Road in Horsham was closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.51 inches in Harleysville and 2.12 inches in Hatboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorns across eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. The thunderstorms themselves moved slowly and caused flash flooding in the Poconos where radar estimated storm totals reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the smaller streams as well as roadway flooding in northeast Monroe County. Flooded roadways were reported in Middle Smithfield Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 5 inches in Price Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms and isolated flash flooding occurred along a stalled frontal boundary across western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding along RT 130/the Tri-Boro highway extending from the Springhill Bridge to Patton ST. Numerous roads closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low moved south across the eastern Great Lakes and combined with daytime heating produced thunderstorms across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia. Isolated flash flooding and severe thunderstorms occurred across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with several roads flooded in Greensburg and Hempfield Townships. This included East Pittsburgh St. and Oakville as well as Jefferson Ave. and Roseytown Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and isolated thunderstorms developed across the Ohio Valley as low pressure moves east across the region. Isolated heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Allegheny county Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with up to one foot of water flowing across the intersection of Allegheny Blvd. and Washington Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from heavy rain during the late morning and early afternoon caused flash flooding of smaller streams, basement and poor drainage flooding mainly across extreme eastern Pennsylvania. Flooding later that afternoon and evening occurred across a few of the larger streams and creeks. Numerous vehicles drove around barricades and motorists had to be rescued. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals averaged around one to three inches with the highest amounts toward New Jersey.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flood waters entered the basement of the Hillside Garden Complex. Three families had water in their apartments and were assisted by the Red Cross. Basement flooding was also reported in Roxborough. The runoff from the heavy rain and the onshore flow also caused minor tidal flooding along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries between 2 p.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.44 feet above mean lower low water and minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1253 p.m. EST through 213 p.m. EST on the 8th. It crested at 7.82 feet at 115 p.m. EST. Event precipitation totals included 2.44 inches in Pine Valley, 2.37 inches at the Franklin Institute, 2.28 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport and 2.05 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from heavy rain during the late morning and early afternoon caused flash flooding of smaller streams, basement and poor drainage flooding mainly across extreme eastern Pennsylvania. Flooding later that afternoon and evening occurred across a few of the larger streams and creeks. Numerous vehicles drove around barricades and motorists had to be rescued. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals averaged around one to three inches with the highest amounts toward New Jersey.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain caused roadway flooding and stream flooding. A woman was rescued from her stranded vehicle in Zucksville Road in Forks Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.53 inches in Tatamy, 2.18 inches in Forks Township, 1.72 inches in Walnutport and 1.52 inches in Bethlehem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain over saturated ground caused flash flooding along roadways and smaller streams in the Philadelphia northwest suburbs. The flooding occurred across northern parts of Chester County and central parts of Montgomery and Bucks Counties. Event totals averaged 1.5 inches to 2.5 inches with over an inch occurring within an hour as the thunderstorms moved through between Midnight and 2 a.m. EDT on the 20th. The thunderstorms formed along and preceding a cold front that was moving through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Chester County, the run-off from the heavy rain led to flooding along the West Branch of the Brandywine Creek at Honey Brook. The creek was above its 7 foot flood stage from 421 a.m. EDT through 825 a.m. EDT on the 20th and crested at 8.41 feet at 545 a.m. EDT. Storm totals included 2.21 inches in Honey Brook and 1.60 inches in Glenmoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent thunderstorms produced heavy rain and Flash Flooding in Warren County. Eventually, the flash flooding threat ended, yet flooding persisted into the morning of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving and repetitive thunderstorms caused flash flooding across northwest Warren County. Portions of State Routes 6, 957, 426 27 and 77 were closed due to flooding. Several water rescues were performed near Sugar Grove along Route 957. Near Youngsville, the porch of a home was washed away, and the resident had to be rescued from the home. Several feet of water over Miles Run Road in Pittsfield Township was also observed. Flash flooding abated, but flooded roads continued into the morning hours, and flood warnings replaced flash flood warnings until waters receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading heavy rain across northeast Pennsylvania from Friday afternoon through Saturday night. Rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches and melting snowfall caused flooding of some roadways, basements, and smaller creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Summit Creek Road was flooded by excessive rain and snow-melt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed south into the area and stalled, as a strong low pressure system moved northeast along the boundary. While areas north and along the frontal boundary received mixed precipitation, heavy rain fell to the south. Combined with runoff from existing snow pack, flash flooding was experienced across parts of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covered three parts of Route 220 in Albany Township from flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading heavy rain across northeast Pennsylvania from Friday afternoon through Saturday night. Rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches and melting snowfall caused flooding of some roadways, basements, and smaller creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Huntsville Creek flowed out of its banks. A portion of Hillside Road was closed for about one hour, as the water receded quickly before major damage occurred. Some basements were flooded, as well as some barns and fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading heavy rain across northeast Pennsylvania from Friday afternoon through Saturday night. Rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches and melting snowfall caused flooding of some roadways, basements, and smaller creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded, along with several basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the Gulf Coast and moved northeast through the Mid-Atlantic states, spreading heavy rain across northeast Pennsylvania from Friday afternoon through Saturday night. Rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches and melting snowfall caused flooding of some roadways, basements, and smaller creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous back roads were flooded and impassible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from heavy rain during the late morning and early afternoon caused flash flooding of smaller streams, basement and poor drainage flooding mainly across extreme eastern Pennsylvania. Flooding later that afternoon and evening occurred across a few of the larger streams and creeks. Numerous vehicles drove around barricades and motorists had to be rescued. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals averaged around one to three inches with the highest amounts toward New Jersey.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding along the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek as well as started flooding along the Neshaminy Creek. Creek flooding occurred along Chatham Avenue in Falls Township. Roadway flooding occurred on Street Road in and around Bensalem. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek was above its 5 foot flood stage from 202 p.m. EST through 345 p.m. EST on the 8th. It crested at 5.55 feet at 245 p.m. EST. The Neshaminy Creek at Langhorne started flooding at 309 p.m. EST on the 8th. Please refer to the flood entry for Bucks County for further details. Event precipitation totals included 2.70 inches in Southampton, 2.38 inches in Newtown, 2.34 inches in Perkasie, 2.26 inches in Neshaminy Falls and 1.85 inches in Springtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain over saturated ground caused flash flooding along roadways and smaller streams in the Philadelphia northwest suburbs. The flooding occurred across northern parts of Chester County and central parts of Montgomery and Bucks Counties. Event totals averaged 1.5 inches to 2.5 inches with over an inch occurring within an hour as the thunderstorms moved through between Midnight and 2 a.m. EDT on the 20th. The thunderstorms formed along and preceding a cold front that was moving through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Event totals included 1.58 inches in Graterford and 1.55 inches in Pottstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain over saturated ground caused flash flooding along roadways and smaller streams in the Philadelphia northwest suburbs. The flooding occurred across northern parts of Chester County and central parts of Montgomery and Bucks Counties. Event totals averaged 1.5 inches to 2.5 inches with over an inch occurring within an hour as the thunderstorms moved through between Midnight and 2 a.m. EDT on the 20th. The thunderstorms formed along and preceding a cold front that was moving through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Event precipitation totals included 1.70 inches in Perkasie and 1.58 inches in Doylestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front that helped end the heat wave across the region also triggered thunderstorms that caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain produced poor drainage flooding and flooding along streams in a narrow axis from Fleetwood in Berks County into Upper and Lower Macungie Townships and South Whitehall Township in Lehigh County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches  within this band. A Cocorahs mesonet observer four miles west of Allentown and near the south end of the heavy rain axis measured 1.91 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from heavy rain during the late morning and early afternoon caused flash flooding of smaller streams, basement and poor drainage flooding mainly across extreme eastern Pennsylvania. Flooding later that afternoon and evening occurred across a few of the larger streams and creeks. Numerous vehicles drove around barricades and motorists had to be rescued. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals averaged around one to three inches with the highest amounts toward New Jersey.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A woman was rescued from flood waters surrounding her stranded vehicle near the Pennypack Creek in Upper Moreland Township. Flooding also started along the Wissahickon Creek in the Fort Washington area. Event precipitation totals included 2.26 inches in Hatboro, 2.01 inches in Pottstown and 1.76 inches in Hatfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding across northwestern Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flooding across northwestern Lancaster County. Flooded roadways were reported in West Donegal and Mt. Joy Townships, including Rutts Road, Maytown Road, Campus Road and Hershey Quarry Road. Flooding was also reported in Manheim and near Lititz on Route 772. A water rescue was performed in Donegal Township at 2151 EST. There were no injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorns across eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. The thunderstorms themselves moved slowly and caused flash flooding in the Poconos where radar estimated storm totals reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding of smaller streams as well as a few roadways in Polk, Chestnuthill and Hamilton Townships. Flooding also affected U.S. Route 209 in Hamilton Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 inches in Polk Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorns across eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. The thunderstorms themselves moved slowly and caused flash flooding in the Poconos where radar estimated storm totals reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding of smaller streams as well as roadways along the Kidder and Penn Forest Township lines. A few roadways remained closed due to flooding into the evening of the 14th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area causing showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A few of the thunderstorms became severe, while an area of training thunderstorms produced flash flooding in northwestern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2 to locally 3.5 inches fell in less than 2 hours across eastern and central Crawford county, flooding several major roadways.  US 6/SR 19 was impassable and closed in multiple locations between Saegertown and Cambridge Springs.  An observer in Springboro recorded 1.95 inches of rainfall from the storms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front extending from southern New England through the Delmarva region pulled eastward as low pressure developed along the boundary. As moisture pulled northward, heavy rain showers and thunderstorms developed, producing severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge was flooded from Cork Hill Creek near Little Meadows. A road was also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dissipating but stalled frontal boundary helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy rain during the late afternoon of the 6th in Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly stationary thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the southern part of Philadelphia. Several vehicles stalled and became stuck in high water along Penrose Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered slow moving thunderstorms developed under weak low pressure aloft across northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania with some flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty NWS employee reported flash flooding along Belleau St in Pittsburgh closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area causing showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A few of the thunderstorms became severe, while an area of training thunderstorms produced flash flooding in northwestern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2 to 3 inches in less than 1.5 hours produced flash flooding in western Crawford county, closing several roadways including SR 77 near Spartansburg and SR 408 near Hydetown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of showers and thunderstorms developed over the warm waters of Lake Erie on the morning of the 22nd.  These storms were characterized by very heavy rainfall rates, and produced flash flooding in northwestern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2 to 3.5 inches fell in less than 1.5 hours across northeastern Erie County, producing flash flooding in and near the town of North East.  Basements and garages were reported flooded all over town due to the runoff, and an apartment complex was flooded by overflow from a creek in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front and tropical moisture that moved into the region from a decaying low pressure system over the Carolinas produced heavy rain over Eastern Pennsylvania between 6 a.m. EDT and 6 p.m. EDT on the 28th. This caused flooding and flash flooding, especially in or near the Lehigh Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused the flooding and washouts of a few roads in Durham and Nockamixon Townships. A large mudslide occurred across Pennsylvania State Route 611 in Durham Township and closed it. Other major roads closed in the area included Center Hill and Kintner Hill Roads. Water poured down the embankment of Pennsylvania State Route 212 overran a house on Old Furnace Road. The water broke windows, filled the basement with water and tore away the driveway. The rush of water also scattered boulders and smaller rocks that clogged Rodges Run under two bridges on Lehnenberg Road. Pennsylvania State Route 611 was closed in both directions until the 29th. Flooding along Gallows Run and rock slides caused the road to be closed from Pennsylvania State Route 212 to Centerhill Road. In Nockamixon Township, a 170-year-old stone wall collapsed under the weight of water cascading off the steep cliffs that hug the southbound side of River Road. The rain overflowed a culvert off the cliff side of the road, washed across the roadway, filled the canal and shattered the wall. Repairs were estimated at $500,000. A homeowner on River Road in the township saw hundreds of rocks carried onto his property by a flooding stream and then onto River Road. The stream knocked down 100 feet of fencing and carried away a propane tank. The precipitation total for the 28th from the Lehigh Valley International Airport was 3.83 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some isolated pulse type thunderstorms that moved across the same areas in Berks County produced falsh flooding during the afternoon of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moving over the same areas of central Berks County produced flash flooding and poor drainage flooding. Creeks in Rockland Township flooded. Poor drainage flooding was reported in Reading. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 5 and 6 inches in Alsace Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Tropical Storm Hanna caused widespread heavy rain and poor drainage flooding. Minor roadway flooding was reported throughout the Philadelphia suburbs. Some basements were flooded in the Lehigh Valley. The runoff also caused flooding along a couple of the smaller streams and creeks in Eastern Pennsylvania. Rain began during the second half of the morning of the 6th and fell at its heaviest during the afternoon and early evening. The rain ended by late that evening. Storm totals averaged from around 2 inches to around 4 inches. The lightest amounts were in the Poconos, the heaviest in the Philadelphia northwest suburbs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding along Frankford Creek. The creek was above its 7 foot flood stage from 613 p.m. EDT through 717 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.27 feet at 645 p.m. EDT. Storm totals included 2.27 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 1.97 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A secondary cold frontal passage coupled with an upper air disturbance aloft helped cause flash flooding in Monroe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused stream, street and poor drainage flooding in Hamilton Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 5 and 6 inches in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Bucks and Montgomery County border on the evening of the 4th. The runoff from the heavy rain later caused flooding along the Neshaminy Creek. Precipitation event totals reached around two inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding across central and lower Bucks Counties. In Warrington Township, Street and Folly Roads were closed. Flooding and road closures also occurred along Taylorsville Road in Lower Makefield Township and Second Street Pike in Southampton Township. Poor drainage flooding was also reported along Indian Creek Drive in Bristol Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.21 inches in Doylestown, 1.99 inches in Washington Crossing and 1.64 inches in Neshaminy Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low moved south across the eastern Great Lakes and combined with daytime heating produced thunderstorms across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia. Isolated flash flooding and severe thunderstorms occurred across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding along Millers Run Rd near  Treveskyn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed south into the area and stalled, as a strong low pressure system moved northeast along the boundary. While areas north and along the frontal boundary received mixed precipitation, heavy rain fell to the south. Combined with runoff from existing snow pack, flash flooding was experienced across parts of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide blocked the road across Route 220 in Monroe Township and closed the road at that location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving southeast across the Great Lakes triggered severe thunderstorms across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening hours. Several of these storms moved repeatedly across the same areas of Columbia County, causing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several thunderstorms produced heavy rain over portions of Columbia County. Two rain gauge reports of 3.55 inches and 4.00 inches was recorded over several hours just east of the Bloomsburg fairgrounds. Overall, there were about 15 roads closed throughout the county including five in Hemlock Township, four in Scott Township, three in the city of Bloomsburg, two in Franklin Township, and at one in each of Montour, Catawissa and Locust Townships. ||Three rock/mud slides were also reported from the heavy rain, in Franklin Township,  Scott Township and near the Bloomsburg Fairgrounds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain produced isolated flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain produced flash flooding across central Potter County. A number of small streams...including the head waters of Mill Creek...were out of their banks in Sweden Township. Small stream flooding and some road flooding was also reported in and around the towns of Odin and Austin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported roads and homes flooded throughout Dunbar Township due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Kennedy BLVD and Franklin AVE in Aliquippa closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported widespread flash flooding across much of western amd central Westmorland county from Murrysville to Greensburg and Mount Pleasant. At least 1,192 buildings were affected, with 136 having major damage and 11 buildings destroyed. Damages were estimated to be around 9 million dollars. Most major roadways had flooding and some were closed well after the water receded to clear debris. The hardest hit areas from Murrysville to Greensburg had rainfall of over 4 inches in 3 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Independence RD closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported 4TH Street near Route 65 closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front advancing eastward through the Ohio Valley. The storms produced isolated wind damage and several areas of locally heavy rainfall from the late afternoon hours through the overnight period. Torrential downpours prompted numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flash flooding in the city of Warren, eastward to near the Kinzua Dam. A rock slide was reported along Route 59 about 1 mile west of Kinzua Dam. Several flooded roads were also noted in and around the city of Warren.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front advancing eastward through the Ohio Valley. The storms produced isolated wind damage and several areas of locally heavy rainfall from the late afternoon hours through the overnight period. Torrential downpours prompted numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding throughout much of northeast and east-central McKean County. Flooding was reported along Route 6, Route 46 and Route 155. Flooding was especially noted in the towns of Smethport, Port Allegheny and Marvindale, with roads closed and some basement flooding. In Port Allegany, the Medberry Manor Assisted Living Facility was evacuated as a result of flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front advancing eastward through the Ohio Valley. The storms produced isolated wind damage and several areas of locally heavy rainfall from the late afternoon hours through the overnight period. Torrential downpours prompted numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in central portions of Huntingdon County. In Smithfield and Juniata Townships, there was a report of a 200 yard wide area of geological subsidence due to a rockslide. Numerous roads were flooded and closed, with basement flooding and some road erosion. Route 22 was flooded. Two bridges were impacted with debris. The debris caused a diversion of a stream into a home which suffered moderate damages. Numerous road closures and basement flooding was also reported in Walker and Union townships. In Walker Township, Hartslog Valley Road, Station Road, Pond Road and Route 26 were closed due to flooding. In total, about 120 homes reported basement flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front advancing eastward through the Ohio Valley. The storms produced isolated wind damage and several areas of locally heavy rainfall from the late afternoon hours through the overnight period. Torrential downpours prompted numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused extensive flash flooding across central and western portions of Perry County. Numerous roads were flooded throughout the county, including Route 233, Route 850, Route 274, Route 34 and Route 74. Approximately 25 to 30 homes along Sherman Creek were evacuated due to rising flood waters. Five water rescues were performed. Over 100 basements were flooded. Much of the flooding occurred between Landisburg and Loysville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front advancing eastward through the Ohio Valley. The storms produced isolated wind damage and several areas of locally heavy rainfall from the late afternoon hours through the overnight period. Torrential downpours prompted numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in northern portions of Cumberland County. Roads were closed in Upper and Lower Mifflin Township. A rock slide occurred along Route 233 southwest of Colonel Denning State Park. Campers were also evacuated from the Park. In the vicinity of Doubling Gap Creek, several roads were also closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm with torrential downpours formed along the warm frontal boundary in Berks County during the evening of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flooding in and around Richmond Township in Berks County. Roads were flooded and closed in the area. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 3.0 inches, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain and moist soil conditions caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and eventually flooding of a larger creek in Montgomery County. While some light rain fell during the evening of the 6th, the heaviest rain fell between Midnight EDT and 3 a.m. EDT on the 7th as thunderstorms moved through the region. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches across sections of central Chester, Montgomery and Bucks Counties. The thunderstorms formed along a warm front that was moving north across the region during the early morning on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Valley Creek at Valley Forge exceeded its 7 foot flood stage from 256 a.m. EDT through 402 a.m. EDT on the 7th. It crested at 7.27 feet at 330 a.m. EDT. Chester County storm totals included 1.74 inches in Downingtown and 1.43 inches in West Chester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm complex, with origins from the Midwest and Ohio Valley, produced a quick one to two inches of rainfall over portions of the Laurel Highlands and south-central Mountains during the early morning.  This lead to rapid rises on small creeks and streams, which overflowed their banks and flooded several secondary roads. Later in the afternoon, isolated severe thunderstorms developed over the Lower Susquehanna Valley ahead of a cold front. These storms produced wind damage in York and Lancaster counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from slow moving thunderstorms caused numerous flooded roads between Spangler and Patton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna during the late afternoon and evening of the 10th into the early morning hours on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported heavy rain and flash flooding in south-central York County. The majority of the significant flooding was in Codorus Township, North Codorus Township, Jefferson Borough, Seven Valleys Borough and Shrewsbury Township. North Codorus Township was most heavily impacted with 15 to 20 roads sustaining moderate to major damage and culvert and berm wash-outs. Some bridge surface wash-out was also reported. Approximately 8 homes had flooded basements, with one garage that also had some foundation damage. During the event, there were two water rescues where water had surrounded their homes. Their were no injuries. ||The onset of minor flooding which included street flooding began around 4:10 pm EDT in North Codorus Township in the vicinity of Shaffers Church Rd and Heindel Rd. The first flooded basement report was received at 4:40 pm EDT. ||Significant Flash Flooding began around 4:50 pm EDT, with water surrounding a house on Strickhouser Road. Roadways under water were reported around 5:37 pm EDT, including Seven Valleys Road and Cherry Street in Codorus township. At 5:54 pm EDT, water up to the first floor of a home was reported on Kraft Mill Rd in North Codorus Township. Significant flash flooding began in Seven Valleys Borough around 5:55 pm EDT where Seven Valleys Fire Station were evacuating personnel and equipment. Several houses in the area had basement flooding in the area.| |Spruce Road and Country Club Road in Shrewsbury Township were completely flooded at 6:04 pm EDT. The surface of a bridge along Route 616 in the area of Junction Road in North Codorus Township was washed away. Flooding peaked and water began subsiding after 9:30 pm EDT.||North Codorus, Codorus Township and the boroughs of Seven Valleys and Jefferson each declared disaster emergencies related to the flash flooding with overall damages estimated well-over 100K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna during the late afternoon and evening of the 10th into the early morning hours on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Emergency Management and local law enforcement reported flash flooding over portions of Franklin County. Three roads were closed in Guilford and Quincy Townships. One vehicle was stranded in Guilford Township. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain and moist soil conditions caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and eventually flooding of a larger creek in Montgomery County. While some light rain fell during the evening of the 6th, the heaviest rain fell between Midnight EDT and 3 a.m. EDT on the 7th as thunderstorms moved through the region. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches across sections of central Chester, Montgomery and Bucks Counties. The thunderstorms formed along a warm front that was moving north across the region during the early morning on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flooding across smaller creeks in central and upper Bucks County. The runoff and smaller stream flooding also led to flooding along the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek in  Montgomery County. Bucks County storm totals included 2.03 inches in Perkasie, 1.18 inches in Doylestown and 1.10 inches in Newtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm complex, with origins from the Midwest and Ohio Valley, produced a quick one to two inches of rainfall over portions of the Laurel Highlands and south-central Mountains during the early morning.  This lead to rapid rises on small creeks and streams, which overflowed their banks and flooded several secondary roads. Later in the afternoon, isolated severe thunderstorms developed over the Lower Susquehanna Valley ahead of a cold front. These storms produced wind damage in York and Lancaster counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding on numerous township and secondary roads in Antis Township. A number of berm washouts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large thunderstorm complex evolved southeastward from the Upper Ohio Valley and across southwestern Pennsylvania during the late evening and early overnight hours. Locally heavy rainfall of over 2 inches in a short duration produced rapid rises on area creeks and streams, causing them to overflow their banks. This resulted in flooded roads and basements across portions of southwestern Somerset County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in Lower Turkeyfoot Township near the town of Ursina. Laurel Hill Creek rose over 4 feet and flooded Humbert and Jersey Hollow Roads. A number of basements were also flooded. Some additional minor flooding and flooded basements were noted south of Somerset.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain and moist soil conditions caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and eventually flooding of a larger creek in Montgomery County. While some light rain fell during the evening of the 6th, the heaviest rain fell between Midnight EDT and 3 a.m. EDT on the 7th as thunderstorms moved through the region. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches across sections of central Chester, Montgomery and Bucks Counties. The thunderstorms formed along a warm front that was moving north across the region during the early morning on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flooding across smaller creeks in central Montgomery County. The runoff and smaller stream flooding also led to flooding along the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek. Montgomery County storm totals included 1.91 inches in Hatfield, 1.55 inches in Oreland, 1.51 inches in Kulpsville, 1.26 inches in Green Lane and 1.20 inches in Pottstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with training thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Middle Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rainfall produced flash flooding along Fishing Creek in Benton. The creek came out of its banks and flooded portions of a boy scout camp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with training thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Middle Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a mudslide along Route 15.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall of 1-2 inches in a short duration produced flash flooding along Route 72 and Route 322 southbound near Cornwall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with training thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Middle Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2-3 inches in a short duration produced flash flooding in the Muncy, Hughesville and Clarkstown areas. Several small streams and creeks exceeded bankfull including Muncy Creek along Routes 405 and 422 between Muncy and Hughesville. Nearly three feet of water closed roads in Muncy Creek Township near Clarkstown. Numerous low-lying and poor drainage flooding was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced significant flash flooding across northern York County. Flooding closed numerous roads in Carrol Township. A water rescue was performed at the intersection of the Gettysburg Pike and Chestnut Street on the Rosegarden underpass, where two vehicles with 4-5 occupants were stranded. Junction Road bridge over the Dogwood Creek was jammed with debris, causing water to spill over the bridge and damage the road/bridge structure. West Siddonsburg Road between Route 15 and Orebank Road was closed due to flooding. A rock slide occurred on Mt. Airy and Ridge Road in Monaghan Township. Significant damage was reported on Guilbert Road between West Siddonsburg Road and Stony Run Road along the Cumberland County line. Route 74 was closed between Campground Road and Williams Grove Road. Fairview and Monaghan Townships each issued disaster declarations for the aftermath of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding just north of Carlisle in North Middletown Township. Three to five feet of water inundated several homes along Echo Road. Water was over the top of resident mailboxes in some areas. Several municipal roads were also closed due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding just south of Chambersburg along Interstate 81 between mile markers 10 and 13. The northbound lane at the Lighthouse Road overpass was covered by four inches of water. Eight residents were displaced due to flooding in Chambersburg Borough along Falling Spring Road. A partial foundation collapse occurred to a home on Country Road in Guilford Township. Nearly five inches of rainfall was reported in Scotland between 330 and 600 pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developing along a squall line caused very heavy rain and flash flooding near the Berks and Chester County borders.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage as well as stream flooding in Caernarvon Township in cluding the Morgantown area. Doppler Radar storm total estimates for the day reached between 3 and 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms that moved across Montgomery and Bucks Counties dropped heavy rain over the region. An unseasonably wet June made it easier for flash flooding to occur across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding of streams in the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek basin in West Rockhill Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.96 inches in the township, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding along the Pennsylvania Turnpike near Newville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding throughout south-central Clinton County. Numerous small streams were flooded causing road and bridge closures in Woolrich, McElhatten and Avis. Flash flooding caused a washout along Coudersport Pike/Route 664 and Middle Hill Road in Woodward Township. Lusk Run, Fairport Road and Orner Road were flooded in Bald Eagle Township. Flooding was also reported on Spong Hollow Road in Dunnstable Township and on Little Plum Road, Gravel Hill Road, Owl Hollow Road, Park Avenue, Sulfur Run Road and Steward Road in Pine Creek Township. Chatham Run was out of its banks at Gravel Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding just southeast of Mechanicsburg in Upper Allen Township. Several residents were evacuated from flooded homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms along a nearly stationary cold front produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley. Rainfall amounts ranged from three to six inches in less than three hours with the highest amounts over eastern Cumberland, eastern Franklin and northern York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding across southwest Lycoming County. The flooding washed out a portion of Route 44 in Watson Township. A rock slide occurred on Route 973 in Watson and Mifflin Townships. The Salladasburg Borough also reported flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, a squall line of thunderstorms that formed near a warm frontal boundary produced flash flooding in Chester County during the morning of June 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding of Goose Creek in West Chester. Residents along the 300 block of East Union Street were evacuated until the flooding subsided that afternoon. No injuries or damage were reported. The morning event total in Downingtown was 1.90 inches.||The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain during the morning and afternoon swelled all creeks in Chester County. Two male kayakers drowned in the swollen Brandywine Creek on the afternoon of the 9th in East Bradford Township. One man was pulled from the creek at 210 p.m. EDT that afternoon. They were last seen on the creek near a four foot high dam north of a bridge near Creek Route and Pennsylvania State Route 52 in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with training thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Middle Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding just north of Watsontown in Delaware Township along Route 405. A trailer park was inundated by up to six feet of water with at least ten trailers flooded. One resident was temporarily evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cool air associated with a strong upper level low over the Great Lakes region combined with warm Lake Erie waters to produce persistent, intense lake-enhanced rainfall which trained repeatedly over northern Erie County, Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of the 30th.  Over 4 inches of rain fell along the Interstate 90 corridor from near Girard to just south of Erie, with isolated locations approaching 7 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ongoing, persistent line of lake-enhanced showers re-intensified around 9am local daylight time and shifted north of Interstate 90, inducing rapid rises along Mill Creek in the City of Erie as well as in many neighborhoods on the south side of town.  Especially hard hit were areas in Belle Valley along Mill Creek, which quickly rose out of its banks, flooding roadways and over 50 homes near East Gore Road.  The Belle Valley Fire Station, located at Norcross Road and State Route 8, flooded to a depth of 6 feet within minutes around 9:30am as Mill Creek rose out of its banks.  800 feet of Henderson Road was washed out just upstream from Belle Valley, while downstream, high water from Mill Creek flooded the Erie Zoo and Glenwood Park Avenue.  Flooding was widespread in residential areas between Interstate 79 and Mill Creek, as storm sewers were overwhelmed by the additional heavy rainfall.  Emergency personnel responded to well over 50 calls for rescue assistance from stranded motorists and homeowners.  At 10:30am, City of Erie authorities requested that non-essential travel stop due to the widespread flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains that moved across the same parts of the Poconos produced flooding during the afternoon and evening of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain forced some small streams out of their banks in Pocono Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were around three inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cool air associated with a strong upper level low over the Great Lakes region combined with warm Lake Erie waters to produce persistent, intense lake-enhanced rainfall which trained repeatedly over northern Erie County, Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of the 30th.  Over 4 inches of rain fell along the Interstate 90 corridor from near Girard to just south of Erie, with isolated locations approaching 7 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ongoing, persistent line of lake-enhanced showers re-intensified around 9am local daylight time and shifted north of Interstate 90, inducing rapid rises along Fourmile Creek in Wesleyville, Harborcreek Township, and Lawrence Park.  Residences along Mindi Court in the Spring Creek Mobile Home Park were flooded as Fourmile Creek rose 4 to 5 feet out of bank.  Fourmile Creek also flooded East Lake Road (State Route 5) in Lawrence Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cool air associated with a strong upper level low over the Great Lakes region combined with warm Lake Erie waters to produce persistent, intense lake-enhanced rainfall which trained repeatedly over northern Erie County, Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of the 30th.  Over 4 inches of rain fell along the Interstate 90 corridor from near Girard to just south of Erie, with isolated locations approaching 7 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The persistent line of lake-enhanced showers causing flooding in Erie increased in intensity westward toward Girard after 9am local daylight time, with two to four inches of rain falling in less than two hours.  Earlier rains had fallen over the headwaters of Elk Creek, creating a high water crest that reached Fairview and Girard Townships just as the additional heavy rainfall struck.   Several roads along Elk Creek were flooded, including North Creek Road near Girard, where water levels were the highest seen in over 20 years.  In Fairview Township, floodwaters from Walnut Creek rendered US Highway 20 impassable, while Trout Run inundated areas along Maple Street just north of Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rain upstream caused flooding along lower parts of the Neshaminy Creek. The Neshaminy Creek at Langhorne was above its 9 foot flood stage from 717 p.m. EDT on the 13th through 259 a.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 11.9 feet at 1230 a.m. EDT on the 14th. Storm totals included 4.61 inches in Richboro and 2.21 inches in Langhorne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and several instances of isolated flash flooding in Warren County throughout the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in northern and Eastern Warren County. Roads were closed in Chandlers Valley and Pine Grove Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough and low pressure moving across the Ohio Valley pushed warm and humid air northward ahead of a cold front moving east with the surface low. Severe thunderstorms were widespread across eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and Garrett county Maryland. Significant flash flooding occurred over eastern Allegheny and western Westmoreland counties in Pennsylvania with estimated damage of 18 million dollars to public infrastructure and private buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding over Allegheny county from the eastern sections of downtown Pittsburgh to Monroeville and areas to the Westmoreland county line. 29 people were trapped in cars, and Emergency Medical Services crews rescued 14 of them. 70 to 80 people were evacuated from about 30 homes in the hardest hit Turtle Creek area. 3 to 4 inches of rain fell across the area in about 3 hours. Allegheny county reported 1,658 buildings were damaged due to flash flooding. Most major roadways were flooded with several closed for hours to remove debris. The estimated damage to both public infrastructure and private buildings is estimated between 8 and 10 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and several instances of isolated flash flooding in Warren County throughout the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain, and caused mudslides across Route 59 near Kinzua Dam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain and isolated flash flooding in eastern Warren County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in Warren and Scandia. A number of roads were closed due to flooding. Reports of manhole covers being lifted off in the city of Warren were also received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours dropped a Doppler Radar estimated 3 to 6 inches across southern Montgomery County from Whitpain Township northeast through Horsham Township. This caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding along the Wissahickon and Pennypack Creeks. Several roads were closed due to the flooding and marine rescues from stranded vehicles. The worst reported flooding occurred along the Pennypack Creek at the Robert Bruce Apartments along the Hatboro and Upper Moreland Township line. The creek flooded into the parking lot and submerged a few vehicles. Residents moved from some lower lying apartments to higher ones as a precaution. Event precipitation totals included 3.78 inches in Willow Grove and 3.50 inches in Ambler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in McKean County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain in northeast McKean County. Numerous roads were flooded in Port Alleghany, and in Eldred Borough. Flooding was also reported near Derrick City, where Foster Brook Creek was overflowed its banks, flooding and closing Derrick Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from the heavy rain across southern Montgomery County led to flooding along the Wissahickon Creek. The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington was above its 9 foot flood stage from 505 p.m. EDT through 1049 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 11.78 feet at 730 p.m. EDT. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 5 and 6 inches in the county. Actual reported amounts included 3.78 inches in Willow Grove and 3.50 inches in Ambler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain produced isolated flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding in Pine Grove in southern Schuylkill County. Numerous roads were flooded and closed in the town, and the Mayor issued a disaster declaration. Two to three feet of water covered Tulpehocken Street in Pine Grove as the Swatara Creek rose seven feet in about 4 hours and exceeded bankful. In addition, over 200 basements were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flooding and flooding of smaller creeks in and around the Mahoning Creek Basin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms that moved across Montgomery and Bucks Counties dropped heavy rain over the region. An unseasonably wet June made it easier for flash flooding to occur across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding of streams in the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek basin in Franconia and Salford Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3.6 inches in this area, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused roadway flooding and flooding of creeks in and around Exton in West Whiteland Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached three inches in the area and a measured storm total of 2.47 inches was reported from nearby Downingtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain affected eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening on the 13th and caused flooding. The thunderstorms formed near an inverted trof boundary that extended north from a low pressure system in North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage as well as flash flooding of smaller streams and creeks including the headwaters of the Neshaminy Creek in and around Doylestown, Warwick, Warrington and Westminster Townships in central Bucks County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 5 and 6 inches in the area.  In Warwick Township, two water rescues were performed by emergency responders. A man became stranded in his vehicle after the Neshaminy overflowed on Creek Road and a woman was rescued from her vehicle on Stover Street after a retention basin overflowed. In Doylestown, both Pine Run and Chapman Road were closed. The Little Neshaminy Creek at Neshaminy was above its 8 foot flood stage from 337 p.m. EDT through 939 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 9.21 feet at 445 p.m. EDT. Event storm totals included 4.61 inches in Richboro (Northampton Township).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms brought locally heavy rainfall to parts of northeast Pennsylvania. Minor flooding problems resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were closed due to flooding. One house was surrounded by water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms brought locally heavy rainfall to parts of northeast Pennsylvania. Minor flooding problems resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lee Road Bridge over Dudaff Creek was washed out and Route 106 was closed. Some basement flooding occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and several instances of isolated flash flooding in Warren County throughout the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding near Warren. Water was covering roads in North Warren, and one house was surrounded by water in Warren.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding of streams in the Octoraro Creek basin in southwestern Chester County. Roadway flooding occurred in Oxford and flooding was reported in Pine Grove (Lower Oxford Township) south of the Octoraro Lake. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3 inches in the southwest part of Chester County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams and roadway flooding in upper Bucks County. Several roadways were closed. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2 to 3 inches. In Springfield Township, Cooks Creek flooded and Durham Road was closed. Other roadways flooded and closed included U.S. Route 309 in Richland and Pennsylvania State Route 313 in Quakertown. Roads were closed in East Rockhill Township. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek was flooding in Perkasie. A couple of roadways suffererd poor drainage flooding along the Delaware River in Solebury, Plumstead and Tinicum Townships. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek at Dublin was above its 5 foot flood stage from 1235 p.m. EDT through 120 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 5.16 feet at 1245 p.m. EDT. Storm rainfall totals included 3.68 inches in Pennsburg, 3.66 inches in Doylestown, 2.70 inches in Springtown and 1.85 inches in Perkasie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front was approaching from the west during the 22nd, while Hurricane Bill passed well to our east. An abundance of moisture in place combined with enough instability, which resulted in showers and thunderstorms with locally torrential rainfall and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek within Philadelphia. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 714 p.m. EDT through 752 p.m. EDT on the 22nd. It crested at 7.8 feet at 730 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 3.35 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding along the Neshaminy Creek basin in lower or southern Bucks County.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached three to four inches in the area. The Neshaminy Creek covered roads and backyards near Langhorne. Four people were canoeing along the rising creek and were thrown into it along the Northampton and Wrightstown border. They were rescued. Numerous roads were flooded in Newtown and Warrington Townships. The Little Neshaminy Creek near Neshaminy was above its 8 foot flood stage from 1130 a.m. EDT through 502 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 9.05 feet at Noon EDT. Storm totals included 3.53 inches in Southampton, 3.46 inches in Furlong and 2.46 inches in Langhorne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front was approaching from the west during the 22nd, while Hurricane Bill passed well to our east. An abundance of moisture in place combined with enough instability, which resulted in showers and thunderstorms with locally torrential rainfall and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along some of the smaller streams within Lower Merion Township. In the Wynnewood section of the township, the West Branch of the Indian Creek flooded along Allandale and Andover Roads. Cars in driveways were inundated and damaged or destoryed. A few water rescues were performed and basements were flooded. Mud and debris was left about on third of the way up driveways. Vehicle water rescues were also performed along the Mill Creek.  Precipitation event totals included 5.35 inches in Wynnewood, 3.35 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 2.45 inches in Norristown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary settled southward across most of the area during the 28th before stalling nearby. Plenty of moisture flowing northward along with incoming energy resulted in some showers and thunderstorms, some of which produced heavy rainfall and localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Little Lehigh and Saucon Creeks in southern Lehigh County. Several roads were flooded and closed. One lane of U.S. Route 222 was also closed in Trexlertown. Other road closures occurred on Spring Creek Road in Lower Macungie Township and Meadows Road in Lower Saucon Township. Spring Creek Road was closed into the evening.  Flooding along the Little Lehigh Creek extended into Allentown near Bogert's Bridge. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level low pressure system brought isolated showers and thunderstorms to northeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon, with isolated flash flooding occurring due to heavy rainfall from slow moving storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms caused a significant urban flood in Swoyersville. Water and debris was several feet deep across Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary in the area along with a weak area of low pressure combined to produce areas of showers and thunderstorms on the 12th, from the late afternoon into the night. The showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in areas of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly stationary thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused roadway flooding as well as flooding of smaller streams in northern Lehigh County in and around Heidelberg Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary in the area along with a weak area of low pressure combined to produce areas of showers and thunderstorms on the 12th, from the late afternoon into the night. The showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in areas of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly stationary thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused roadway flooding as well as flooding of smaller streams in east centra; Lehigh County in and around Whitehall and North Whitehall Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary in the area along with a weak area of low pressure combined to produce areas of showers and thunderstorms on the 12th, from the late afternoon into the night. The showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in areas of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused significant roadway flooding as well as flooding of smaller streams in and around Lake Harmony in Kidder Township. Roadway flooding and flooding of smaller streams also occurred in the western part of the county. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 5 to 6 inches within the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding along Cobbs Creek and other small streams particularly in the eastern half of Delaware County. Many water rescues from trapped vehicles occurred. Hardest hit was Haverford Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches in the northeast part of the county. ||In Haverford Township, an emergency disaster was declared. Homes bordering Cobbs Creek and its tributaries were damaged. On Eagle Road, cars were submerged and homes were surrounded by water. Roads and bridges on Hathaway Lane were damaged. Homes and vehicles on Wynnefield Drive were flooded. Six roads in the township were flooded. In Darby Borough, flood waters from the Darby Creek washed away a portion of McDade Boulevard. Ten residents were evacuated from Springfield Road. Roadway and basement flooding also occurred in Lansdowne Borough and Chester City. The precipitation event total at the Philadelphia International Airport was 1.59 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary in the area along with a weak area of low pressure combined to produce areas of showers and thunderstorms on the 12th, from the late afternoon into the night. The showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in areas of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flooding of smaller streams in northeastern Montgomery County in and around Green Lane (Marlborough Township).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in the headwaters of the Perkiomen River Basin in northern Montgomery County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged around three inches in the area. The West Branch of the Perkiomen Creek at Hillegass was above its 5 foot flood stage from 1213 p.m. EDT through 110 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 5.11 feet at 1245 p.m. EDT. The Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville was above its 4 foot flood stage from 1142 a.m. EDT through 414 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 4.91 feet at 315 p.m. EDT. In Palm, the actual storm precipitation total was 3.22 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding.
