The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flooding of streams as well as poor drainage flooding in southeastern Berks County from around Cumru and Robeson Townships northeast through Rockland and Pike Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached four inches within this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flooding along the Saucon Creek in Upper Saucon Township as well as flooding along some of the smaller tributaries of the creek in Coopersburg Borough. North Main Street in Coopersburg was flooded by one of these tributaries and closed.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain and recent wet weather conditions produced some flash flooding across the southeastern part of the state from mid afternoon into early evening on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flooding along Frankford Creek within Philadelphia. The Frankford Creek at the Castor Avenue gauge exceeded its 7 foot flood stage from 510 p.m. through 540 p.m EDT on the 31st. It crested at 8.26 feet. The storm total at the Philadelphia International Airport was 1.42 inches, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms produced 2 to 4 inches of rain which caused flash flooding in far northern Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A major flash flood occurred in the Little Meadows area, when 2 to 4 inches of rain fell in less than 2 hours. The heavy rain caused debris to block 3 large drainage pipes, which then caused significant flash flooding. Flooding occurred on the lower part of Cork Hill Road. The water ran down from the upper part of the road into this area. The water then entered a home owner's yard. A small bridge was also washed out on State Route 4013.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms with heavy rain and recent wet weather conditions produced some flash flooding across the southeastern part of the state from mid afternoon into early evening on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flooding as well as stream flooding in central and southwest Chester County from around Thorndale in Caln Township southwest into West Fallowfield and Lower Oxford Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 3 to 4 inches in western Chester County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains that moved across the same parts of the Poconos produced flooding during the afternoon and evening of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell over the same areas caused poor drainage and smaller stream flooding in parts of Polk, Eldred, Penn Forest and Towamensing Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall in a short duration associated with slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall of 1-2 inches in a short duration resulted in flash flooding across mainly rural areas in extreme southeastern Lancaster County. A mudslide closed one lane of Route 472 in Colerain Township near Mount Eden Road. Two feet of water was also reported covering Spruce Grove Road in Colerain Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain caused flash flooding of small streams in eastern Cumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding along a small stream tributary of the Yellow Breaches Creek. The high water covered a bridge along Hertzler Road in Upper Allen Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains that moved across the same parts of the Poconos produced flooding during the afternoon and evening of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell over the same areas caused poor drainage and smaller stream flooding in west central Monroe County with the heaviest rain falling in Polk and Chestnut Townships.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches. An actual storm total included 2.87 inches in Kresgeville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell during the late afternoon and early evening on the 24th.  Event precipitation totals averaged 1.5 to 3.0 inches across southeastern Pennsylvania with the heaviest rain across the fall line region from eastern Chester County northeast across southern or lower Montgomery and Bucks Counties. This caused flash flooding during the early evening and runoff flooding through the night of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Schuylkill Expressway and other low lying roadways in Lower Merion Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell during the late afternoon and early evening on the 24th.  Event precipitation totals averaged 1.5 to 3.0 inches across southeastern Pennsylvania with the heaviest rain across the fall line region from eastern Chester County northeast across southern or lower Montgomery and Bucks Counties. This caused flash flooding during the early evening and runoff flooding through the night of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of some of the smaller creeks as well as poor drainage flooding mainly in the central third of Bucks County during the evening of the 24th. The runoff from the heavy rain that evening caused the Neshaminy Creek to just reach its 9 foot flood stage early on the 25th. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek flooded in Perkasie and caused some road closures. Event precipitation totals included 2.70 inches in Perkasie, 2.54 inches in Doylestown, 2.17 inches in Newtown, 1.87 inches in Southampton, 1.71 inches in Penndel  and 1.50 inches in Springtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell during the late afternoon and early evening on the 24th.  Event precipitation totals averaged 1.5 to 3.0 inches across southeastern Pennsylvania with the heaviest rain across the fall line region from eastern Chester County northeast across southern or lower Montgomery and Bucks Counties. This caused flash flooding during the early evening and runoff flooding through the night of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream flooding as well as poor drainage flooding along Pennsylvania State Route 29 and U.S. Route 30 in Tredyffrin and East Whiteland Townships. Event precipitation totals included 2.34 inches in Valley Forge, 2.19 inches in Downingtown and 2.09 inches in Longwood Gardens.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that fell during the late afternoon and early evening on the 24th.  Event precipitation totals averaged 1.5 to 3.0 inches across southeastern Pennsylvania with the heaviest rain across the fall line region from eastern Chester County northeast across southern or lower Montgomery and Bucks Counties. This caused flash flooding during the early evening and runoff flooding through the night of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek and also poor drainage flooding within Philadelphia. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 725 p.m. EDT through 739 p.m. EDT on the 24th. it crested at 7.57 feet at 730 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 1.61 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport, 1.52 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 1.50 inches within Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was located northwest of the region during the afternoon and evening hours of the 10th. A warm and unstable airmass caused showers and thunderstorms to develop shortly after noontime and persist through the afternoon and evening hours. Some of the thunderstorms became severe producing severe winds and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms produced nearly 3.5 inches of rain in less than 2 hours in south-central Erie county just north and west of Waterford, PA.  Flash flooding ensued on several smaller creeks in the area, including an unnamed tributary to Le Boeuf Creek which flows through the Rainbow Valley Mobile Home Park north of Waterford.  Several mobile homes were flooded and had their foundation skirting ripped off by the fast moving water.  State Route 19 flooded as well, with large logs deposited on the roadway by the fast moving water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary slowly lifted northward during the 29th. Plenty of moisture flowed northward and included some moisture from once Tropical Storm Danny. As a cold front moved through the region, showers and thunderstorms formed, some of which produced heavy rainfall and localized flooding during the evening hours of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding within Upper Darby Township. Motorists were rescued from flooded vehicles on Marshall Street and Normandy Roads. A family was trapped in a flooded basement on Ashton Street. A Skywarn Spotter measured 2.62 inches of rain in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was located northwest of the region during the afternoon and evening hours of the 10th. A warm and unstable airmass caused showers and thunderstorms to develop shortly after noontime and persist through the afternoon and evening hours. Some of the thunderstorms became severe producing severe winds and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of up to 3 inches in 2 hours caused flash flooding on small creeks and streams in north central Crawford County near Venango.  A moblie home was flooded, and US Highway 6/19 north of Venango was closed due to the high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along most of the smaller creeks within Philadelphia as well as considerable urban and poor drainage flooding. The Green Tree Run was scoured by flood waters. Along the Wissahickon Creek, culverts were washed out and roads and trails were undermined. Flooding along the Pennypack Creek spread into the picnic area near Pine Road in Pennypack Park. Flooding was reported along Cobbs Creek along the border with Delaware County. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1129 a.m. EDT through 956 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 11.02 feet at 7 p.m. EDT. Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1149 a.m. EDT through 1234 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. It crested at 9.76 feet at Noon EDT. The event precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was 1.59 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved into northern Pennsylvania late in the day. Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed, which produced isolated areas of heavy rain and minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few  roads were  flooded in Old Forge and Moosic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that moved northeast in the morning and a cold front that arrived from the west late in the day on the 2nd resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area with heavy rain and flash flooding. The region was already saturated from all of the heavy rain that fell during the last week of July. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 4 to 5 inches across eastern Chester, southern Montgomery and southwestern Bucks Counties and caused flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates also exceeded 3 inches in parts of western and southern Berks County. Because of the flooding, Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell requested and received approval from the United States Small Business Administration to have disaster area declaration for Berks, Bucks, Chester, Delaware, Lehigh, Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in several municipalities and a major mudslide across southern Montgomery County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged between 2.5 inches and 4.5 inches.||In Lower Merion Township, a mudslide closed both directions of the Schuylkill Expressway at the Conshohocken Curve from 11 a.m. EDT through 230 p.m. EDT. The westbound lanes were reopened first and the eastbound lanes were reopened at 730 p.m. EDT. Motorists were stranded on the expressway when the mudslide initially occurred. Elsewhere in the township, the Mill Creek flooded and washed out a couple of roads in its basin. There were about a half dozen water rescues. West Mill Creek Park was closed indefinitely. The Mill Creek Pumping Station was under five feet of water. Most roads that were closed were reopened by the 3rd, but River Road was under five feet of water and rocks. In the Wynnewood section, Indian Creek also flooded.||In Upper Dublin Township, flooding occured along the Wissahickon Creek Basin and also included the Rapp and Pine Runs. The Fort Washington Office Park was severely affected and was surrounded by water. Many businesses were flooded and damaged. At least one vehicle was submerged. Ten people were evacuated from one office building.  Virginia Drive flooded was severely flooded. The Fort Washington exit ramp off of the Pennsylvania Turnpike and U.S. Route 309 were flooded and closed. A Hilton Inn on West Pennsylvania Avenue was flooded with up to three feet of water on its first floor. It was expected to be closed for a month. Damage to the Industrial Park was estimated at 10 million dollars.||In Whitpain Township, about a dozen residents were asked to evacuate from Maple Street after a culvert flooded. The BoRit asbestos site was damaged as Chestnut Avenue was flooded. In Ambler Borough, several businesses suffered water damage as up to five feet of water accumulated on Main Street. The Butler Pike was closed after a landslide. In Whitemarsh Township, one home had nine feet of water in it. About four streets were flooded. In Springfield Township, the Valley Green Inn was closed for about 24 hours because of Wissahickon Creek flooding.||Event precipitation totals included 5.19 inches in Flourtown, 4.09 inches in Willow Grove, 3.40 inches in Ambler and 2.76 inches in Blue Bell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of slow moving thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall in a short duration across portions of McKean County, resulting in flash flooding and water covering roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain in a short duration resulted in flash flooding and water over roadways from Farmers Valley to Kane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level low pressure system brought isolated showers and thunderstorms to northeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon, with isolated flash flooding occurring due to heavy rainfall from slow moving storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused a mudslide which closed Bunker Hill Road. Several other roads were also closed due to flooding. Additionally, the heavy rain flooded several basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across western Pennsylvania produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rain. Flash flooding occurred across parts of western Pennsylvania  and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding in New Kensington with Pucketa Creek flooding Seventh Street and closing the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across western Pennsylvania produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rain. Flash flooding occurred across parts of western Pennsylvania  and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding in downtown Calrion with North 5TH Street and South Street closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rain produced flash flooding across northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania ahead of a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding along Saw Mill Run BLVD between the Liberty Tunnel and the intersection of SR 51 and SR 88 and the intersection of Mcneilly Road. The Overbrook T line transportation system was closed due to flash flooding from Grove Road to SR 88.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across western Pennsylvania produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rain. Flash flooding occurred across parts of western Pennsylvania  and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fire Deparment reported Harkins Mill Road Road in New Sewickley Township closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across western Pennsylvania produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rain. Flash flooding occurred across parts of western Pennsylvania  and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported flashing flooding with over a foot of water running across I-376 between mile markers 63 and 64.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of thunderstorms develped ahead of a cold front producing isolated damage in eastern Ohio and some flash flooding across parts of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a creek flooding a parking lot and a basement along Babcock BLVD.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of thunderstorms develped ahead of a cold front producing isolated damage in eastern Ohio and some flash flooding across parts of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding with State Route 228 blocked by flowing water in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of thunderstorms develped ahead of a cold front producing isolated damage in eastern Ohio and some flash flooding across parts of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported numerous roads closed due to flash flooding and debris washed onto roads across Jackson and Lancaster Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of thunderstorms develped ahead of a cold front producing isolated damage in eastern Ohio and some flash flooding across parts of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported numerous roads closed across Penn Township due to flash flooding and debris washed onto roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the upper Ohio valley was the focus for severe thunderstorms. A few supercells developed along the front with one severe thunderstorm producing a tornado in Tuscarawas county Ohio. Scattered severe thunderstorms with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding also occurred over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding with 3 feet of water moving across the intersection of SR 88 and SR 51 closing the roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the upper Ohio valley was the focus for severe thunderstorms. A few supercells developed along the front with one severe thunderstorm producing a tornado in Tuscarawas county Ohio. Scattered severe thunderstorms with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding also occurred over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding along Cliff Mine road and across nearby roads in North Fayette Township with roads closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall between 1 and 4 inches produced widespread areal flooding across all of central Pennsylvania. Cold season hydrologic conditions, including snow and ice melt contributed to enhanced run-off especially across the higher elevations and northern mountains. Many small streams and creeks came out of their banks, resulting in numerous secondary road closures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused rapid rises and flash flooding along many small streams and creeks which eventually spilled over their banks. The flash flooding closed several roads in the towns of Winfield and Lewisburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall between 1 and 4 inches produced widespread areal flooding across all of central Pennsylvania. Cold season hydrologic conditions, including snow and ice melt contributed to enhanced run-off especially across the higher elevations and northern mountains. Many small streams and creeks came out of their banks, resulting in numerous secondary road closures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain during the morning hours caused significant flash flooding along Fishing Creek. Little Fishing Creek actually changed its natural course, and the flash flood waters surged into downtown Benton. A dyke system failed, leading to several residences having moderate to major flooding. Many people were evacuated to Red Cross Shelters. A disaster declaration was announced for the Benton area with initial damages estimates approaching one million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered strong to severe thunderstorms that produced dime to golf ball size hail across central Pennsylvania during the mid-afternoon. The storms were slow-moving and trained over the ridges of the south-central mountains, resulting in locally heavy rainfall and isolated flash flooding in the hilly terrain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed several roads near Lake Gordon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong heating of a very moist low level air mass aided severe thunderstorm development during the afternoon and evening over the south central mountains and lower Susquehanna valley. Despite weak upper level support and vertical wind shear, several storms produced damaging winds and hail up to one inch in diameter. In addition, this environment proved to be favorable for slow-moving/training storms which resulted in localized flash flooding in Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains in excess of 3 inches in a few hours caused flash flooding in west-central Lancaster County during the evening. The areas most affected included Columbia and Marietta Boroughs and much of West Hempfield Township. Several municipal roads including State Routes 23 and 441 were closed due to flooding. A mudslide on SR 411 contributed to a three-vehicle accident. A several roads were closed in the Willow Street/Pequea Township and Lancaster areas. The Rheems Fire Department reported areas of flash flooding in Maytown. Route 30 was closed near Columbia. Several basements were flooded. ||The flash flooding eventually transitioned to areal flooding later in the evening before receding around midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered strong to severe thunderstorms that produced dime to golf ball size hail across central Pennsylvania during the mid-afternoon. The storms were slow-moving and trained over the ridges of the south-central mountains, resulting in locally heavy rainfall and isolated flash flooding in the hilly terrain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash Flooding closed Knob Run Road at the intersection of Johnstown Road along Route 164. Flood waters also covered portions of Ski Gap/Right Hand Gap Road and the intersection of Johnstown/Polecat Road. The roads are located over hilly terrain in rural areas of Greenfield and Freedom Townships. Local residents reported a rapid rise along Poplar Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and snowmelt caused flooding of Route 467 in Le Raysville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain on top of existing snow pack caused flash flooding in the Troy area. Streams went out of their banks and flooded Fall Brook Road near Troy. Route 14 was also flooded off Armenia Mountain near Troy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and snowmelt caused flooding on Route 220 in South Towanda. Both lanes were closed due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 87 in Mehoopany was closed due to flash flooding and a rockslide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Mehoopany Creek to rapidly flood ten homes in Forkston. 3 families were evacuated due to the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 267 was flooded in the Auburn Center area, about 2 miles north of the Wyoming county line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in the Montrose area due to heavy rains. This included Route 29 in Montrose.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slowly westward moving backdoor cold front produced thunderstorms with heavy rain in Northampton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding of streams just north of Roseto and East Bangor Boroughs along the Washington and Upper Mount Bethel Township Lines. Doppler Radar storm total estimates approached three inches, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front collided with a very moist air mass over central Pennsylvania to produce isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding over portions of the city of Harrisburg. Several roads were flooded and closed, including Cameron Street, Berryhill Road, Arsenal Boulevard, Locust Lane and Elmerton Avenue. Four water rescues were performed, when vehicles became stranded in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong heating of a very moist low level air mass aided severe thunderstorm development during the afternoon and evening over the south central mountains and lower Susquehanna valley. Despite weak upper level support and vertical wind shear, several storms produced damaging winds and hail up to one inch in diameter. In addition, this environment proved to be favorable for slow-moving/training storms which resulted in localized flash flooding in Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains in excess of 3 inches in a few hours caused flash flooding in west-central Lancaster County during the evening. The areas most affected included Columbia and Marietta Boroughs and much of West Hempfield Township. Several municipal roads including State Routes 23 and 441 were closed due to flooding. A mudslide on SR 411 contributed to a three-vehicle accident. A several roads were closed in the Willow Street/Pequea Township and Lancaster areas. The Rheems Fire Department reported areas of flash flooding in Maytown. Route 30 was closed near Columbia. Several basements were flooded. ||The flash flooding eventually transitioned to areal flooding later in the evening before receding around midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent area of heavy thunderstorm rains produced isolated flash flooding across south-central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent heavy rain from slow-moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding in west-central Franklin County. Numerous roads were closed in Peters, Hamilton and Letterkenny Townships. Several cars and recreational vehicles were submerged in flood waters of 5 feet or more at the Twin Bridge Meadow Family campground near Chambersburg, where at least 10-15 campers were rescued after being stranded. A wall collapse occurred at a residence in St. Thomas Township due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent area of heavy thunderstorm rains produced isolated flash flooding across south-central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused small streams to rise and close several roads in southeastern Huntingdon County. Portions of Decorum Road were closed due to small stream flooding, and a local bridge was swamped and sustained damage. A covered bridge, located north of Shade Gap also was flooded from rising creek waters. A small earthen dam located on private property was also breached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorms rains produced localized flash flooding along Route 222 in Manheim Township Lancaster County. The flash flooding eventually transitioned to areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains over a short duration produced localized flash flooding near the city of Lancaster in Manheim Township. The heavy rains flooded two underpasses and one on-ramp on Route 222.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across northeast Pennsylvania in the vicinity of a stalled frontal boundary. With a very moist air mass in place across the region, the storms that developed produced very heavy rainfall. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches occurred in a 2 hour time period over the Scranton area. This intense rainfall resulted in flash flooding. The west and south side of Scranton were the hardest hit areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Scranton area. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches fell in a two hour period of time, with the west and south-side of Scranton hardest hit. Numerous locations in Scranton were closed due to high water. Some cars had water up to the windows. Locations where cars were stranded due to high water included the intersection of Luzerne Street and Meridian Avenue, South Wyoming Avenue, Birney Avenue and Hickory Street. Large rocks and debris were reported on Molltke Avenue. A couple of homes had water up to the first floor level on Railroad Avenue. ||Flooding was not limited to the city of Scranton. A car was also swamped in the Borough of Taylor along Union Street. Saint John's Creek in Old Forge flooded a city park and a portion of Sibley Avenue where the occupants of a vehicle had to be rescued by boat. Rocks and debris were washed onto portions of Creek Road in Ransom Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across northeast Pennsylvania in the vicinity of a stalled frontal boundary. With a very moist airmass in place across the region, the storms that developed produced very heavy rainfall. Rainfall rates over one inch per hour occurred in Wayne county and resulted in some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed across northern Wayne county due to high water. Over two feet of water was reported on a portion of the Dixie Highway in the Township of Preston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms during the morning of the 13th caused flooding in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania including Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek as well as poor drainage flooding in central Philadelphia. The heavy rain also caused the tracks for the Market-Frankford el to be underwater. Service was suspended between 9 a.m. EDT and 2 p.m. EDT. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 859 a.m. EDT through 1258 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 11.28 feet at 10 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms during the morning of the 13th caused flooding in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania including Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the Pennypack Creek as well as poor drainage flooding in northeast Philadelphia. A 20-year-old man drowned while rafting on the swollen Pennypack Creek. During the morning, fire officials rescued a man stuck next to the pillar of a rail bridge near the intersection of Ashburner Street and Frankford Avenue on the creek. Later that day, two men fell into the water after their raft overturned near Winchester Avenue and Roosevelt Boulevard, but only one man survived. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1018 a.m. EDT through 617 p.m. EDT EDT on the 13th. It crested at 9.1 feet at 4 p.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms during the morning of the 13th caused flooding in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania including Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the Wissahickon Creek as well as in northern Philadelphia. Lincoln Drive along the creek was flooded. The Wissahickon Creek at its mouth was above its 5 foot flood stage from 910 a.m. EDT through 1031 a.m. EDT EDT on the 13th. It crested at 5.64 feet at 10 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential downpours caused by successive thunderstorms caused flash flooding along the Monocacy Creek as well as urban and poor drainage flooding in the Lehigh Valley during the morning of the 10th. Runoff from morning heavy rain also caused flooding to occur in Chester County along the East Branch of the Brandywine Creek on the afternoon of the 10th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 4 to 5 inches in the Lehigh Valley and the Lehigh Valley International Airport measured 5.67 inches. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 3 to 4 inches in central Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of the Monocacy Creek at the Colonial Industrial Quarter in Bethlehem around 8 a.m. EDT on the 10th. The creek flooded four structures in the area near the intersection of Main and West Church Streets. Tree branches slammed against the buildings and a couple of windows were broken. Rainfall reached 5.67 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport. The flooding in the area was described as the worst since the remnants of Hurricane Ivan in 2004. Up to about 5 feet of water accumulated within the 1761 Tannery, 1762 Waterworks and 1869 Luckenbach Mill. In the 1762 Waterworks, the 18 foot water wheel was clogged and damaged. In the 1761 Tannery, wooden vats were destroyed, the heating system was damaged and the wooden floor buckled.  There was concern about the 1762 Waterworks and the 1761 Tannery structural integrity. The two buildings took on water for the longest period of time. A few feet of water still occupied the buildings during the afternoon of the 10th. The rushing water also damaged the Springhouse and the ground floor of the 1869 Luckenbach Mill. Elsewhere in the Lehigh Valley, the Schoenersville exit to U.S. Route 22 was closed. Roads were closed due to floodng in Allentown and Bethlehem and basements were flooded in Catasauqua and Lower Nazareth Township. The Monocacy Creek at Bethlehem was above its 5 foot flood stage from 815 a.m. EDT through 1038 a.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 5.44 feet at 9 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms during the morning of the 13th caused flooding in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania including Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused the closure of the Schuylkill Expressway along the Conshohocken Curve from Belmont to City Avenues between 930 a.m. EDT and 1130 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms during the morning of the 13th caused flooding in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania including Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man was rescued from the roof of his car along the intersection of Tookany Creek Parkway and Central Avenue in Cheltenham. The Tookany Creek flooded after a Doppler Radar estimated three to four inches of rain fell during the morning of the 13th in lower Montgomery County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacting with abundant tropical moisture from the remnants of what had been Tropical Storm Nicole dropped 2 to 7 inches of rain across northeast Pennsylvania. Steady and occasionally heavy rain fell across much of northeast Pennsylvania, causing flash flood problems, as well as minor flooding of the larger main stem rivers. The rain and flooding continued into the overnight and next day (October 1), especially across parts of the northern Poconos. Locally higher amounts of rain were reported, with the highest amount of 10.38 inches in Moscow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pennsylvania Route 115 was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacting with abundant tropical moisture from the remnants of what had been Tropical Storm Nicole dropped 2 to 7 inches of rain across northeast Pennsylvania. Steady and occasionally heavy rain fell across much of northeast Pennsylvania, causing flash flood problems, as well as minor flooding of the larger main stem rivers. The rain and flooding continued into the overnight and next day (October 1), especially across parts of the northern Poconos. Locally higher amounts of rain were reported, with the highest amount of 10.38 inches in Moscow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were washed out in Moscow. Also, Van Brunt Creek went out of its banks, resulting in two homes being evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacting with abundant tropical moisture from the remnants of what had been Tropical Storm Nicole dropped 2 to 7 inches of rain across northeast Pennsylvania. Steady and occasionally heavy rain fell across much of northeast Pennsylvania, causing flash flood problems, as well as minor flooding of the larger main stem rivers. The rain and flooding continued into the overnight and next day (October 1), especially across parts of the northern Poconos. Locally higher amounts of rain were reported, with the highest amount of 10.38 inches in Moscow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding as several roads were closed in Dyberry Township. Also water flowed over a bridge in Buckingham Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving north-south oriented frontal boundary and surges of tropical moisture along this boundary produced excessive rainfall in southeastern Pennsylvania. The deep tropical moisture connection was associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole. Widespread heavy rainfall amounts on the order of 3 to 6 inches were recorded over a 48 hour period, with isolated amounts as high as 8 inches. This was a record rain event over most of the area and resulted in significant flooding and flash flooding. Fortunately, very dry antecedent conditions prevented major flooding on area rivers, streams and creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding over much of the county. Numerous road closures caused several municipalities to declare a State of Emergency. As a result, many schools and businesses closed early. Dozens of roads were flooded in the city of Lancaster as torrential rains clogged storm drains.  A sink hole developed in East Lampeter Township. Many smaller streams and creeks exceeded bankfull levels and minor flooding was observed along the Conestoga River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving north-south oriented frontal boundary and surges of tropical moisture along this boundary produced excessive rainfall in southeastern Pennsylvania. The deep tropical moisture connection was associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole. Widespread heavy rainfall amounts on the order of 3 to 6 inches were recorded over a 48 hour period, with isolated amounts as high as 8 inches. This was a record rain event over most of the area and resulted in significant flooding and flash flooding. Fortunately, very dry antecedent conditions prevented major flooding on area rivers, streams and creeks. This episode is a continuation of the flood and flash flood events that began on September 30, 2010.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding over much of the county. The flooding closed multiple secondary roads and a few municipalities made emergency declarations. Many smaller streams and creeks exceeded bankfull levels and minor flooding was observed.This event is a continuation of the flash flood event that began on September 30, 2010.

This was a record rain event over most of the area and resulted in significant flooding and flash flooding. The deep tropical moisture connection was associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole. Widespread heavy rainfall amounts on the order of 3 to 6 inches were recorded over a 48 hour period, with isolated amounts as high as 8 inches. This was a record rain event over most of the area and resulted in significant flooding and flash flooding. Fortunately, very dry antecedent conditions prevented major flooding on area rivers, streams and creeks. This episode is a continuation of the flood and flash flood events that began on September 30, 2010.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall resulted in significant flash flooding over much of the county. Numerous road closures caused several municipalities to declare a State of Emergency. As a result, many schools and businesses closed early. Dozens of roads were flooded in the city of Lancaster as torrential rains clogged storm drains.  A sink hole developed in East Lampeter Township. Many smaller streams and creeks exceeded bankfull levels and minor flooding was observed along the Conestoga River. This event is a continuation of the flash flood event that began on September 30, 2010.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains over a short duration produced flash flooding across the lower Susquehanna Valley during the mid to late afternoon. The very heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in downtown Harrisburg, northern York County and southern Adams County. Much of the area received locally heavy rains during the early morning hours which ultimately set the stage for the afternoon convective rainfall to quickly run off into low-lying and poor drainage areas and small creeks and streams. The urbanized areas of the Harrisburg metro area bore the brunt of the flooding, mainly due to the intensity of the rain and the concrete and other impervious surfaces that did not allow water to soak into the ground. There were numerous road closures due to high water and several people were rescued from stranded vehicles. High water also forced the evacuation of 40 residents on 19th and Rollerston Streets.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced flash flooding in Heidelberg Township. The flash flooding closed roads and stranded vehicles. One person had to be rescued from a flooded vehicle at the intersection of Thoman and Stennen Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains over a short duration produced flash flooding across the lower Susquehanna Valley during the mid to late afternoon. The very heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in downtown Harrisburg, northern York County and southern Adams County. Much of the area received locally heavy rains during the early morning hours which ultimately set the stage for the afternoon convective rainfall to quickly run off into low-lying and poor drainage areas and small creeks and streams. The urbanized areas of the Harrisburg metro area bore the brunt of the flooding, mainly due to the intensity of the rain and the concrete and other impervious surfaces that did not allow water to soak into the ground. There were numerous road closures due to high water and several people were rescued from stranded vehicles. High water also forced the evacuation of 40 residents on 19th and Rollerston Streets.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced significant flash flooding throughout the city of Harrisburg. The flooding closed multiple roads including a portion of the I-283/83 interchange. High water also forced the evacuation of 40 residents on 19th and Rollerston Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains over a short duration produced flash flooding across the lower Susquehanna Valley during the mid to late afternoon. The very heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in downtown Harrisburg, northern York County and southern Adams County. Much of the area received locally heavy rains during the early morning hours which ultimately set the stage for the afternoon convective rainfall to quickly run off into low-lying and poor drainage areas and small creeks and streams. The urbanized areas of the Harrisburg metro area bore the brunt of the flooding, mainly due to the intensity of the rain and the concrete and other impervious surfaces that did not allow water to soak into the ground. There were numerous road closures due to high water and several people were rescued from stranded vehicles. High water also forced the evacuation of 40 residents on 19th and Rollerston Streets.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced flash flooding in Mount Holly Springs. Several municipal streets and underpasses were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains over a short duration produced flash flooding across the lower Susquehanna Valley during the mid to late afternoon. The very heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in downtown Harrisburg, northern York County and southern Adams County. Much of the area received locally heavy rains during the early morning hours which ultimately set the stage for the afternoon convective rainfall to quickly run off into low-lying and poor drainage areas and small creeks and streams. The urbanized areas of the Harrisburg metro area bore the brunt of the flooding, mainly due to the intensity of the rain and the concrete and other impervious surfaces that did not allow water to soak into the ground. There were numerous road closures due to high water and several people were rescued from stranded vehicles. High water also forced the evacuation of 40 residents on 19th and Rollerston Streets.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced flash flooding in Gettysburg. Several vehicles were stranded by high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive day, slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain caused heavy rain and flash flooding in and around Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as considerable highway and poor drainage flooding. In Trainer Borough, the Stoney Brook Creek flooded. Cars became stuck in three feet of water at the intersection of Main and Pennsylvania Streets in the borough. Interstates 476 and 95 as well as McDade Boulevard (within Darby) were flooded. Poor drainage flooding was also reported in Norwood, Prospect Park, Ridley and Tinicum Townships. Two day Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 5 to 6 inches in Delaware County. The actual two day precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was 4.31 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive day, slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain caused heavy rain and flash flooding in and around Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding as well as considerable highway and poor drainage flooding in south Philadelphia. The ramps to Interstate 95 were closed at Broad Street. The heavy rain also caused incoming flight delays of 90 minutes at Philadelphia International Airport. Two day Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 to 8 inches in southwestern Philadelphia. The actual two day precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was 4.31 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the upper Ohio valley was the focus for severe thunderstorms. A few supercells developed along the front with one severe thunderstorm producing a tornado in Tuscarawas county Ohio. Scattered severe thunderstorms with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding also occurred over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding and a mud slide at the entrance to the Rankin Bridge closing the bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacting with abundant tropical moisture from the remnants of what had been Tropical Storm Nicole dropped 2 to 7 inches of rain across northeast Pennsylvania. Steady and occasionally heavy rain fell across much of northeast Pennsylvania, causing flash flood problems, as well as minor flooding of the larger main stem rivers. The rain and flooding continued into the overnight and next day (October 1), especially across parts of the northern Poconos. Locally higher amounts of rain were reported, with the highest amount of 10.38 inches in Moscow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved northeastward toward northern Pennsylvania, and through the region on the 25th. A surge of deep moisture associated with this system produced a period of heavy rain from late on the 24th, through the morning hours on the 25th. In addition, mild temperatures combined with the rain to melt an existing snow-pack to cause isolated areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in the Little Meadows area including Bolles Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary was the focus for showers and thunderstorms to develop and train across portions of eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia panhandle, and western Pennsylvania producing flash flooding and flooding. The worst flash flooding occurred in Belmont county, Ohio in Willow Grove, which is near Neffs. 97 homes and businesses were damaged, with other damage to roads and bridges. The estimated total damage was near 1.3 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Washington Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed with daytime heating and instability as an upper level disturbance moved across the area.  Scattered storms became severe, producing damaging wind gusts and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water flowed over county route 191.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front and a moist unstable airmass combined to produce scattered severe thunderstorms and flash flooding across eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania. Flash flooding was deadly in Pittsburgh when approximately 2.5 inches of rain fell in a very urbanized area just east of downtown Pittsburgh on Washington Blvd in just under an hour. This resulted in four fatalities and up to 15 water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Bigelow BLVD at Frank Curto Park closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front and a moist unstable airmass combined to produce scattered severe thunderstorms and flash flooding across eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania. Flash flooding was deadly in Pittsburgh when approximately 2.5 inches of rain fell in a very urbanized area just east of downtown Pittsburgh on Washington Blvd in just under an hour. This resulted in four fatalities and up to 15 water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with 2 to 3 feet of water flowing across Sohn Road with debris.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front and a moist unstable airmass combined to produce scattered severe thunderstorms and flash flooding across eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania. Flash flooding was deadly in Pittsburgh when approximately 2.5 inches of rain fell in a very urbanized area just east of downtown Pittsburgh on Washington Blvd in just under an hour. This resulted in four fatalities and up to 15 water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding in Beaver with debris flow in streets and water in a few buildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Irene produced heavy flooding rain, tropical storm force wind gusts with hundreds of thousands of outages, moderate tidal flooding along the Delaware River and one flooding related death in Eastern Pennsylvania over the weekend of August 27th and 28th. Moderate stream and river flooding occurred in the Poconos and Lehigh Valley and moderate to major river flooding occurred in southeast Pennsylvania. For many places in southeastern Pennsylvania, it was the worst creek and river flooding since Hurricane Floyd in 1999 or the remnants of Hurricane Jeanne in 2004. Flooding along non-tidal sections of the Delaware River was minor to moderate. There were two direct storm caused deaths: a wind related death in Monroe County and a drowning in Montgomery County.  About 500,000 PECO Energy and 420,000 Pennsylvania Power and Light customers lost power in Eastern Pennsylvania. For both utilities this ranked within the top five outages of all time.  Preliminary damage estimates were around six million dollars. In addition to property damage, the winds and rains badly damaged the corn crop in southeastern Pennsylvania. The Delaware Water Gap National Recreational Area was closed through Labor Day Weekend (September 5th). ||Tropical storm force wind gusts overspread Eastern Pennsylvania during the evening of the 27th and persisted into the afternoon of the 28th. Peak wind gusts averaged around 50 mph. The strongest winds associated with Irene occurred at two distinct times. The first surge occurred during bands of heavier rain during the evening of the 27th and early morning of the 28th. The second peak occurred during the afternoon of the 28th when skies were clearing and deeper mixing of the atmosphere brought stronger winds to the ground. Most of the peak wind gusts occurred at this time. The rain associated with Irene overspread Eastern Pennsylvania during the late morning on the 27th, fell at its heaviest from during the evening of the 27th into the early morning of the 28th and ended during the early afternoon on the 28th. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 7 inches and caused widespread flooding. Because the flash flooding and flooding blended into one, all flooding related stormdata county entries were combined into one under flood events. The storm surge of 3 to 5 feet caused moderate tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River overnight on the 27th. Minor tidal flooding occurred during the high tide cycles from the 29th through the 31st. | |In Stroudsburg (Monroe County), a 44-year-old man died when a tree fell on him in his backyard. He pushed his son to safety. Governor Tom Corbett declared a state of emergency for the city of Philadelphia and the surrounding suburbs. The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority halted all commuter rail service during the evening of the 27th as multiple tornado warnings were issued.  Three large shelters on the evening of August 27th in Philadelphia. The Philadelphia International Airport closed at 1030 p.m. EDT on the 27th and reopened on Monday the 29th. In Philadelphia, the storm left thousands without power. More than 500 trees fell in the city, seven buildings collapsed and twenty roads were closed. PECO Energy restored power by August 31st.||The highest wind gusts recorded during Irene were 57 mph in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), 53 mph in Allentown (Lehigh County), 52 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport (Philadelphia County), 48 mph in Reading (Berks County), 46 mph in Coatesville (Chester County), 45 mph in Northeast Philadelphia (Philadelphia County), 44 mph in Pottstown (Montgomery County), 44 mph in Newbold (Bucks County) and 40 mph in Quakertown (Bucks County). The high tide in Philadelphia reached 9.89 feet above mean lower low water during the early morning of the 28th. Moderate tidal flooding begins at 9.20 feet above mean lower low water. ||Hurricane Irene formed east of the Leeward Islands on Saturday the 20th. It moved northeast and passed over Puerto Rico overnight on the 21st. As Irene moved off the island, it intensified into a hurricane. Irene just bypassed the island of Hispaniola to its north and then passed over the Eastern Bahamas on the 25th as it reached category three hurricane strength. From the Bahamas, Irene moved nearly due north and slowly weakened to a category two hurricane on the 26th and a category one hurricane on the 27th. Irene made her initial landfall near Cape Lookout, North Carolina at 8 a.m. EDT on the 27th and then proceeded to the northnortheast and went back over the Atlantic Ocean near the Virginia and North Carolina border at 7 p.m. EDT on the 27th. From there Irene paralleled the Delmarva Peninsula and the center passed about 15 miles east of Delaware between 3 a.m. and 4 a.m. EDT on the 28th. Irene made her second landfall as a tropical storm on Brigantine Island, just north of Atlantic City, New Jersey at 535 a.m. EDT on the 28th. From there the center of Irene moved along eastern parts of Ocean and Monmouth Counties and was located near Tinton Falls Township in Monmouth County at 8 a.m. EDT on the 28th. At about 9 a.m. EDT the center of Irene passed over New York City.||Irene helped shatter all time monthly precipitation records. In Philadelphia, the 19.31 inches of rain established a new all-time August as well as monthly record. It was nearly half of the normal yearly precipitation total. A new August as well as all-time monthly rainfall record of 13.47 inches was also established in Allentown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

The Delaware Water Gap National Recreational Area was closed through Labor Day Weekend (September 5th). ||Tropical storm force wind gusts overspread Eastern Pennsylvania during the evening of the 27th and persisted into the afternoon of the 28th. Peak wind gusts averaged around 50 mph. The strongest winds associated with Irene occurred at two distinct times. The first surge occurred during bands of heavier rain during the evening of the 27th and early morning of the 28th. The second peak occurred during the afternoon of the 28th when skies were clearing and deeper mixing of the atmosphere brought stronger winds to the ground. Most of the peak wind gusts occurred at this time. The rain associated with Irene overspread Eastern Pennsylvania during the late morning on the 27th, fell at its heaviest from during the evening of the 27th into the early morning of the 28th and ended during the early afternoon on the 28th. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 7 inches and caused widespread flooding. Because the flash flooding and flooding blended into one, all flooding related stormdata county entries were combined into one under flood events. The storm surge of 3 to 5 feet caused moderate tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River overnight on the 27th. Minor tidal flooding occurred during the high tide cycles from the 29th through the 31st. | |In Stroudsburg (Monroe County), a 44-year-old man died when a tree fell on him in his backyard. He pushed his son to safety. Governor Tom Corbett declared a state of emergency for the city of Philadelphia and the surrounding suburbs. The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority halted all commuter rail service during the evening of the 27th as multiple tornado warnings were issued.  Three large shelters on the evening of August 27th in Philadelphia. The Philadelphia International Airport closed at 1030 p.m. EDT on the 27th and reopened on Monday the 29th. In Philadelphia, the storm left thousands without power. More than 500 trees fell in the city, seven buildings collapsed and twenty roads were closed. PECO Energy restored power by August 31st.||The highest wind gusts recorded during Irene were 57 mph in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), 53 mph in Allentown (Lehigh County), 52 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport (Philadelphia County), 48 mph in Reading (Berks County), 46 mph in Coatesville (Chester County), 45 mph in Northeast Philadelphia (Philadelphia County), 44 mph in Pottstown (Montgomery County), 44 mph in Newbold (Bucks County) and 40 mph in Quakertown (Bucks County). The high tide in Philadelphia reached 9.89 feet above mean lower low water during the early morning of the 28th. Moderate tidal flooding begins at 9.20 feet above mean lower low water. ||Hurricane Irene formed east of the Leeward Islands on Saturday the 20th. It moved northeast and passed over Puerto Rico overnight on the 21st. As Irene moved off the island, it intensified into a hurricane. Irene just bypassed the island of Hispaniola to its north and then passed over the Eastern Bahamas on the 25th as it reached category three hurricane strength. From the Bahamas, Irene moved nearly due north and slowly weakened to a category two hurricane on the 26th and a category one hurricane on the 27th. Irene made her initial landfall near Cape Lookout, North Carolina at 8 a.m. EDT on the 27th and then proceeded to the northnortheast and went back over the Atlantic Ocean near the Virginia and North Carolina border at 7 p.m. EDT on the 27th. From there Irene paralleled the Delmarva Peninsula and the center passed about 15 miles east of Delaware between 3 a.m. and 4 a.m. EDT on the 28th. Irene made her second landfall as a tropical storm on Brigantine Island, just north of Atlantic City, New Jersey at 535 a.m. EDT on the 28th. From there the center of Irene moved along eastern parts of Ocean and Monmouth Counties and was located near Tinton Falls Township in Monmouth County at 8 a.m. EDT on the 28th. At about 9 a.m. EDT the center of Irene passed over New York City.||Irene helped shatter all time monthly precipitation records. In Philadelphia, the 19.31 inches of rain established a new all-time August as well as monthly record. It was nearly half of the normal yearly precipitation total. A new August as well as all-time monthly rainfall record of 13.47 inches was also established in Allentown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms caused flash flooding in portions of downtown State College. One floot of water was reported on portions of Atherton Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy Rain caused flash flooding in Cass Township. Several structures in the township experienced flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding over portions of Franklin County. Much of the flooding was confined to urban areas of Chambersburg (where portions of Main Street were closed) and Mercersburg (where portions of East Seminary Street were closed).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Port Royal. Flooded basements and road closures were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded from intense rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought thunderstorms with locally heavy rain to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening of September 23rd, 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flash flooding in northeast Schuylkill County. Flood waters were over portions of I-81 and Route 309 near Mcadoo, and across portions of I-81 near Frackville. Several roads were reported to be washed out near Hometown in Rush Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash Flooding was noted near Coledale, when water from 6 Mile Run overflowed the banks and flooded portions of 6 Mile Run Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving upper level impulse and attendant surface low pressure system moved across the Great Lakes Region. An unseasonably warm and relatively moist air mass /surface temperatures in the 70s to low 80s and dewpoints in the upper 50s/ resided over central Pennsylvania in advance of this system and aided in strong destabilization. The moderate instability combined with strong vertical wind shear profiles promoted organized thunderstorms with supercells and bowing line segments. Large hail and damaging winds were the main threats, however sufficient low-level wind shear was present to support isolated tornadoes. A tornado watch was issued around 1500 EDT on 27 April 2011.||The severe weather threat continued through the evening and into the overnight and early morning hours on 28 April 2011. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several road closures and water rescues were reported in and around New Cumberland.  |Widespread flooding in Lower Allen Township. Cedar Run out of its banks flooding Old Gettysburg Road. Cars reported flooded, two homes and a business also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving upper level impulse and attendant surface low pressure system moved across the Great Lakes Region. An unseasonably warm and relatively moist air mass /surface temperatures in the 70s to low 80s and dewpoints in the upper 50s/ resided over central Pennsylvania in advance of this system and aided in strong destabilization. The moderate instability combined with strong vertical wind shear profiles promoted organized thunderstorms with supercells and bowing line segments. Large hail and damaging winds were the main threats, however sufficient low-level wind shear was present to support isolated tornadoes. A tornado watch was issued around 1500 EDT on 27 April 2011.||The severe weather threat continued through the evening and into the overnight and early morning hours on 28 April 2011. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East Branch of Antietam Creek out of its banks at Renfrew Park.  Water across State Line Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy, short duration rainfall resulted in small stream flooding and several road closures near Linglestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 center reported three flooded roadways in the Tower City and St. Clair areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall in a short period of time resulted in Quittaphilla Creek flooding from 22nd Street in Lebanon to Route 442 in Annville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in a water rescue in Fairview Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving upper level impulse and attendant surface low pressure system moved across the Great Lakes Region. An unseasonably warm and relatively moist air mass /surface temperatures in the 70s to low 80s and dewpoints in the upper 50s/ resided over central Pennsylvania in advance of this system and aided in strong destabilization. The moderate instability combined with strong vertical wind shear profiles promoted organized thunderstorms with supercells and bowing line segments. Large hail and damaging winds were the main threats, however sufficient low-level wind shear was present to support isolated tornadoes. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several road closures, mudslides and small stream flooding were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved across the Upper Ohio Valley bringing heavy rain as well as a line of severe thunderstorms. Flooding of streams and creeks was widespread across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Isolated wind damage from severe thunderstorms occurred with a cold front in the morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The broadcast media reported Mcknight Road closed with water lifting manhole covers inot the street.

A tornado watch was issued around 1500 EDT on 27 April 2011.||The severe weather threat continued through the evening and into the overnight and early morning hours on 28 April 2011. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small streams were reported out of their banks and road washouts reported in Westfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving upper level impulse and attendant surface low pressure system moved across the Great Lakes Region. An unseasonably warm and relatively moist air mass /surface temperatures in the 70s to low 80s and dewpoints in the upper 50s/ resided over central Pennsylvania in advance of this system and aided in strong destabilization. The moderate instability combined with strong vertical wind shear profiles promoted organized thunderstorms with supercells and bowing line segments. Large hail and damaging winds were the main threats, however sufficient low-level wind shear was present to support isolated tornadoes. A tornado watch was issued around 1500 EDT on 27 April 2011.||The severe weather threat continued through the evening and into the overnight and early morning hours on 28 April 2011. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported on Route 443.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Route 6 in Plymouth Township, with scattered areas of road flooding elsewhere across Luzerne county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several bands of strong to severe thunderstorms developed along two north-south axes of low level confluence across central Pennsylvania into upstate New York. The storms produced large hail, damaging winds and intense short-duration rainfall from the mid afternoon hours through the late evening. The combination of the heavy rain, above normal soil moisture and high stream-flows resulted in significant localized flash flooding in Sullivan County which lasted into the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A flash flood brought widespread damage to the town of Dushore.  Numerous roads were closed.  Several homes were damaged due to high water.  Two water rescues were performed in Cherry and Colley Townships.  German Street Bridge, SR 220 was damaged from flood waters.  About 30 residents were displaced due to flooding in downtown Dushore.  Two feet of water was estimated in downtown Dushore.
