An unseasonably warm and relatively moist air mass /surface temperatures in the 70s to low 80s and dewpoints in the upper 50s/ resided over central Pennsylvania in advance of this system and aided in strong destabilization. The moderate instability combined with strong vertical wind shear profiles promoted organized thunderstorms with supercells and bowing line segments. Large hail and damaging winds were the main threats, however sufficient low-level wind shear was present to support isolated tornadoes. A tornado watch was issued around 1500 EDT on 27 April 2011.||The severe weather threat continued through the evening and into the overnight and early morning hours on 28 April 2011. By this time, thunderstorms had evolved into largely north-south oriented clusters or broken lines with embedded supercell structures. Above normal soil moisture from recent heavy rains combined with high stream-flows and intense short duration rainfall contributed to flash flooding. The storms finally exited the region by mid-morning on 28 April 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 234 was closed due to high water.  Small stream flooding, water rescues, basements flooded and water flowing over blocking roads reported in Biglerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along several roads in Wysox.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in 12 water rescues of people in cars on flooded roads at several locations.  Cedar Run was reported out of banks and flooding Old Gettysburg Road near Shiremanstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous water rescues of stranded motorists were made by boats and helicopters. No injuries were reported but several people were taken to area hospitals for evaluation. Several residences were evacuated due to high waters along area creeks. The Gettysburg Fire Department, assisted by several local fire departments, evacuated 27 boy scouts via boat from the Gettysburg Campground. The boy scouts were relocated to the Eisenhower Inn. SR 94 was closed due to high water in Reading Township. Helicopters used in rescue operations were provided by Troop 3 of Maryland State Police and Stat Medivac from Thomasville, York County, PA. Opossum Creek was also out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A creek in Laceyville flooded, with several homes threatened. Several other roads were also flooded and washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a series of thunderstorms and moist antecedent conditions caused poor drainage and flash flooding in the Poconos, primarily in Carbon County. Event precipitation totals averaged 1.5 to 2.0 inches, most of which fell during the first half of the day on the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Lehighton. Water rescues occurred along Pennsylvania State Route 248.  No serious injuries were reported. Precipitation totals included 1.87 inches in Palmerton and 1.83 inches in Bowmanstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bradford County experienced significant flash flooding on the overnight period of April 26th into April 27th.  The bulk of the damage was roadway related with most townships in the county reporting at least some flooded roads. Some bridges suffered damage, as well. The township with the greatest damage was Troy, with over $1 million in damages. One home in North Towanda had significant structural damage with a wall collapse due to the flash flooding.  Other homes only reported basement flooding or other minor damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dynamic area of low pressure and trailing frontal zone moved across southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening, producing intense lines of heavy showers and thunderstorms. Deep moisture and very strong wind fields ahead of the frontal system produced torrential rains, flash flooding and localized wind damage across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was widespread across the area.  Some reports included flooding at Falling Spring Creek at Kennedy Street and 5th Avenue in Chambersburg as well as the   intersection of Hickory Run Road and Orestown Road.  A water rescue was reported in Southhampton Township.  Also in Chambersburg, Conococheague Creek was flooded at Commerce Street.  Roads were flooded and closed in Letterkenny and Lurgan Townships.  Iron Bridge Road was reported flooded at the Confluence of the West and East Branch of Antietam Creek near Waynesboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper air disturbance helped trigger thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th. The thunderstorms were training and not fast movers. Coupled with the recent run of wet weather helped cause flash flooding in eastern parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2 to 4 inches where repeat (training) thunderstorms occurred. The event precipitation total in Martins Creek in Lower Mount Bethel Township in Northampton County was 3.24 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Creek flash flooding caused the washout of a bridge on North Delaware Drive (Pennsylvania State Route 611) in Lower Mount Bethel Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper air disturbance helped trigger thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th. The thunderstorms were training and not fast movers. Coupled with the recent run of wet weather helped cause flash flooding in eastern parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2 to 4 inches where repeat (training) thunderstorms occurred. The event precipitation total in Martins Creek in Lower Mount Bethel Township in Northampton County was 3.24 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding forced the closure of Pennsylvania State Route 115 in Plainfield Township near Church Road. No homes in the area were flooded and the roadway was reopened by 8 p.m. EDT that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper air disturbance helped trigger thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th. The thunderstorms were training and not fast movers. Coupled with the recent run of wet weather helped cause flash flooding in eastern parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2 to 4 inches where repeat (training) thunderstorms occurred. The event precipitation total in Martins Creek in Lower Mount Bethel Township in Northampton County was 3.24 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out the bridge at the intersection of Cedar and Richmond Roads in Washington Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper air disturbance helped trigger thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th. The thunderstorms were training and not fast movers. Coupled with the recent run of wet weather helped cause flash flooding in eastern parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2 to 4 inches where repeat (training) thunderstorms occurred. The event precipitation total in Martins Creek in Lower Mount Bethel Township in Northampton County was 3.24 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in southeastern Monroe County in Hamilton, Middle Smithfield and Stroud Townships.  In Hamilton Township, flooding occurred along the intersection of U.S. Routes 209 and Pennsylvania State Route 33. In Middle Smithfield Township, flooding occurred near Werry's Pub near Marshalls Creek on U.S. Route 209. In Stroud Township, high water  occurred on Pennsylvania State Routes 611 and 33 and U.S. Route 209.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved up from the Mississippi River Valley into Ohio and western Pennsylvania. The storm system had adequate moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, which increased rainfall rates to over an inch and a half per hour. This intense rainfall triggered several small rivers and streams to overflow their banks, and for low lying and poor drainage areas to flood. Rainfall amounts around one to two inches were observed. Saturated ground cover from recent rains supported complete runoff, so though relatively small rainfall amounts the flooding was still significant in areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rainfall with rates over an inch per hour fell over portions of western Crawford County. Though rainfall amounts were generally one to two inches, the rain rate combined with saturated ground conditions resulted in rapid runoff. The runoff resulted in flooded basements and roads. Cars stalled along highway 6 near Maples Road as water depths were over hoods.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of snow melt and rainfall caused ice jam flooding at the mouth of Oil Creek. The jam broke after about an hour and moved into the Allegheny River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam at the mouth of Oil Creek caused a rapid rise in water levels with ice and water backed up to near SR 8 in Oil city. The jam broke and went into the Allegheny River after about an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of severe thunderstorms formed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon, and produced localized wind damage and heavy rainfall across portions of east-central Pennsylvania. The heavy rain combined with above normal soil moisture and high stream-flows contributed to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed Sugar Grove Road east of Huntingdon in Henderson Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of severe thunderstorms formed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon, and produced localized wind damage and heavy rainfall across portions of east-central Pennsylvania. The heavy rain combined with above normal soil moisture and high stream-flows contributed to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed PA 26 at the intersection of PA 164 between Martinsburg and Saxton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of severe thunderstorms formed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon, and produced localized wind damage and heavy rainfall across portions of east-central Pennsylvania. The heavy rain combined with above normal soil moisture and high stream-flows contributed to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed Back Maitland Road (SR 2004) in Derry Township northeast of Lewistown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of severe thunderstorms formed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon, and produced localized wind damage and heavy rainfall across portions of east-central Pennsylvania. The heavy rain combined with above normal soil moisture and high stream-flows contributed to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed Ridge Road (SR 4004) in West Beaver Township near McClure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms and tornadoes moved through the area. Two EF1 tornadoes were confirmed in Huntingdon County. There was one report of localized flash flooding in Bedford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains flooded and closed PA 26 near the intersection of PA 36 along Yellow Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from slow-moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding in and around the city of Lancaster during the early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and poor drainage caused the temporary closing of several roadways including PA 340 and 372. There were several reports of water rescues for motorists being stranded in low lying flooded areas, including the Plum Street underpass and Wabank Road in Lancaster Township. Several residents also reported basement flooding. No injuries or major damages were reported.  Some video of this event is available at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HkfaX6NO3OA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cut-off low over the central Appalachians produced slow-moving and training showers and thunderstorms across portions of central Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall over a short duration resulted in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall produced localized flash flooding from York city northward across portions of Manchester and Newberry Townships. Tyler Run exceeded bankful in southern York and two motorists were rescued from flood waters in Newberry Township. Approximately 10 people were evacuated due to a dam break at on pond on Blossom Drive in East Manchester Township. 100 people were evacuated due to flooding along Walnut Street in Mount Wolf Borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cut-off low over the central Appalachians produced slow-moving and training showers and thunderstorms across portions of central Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall over a short duration resulted in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall produced localized flash flooding and closed several roads in the Meyersdale area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding closed PA routes 646 and 342 east of Bradford in Foster Township.  Derrick Road was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding closed several roads in Chatham Township between Westfield and Keeneyville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level low pressure system brought scattered showers and thunderstorms to northeast Pennsylvania. Some of the storms brought heavy rainfall, and isolated storms produced flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bird Creek Road was partially washed away in Wells Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Ohio Valley to the Great Lakes and strengthened. Heavy rain moved into northeast Pennsylvania late in the evening on the 10th, and continued into the overnight hours on the 11th. Rainfall amounts ranged from around 1.5 to over 2 inches in areas that experienced flooding, with isolated amounts over 3 inches in Pike county. The rain combined with melting snow, adding to the runoff and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed across the county due to mudslides, or water over the roads. The hardest hit area was Laceyville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Ohio Valley to the Great Lakes and strengthened. Heavy rain moved into northeast Pennsylvania late in the evening on the 10th, and continued into the overnight hours on the 11th. Rainfall amounts ranged from around 1.5 to over 2 inches in areas that experienced flooding, with isolated amounts over 3 inches in Pike county. The rain combined with melting snow, adding to the runoff and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of Routes 414 and 14 were closed due to flash flooding. Hardest hits areas were Troy and Canton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Ohio Valley to the Great Lakes and strengthened. Heavy rain moved into northeast Pennsylvania late in the evening on the 10th, and continued into the overnight hours on the 11th. Rainfall amounts ranged from around 1.5 to over 2 inches in areas that experienced flooding, with isolated amounts over 3 inches in Pike county. The rain combined with melting snow, adding to the runoff and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A creek went out of its banks in Rice Township near Blytheburn Road in the vicinity of the Valley Stream Mobile Home Park. Wapwallopen Creek went out of its banks in parts of Hollenback Township. Faux Road was flooded and not passable. Flooding also occurred on Moyers Grove Road. In Shavertown, some damage occurred to Hillside Road and to some homes along the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Ohio Valley to the Great Lakes and strengthened. Heavy rain moved into northeast Pennsylvania late in the evening on the 10th, and continued into the overnight hours on the 11th. Rainfall amounts ranged from around 1.5 to over 2 inches in areas that experienced flooding, with isolated amounts over 3 inches in Pike county. The rain combined with melting snow, adding to the runoff and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road flooding occurred throughout the county. Schools were delayed due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance and weak, nearly stalled frontal boundary helped to produce scattered showers and thunderstorms during the heating the afternoon and early evening. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail and damaging wind gusts. Heavy rains from the storms also caused flash flooding across portions of Lackawanna and Wayne counties, where 3 to 5 inches of rain fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and rocks flowed across the Owego Turnpike, and some washouts were reported on secondary county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance and weak, nearly stalled frontal boundary helped to produce scattered showers and thunderstorms during the heating the afternoon and early evening. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail and damaging wind gusts. Heavy rains from the storms also caused flash flooding across portions of Lackawanna and Wayne counties, where 3 to 5 inches of rain fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multi-cell thunderstorms repeating over the same locations produced 3 to 5 inches of rainfall during the late afternoon.  Campers reported washouts of secondary county and dirt roads leading to a campground. Travelers also reported water and rocks flowing across the Owego Turnpike.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance and weak, nearly stalled frontal boundary helped to produce scattered showers and thunderstorms during the heating the afternoon and early evening. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail and damaging wind gusts. Heavy rains from the storms also caused flash flooding across portions of Lackawanna and Wayne counties, where 3 to 5 inches of rain fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of Route 167 were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of thunderstorms preceding a cold front produced heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and first half of the evening on the 25th. The thunderstorms caused poor drainage and creek flooding in the Lehigh Valley and the local Philadelphia area. Where thunderstorms moved over similar locations,  storm totals reached 3 to 6 inches in Northampton and Carbon Counties and 2 to 4 inches in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused basement and stream flooding in and around Lehigh Township and Walnutport in northwestern Northampton County. Precipitation event totals included 6.00 inches in both Berlinsville and Walnutport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of thunderstorms preceding a cold front produced heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and first half of the evening on the 25th. The thunderstorms caused poor drainage and creek flooding in the Lehigh Valley and the local Philadelphia area. Where thunderstorms moved over similar locations,  storm totals reached 3 to 6 inches in Northampton and Carbon Counties and 2 to 4 inches in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Monocacy Creek in Bethlehem. The thunderstorms also caused poor drainage flooding in Northampton County.  The Monocacy Creek in Bethlehem was above its 4.5 foot flood from 456 p.m. EDT through 725 p.m. EDT on the 25th. It crested at 5.19 feet at 6 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 3.74 inches in Forks Township, 3.70 inches in Bethlehem, 3.48 inches in Easton and 2.53 inches in Martins Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of thunderstorms preceding a cold front produced heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and first half of the evening on the 25th. The thunderstorms caused poor drainage and creek flooding in the Lehigh Valley and the local Philadelphia area. Where thunderstorms moved over similar locations,  storm totals reached 3 to 6 inches in Northampton and Carbon Counties and 2 to 4 inches in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding of creeks in eastern Chester County. West Chester was one of the hardest hit municipalities with several water rescues as vehicles became stranded in flood waters. Flooding was reported on Adams, Franklin, Miner, Bolmar, Washington and Market Streets as well as Bradford and Hannum (U.S. Route 322) Avenues and the West Chester By Pass (U.S. Route 202). Farther to the northeast, the Valley Creek at Valley Forge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 938 p.m. EDT through 1032 p.m. EDT on the 25th. It crested at 7.2 feet at 10 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 4.26 inches in Exton and 2.03 inches in West Chester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought thunderstorms with locally heavy rain to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening of September 23rd, 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain and flash flooding over eastern Lancaster County. Several roadways were flooded in Fulton Township including Soapstone Hill Road, Little Briton Road, Cedar Hill Road and Quarry Road. A water rescue was performed at a home surrounded by water south of Wrightsdale. Several roads were also closed in the Goodville area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee moved northward from the southern Appalachians on the 6th to the middle Atlantic states on the 7th before stalling on the 8th. The moisture from Lee interacted with a frontal system to the west across the eastern Ohio Valley and eastern Great Lakes. In addition, moisture was drawn into New York and Pennsylvania from Hurricane Katia which was moving northward off the east coast in tandem with the remnants of Lee. This complicated scenario led to an extreme amount of rain for central New York and northeast Pennsylvania, most of which fell over a 48 hour period from the 6th to the 8th. Rainfall of 6 to 12 inches occurred over most of the upper Susquehanna river basin in New York and northeast Pennsylvania. The heavy rain caused massive, record breaking flooding on small streams, creeks and the Susquehanna River and its larger tributaries. ||The main branch of the Susquehanna River in New York from Binghamton to Vestal, Owego and Waverly crested from 1 to 4 feet higher than the previous record crests set in June 2006.  In Pennsylvania, record crests occurred along the Susquehanna River at Meshoppen and Wilkes Barre which exceeded the long-standing record crests by around 1 foot associated with Hurricane Agnes in 1972. ||Damages in the upper Susquehanna River Basin in New York and Pennsylvania are close to 1 billion dollars. Unfortunately, the flooding claimed 1 life and injured 1 person in central New York and northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Monroeton from the Towanda Creek. The levee was destroyed by the flash flooding. Routes 220, 414 and 6 are all closed due to flash flooding. Many homes have been flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in central Schuylkill County between Pine Grove Township and Tremont. Several water rescues were performed, to save people from flash flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee moved northward from the southern Appalachians on the 6th to the middle Atlantic states on the 7th before stalling on the 8th. The moisture from Lee interacted with a frontal system to the west across the eastern Ohio Valley and eastern Great Lakes. In addition, moisture was drawn into New York and Pennsylvania from Hurricane Katia which was moving northward off the east coast in tandem with the remnants of Lee. This complicated scenario led to an extreme amount of rain for central New York and northeast Pennsylvania, most of which fell over a 48 hour period from the 6th to the 8th. Rainfall of 6 to 12 inches occurred over most of the upper Susquehanna river basin in New York and northeast Pennsylvania. The heavy rain caused massive, record breaking flooding on small streams, creeks and the Susquehanna River and its larger tributaries. ||The main branch of the Susquehanna River in New York from Binghamton to Vestal, Owego and Waverly crested from 1 to 4 feet higher than the previous record crests set in June 2006.  In Pennsylvania, record crests occurred along the Susquehanna River at Meshoppen and Wilkes Barre which exceeded the long-standing record crests by around 1 foot associated with Hurricane Agnes in 1972. ||Damages in the upper Susquehanna River Basin in New York and Pennsylvania are close to 1 billion dollars. Unfortunately, the flooding claimed 1 life and injured 1 person in central New York and northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed in the Towanda area due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that moved through eastern Berks, northern Montgomery, southern Lehigh, western Northampton and Monroe Counties caused poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding in Northampton and Monroe Counties during the evening of the 28th. Along the heaviest band, event precipitation totals averaged 2 to 4 inches. Runoff from the heavy rain then caused some creek flooding that persisted into the 29th in Montgomery and Northampton Counties. The thunderstorms also caused lightning damage to a home in Northampton County.  The heavy rain culminated the wettest September for the state of Pennsylvania dating back to 1895. The 9.71 inch statewide average for the month was more than twice the normal value. It was also the wettest September on record in Allentown (12.99 inches) and the third wettest September on record in Philadelphia (10.27 inches).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding from Bath through Bethlehem in the Monocacy Creek drainage basin. In Bath, water rescues and voluntary evacuations occurred. The Monocacy Creek flooded businesses and a senior high rise building. Flooding was also reported into the first floor of a few homes. Flooding was reported on Main, Chestnut and Northampton Streets. Downstream in East Allen Township, basement flooding up to twelve feet was reported.  In Bethlehem, the Monocacy Creek at Illicks Mill Road was above its 4.5 foot flood stage from 820 p.m. EDT through 950 p.m. EDT on the 28th. It crested at 4.94 feet at 915 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 3.24 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport, 2.56 inches in Martins Creek and 1.74 inches in Bethlehem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that moved through eastern Berks, northern Montgomery, southern Lehigh, western Northampton and Monroe Counties caused poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding in Northampton and Monroe Counties during the evening of the 28th. Along the heaviest band, event precipitation totals averaged 2 to 4 inches. Runoff from the heavy rain then caused some creek flooding that persisted into the 29th in Montgomery and Northampton Counties. The thunderstorms also caused lightning damage to a home in Northampton County.  The heavy rain culminated the wettest September for the state of Pennsylvania dating back to 1895. The 9.71 inch statewide average for the month was more than twice the normal value. It was also the wettest September on record in Allentown (12.99 inches) and the third wettest September on record in Philadelphia (10.27 inches).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small creek flash flooding in south central Monroe County, mainly in Ross and Chestnuthill Townships. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 3 to 4 inches in the townships. Event precipitation totals included 3.84 inches in Hamilton Township and 2.71 inches in Blakeslee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee that interacted with a stalled frontal boundary produced several days with periods of heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania from the 5th into the 8th. Event precipitation totals averaged 4 to 9 inches, except in Berks County where 6 to 12 inches fell.  One drowning occurred in Philadelphia. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as moderate flooding along the Delaware and Schuylkill Basins and minor to moderate flooding along the Lehigh River Basin. Crests in the upper Schuylkill, Lehigh and Delaware River Basins were higher than what occurred with Irene the previous month and the highest crests since late June of 2006 in most instances. The crests along the Delaware River were 2 to 4 feet higher than what occurred during Irene. Some of the smaller streams in southeastern Pennsylvania reached major flooding levels, but most of those crests were lower than what occurred with Irene. In addition to the freshwater flooding, moderate tidal flooding occurred along the lower Delaware River and its tributaries. ||In the most recent available flooding assessment for Eastern Pennsylvania, there were 22 homes and businesses that were destroyed, 201 that suffered major damage, 672 that had minor damage and 1217 others that were affected. The preliminary damage estimate for the state of Pennsylvania was five hundred million dollars.  Please look for possible updates in future monthly issues of stormdata.| |The combination of fresh water runoff and a weak southerly flow produced moderate tidal flooding during the evening high tide cycles from the 7th through the 9th and minor tidal flooding with all of the other high tide cycles from the evening of the 6th through overnight on the 11th. The highest tides occurred during the evening high tide cycle on the 8th in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and the evening high tide cycle on the 9th in Bucks County.  The evening high tide on the 8th in Philadelphia reached 9.41 feet above mean lower low water. Moderate tidal flooding starts at 9.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Newbold Island (Bucks County) reached 12.11 feet above mean lower low water. There is no current categorical tide gage information for this site.  ||Tropical Storm Lee made landfall in Louisiana during the morning of the 4th and moved slowly northeast. An approaching cold front from the Mississippi Valley reached Lee by the morning of the 5th and transformed it to an extratropical system on the 5th in Mississippi. The same cold front acted as a conduit for Lee's moisture farther to the northeast. Showers and thunderstorms from that approaching cold front arrived during the evening and overnight on the 5th  and set off the first round of flash flooding rains in Northeast Pennsylvania. The front then stalled just south of Delmarva on the 6th. A relative lull in the rain then occurred during the morning of the 6th. As the front started to back north as a warm front later in the day on the 6th, more bands of heavier rain returned that afternoon and particularly that evening. A blocking weather pattern then moved the frontal boundary little from the morning of the 7th into the morning of the 8th across southeast Pennsylvania. A couple of bands of flash flood producing rains started to form and move east into Eastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th and continued through the night.  The frontal boundary started to drift offshore later in the day on the 8th and most of the precipitation associated with Lee was done.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy downpours caused flash flooding along a tributary of Cobbs Creek in Haverford Township. A state of emergency was declared in the township. Vehicles were stranded and schools were closed on the 8th. A shelter was opened at the Linwood Elementary School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee moved northward from the southern Appalachians on the 6th to the middle Atlantic states on the 7th before stalling on the 8th. The moisture from Lee interacted with a frontal system to the west across the eastern Ohio Valley and eastern Great Lakes. In addition, moisture was drawn into New York and Pennsylvania from Hurricane Katia which was moving northward off the east coast in tandem with the remnants of Lee. This complicated scenario led to an extreme amount of rain for central New York and northeast Pennsylvania, most of which fell over a 48 hour period from the 6th to the 8th. Rainfall of 6 to 12 inches occurred over most of the upper Susquehanna river basin in New York and northeast Pennsylvania. The heavy rain caused massive, record breaking flooding on small streams, creeks and the Susquehanna River and its larger tributaries. ||The main branch of the Susquehanna River in New York from Binghamton to Vestal, Owego and Waverly crested from 1 to 4 feet higher than the previous record crests set in June 2006.  In Pennsylvania, record crests occurred along the Susquehanna River at Meshoppen and Wilkes Barre which exceeded the long-standing record crests by around 1 foot associated with Hurricane Agnes in 1972. ||Damages in the upper Susquehanna River Basin in New York and Pennsylvania are close to 1 billion dollars. Unfortunately, the flooding claimed 1 life and injured 1 person in central New York and northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Little Meadows from very heavy rains. Numerous roads, homes and bridges were severely damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred along Route 187. Numerous roads, homes and bridges were severely damaged. A road collapsed from the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee that interacted with a stalled frontal boundary produced several days with periods of heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania from the 5th into the 8th. Event precipitation totals averaged 4 to 9 inches, except in Berks County where 6 to 12 inches fell.  One drowning occurred in Philadelphia. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as moderate flooding along the Delaware and Schuylkill Basins and minor to moderate flooding along the Lehigh River Basin. Crests in the upper Schuylkill, Lehigh and Delaware River Basins were higher than what occurred with Irene the previous month and the highest crests since late June of 2006 in most instances. The crests along the Delaware River were 2 to 4 feet higher than what occurred during Irene. Some of the smaller streams in southeastern Pennsylvania reached major flooding levels, but most of those crests were lower than what occurred with Irene. In addition to the freshwater flooding, moderate tidal flooding occurred along the lower Delaware River and its tributaries. ||In the most recent available flooding assessment for Eastern Pennsylvania, there were 22 homes and businesses that were destroyed, 201 that suffered major damage, 672 that had minor damage and 1217 others that were affected. The preliminary damage estimate for the state of Pennsylvania was five hundred million dollars.  Please look for possible updates in future monthly issues of stormdata.| |The combination of fresh water runoff and a weak southerly flow produced moderate tidal flooding during the evening high tide cycles from the 7th through the 9th and minor tidal flooding with all of the other high tide cycles from the evening of the 6th through overnight on the 11th. The highest tides occurred during the evening high tide cycle on the 8th in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and the evening high tide cycle on the 9th in Bucks County.  The evening high tide on the 8th in Philadelphia reached 9.41 feet above mean lower low water. Moderate tidal flooding starts at 9.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Newbold Island (Bucks County) reached 12.11 feet above mean lower low water. There is no current categorical tide gage information for this site.  ||Tropical Storm Lee made landfall in Louisiana during the morning of the 4th and moved slowly northeast. An approaching cold front from the Mississippi Valley reached Lee by the morning of the 5th and transformed it to an extratropical system on the 5th in Mississippi. The same cold front acted as a conduit for Lee's moisture farther to the northeast. Showers and thunderstorms from that approaching cold front arrived during the evening and overnight on the 5th  and set off the first round of flash flooding rains in Northeast Pennsylvania. The front then stalled just south of Delmarva on the 6th. A relative lull in the rain then occurred during the morning of the 6th. As the front started to back north as a warm front later in the day on the 6th, more bands of heavier rain returned that afternoon and particularly that evening. A blocking weather pattern then moved the frontal boundary little from the morning of the 7th into the morning of the 8th across southeast Pennsylvania. A couple of bands of flash flood producing rains started to form and move east into Eastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th and continued through the night.  The frontal boundary started to drift offshore later in the day on the 8th and most of the precipitation associated with Lee was done.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage areas in the southern part of Montgomery County. Flooding occurred along the Wissahickon Creek and continued along the Schuylkill River. In Whitpain Township, along the Wissahickon Creek, 40 residents were evacuated on West Maple Street. Two buildings collapsed in Ambler Borough.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in lower Bucks County. Flooding occurred in the Neshaminy Basin and the heavy rain helped exacerbate the ongoing or starting of flooding along the Delaware River. Along the Neshaminy Creek, in Langhorne, creek flooding reached the Bridgetown Mill House.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee produced widespread flooding, flash flooding and river flooding mainly near and to the east of the Susquehanna Valley from September 4-10. Several locations in the Susquehanna Basin came close to records set by Hurricane Agnes (June 1972) and a few points (Bloomsburg, Hershey and Loyalsockville) set new floods of record. Flooding along Swatara Creek resulted in property damage and several deaths. Severe flooding occurred along Loyalsock Creek and many points along the main-stem of the Susquehanna River. The interaction of a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid-Atlantic region, a strong northern stream short-wave (with a persistent jet entrance region) and deep tropical moisture associated the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee resulted in multi-day, significant heavy rainfall event over Pennsylvania. ||Tropical storm Lee was the twelfth named storm of the 2011 season forming over the Gulf of Mexico on September 1. A strong northern stream short-wave interacted with Lee causing the storm to re-curve to the north-northeast. By 1200 UTC September 6, having undergone extra-tropical transition, post-tropical Lee was located over northern Georgia. The surface low weakened as it moved up the Appalachian Mountain chain. However, the strong low-level flow and the above normal precipitable water produced an extensive, north-to-south oriented band of heavy rainfall.||The rainfall associated with the remnants of Lee produced the 4th largest flood of record in the Mid-Atlantic Region. The five-day storm rainfall totals for September 5 to 9 were generally in the 5-8 inch range over the mid-section of central Pennsylvania and in the 8-12 inch range in the Susquehanna Valley region. There were local amounts reported in excess of 15 inches east of the Susquehanna River. The local climate sites in Harrisburg (KMDT) and Williamsport (KIPT) reported 13.44 and 9.03 inches respectively. On September 7, 2011 both KMDT and KIPT set their all-time daily (24-hour) rainfall for the month of September at 7.71 and 6.76 inches respectively. These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Life-threatening flash flooding occurred across a large part of western Lancaster County, inlcuding Elizabethtown, Manheim, Marietta and Columbia much of the day into the evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Repeating showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage areas in western Berks County during the afternoon and evening of the 7th. Twenty-four hour rainfall totals ending at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th reached around 6 inches. Hardest hit were Bethel, Tulpehocken and Marion Townships. In Marion Township, water rescues were performed. Off of Canal Road within the township, a herd of cattle became stranded in a field. U.S. Route 422 was closed in Wolmelsdorf Borough.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another band of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage areas in the eastern half of Berks County during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th. Water rescues were performed in Cumru, Exeter (U.S. Route 422) and Oley Townships. Road closures occurred in Exeter, Ontelaunee, Cumru, Richmond and Greenwich Townships. In Reading, flash flooding was reported along Pennsylvania State Route 12. In Birdsboro, West Main Street was closed after the Hay Creek started to flood. Flooding along the Manatawny Creek was reported in Oley Township. The sewage system in Kutztown was getting overwhelmed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: National guard was called in to rescue trapped residents due to catastrophic flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system brought unsettled weather to the region. |An extensive plume of Atlantic moisture into the system brought periods of heavy rain.  Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six homes were isolated, and two homes were surrounded by water on McChord and Harrison Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system brought unsettled weather to the region. |An extensive plume of Atlantic moisture into the system brought periods of heavy rain.  Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 81 was closed in South Abington Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system brought unsettled weather to the region. |An extensive plume of Atlantic moisture into the system brought periods of heavy rain.  Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a water rescue for occupants of a vehicle that fell into a sink hole on Keelersburg Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to six inches of rain across sections of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia and its nearby suburbs. This caused flash flooding and flooding of streams and creeks that started in Berks County and the Lehigh valley during the evening of the 13th and spread to the local Philadelphia area during the morning of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused roadway flooding and flash flooding of smaller streams in Albany, Greenwich, Tilden and Windsor Townships as well as Hamburg across the northern tier of Berks County. A few homes were also flooded and a mud slide was reported in Hamburg. Event precipitation totals included 4.17 inches in Hamburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from heavy rain caused flash flooding in Montgomery County during the evening of the 19th and creek flooding overnight on the 19th in lower Montgomery County and eastern Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in lower Montgomery County. Several roads were closed and water rescues performed.  Fourteen county roads were closed due to flooding and there were fifty-three county dispatches for water rescues in Whitemarsh, Upper Dublin, Springfield, Abington and Upper Moreland Townships. In Plymouth Township, the ground floor of the Macy's was flooded at the Plymouth Meeting Mall.  The home furnishing, junior's and children's departments were damaged. The store closed early that evening, but reopened the next day.  No serious injuries were reported. In addition, The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington was briefly above its 9 foot flood stage from 1030 p.m. EDT through 1103 p.m. EDT on the 19th. It crested at 9.07 feet at 1045 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 2.50 inches in Plymouth Meeting and 1.03 inches in Willow Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system brought unsettled weather to the region. |An extensive plume of Atlantic moisture into the system brought periods of heavy rain.  Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were washed out.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A creek went out of it's bands and crossed the roadway near Northern BLVD.

Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that moved through eastern Berks, northern Montgomery, southern Lehigh, western Northampton and Monroe Counties caused poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding in Northampton and Monroe Counties during the evening of the 28th. Along the heaviest band, event precipitation totals averaged 2 to 4 inches. Runoff from the heavy rain then caused some creek flooding that persisted into the 29th in Montgomery and Northampton Counties. The thunderstorms also caused lightning damage to a home in Northampton County.  The heavy rain culminated the wettest September for the state of Pennsylvania dating back to 1895. The 9.71 inch statewide average for the month was more than twice the normal value. It was also the wettest September on record in Allentown (12.99 inches) and the third wettest September on record in Philadelphia (10.27 inches).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Catasauqua Creek. Several businesses along the creek were flooded and suffered damage. Event precipitation totals included 3.24 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 2.91 inches within Allentown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flash flooding of smaller streams in lower Lehigh County mainly in Lower Milford and Upper Saucon Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 3 inches in this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee that interacted with a stalled frontal boundary produced several days with periods of heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania from the 5th into the 8th. Event precipitation totals averaged 4 to 9 inches, except in Berks County where 6 to 12 inches fell.  One drowning occurred in Philadelphia. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as moderate flooding along the Delaware and Schuylkill Basins and minor to moderate flooding along the Lehigh River Basin. Crests in the upper Schuylkill, Lehigh and Delaware River Basins were higher than what occurred with Irene the previous month and the highest crests since late June of 2006 in most instances. The crests along the Delaware River were 2 to 4 feet higher than what occurred during Irene. Some of the smaller streams in southeastern Pennsylvania reached major flooding levels, but most of those crests were lower than what occurred with Irene. In addition to the freshwater flooding, moderate tidal flooding occurred along the lower Delaware River and its tributaries. ||In the most recent available flooding assessment for Eastern Pennsylvania, there were 22 homes and businesses that were destroyed, 201 that suffered major damage, 672 that had minor damage and 1217 others that were affected. The preliminary damage estimate for the state of Pennsylvania was five hundred million dollars.  Please look for possible updates in future monthly issues of stormdata.| |The combination of fresh water runoff and a weak southerly flow produced moderate tidal flooding during the evening high tide cycles from the 7th through the 9th and minor tidal flooding with all of the other high tide cycles from the evening of the 6th through overnight on the 11th. The highest tides occurred during the evening high tide cycle on the 8th in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and the evening high tide cycle on the 9th in Bucks County.  The evening high tide on the 8th in Philadelphia reached 9.41 feet above mean lower low water. Moderate tidal flooding starts at 9.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Newbold Island (Bucks County) reached 12.11 feet above mean lower low water. There is no current categorical tide gage information for this site.  ||Tropical Storm Lee made landfall in Louisiana during the morning of the 4th and moved slowly northeast. An approaching cold front from the Mississippi Valley reached Lee by the morning of the 5th and transformed it to an extratropical system on the 5th in Mississippi. The same cold front acted as a conduit for Lee's moisture farther to the northeast. Showers and thunderstorms from that approaching cold front arrived during the evening and overnight on the 5th  and set off the first round of flash flooding rains in Northeast Pennsylvania. The front then stalled just south of Delmarva on the 6th. A relative lull in the rain then occurred during the morning of the 6th. As the front started to back north as a warm front later in the day on the 6th, more bands of heavier rain returned that afternoon and particularly that evening. A blocking weather pattern then moved the frontal boundary little from the morning of the 7th into the morning of the 8th across southeast Pennsylvania. A couple of bands of flash flood producing rains started to form and move east into Eastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th and continued through the night.  The frontal boundary started to drift offshore later in the day on the 8th and most of the precipitation associated with Lee was done.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flash flooding of smaller streams in lower Northampton County mainly in Williams and Lower Saucon Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 3 inches in this area and event precipitation totals through the morning of the 6th included 2.87 inches in Glendon and 2.60 inches in Martins Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee moved northward from the southern Appalachians on the 6th to the middle Atlantic states on the 7th before stalling on the 8th. The moisture from Lee interacted with a frontal system to the west across the eastern Ohio Valley and eastern Great Lakes. In addition, moisture was drawn into New York and Pennsylvania from Hurricane Katia which was moving northward off the east coast in tandem with the remnants of Lee. This complicated scenario led to an extreme amount of rain for central New York and northeast Pennsylvania, most of which fell over a 48 hour period from the 6th to the 8th. Rainfall of 6 to 12 inches occurred over most of the upper Susquehanna river basin in New York and northeast Pennsylvania. The heavy rain caused massive, record breaking flooding on small streams, creeks and the Susquehanna River and its larger tributaries. ||The main branch of the Susquehanna River in New York from Binghamton to Vestal, Owego and Waverly crested from 1 to 4 feet higher than the previous record crests set in June 2006.  In Pennsylvania, record crests occurred along the Susquehanna River at Meshoppen and Wilkes Barre which exceeded the long-standing record crests by around 1 foot associated with Hurricane Agnes in 1972. ||Damages in the upper Susquehanna River Basin in New York and Pennsylvania are close to 1 billion dollars. Unfortunately, the flooding claimed 1 life and injured 1 person in central New York and northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 6 was closed between Wysox and Wyalusing due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system brought unsettled weather to the region. |An extensive plume of Atlantic moisture into the system brought periods of heavy rain.  Several areas that had been very wet from previous rains earlier in the month received additional minor flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Nescopeck Creek, flooding homes and roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, which occurred from the morning of the 18th into the overnight of the 18th caused flash flooding in parts of southeastern Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along sections of the Brandywine Creek along the Birmingham and Pocopson Township line and along the source of the Chester Creek in Westtown Township. Roads were closed near the Brandywine Creek in Birmingham and roadway flooding as well as underpass flooding was reported in Westtown. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches. Event totals included 2.02 inches in Unionville (East Marlborough Township).

This also helped initiate and exacerbate the flooding in the Brandywine Creek Basin as well as along the Schuylkill River.

Several towns were not accessible from the flash flooding. Students were unable to leave Northeast Bradford High School and evacuations took place in several communities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed in the afternoon as a cold front began to sag across the region on the 3rd. The weak front then stalled along the Mason-Dixon line. As an upper level short wave progressed across the front on July 4th, additional thunderstorms developed. Wind damage and flooding occurred in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reports that flooding has closed the intersection of Beechwood Blvd and Forward Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small cluster of regenerating/training thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding in the vicinity of the Harrisburg Metro area east-southeast along and north of Interstate 76 toward Mt. Gretna in southern Lebanon County. Highly anomalous deep-layer moisture with precipitable water values over 200% above the climatological normal values contributed to excessive rainfall rates between 1-2 inches per hour, which resulted in local rainfall totals of 3-7 inches in only a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rainfall from clusters of slow-moving and regenerating thunderstorms produced flash flooding in western Lebanon County, mainly between Interstates 76 and 81 west of Lebanon city. Excessive rainfall rates between 1-2 inches per hour were observed and resulted in localized rainfall amounts of 3-7 inches in a very short period. The flash flooding closed numerous roads and caused extensive basement flooding. First responders performing water rescues in Quentin experienced water up to 3 feet (knee-high) in some areas. A church and restaurant had over 5 feet of water in the basements. Water levels reached 3-4 feet in downtown Quentin. A mudslide occurred later that morning along Spangler Road in West Cornwall Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave traveling north over a broad ridge in the central U.S dragged a weak cold front over the Ohio Valley. This coldfront set off thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening hours on the 18th. There were several reports of wind damage in eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania with more than 11,000 people without power in western PA alone. In addition urban flooding and flash flooding occurred in various parts of Allegheny and Beaver counties. Cars were stranded in high water right around rush-hour on Washington Blvd in downtown Pittsburgh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Washington Blvd/Route 8 at the Negley Run intersection was closed due to rapidly rising water. Numerous cars were stranded or stalled with two people needing to be rescued from their vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across lower Ontario pulled a warm front across northeast Pennsylvania and central New York. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the unstable airmass as a cold front approached in the afternoon.  A few of the storms became severe and produced damaging winds. Heavy rain from the storms also caused some flooded roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in town were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across lower Ontario pulled a warm front across northeast Pennsylvania and central New York. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the unstable airmass as a cold front approached in the afternoon.  A few of the storms became severe and produced damaging winds. Heavy rain from the storms also caused some flooded roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads were flooded due to flash flooding in the Edwardsville and Larksville areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains from slow-moving thunderstorms occurred at multiple times during the day, with events early in the morning, during the mid afternoon and early evening hours in Plymouth Borough.  The rains fell over the Coal Creek basin, causing the creek to rapidly exceed its banks and flood portions of the borough. Storm total radar estimates indicated 5 to 6 inches for the combined events. A bucket survey, solicited by the NWS via local broadcast meteorologists, was able to obtain several measured and estimated rainfall totals from the evening event.  These amounts ranged from 4.5 to 5.0 inches, and eyewitnesses reported that these amounts occurred within 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well over 200 homes and businesses were affected by flooding from heavy rains over the Coal Creek basin.  Video captured by local residents showed significant damage occurring to infrastructure and homes, with torrents of water flushing down area roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front and a moist unstable airmass combined to produce scattered severe thunderstorms and flash flooding across eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania. Flash flooding was deadly in Pittsburgh when approximately 2.5 inches of rain fell in a very urbanized area just east of downtown Pittsburgh on Washington Blvd in just under an hour. This resulted in four fatalities and up to 15 water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS storm survey found that 2.5 inches of rain fell in one hour in a very urbanized 4.8 sq mi watershed just east of downtown Pittsburgh. Severe flash flooding developed on Washington Blvd resulting in four fatalities and up to 15 water rescues.  A mother and two daughters were drowned inside a van when it became submerged in approximately 9 ��� 10 feet of water.  An elderly lady who abandoned her car was apparently swept or fell into an open manhole or catch basin and drowned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain fell in the western Catskills with portions of Wyoming and northern Susquehanna Counties in northeast Pennsylvania and southern Broome County in  New York receiving 6 to 8 inches of rain. The heavy rains caused catastrophic flash flooding in Forkston and Noxen of Wyoming County where nearly one hundred homes were flooded. At least 25 roads were closed due to flooding in this area. Many people were cut off and had to be rescued by helicopter. Damages are estimated to be in the tens of millions. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was threatening a trailer park in the Great Bend. Twenty homes were affected. There were also numerous road closures due to flooding. Two bridges were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain fell in the western Catskills with portions of Wyoming and northern Susquehanna Counties in northeast Pennsylvania and southern Broome County in  New York receiving 6 to 8 inches of rain. The heavy rains caused catastrophic flash flooding in Forkston and Noxen of Wyoming County where nearly one hundred homes were flooded. At least 25 roads were closed due to flooding in this area. Many people were cut off and had to be rescued by helicopter. Damages are estimated to be in the tens of millions. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten trailer homes were flooded in the New Milford area. There were also numerous roads flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee produced widespread flooding, flash flooding and river flooding mainly near and to the east of the Susquehanna Valley from September 4-10. Several locations in the Susquehanna Basin came close to records set by Hurricane Agnes (June 1972) and a few points (Bloomsburg, Hershey and Loyalsockville) set new floods of record. Flooding along Swatara Creek resulted in property damage and several deaths. Severe flooding occurred along Loyalsock Creek and many points along the main-stem of the Susquehanna River. The interaction of a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid-Atlantic region, a strong northern stream short-wave (with a persistent jet entrance region) and deep tropical moisture associated the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee resulted in multi-day, significant heavy rainfall event over Pennsylvania. ||Tropical storm Lee was the twelfth named storm of the 2011 season forming over the Gulf of Mexico on September 1. A strong northern stream short-wave interacted with Lee causing the storm to re-curve to the north-northeast. By 1200 UTC September 6, having undergone extra-tropical transition, post-tropical Lee was located over northern Georgia. The surface low weakened as it moved up the Appalachian Mountain chain. However, the strong low-level flow and the above normal precipitable water produced an extensive, north-to-south oriented band of heavy rainfall.||The rainfall associated with the remnants of Lee produced the 4th largest flood of record in the Mid-Atlantic Region. The five-day storm rainfall totals for September 5 to 9 were generally in the 5-8 inch range over the mid-section of central Pennsylvania and in the 8-12 inch range in the Susquehanna Valley region. There were local amounts reported in excess of 15 inches east of the Susquehanna River. The local climate sites in Harrisburg (KMDT) and Williamsport (KIPT) reported 13.44 and 9.03 inches respectively. On September 7, 2011 both KMDT and KIPT set their all-time daily (24-hour) rainfall for the month of September at 7.71 and 6.76 inches respectively. These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Life-threatening flash flooding closed Route 230 between Highspire and Middletown.

Several locations in the Susquehanna Basin came close to records set by Hurricane Agnes (June 1972) and a few points (Bloomsburg, Hershey and Loyalsockville) set new floods of record. Flooding along Swatara Creek resulted in property damage and several deaths. Severe flooding occurred along Loyalsock Creek and many points along the main-stem of the Susquehanna River. The interaction of a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid-Atlantic region, a strong northern stream short-wave (with a persistent jet entrance region) and deep tropical moisture associated the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee resulted in multi-day, significant heavy rainfall event over Pennsylvania. ||Tropical storm Lee was the twelfth named storm of the 2011 season forming over the Gulf of Mexico on September 1. A strong northern stream short-wave interacted with Lee causing the storm to re-curve to the north-northeast. By 1200 UTC September 6, having undergone extra-tropical transition, post-tropical Lee was located over northern Georgia. The surface low weakened as it moved up the Appalachian Mountain chain. However, the strong low-level flow and the above normal precipitable water produced an extensive, north-to-south oriented band of heavy rainfall.||The rainfall associated with the remnants of Lee produced the 4th largest flood of record in the Mid-Atlantic Region. The five-day storm rainfall totals for September 5 to 9 were generally in the 5-8 inch range over the mid-section of central Pennsylvania and in the 8-12 inch range in the Susquehanna Valley region. There were local amounts reported in excess of 15 inches east of the Susquehanna River. The local climate sites in Harrisburg (KMDT) and Williamsport (KIPT) reported 13.44 and 9.03 inches respectively. On September 7, 2011 both KMDT and KIPT set their all-time daily (24-hour) rainfall for the month of September at 7.71 and 6.76 inches respectively. These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Life-threatening flash flooding resulted in numerous water rescues across York County. Additionally, home evacuations were reported in Dover and Felton, and Route 74 was closed near Weigelstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to six inches of rain across sections of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia and its nearby suburbs. This caused flash flooding and flooding of streams and creeks that started in Berks County and the Lehigh valley during the evening of the 13th and spread to the local Philadelphia area during the morning of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along the Monocacy Creek caused the evacuation of vendors at the Musikfest in the historical district in Bethlehem. Both the Handwerkplatz and Volksplatz were evacuated and canceled for the 14th. Some vendors lost jewelry, tubs and tablecloths. Vehicles were flooded as was some electrical equipment and tents. Several booths and propane tanks were swept away. No injuries were reported. The Monocacy Creek at Bethlehem was above its 4.5 foot flood stage from 1140 p.m. EDT on the 13th through 335 a.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 5.18 feet at 1 a.m. EDT on the 14th. Precipitation event totals included 5.20 inches in Bethlehem, 5.18 inches in Nazareth and 4.53 inches in Glendon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported in homes and covering parts of main street in Coledale.||A preliminary total of 20 structures reported minor damage with a total of 42 structures impacted.  Damage was estimated at $197,460 for public facilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene moved north-northeast along the Mid-Atlantic Coast from North Carolina to Long Island New York. The tropical system produced extensive flooding and strong damaging winds over from the Endless Mountain region of Sullivan County southward to the lower Susquehanna Valley, with heavy rainfall amounts generally between 2 to 4 inches and several reports of non-thunderstorm wind damage. Localized 5 to 6 inch rainfall totals were also observed. Despite the widespread heavy rainfall, the most significant flooding was primarily confined to faster-responding, smaller waterways such as the Conestoga River and Loyalsock Creek as well as low-lying and poor drainage areas. Flood waters closed numerous secondary roads and washed out several small bridges. The strong winds with peak gusts over tropical storm-force downed trees and utility wires, leaving thousands of residents without power. One tree fell on a 59-year old man and 56-year old woman who were camping in East Hanover Township, Dauphin County. The man was killed but the woman survived and sustained a serious head injury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy tropical rainfall from Hurricane Irene produced catastrophic flash flooding, with portions of the county receiving up to 6 inches of rain. Flood waters closed all major roads and caused evacuations of homes and businesses in Lopez (Colley Township), Mildred (Cherry Township), Dushore Borough, Laporte Borough, Forks Township, Forksville Borough and Hillsgrove Township. Unprecedented flooding in Lopez caused the the bridge that carries PA 487 over Loyalsock Creek to collapse. This greatly impacted water rescue efforts, increasing response time to 40 minutes despite the local fire and EMS department being only 3 miles from the town of Lopez. A multi-family along PA 487 was totally surrounded by water. The building, which experienced significant flooding back in April, was condemned leaving 10 homeless. Another single-family home lost its foundation due to fast-moving flood waters. Several cabins were were damaged/destroyed by high water along Rock Run Road in Forks Township. Several other homes sustained major damage in Cherry and Colley Townships. Major flooding impacted downtown Dushore for a second time, following the April 26 flash flood event which caused over 2 million in damages. A presidential disaster declaration was issued for the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding over Northumberland County, resulting in many closed roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in urban areas, including Cameron Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding county-wide, with many roads closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused urban and small stream flash flooding countywide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding, resulting in numerous road wash-outs across Columbia County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused roadway flooding and flash flooding of smaller streams across the central third of Lehigh County from Allentown, Bethlehem and Hanover westnorthwest through all of the Whitehall Townships as well as Lowhill and Weisenberg Townships. In Allentown, the heavy rain caused a roof collapse and the evacuation of thirteen people. Event precipitation totals included 4.24 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport, 3.90 inches in Allentown and 3.73 inches in Schnecksville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in the closing of roads in the vicinity of the Horseshoe Curve.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms that formed near a stationary front produced heavy downpours and flash flooding in western Berks County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours on already saturated grounds because of the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee produced small stream and poor drainage flooding in western Berks County mainly in Penn, Bern, North and Lower Heidelberg Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought thunderstorms with locally heavy rain to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening of September 23rd, 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flooding over portions of Adams County. Significant stream flash flooding, resulting in over 40 road closures, was noted in the vicinity of US 15, US 30 and Route 94. The flash flooding transitioned into an areal flood event, which extended into the evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding and closed a number of roads across central Adams County. These included: Chambersburg Street, Buford, Water and North Stratton in Gettysburg Borough; Home Pike, Baltimore Pike and Speelman Klinger Road in Mount Joy Township; Dutch Road, Two Taverns Road, Willow Road, Route 116, Bon-Ox Road and Centennial Road in Mount Pleasant Township; and Granite Station Road and Shrivers Corner in Straban Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to six inches of rain across sections of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia and its nearby suburbs. This caused flash flooding and flooding of streams and creeks that started in Berks County and the Lehigh valley during the evening of the 13th and spread to the local Philadelphia area during the morning of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flash flooding along the Pennypack and in particular Frankford Creek in Philadelphia. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 705 a.m. EDT through 737 a.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 8.08 feet at 715 a.m. EDT. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 651 a.m. EDT through 821 p.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 7.64 feet at 415 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 5.80 inches in Rockledge and at the Philadelphia International Airport and 4.18 inches in Wyndmoor.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several water rescues were reported in Port Royal and along Route 75 outside of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with heavy rain from the middle of the afternoon through the middle of the evening on the 21st caused poor drainage and stream flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. Event precipitation totals averaged two to three inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain across the northern half of Philadelphia caused poor drainage flooding and stream flash flooding along the Wissahickon, Frankford and Pennypack Creeks.  Event precipitation totals averaged 2 to 3.5 inches. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue had major flooding and was above its 7 foot flood stage from 316 p.m. EDT through 612 p.m. EDT on the 21st. It crested at 10.04 feet at 345 p.m. EDT.  The Wissahickon Creek at its mouth was above its 5 foot flood stage from 344 p.m. EDT through 1149 p.m. EDT on the 21st. It crested at 5.40 feet at 1000 p.m. EDT.  The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 351 p.m. EDT through 404 p.m. EDT on the 21st. It crested at 7.12 feet at 400 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 3.33 inches in Wyndmoor, 2.78 inches in Rockledge and 2.73 inches in Northeast Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain fell in the western Catskills with portions of Wyoming and northern Susquehanna Counties in northeast Pennsylvania and southern Broome County in  New York receiving 6 to 8 inches of rain. The heavy rains caused catastrophic flash flooding in Forkston and Noxen of Wyoming County where nearly one hundred homes were flooded. At least 25 roads were closed due to flooding in this area. Many people were cut off and had to be rescued by helicopter. Damages are estimated to be in the tens of millions. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Huntington creek flooded Route 239.
