These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding was reported in several townships, including Sonestown, Dushore and Hillsgrove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee produced widespread flooding, flash flooding and river flooding mainly near and to the east of the Susquehanna Valley from September 4-10. Several locations in the Susquehanna Basin came close to records set by Hurricane Agnes (June 1972) and a few points (Bloomsburg, Hershey and Loyalsockville) set new floods of record. Flooding along Swatara Creek resulted in property damage and several deaths. Severe flooding occurred along Loyalsock Creek and many points along the main-stem of the Susquehanna River. The interaction of a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid-Atlantic region, a strong northern stream short-wave (with a persistent jet entrance region) and deep tropical moisture associated the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee resulted in multi-day, significant heavy rainfall event over Pennsylvania. ||Tropical storm Lee was the twelfth named storm of the 2011 season forming over the Gulf of Mexico on September 1. A strong northern stream short-wave interacted with Lee causing the storm to re-curve to the north-northeast. By 1200 UTC September 6, having undergone extra-tropical transition, post-tropical Lee was located over northern Georgia. The surface low weakened as it moved up the Appalachian Mountain chain. However, the strong low-level flow and the above normal precipitable water produced an extensive, north-to-south oriented band of heavy rainfall.||The rainfall associated with the remnants of Lee produced the 4th largest flood of record in the Mid-Atlantic Region. The five-day storm rainfall totals for September 5 to 9 were generally in the 5-8 inch range over the mid-section of central Pennsylvania and in the 8-12 inch range in the Susquehanna Valley region. There were local amounts reported in excess of 15 inches east of the Susquehanna River. The local climate sites in Harrisburg (KMDT) and Williamsport (KIPT) reported 13.44 and 9.03 inches respectively. On September 7, 2011 both KMDT and KIPT set their all-time daily (24-hour) rainfall for the month of September at 7.71 and 6.76 inches respectively. These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in the Pine Grove area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in portions of Blair County, including Newry and Logan Townships. A flooded mobile home park in Allegheny Township was also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flood waters stranded a vehicle in high water in Paradise Township near East Berlin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought thunderstorms with locally heavy rain to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening of September 23rd, 2011.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding along Route 74 form Route 15 to Williams Grove Road. Several other roads around Dillsburg were also closed by flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with heavy rain from the middle of the afternoon through the middle of the evening on the 21st caused poor drainage and stream flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. Event precipitation totals averaged two to three inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain across the extreme lower part of Bucks County  caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding. Event precipitation totals averaged 2 to 3 inches. Flooding was reported in Bensalem and Bristol.  In Bristol, the Mill Street parking lot as well as Farragut Avenue flooded. Several underpasses were also closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.51 inches in Bensalem and 2.46 inches in Penndel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain fell in the western Catskills with portions of Wyoming and northern Susquehanna Counties in northeast Pennsylvania and southern Broome County in  New York receiving 6 to 8 inches of rain. The heavy rains caused catastrophic flash flooding in Forkston and Noxen of Wyoming County where nearly one hundred homes were flooded. At least 25 roads were closed due to flooding in this area. Many people were cut off and had to be rescued by helicopter. Damages are estimated to be in the tens of millions. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wapwallopen creek flooded numerous roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain fell in the western Catskills with portions of Wyoming and northern Susquehanna Counties in northeast Pennsylvania and southern Broome County in  New York receiving 6 to 8 inches of rain. Many people were cut off and had to be rescued by helicopter. Damages are estimated to be in the tens of millions. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding reported. Almost 100 homes either flooded or surrounded by water. Hundreds of people evacuated with two people rescued from the high waters. Dozens of roads were washed out, damaged and/or closed during the height of the flash flood.

Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dunlap grove bridge was damaged by floodwaters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in Northumberland County. Several water rescues were reported, along with reports of several roads being washed out and water over bridges.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving heavy rain showers and thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding across central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding, resulting in two structure collapses and many roads being flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene brought heavy rains and high winds from northeast Pennsylvania to the Catskill Mountains of New York from Saturday evening the 27th to Sunday afternoon the 28th. Rainfall totaled from 2 to 5 inches over most of northeast Pennsylvania and in the Susquehanna Region of central New York. Susquehanna County also was hard hit by flash flooding, especially in the northern part of the county. ||In addition, to the heavy rains, high winds from Irene knocked down numerous trees and power-lines across much of northeast Pennsylvania, especially in the higher terrain areas and the Poconos. Almost 50,000 residences were without power, some not seeing power restored for up to one week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kitchen Creek flooded one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours during the early morning of the 7th caused flash flooding in Carbon County. Event precipitation totals reached around four inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Lizard Creek in East Penn Township. Pennsylvania State Route 895 was flooded by the creek and closed. Event precipitation totals included 4.45 inches in Lower Towamensing Township, 3.98 inches in Bowmanstown and 3.92 inches in Palmerton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather and flash flood outbreak developed across northeast Pennsylvania as a storm system moved east from the Great Lakes.  Thunderstorms with damaging winds and very heavy rain developed and moved across the area during the overnight hours on the 28th. One supercell thunderstorm produced a tornado in Susquehanna county. Significant flash flooding also occurred across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flash flooding developed, especially in the borough of Burlington.  Eight to ten inches of water was flowing through the borough, with mudslides and numerous roads closed. Route 14 in Canton was closed due to flooding. Many roads were also flooded and closed in Troy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along Route 6 in West Burlington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: City fire crews and First Aid/Safety Patrol were dispatched to a flooded basement with people entrapped at 320 E. Weidman St. Several other homes in the 300 block of East Weidman Street had flooded basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A residential water rescue was performed at 1401 E. Cumberland St in North Lebanon Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding stranded vehicles with people trapped inside at East Weidman Street and North Sixth Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Glenville Road was flooded by heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A residential water rescue was performed along PA 72 and Jonestown Road in Union Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rainfall produced flash flooding in Carlisle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rainfall produced localized flash flooding in Carlisle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather and flash flood outbreak developed across northeast Pennsylvania as a storm system moved east from the Great Lakes.  Thunderstorms with damaging winds and very heavy rain developed and moved across the area during the overnight hours on the 28th. One supercell thunderstorm produced a tornado in Susquehanna county. Significant flash flooding also occurred across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding and damage, especially in the Wilkes-Barre area.  Sinkhole repairs for South Wilkes-Barre came to about $50,000.  The walls along Laurel Run Creek were damaged, with approximately 250 feet of wall collapsed.  Hollenback Golf Course suffered damage to its clubhouse roof and interior.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from Illinois to the Great Lakes region during the day. With high pressure to the east over New England, a tightening pressure gradient brought an increase in winds as the low approached. Localized wind gusts greater than 50 knots caused some minor damage in a few locations in northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of roadways in the area. Flooding occurred on Route 6 near West Burlington, where water was up to the windows on one car. The road was down to one lane, with water over the road from Sugar Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small cluster of regenerating/training thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding in the vicinity of the Harrisburg Metro area east-southeast along and north of Interstate 76 toward Mt. Gretna in southern Lebanon County. Highly anomalous deep-layer moisture with precipitable water values over 200% above the climatological normal values contributed to excessive rainfall rates between 1-2 inches per hour, which resulted in local rainfall totals of 3-7 inches in only a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rainfall from clusters of slow-moving and regenerating thunderstorms produced flash flooding in south-central Dauphin County, mainly between Interstates 76 and 81. Excessive rainfall rates between 1-2 inches per hour were observed and resulted in localized rainfall amounts of 3-7 inches in a very short period. The flash flooding closed numerous roads and caused extensive basement flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road flooded at Indian Rock Dam Road and Crull School Road in Spring Garden Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding on North George Street (Interstate 83) and Arch Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding caused a sink hole on Water Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lebabnon County 911 call center reported a flooded house in Jonestown Borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported flooding on Royal Road between Oak Street and Colebrook Road near the Lebanon Country Club.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of the Lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon and evening. Soils were already saturated from heavy rainfall the night before which contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quittapahilla Creek came out of its banks and over Dairy Road.  Numerous secondary roads were flooded in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding along US 15 at the junction of PA 49.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather outbreak occurred across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening hours on 26 May 2011. A total of 6 tornadoes were confirmed ranging from EF0-EF2 in magnitude with multiple reports of large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds.  Flash flooding was also reported with Franklin County with these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense rainfall brought flash flooding to the Chambersburg area.  Several roads were closed and one water rescue was performed in which two people were trapped in flash flood waters in Chambersburg.  The pair attempted to drive through a flooded area of Commerce Drive in Hamilton Township when they became stuck in water that covered the hood.  They were rescued without injury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Lee that interacted with a stalled frontal boundary produced several days with periods of heavy rain across Eastern Pennsylvania from the 5th into the 8th. Event precipitation totals averaged 4 to 9 inches, except in Berks County where 6 to 12 inches fell.  One drowning occurred in Philadelphia. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as moderate flooding along the Delaware and Schuylkill Basins and minor to moderate flooding along the Lehigh River Basin. Crests in the upper Schuylkill, Lehigh and Delaware River Basins were higher than what occurred with Irene the previous month and the highest crests since late June of 2006 in most instances. The crests along the Delaware River were 2 to 4 feet higher than what occurred during Irene. Some of the smaller streams in southeastern Pennsylvania reached major flooding levels, but most of those crests were lower than what occurred with Irene. In addition to the freshwater flooding, moderate tidal flooding occurred along the lower Delaware River and its tributaries. ||In the most recent available flooding assessment for Eastern Pennsylvania, there were 22 homes and businesses that were destroyed, 201 that suffered major damage, 672 that had minor damage and 1217 others that were affected. The preliminary damage estimate for the state of Pennsylvania was five hundred million dollars.  Please look for possible updates in future monthly issues of stormdata.| |The combination of fresh water runoff and a weak southerly flow produced moderate tidal flooding during the evening high tide cycles from the 7th through the 9th and minor tidal flooding with all of the other high tide cycles from the evening of the 6th through overnight on the 11th. The highest tides occurred during the evening high tide cycle on the 8th in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and the evening high tide cycle on the 9th in Bucks County.  The evening high tide on the 8th in Philadelphia reached 9.41 feet above mean lower low water. Moderate tidal flooding starts at 9.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Newbold Island (Bucks County) reached 12.11 feet above mean lower low water. There is no current categorical tide gage information for this site.  ||Tropical Storm Lee made landfall in Louisiana during the morning of the 4th and moved slowly northeast. An approaching cold front from the Mississippi Valley reached Lee by the morning of the 5th and transformed it to an extratropical system on the 5th in Mississippi. The same cold front acted as a conduit for Lee's moisture farther to the northeast. Showers and thunderstorms from that approaching cold front arrived during the evening and overnight on the 5th  and set off the first round of flash flooding rains in Northeast Pennsylvania. The front then stalled just south of Delmarva on the 6th. A relative lull in the rain then occurred during the morning of the 6th. As the front started to back north as a warm front later in the day on the 6th, more bands of heavier rain returned that afternoon and particularly that evening. A blocking weather pattern then moved the frontal boundary little from the morning of the 7th into the morning of the 8th across southeast Pennsylvania. A couple of bands of flash flood producing rains started to form and move east into Eastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th and continued through the night.  The frontal boundary started to drift offshore later in the day on the 8th and most of the precipitation associated with Lee was done.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flash flooding of smaller streams in extreme northern Montgomery County in Upper Hanover Township. The Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville was above its 4 foot flood stage from 916 p.m. EDT on the 5th through 344 a.m. EDT on the 6th. It crested at 5.57 feet at 1 a.m. EDT on the 6th. Event precipitation totals through the morning of the 6th included 3.00 inches in Palm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in Philadelphia. It also caused the drowning death of a 27-year-old woman who was caught in flood waters in the East Germantown section of the city.  She was discovered in the rear of her Sports Utility Vehicle at the intersection of Musgrave and Haines Streets on the morning of the 8th.  The Wingohocking Creek, which is a creek that was buried underground during the 19th century had its waters back out of sewer grates and manhole covers in that section of the city.  Godfrey Avenue and Wister Street also flooded in East Germantown. The wall of a church also collapsed. Most gaged creeks within Philadelphia flooded as well as the Schuylkill River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front pushed northward across northeast Pennsylvania late in the afternoon on April 25th. A warm and relatively moist air mass covered the region, with showers and storms developing, especially in the unstable air south of the frontal boundary, where breaks in the cloud cover allowed temperatures to rise to near 70 degrees. Severe weather developed, and in addition to reports of severe wind damage and hail, areas of heavy rain caused significant flash flooding in several locations of northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along several roads in Troy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger numerous  thunderstorms during the second half of the afternoon in southeastern Pennsylvania. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches within Philadelphia and led to poor drainage and stream flash flooding. Because this coincided with a Friday afternoon, it caused many traffic tie-ups across the local Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused brief flash flooding along the Franklin Creek. The Franklin Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 413 p.m. through 425 p.m. EDT on the 8th. It crested at 7.05 feet at 415 p.m. EDT. The heavy rain also caused flooding along Interstate 95 in the Bridesburg section of the city. Event precipitation totals included 1.85 inches in Center City and 1.48 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport. Doppler Radar storm total estimates of 2 to 3 inches occurred near the Franklin Creek basin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee produced widespread flooding, flash flooding and river flooding mainly near and to the east of the Susquehanna Valley from September 4-10. Several locations in the Susquehanna Basin came close to records set by Hurricane Agnes (June 1972) and a few points (Bloomsburg, Hershey and Loyalsockville) set new floods of record. Flooding along Swatara Creek resulted in property damage and several deaths. Severe flooding occurred along Loyalsock Creek and many points along the main-stem of the Susquehanna River. The interaction of a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid-Atlantic region, a strong northern stream short-wave (with a persistent jet entrance region) and deep tropical moisture associated the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee resulted in multi-day, significant heavy rainfall event over Pennsylvania. ||Tropical storm Lee was the twelfth named storm of the 2011 season forming over the Gulf of Mexico on September 1. A strong northern stream short-wave interacted with Lee causing the storm to re-curve to the north-northeast. By 1200 UTC September 6, having undergone extra-tropical transition, post-tropical Lee was located over northern Georgia. The surface low weakened as it moved up the Appalachian Mountain chain. However, the strong low-level flow and the above normal precipitable water produced an extensive, north-to-south oriented band of heavy rainfall.||The rainfall associated with the remnants of Lee produced the 4th largest flood of record in the Mid-Atlantic Region. The five-day storm rainfall totals for September 5 to 9 were generally in the 5-8 inch range over the mid-section of central Pennsylvania and in the 8-12 inch range in the Susquehanna Valley region. There were local amounts reported in excess of 15 inches east of the Susquehanna River. The local climate sites in Harrisburg (KMDT) and Williamsport (KIPT) reported 13.44 and 9.03 inches respectively. On September 7, 2011 both KMDT and KIPT set their all-time daily (24-hour) rainfall for the month of September at 7.71 and 6.76 inches respectively. These sites later went on to break the all-time monthly (September) and annual precipitation records, making 2011 the wettest year on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 55-year old man was swept away in floodwaters from Route 72 just north of Frog Hollow Drive in Swatara Township.  He was trapped in rising waters on Swatara Creek.|The Lebanon County Emergency Management Agency fielded 4,500 calls, normal calls number 200. Another man attempted to warn motorists of the high water potential when he was struck and killed by a vehicle on West Cumberland Street in North Lebanon Township.||The Quittapahilla Creek was out of its banks and flooding roadways around Annville.  Cleona Borough reported significant flooding from this creek.  Dozens of homes experienced several feet of water in basements.  All bridges over this creek were under water.||Major flooding occurred in the Palmyra area with numerous dispatches for help.|Lebanon City and Myerstown had many flooded roads with stranded cars.||All major routes in and out of Jonestown were closed. Interstate 81 was closed near Swatara Creek. A preliminary total of 148 structures were destroyed, 1601 suffered major damage, and 701 minor damage with a total of 3398 structures impacted.  Damage was estimated at $2,030,985 for public facilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a warm front moving slowly across western Pennsylvania during the late afternoon of the 7th into the early morning of the 8th. Isolated severe thunderstorms and flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with several roads closed from Sharon to Hermitage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding across portions of Westmoreland county. Up to 3 inches of rain were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported heavy rains producing flash flooding across numerous roads and on private properties across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding across portions of Westmoreland county. Up to 3 inches of rain were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flooding of church basement in Greensburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding across portions of Westmoreland county. Up to 3 inches of rain were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a stream flooding homes on 14th Street in Jeannette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding across portions of Westmoreland county. Up to 3 inches of rain were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flooding of a personal care home west of the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding across portions of Westmoreland county. Up to 3 inches of rain were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported numerous roads flooded in Hempfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm in McKean County produced localized heavy rain and flash flooding during the late evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding in the small town of Rew. Flood waters covered the Main Street intersection (SR 46 and 646) which runs through the center of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, preceding a slowing cold front, during the afternoon of the 26th moved across the Poconos. They not only produced severe weather, but also flash flooding in several municipalities across western Carbon and southeast Monroe County.  Many roadways and basements were flooded and this included at least one road washout.  Heavier rainfall amounts were two to three inches per hour and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches in Hamilton Township (Monroe County).  The highest reported storm total was 7.40 inches in Lansdale in Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as  poor drainage flooding in Nesquehoning Borough. The Wash Shanty Hill portion of U.S. Route 209 was closed because of significant water and debris runoff. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered strong to locally severe thunderstorms during the early afternoon over portions of the Mid-Susquehanna Valley. Later in the evening, a slow-moving isolated thunderstorm produced locally heavy rainfall and flash flooding in extreme southern Dauphin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding in the Middletown area. A police vehicle was trapped in flooded waters below an underpass. Minor flooding persisted into the late evening across southeastern Dauphin County near the Lancaster County line, where radar estimated rainfall was between 3-4 inches in four hours between 7 and 11 pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread thunderstorms developed across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon.  Several of these storms became severe producing damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding over the northeastern-third of the county or along and east of Routes 209/309. The McAdoo area experienced some of the worst flooding with 31 homes affected. A railroad crossing was also washed out. Widespread flooding was reported in Schuylkill Township in and around the Tuscarora area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, preceding a slowing cold front, during the afternoon of the 26th moved across the Poconos. They not only produced severe weather, but also flash flooding in several municipalities across western Carbon and southeast Monroe County.  Many roadways and basements were flooded and this included at least one road washout.  Heavier rainfall amounts were two to three inches per hour and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches in Hamilton Township (Monroe County).  The highest reported storm total was 7.40 inches in Lansdale in Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams in Pocono Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches within 45 minutes within the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pre-frontal convection developed early in the day across western Pennsylvania and produced isolated wind damage and marginally severe hail. Additional strong to severe thunderstorms formed later in the afternoon and evening across portions of central and eastern Pennsylvania. This activity became more widespread and produced multiple reports of large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of intense heavy thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding across much of the county. Carlisle reported 2.3 inches of rainfall in a short period of time. Flooded roads were reported in Camp Hill, Carlisle, Shippensburg and Southampton Townships.  A water rescue was reported on Hummel Avenue in Camp Hill.  Two cars were rescued from flood waters in Carlisle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, preceding a slowing cold front, during the afternoon of the 26th moved across the Poconos. They not only produced severe weather, but also flash flooding in several municipalities across western Carbon and southeast Monroe County.  Many roadways and basements were flooded and this included at least one road washout.  Heavier rainfall amounts were two to three inches per hour and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches in Hamilton Township (Monroe County).  The highest reported storm total was 7.40 inches in Lansdale in Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage as well as small creek flash flooding in and around East Stroudsburg. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 4.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper-air disturbance moving southeast from the Great Lakes triggered numerous thunderstorms over northwest Pennsylvania between 3 and 4 pm local time. These storms become severe and eventually organized into large squall line that surged southeast across central and southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening hours. The well-defined, bowing line producing widespread wind damage and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks in Catawissa and Franklin Townships, taking large objects including cars downstream in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper-air disturbance moving southeast from the Great Lakes triggered numerous thunderstorms over northwest Pennsylvania between 3 and 4 pm local time. These storms become severe and eventually organized into large squall line that surged southeast across central and southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening hours. The well-defined, bowing line producing widespread wind damage and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense heavy rainfall resulted in stream flooding along at least eight roadways in the Johnstown area. Two roads were closed and 19 basements were flooded.  One bridge was reported to be sagging after the flooding and was closed for repairs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms also dropped heavy rain. The recent wet antecedent conditions led to flash flooding in southern Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage as well as creek flash flooding along the southern tier of Carbon County from Palmerton Borough through Lower Towamensing Township. The heavy rain caused a rock slide onto Maunch Chunk Road in Palmerton.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached nearly three and one-quarter inches in southern Carbon County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Series of thunderstorms with heavy rain that developed south of a nearly stationary front produced poor drainage and creek flash flooding during the early morning of the 27th in Upper Montgomery County in the northern parts of the Perkiomen drainage basin. Residual flooding occurred later that day in Montgomery and Bucks Counties along parts of the Perkiomen Creek as runoff went farther downstream.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around two inches in the upper part of the basin. Heavy rain fell in upper Montgomery County between 3 a.m. EDT and 5 a.m. EDT and in the northern half of  Bucks County between 830 a..m. and 11 a.m. EDT on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flash flooding along part of the Perkiomen Creek as well as poor drainage flooding. The heaviest rain fell in Upper Hanover Township and also in East Greensville, Pennsburg and Red Hill Boroughs.  The main stem of the Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville was above its 4 foot flood stage from 533 a.m. EDT through 725 a.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 4.17 feet at 6 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dissipating cold front had enough remaining forcing to trigger thunderstorms with heavy rain in Lehigh County. The heavy rain caused creek and poor drainage flooding in the southeast part of the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in southeastern Lehigh County. In Upper Saucon Township. Pennsylvania State Route 309 was covered by three feet of water which closed the roadway during rush hour. West Union Street in Allentown was closed. Late that evening, a 25-year-old man was injured while bicycling when he rode it into a barricade on that street. In Whitehall Township, Mauch Chunk Road was closed near the Jordan Creek. Doppler Radar storm estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches within Allentown and in Upper Saucon Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain during the evening of the 15th into the early morning of the 16th. Event precipitation totals during  multiple thunderstorms reached between 2.0 and 3.5 inches and caused flash flooding and flooding of smaller streams and creeks in southeastern Pennsylvania.  Hardest hit was the tri-county area of Delaware, Montgomery and Chester Counties where Doppler Radar storm total estimates and surface reports reached around 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in extreme southeast Chester County overnight on the 15th with Tredyffrin and Easttown Townships hit the hardest. There were eight water rescues as flash flooding occurred along the headwaters of the Valley and Darby Creeks.  The Valley Creek at Valley Forge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1252 a.m. EDT through 207 a.m. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 7.91 feet at 130 a.m. EDT.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3.5 inches in those townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain during the evening of the 15th into the early morning of the 16th. Event precipitation totals during  multiple thunderstorms reached between 2.0 and 3.5 inches and caused flash flooding and flooding of smaller streams and creeks in southeastern Pennsylvania.  Hardest hit was the tri-county area of Delaware, Montgomery and Chester Counties where Doppler Radar storm total estimates and surface reports reached around 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in extreme southwest Montgomery County overnight on the 15th centered around Upper Merion Township. In the township, flash flooding was reported along South Gulph Road as Gulph Creek flooded  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3.5 inches in the township. Actual event totals included 3.46 inches in Norristown and 2.07 inches in West Norriton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain during the evening of the 15th into the early morning of the 16th. Event precipitation totals during  multiple thunderstorms reached between 2.0 and 3.5 inches and caused flash flooding and flooding of smaller streams and creeks in southeastern Pennsylvania.  Hardest hit was the tri-county area of Delaware, Montgomery and Chester Counties where Doppler Radar storm total estimates and surface reports reached around 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in extreme northern Delaware County and included the headwaters of the Darby Creek as well as Crum Creek. Hardest hit were Radnor and Newtown Townships.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3.5 inches in the northern part of those townships.  The Crum Creek near Newtown Square was above its 5 foot flood stage from 141 a.m. EDT through 543 a.m.. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 7.57 feet at 245 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain during the evening of the 15th into the early morning of the 16th. Event precipitation totals during  multiple thunderstorms reached between 2.0 and 3.5 inches and caused flash flooding and flooding of smaller streams and creeks in southeastern Pennsylvania.  Hardest hit was the tri-county area of Delaware, Montgomery and Chester Counties where Doppler Radar storm total estimates and surface reports reached around 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek in Philadelphia. Urban and poor drainage flooding occurred elsewhere in the city.  The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 225 a.m. EDT through 255 a.m. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 7.9 feet at 245 a.m. EDT.   Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 2.5 inches in the northern part of the city. Actual event totals included 2.57 inches in Rockledge, 2.43 inches in Rhawnhurst and 2.26 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching a moist, unstable airmass across the Middle Atlantic region triggered numerous showers and thunderstorms across Eastern Pennsylvania, particularly during the evening and early in the  overnight on the 1st. This caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding in the headwaters of the Perkiomen Creek. Event precipitation totals reached two to three inches in eastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and southern Lehigh Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the headwaters of the Perkiomen Creek in northern Montgomery County. The Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville started flooding at 107 a.m. EDT on the 2nd and the West Branch of the Perkiomen Creek at Hillegass started flooding at 135 a.m. EDT on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching a moist, unstable airmass across the Middle Atlantic region triggered numerous showers and thunderstorms across Eastern Pennsylvania, particularly during the evening and early in the  overnight on the 1st. This caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding in the headwaters of the Perkiomen Creek. Event precipitation totals reached two to three inches in eastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and southern Lehigh Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding and roadway flooding near and along smaller creeks in Alburtis, Macungie, Lower and Upper Macungie Townships. Event precipitation totals included 2.78 inches in Orefield and 2.02 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, preceding a slowing cold front, during the afternoon of the 26th moved across the Poconos. They not only produced severe weather, but also flash flooding in several municipalities across western Carbon and southeast Monroe County.  Many roadways and basements were flooded and this included at least one road washout.  Heavier rainfall amounts were two to three inches per hour and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches in Hamilton Township (Monroe County).  The highest reported storm total was 7.40 inches in Lansdale in Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours hit Hamilton Township the hardest in Monroe County as Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches during the afternoon of the 26th.  Multiple roadways were flooded and included Pennsylvania State Route 33 between Syndersville and Interstate 80. The roadway was closed for nearly two hours and reopened at 620 p.m. EDT that evening. Beaver Valley Road between Turkey Hill Road and Haney Road was closed because it was undermined by a flooding creek. The combination of damaging winds, flooding rains and lightning caused about 2.000 Pennsylvania Power and Light and Metropolitan Edison customers to lose power.  The Pocono Creek near Brislin Road in Stroud Township crested at 10.99 feet. There is no established flood stage for the creek at that site. An event total of 3.23 inches was measured in Syndersville in Hamilton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms, preceding a slowing cold front, during the afternoon of the 26th moved across the Poconos. They not only produced severe weather, but also flash flooding in several municipalities across western Carbon and southeast Monroe County.  Many roadways and basements were flooded and this included at least one road washout.  Heavier rainfall amounts were two to three inches per hour and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 and 7 inches in Hamilton Township (Monroe County).  The highest reported storm total was 7.40 inches in Lansdale in Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as extensive poor drainage flooding in Lansford and Summit Hill Boroughs and the northwest part of Mahoning Township. Roadways were closed and many basements were flooded. In Summit Hill, Pennsylvania State Route 902 was shut down for two and a half hours because of debris and rocks pushed onto the roadway. A portion of Oak Street was also closed. Firefighters responded to thirty-six calls of flooded basements. The annual Stay At Home Festival never opened because volunteers had to rebuild the stands and the field was swamped by flood waters. In Lansford, there was four feet of water on U.S. Route 209 and one motorist had to be rescued.  Other roadways in the borough were damaged by flooding as asphalt was washed away. A storm total measurement of 7.40 inches was measured in Lansford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong instability and deep moisture combined with a vigorous upper-level disturbance over the Lower Great Lakes and weak frontal boundary/inverted lee trough east of the Blue Ridge Mountains to produce isolated severe thunderstorms and localized heavy rainfall during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Slow steering motions aloft allowed thunderstorms to remain nearly stationary and produce flash flooding in the  Williamsport area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains (1-2 inches in less than one hour) caused urbanized flash flooding in downtown Williamsport. Numerous roads were flooded with approximately 15-20 occupied vehicles stranded in standing water. Local emergency officials and fire departments took part in several water rescues. Some roads were damaged due to wash-outs from the flash flooding. The Lycoming County Emergency Operations Center was activated for about two hours due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level circulation moved from western Virgina east-northeast into the Chesapeake Bay/Delmarva region. This system tapped into a narrow axis of deep moisture and instability to trigger scattered thunderstorms across northern Maryland and south-central Pennsylvania. Heavy thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding. Storms moved north-northwest as they crossed the Mason-Dixon line. Wind shear profiles were marginally favorable for isolated damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding in and around the Shippensburg area. Several roads were closed and impassable at times including Walnut Bottom Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave helped support an mesoscale convective system as it crossed ohio. This system weakened as it reached eastern Ohio but not before some wind damage was reported. Thunderstorms out ahead of the system also caused flash flooding to areas of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported several small, unnamed creeks out of their banks. Chapel Hill Road is flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave helped support an mesoscale convective system as it crossed ohio. This system weakened as it reached eastern Ohio but not before some wind damage was reported. Thunderstorms out ahead of the system also caused flash flooding to areas of western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reported several roads flooded in Donegal Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the Upper Ohio Valley produced scattered strong thunderstorms. A few storms contained very heavy rainfall and produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with roads closed and debris blocking drains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the Upper Ohio Valley produced scattered strong thunderstorms. A few storms contained very heavy rainfall and produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Duss Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the Upper Ohio Valley produced scattered strong thunderstorms. A few storms contained very heavy rainfall and produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported numerous basements flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a slow moving cold front from eastern Ohio, to northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. Heavy rainfall from a few storms also produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were reported closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a slow moving cold front from eastern Ohio, to northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. Heavy rainfall from a few storms also produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding reported on Connellsville Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a slow moving cold front from eastern Ohio, to northern West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. Heavy rainfall from a few storms also produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with water in homes and roads closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty NWS employee reported a creek flooding roads with water approaching a few homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reproted flash flooding on Blind Lane Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty NWS employee reproted water into homes and bridges flooded on McClaren Raod.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Oakdale Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Cliff Mine Road and Mahoney Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the Upper Ohio Valley produced scattered strong thunderstorms. A few storms contained very heavy rainfall and produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding and a mudslide in SR 51.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported SR 51 near Whitehall was flooded with a vehicle floating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported SR 51 at East Bruceton Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding on roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported creeks out of their banks flooding roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported creeks out of their banks and flooding streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Coal Valley Road at Clairton Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on E 5th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported SR 51 and Brownsville Road is completely shut down by flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Worthington Ave clsoed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Oakdale Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding on Campbells Run Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong frontal system with abundant moisture brought a period of heavy rainfall and damaging thunderstorm winds to portions of the lower Susquehanna Valley. The intense thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains brought small streams out of their banks and closed numerous roads.  The South Branch of Codorus Creek spilled out of its banks closing Indian Rock Dam Road at Croll School Road and Hokes Mill Road. A small mobile home park located along SR 74 between Pine Road and Emig Mill Road in Dover Township was evacuated due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong frontal system with abundant moisture brought a period of heavy rainfall and damaging thunderstorm winds to portions of the lower Susquehanna Valley. The intense thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains resulted in flash flooding and road closures in West Penn Township, especially in the area of Route 895 and Dorset Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and a mid level disturbance, along with an increasingly hot and humid air mass, triggered strong to severe thunderstorms, which produced heavy rain and flooding in Pennsylvania. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported to be flooded due to heavy rains of 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low pressure system was moving across the upper Ohio Valley towards the Pittsburgh area associated with showers. As the system moved over Allegheny County, it strengthened and spawned heavy rain with windy conditions. Some of the winds had mixed down with the heavy showers causing sporadic areas of damage.  Before the center of the low started crossing Allegheny County, very small vortices spun up on the southern side of the low, producing two weak and short lived tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash fLooding was reported in Clairton, Wilkins Township, and Baldwin where a vehicle rescue was performed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours affected parts of southeastern Pennsylvania mainly during the first half of the day on the 3rd. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in western sections of Delaware County and eastern sections of Chester County.. The heavy rain was caused by the combination of a nearby stationary front and the approaching remnants associated with Hurricane Isaac.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage and roadway flooding in West Chester and West Goshen Township. A couple of roads were closed in West Chester. Doppler Radar rainfall estimates were around three inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours affected parts of southeastern Pennsylvania mainly during the first half of the day on the 3rd. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in western sections of Delaware County and eastern sections of Chester County.. The heavy rain was caused by the combination of a nearby stationary front and the approaching remnants associated with Hurricane Isaac.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the Chester Creek.  The Chester Creek near Chester exceeded its 8 foot flood stage from 618 p.m. EDT through 824 p.m. EDT on the 3rd. It crested at 8.92 feet at 7 p.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours affected parts of southeastern Pennsylvania mainly during the first half of the day on the 3rd. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in western sections of Delaware County and eastern sections of Chester County.. The heavy rain was caused by the combination of a nearby stationary front and the approaching remnants associated with Hurricane Isaac.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Valley Creek.  The Valley Creek near Valley Forge exceeded its 7 foot flood stage from 549 a.m. EDT through 716 a.m. EDT on the 3rd. It crested at 7.78 feet at 645 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours affected parts of southeastern Pennsylvania mainly during the first half of the day on the 3rd. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in western sections of Delaware County and eastern sections of Chester County.. The heavy rain was caused by the combination of a nearby stationary front and the approaching remnants associated with Hurricane Isaac.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: For the second time within the same day, thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Valley Creek.  The Valley Creek near Valley Forge exceeded its 7 foot flood stage from 1118 a.m. EDT through 1230 p.m. EDT on the 3rd. It crested at 7.29 feet at Noon EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 3rd into the evening of the 4th produced pockets of flash flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania.  By far the worst flash flooding occurred in Monroe County where Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of small creeks as well as poor drainage and low lying area flooding in and around Stroudsburg. A precipitation event total of 5.75 inches was measured in East Stroudsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 3rd into the evening of the 4th produced pockets of flash flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania.  By far the worst flash flooding occurred in Monroe County where Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Southampton Creek in Upper Moreland Township.  Flooding from the creek was reported around Byberry and Pioneer Roads.  Storm totals included 2.22 in Williow Grove and 2.12 inches in Jenkintown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 3rd into the evening of the 4th produced pockets of flash flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania.  By far the worst flash flooding occurred in Monroe County where Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding in the Spruce Hill section of Philadelphia, in particular around 43rd and Baltimore Streets. The precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport for September 4th was 3.12 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and a mid level disturbance, along with an increasingly hot and humid air mass, triggered strong to severe thunderstorms, which produced heavy rain and flooding in Pennsylvania. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge rose rapidly to 7.0 feet, exceeding flood stage and spilling over its banks. Poor drainage flooding also occurred within Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A protracted period of rain that included embedded thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in sections of northern Lehigh County as well as in the Poconos. Rain began during the early morning on the 18th, but fell heavily in thunderstorms during the mid to late afternoon on the 18th when flash flooding occurred. The rain became lighter and more intermittent during the evening of the 18th and ended overnight. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding across several locations in Carbon County. In Lehighton, the exit ramps to U.S. Route 209 from the Northeast Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike were closed due to flash flooding. A couple of water rescues were performed. In Kidder Township, Pennsylvania State Route 903 was closed between Pennsylvania State Route 534 and Johnathan Point Drive. The Mud Run Bridge on Pennsylvania State Route 903 was closed due to flooding. The latter roadway was not expected to be open until it was inspected the next day (the 19th).  In Franklin Township, driveways were swept into the street. Tons of debris had to be hauled away. Floodwaters ripped a pipe from the ground. In Mahoning Township, Country Club Road was closed between Pennsylvania State Routes 443 and 902. The Pohopoco Creek below Beltzville Lake at Parryville was above its 5.5 foot flood stage from 343 p.m. EDT through 425 p.m. EDT on the 18th. It crested at 5.62 feet at 4 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 5.75 inches in Lehighton, 5.66 inches in Beltzville, 5.41 inches in Jim Thorpe, 5.28 inches in Bowmanstown and 4.99 inches in Palmerton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A protracted period of rain that included embedded thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in sections of northern Lehigh County as well as in the Poconos. Rain began during the early morning on the 18th, but fell heavily in thunderstorms during the mid to late afternoon on the 18th when flash flooding occurred. The rain became lighter and more intermittent during the evening of the 18th and ended overnight. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding and road closures, particularly in central and northern Monroe County. Road closures were reported in Lehman, Tobyhanna and Pocono Townships. Event precipitation totals included 5.78 inches in Blakeslee,  5.75 inches in Pocono Summit and 5.67 inches in Mount Pocono.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low pressure system was moving across the upper Ohio Valley towards the Pittsburgh area associated with showers. As the system moved over Allegheny County, it strengthened and spawned heavy rain with windy conditions. Some of the winds had mixed down with the heavy showers causing sporadic areas of damage.  Before the center of the low started crossing Allegheny County, very small vortices spun up on the southern side of the low, producing two weak and short lived tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported 10 inches of water flowing across Nadine Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low pressure system was moving across the upper Ohio Valley towards the Pittsburgh area associated with showers. As the system moved over Allegheny County, it strengthened and spawned heavy rain with windy conditions. Some of the winds had mixed down with the heavy showers causing sporadic areas of damage.  Before the center of the low started crossing Allegheny County, very small vortices spun up on the southern side of the low, producing two weak and short lived tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 center reported Center Ave buckling due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 3rd into the evening of the 4th produced pockets of flash flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania.  By far the worst flash flooding occurred in Monroe County where Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of small creeks and roadways in sections of Chestnut Hill, Hamilton, Jackson, Middle Smithfield and Stroud Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches within the core of the heaviest rain.  Pennsylvania State Route 191 near the former Penn Hills Resort in Stroud Township flooded. Flooding was also reported along sections of the Brodhead Creek that reached onto other roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced isolated wind damage, large hail and flash flooding across portions of the mid and lower Susquehanna Valley during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm downpours produced an inch of rainfall in 20 minutes in York. This resulted in significant urban flooding with numerous flooded streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams in northeastern Northampton County.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller streams in Upper Mount Bethel Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system moved east from the Ohio Valley and triggered numerous strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. A few storms produced isolated reports of large hail and damaging winds. A cluster of training thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall across portions of the lower Susquehanna Valley. Localized flash flooding occurred over eastern Cumberland County where radar and rain gage reports indicated 1-2 inches fell in less than one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains of 1-2 inches in less than an hour produced numerous reports of flash flooding across the eastern half of Cumberland County. Flash flooding closed SR 42 near Mt. Holly Springs, South Front and Market Streets in Lemoyne, SR 11 in Silver Springs Township and the 400 block of Front Street in Hampden Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours affected parts of southeastern Pennsylvania mainly during the first half of the day on the 3rd. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in western sections of Delaware County and eastern sections of Chester County.. The heavy rain was caused by the combination of a nearby stationary front and the approaching remnants associated with Hurricane Isaac.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage and roadway flooding in Concord and Thornbury Townships. Doppler Radar rainfall estimates were around four inches within the townships..

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered severe thunderstorms from the afternoon through the late evening. The storms produced marginally severe hail and localized heavy downpours that resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains from slow-moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding south of Morris. Rain gage reports indicated 2-4 inches fell over a short duration. The flooding closed a portion of SR 414 and caused a rock-slide along SR 287.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 3rd into the evening of the 4th produced pockets of flash flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania.  By far the worst flash flooding occurred in Monroe County where Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Pennypack Creek as well as poor drainage flooding in northeastern Philadelphia. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 203 p.m. EDT through 239 p.m. EDT on the 4th. It crested at 7.78 feet at 215 p.m. EDT. Of the three times the Pennypack Creek flooded on the 4th, this was its highest crest of the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced flash flooding mainly across Pittsburgh and Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding in Dravosburg on SR 837.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong frontal system with abundant moisture brought a period of heavy rainfall and damaging thunderstorm winds to portions of the lower Susquehanna Valley. The intense thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding along small streams and creeks in the southern part of the county. The flooding also closed many roads and resulted in several water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A protracted period of rain that included embedded thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in sections of northern Lehigh County as well as in the Poconos. Rain began during the early morning on the 18th, but fell heavily in thunderstorms during the mid to late afternoon on the 18th when flash flooding occurred. The rain became lighter and more intermittent during the evening of the 18th and ended overnight. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage flooding in northern Lehigh County. Event precipitation totals included 2.76 inches in Schnecksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced some flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call center reported flash flooding on Boston Hollow Raod with 5 vehicles swamped, swift water rescues were underway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced some flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported water in homes due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported Sunny Drive closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 899 closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced some flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported basement flooding on Boston Hollow Road with some residents trapped by high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused localized flash flooding in York County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains produced localized flash flooding in south-central York County. Significant ponding of water closed a portion of I-83 near Lake Redman. Street flooding also occurred in Red Lion as runoff quickly overwhelmed storm drains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across the region as a cold front moved south. Isolated flash flooding occurred over Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding as Turtle Creek came out of its banks and flooded Route 48.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across the region as a cold front moved south. Isolated flash flooding occurred over Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported flash flooding with vehicles with passengers swamped on Route 837.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across the region as a cold front moved south. Isolated flash flooding occurred over Allegheny county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center found an unoccupied car in flash flooding on 5th Avenue and Cliff Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A week after a flash flood even in eastern Erie County, another heavy rain event came through with 3 to 5 inches of rain. The hardest hit areas were Summit, McKean, and Greene Townships in eastern Erie County. The City of Erie also suffered some flash flooding as a major thruway was cut off by high water. Four hikers were rescued in a gorge as the creek rose quickly, but no injuries were reported. The rain event was caused by short wave trough over the region, with northwest Pennsylvania situated in the warm sector with dew points in the lower 60s. Some overrunning, training, and lift associated with the higher topography in the region supported high rainfall amounts which fell over an 18 hour period. Rainfall from the week before kept the soil conditions wet, and flash flood guidance was as low as 0.65 for 1 hour rainfall during the event. The observed rainfall rates were not notable, however one observer reported over 2/hr at one point when a heavier cell moved over Greene Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A home in Millcreek was flooded from water inundating the first floor and then into the basement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-stationary boundary remained the focus for afternoon showers and thunderstorms again on June 30th. While shear and instability remained meager, with cape values of 1000j/kg or less, some storms were able to support themselves to severe levels. A little more than a dozen wind damage and hail reports combined made up the afternoon. But, once again, training thunderstorms produced flooding problems, this time over Allegheny county in Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported that the intersection of Rodi and Tulip Roads was flooded. In addition, at the intersection of Rodi and Duff Roads a vehicle with occupants was stuck in high water and a water rescue was taking place.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-stationary boundary remained the focus for afternoon showers and thunderstorms again on June 30th. While shear and instability remained meager, with cape values of 1000j/kg or less, some storms were able to support themselves to severe levels. A little more than a dozen wind damage and hail reports combined made up the afternoon. But, once again, training thunderstorms produced flooding problems, this time over Allegheny county in Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported that the 700 block of Freeport Road was flooded.
