Four hikers were rescued in a gorge as the creek rose quickly, but no injuries were reported. The rain event was caused by short wave trough over the region, with northwest Pennsylvania situated in the warm sector with dew points in the lower 60s. Some overrunning, training, and lift associated with the higher topography in the region supported high rainfall amounts which fell over an 18 hour period. Rainfall from the week before kept the soil conditions wet, and flash flood guidance was as low as 0.65 for 1 hour rainfall during the event. The observed rainfall rates were not notable, however one observer reported over 2/hr at one point when a heavier cell moved over Greene Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell over the higher terrain near Erie, PA. The runoff from the estimated 1 to 2.5 of rainfall in the basin was sufficient to flood several area roads. The off and on ramps for I-90 at the route 97 exit were shut down for several hours, starting at rush hour. Water depths were up to 6 feet in areas. One motorists had to be rescued after entering the flood waters. Water inundated two nearby gas stations underground storage tanks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A week after a flash flood even in eastern Erie County, another heavy rain event came through with 3 to 5 inches of rain. The hardest hit areas were Summit, McKean, and Greene Townships in eastern Erie County. The City of Erie also suffered some flash flooding as a major thruway was cut off by high water. Four hikers were rescued in a gorge as the creek rose quickly, but no injuries were reported. The rain event was caused by short wave trough over the region, with northwest Pennsylvania situated in the warm sector with dew points in the lower 60s. Some overrunning, training, and lift associated with the higher topography in the region supported high rainfall amounts which fell over an 18 hour period. Rainfall from the week before kept the soil conditions wet, and flash flood guidance was as low as 0.65 for 1 hour rainfall during the event. The observed rainfall rates were not notable, however one observer reported over 2/hr at one point when a heavier cell moved over Greene Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edinboro University of Pennsylvania campus was closed due to flash flooding between Earrly Hall to Hendricks Hall. Several roads were barricaded including Scotland Road, Heather Road, and Darrow Roads. Sand Bags were put in place to prevent inundation into buildings. Some minor water problems were reported in some of the buildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly moving across the Ohio Valley was the focus for the development of scattered thunderstorms, some of which were severe, through the evening hours of the 16th of April. While cloud cover kept instability weak, some deep layer shear helped maintain some storms to severe levels. Quarter sized hail and wind damage was reported in portions of western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service employee reported mud and debris flow blocked half of Robinson Town Centre Boulevard near Park Manor Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly moving across the Ohio Valley was the focus for the development of scattered thunderstorms, some of which were severe, through the evening hours of the 16th of April. While cloud cover kept instability weak, some deep layer shear helped maintain some storms to severe levels. Quarter sized hail and wind damage was reported in portions of western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported cars stuck in water on route 51 near the West End Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass over the Ohio Valley was broken up on the 10th by a shortwave trough and a surface cold front that came moved through during the afternoon hours. Storms developed ahead of the cold front around noon, and ended with the exit of the cold front through northwest Pennsylvania around 7 pm. The humid and unstable airmass supported intense rainfall rates verified with reports of 0.75 in 15 minutes. These storms moved over an area that was already saturated from weeks of hit and miss storms and floods, and could not support the additional runoff produced during this event. The result was widespread flash flooding as the storms affected every county in the WFO Cleveland county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement reported numerous road closures due to torrential rain from storms that moved through the area between 330 PM and 430 PM. NWS radar estimates rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches fell over the area during that time. A steel bridge along Keepville Road was completely under water and Route 18 was closed. Albion Local Officials requested evacuations near the Albion Boro Park. In Cranesville, just north of Albion, the sewer system was compromised.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced marginally severe hail and torrential rains over southeastern Somerset County. The heavy rain lead to localized flash flooding in Larimer Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains produced significant, localized flash flooding in Larimer Township. Rain gauge reports indicate over 2 inches of rain fell in less than 1 hour. The flash flooding caused washouts and severe damage to White Oak Hollow Road (TR-828) and Porter Road (TR-402). The heavy rains caused Wills Creek to rapidly rise out of its banks and cover White Oak Hollow Road. The elevated terrain along with the flash flooding contributed to major damage along Porter Road, as a stream of water took out a large portion of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on MILLERSTOWN Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a vehicle stuck in flowing water at the intersection of Mayview Road and Boyce Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Streets Run Road and Baldwin Road closed due to flash flooding. One water rescue reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fairly large area of moderate to heavy rainfall (1-2.5 inches) occurred across eastern Pennsylvania, ahead of an upper-level trough pushing eastward from the Mississippi Valley into the Mid-Atlantic region. Broad south-southwest flow ahead of the upper trough and associated frontal band maintained a strong moisture flux with deep-layer moisture (PWAT) values +2SD above normal, and surface dewpoints in the upper 60s and low 70s. Several rounds of rain fell across the middle Susquehanna Valley early on the 10th, with the final burst of heavy rain producing isolated flash flooding in southern half of Northumberland County during the late evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding across the lower half of Northumberland County. Several roads were closed due to flooding:  Tharp Street, Trevorton Road, West Walnut Street, West Wood Street, and Bear Valley Avenue in Coal Township; Sixth and Pine streets and Fourth and Mulberry streets in Shamokin, and Mountain Road in Ralpho Township. Carbon Run, which flows north toward Shamokin Creek, overtook its banks near the Fifth Street playground in Shamokin, sending black, culm filled water onto the streets. A water rescue was performed near the Shamokin Area High School on State Street, where crews helped a family of three leave a car stranded by water. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak low pressure area over Ohio entering a moist environment over PA with high precipitable water values sponsored a flash flooding episode in the lower Susquehanna Valley region late in the afternoon and evening. Thunderstorms repeatedly developing and training over southern Lebanon County dumped up to 7 inches of rain (7.03 measured at the Lebanon COOP) over several hours leading to flooded streams and creeks, roads, and basements especially in and around the City of Lebanon. The flash flooding stranded vehicles and prompted several water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from training thunderstorms produced localized flash flooding across portions of south-central York County. Some locations that were impacted include but are not limited to the city of York and Spring Garden and North Hopewell Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported Wylie Ave flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio reported flash flooding near Cascade Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a mudslide due to flash flooding on Turner Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Wesley Ave, just west of Charleroi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding reported along US 30 and under the US 30 bridge in the Raccoon Creek area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak low pressure area over Ohio entering a moist environment over PA with high precipitable water values sponsored a flash flooding episode in the lower Susquehanna Valley region late in the afternoon and evening. Thunderstorms repeatedly developing and training over southern Lebanon County dumped up to 7 inches of rain (7.03 measured at the Lebanon COOP) over several hours leading to flooded streams and creeks, roads, and basements especially in and around the City of Lebanon. The flash flooding stranded vehicles and prompted several water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record heavy rain event affected southern Lebanon County during the late afternoon and evening hours. Most of the rain fell in a 3-hour period, resulting in significant flash flooding. The estimated 3-hour rainfall rates exceeded the value for a 1000-year return period. The Quittapahilla Creek was overwhelmed by the intense rainfall, rising quickly and overflowing its banks in the city of Lebanon. The Quittapahilla Creek is a 16.8-mile-long tributary of Swatara Creek.||The pattern over much of the Mid-Atlantic region contained all of the ingredients for a significant heavy rainfall event, including above normal moisture (PWAT) and strong low-level southerly flow. Moderate instability was also a factor early in the event, with CAPE values above 1200 J/KG supporting deep moist convection.||Numerous water rescues were conducted across southern Lebanon County. The Townships that experienced the greatest flooding impacts included Londonderry, Annville, Cornwall, Lebanon, Heidelburg and Millcreek. The flash flooding transitioned into areal flooding/standing water by later in the evening and lasted into the overnight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported Robinson Run flooding Clinton and Union Avenues in Oakdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding off of Route 119 with the Everson exit closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms produced isolated wind damage in McKean County after midnight. A weak shortwave moved eastward across eastern KY during the predawn hours into the early morning, preceded by a field of large-scale lift and deep moisture transport focused into the lower Susquehanna Valley. Although storm motions were relatively quick, areas of training combined with 2+ precipitable water values, intense precipitation rates and seasonably high stream flows lead to flash flooding and road closures. In addition, low instability coupled with modest low-level shear produced a few supercell storm-structures and isolated damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding across south-central York County. The flooding lead to temporary road closures, with most of the impacts occurring in Hanover Borough and along the Codorus Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported motorists trapped in cars on Worthington Ave due to flash flooding.

This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported Valley Brook Creek was flooding Valley Brook Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred on US 30 in Hanover and Independence Townships.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a creek out of its banks causing flash flooding at Forest Ave and June Ann Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported Campbells Run Road blocked due to rain and mud.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that moved across southeast Pennsylvania during the day on the 10th caused renewed flooding in the area. Event precipitation totals averaged between 1.5 and 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that fell during the 10th led to flash flooding of roadways and gaged streams and creeks in Chester County. The East Branch of the Brandywine Creek at Downingtown was above its 7 foot flood stage from 834 a.m. EDT through 124 p.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 8.67 feet at 1130 a.m. EDT. The French Creek at Phoenixville was above its 8 foot flood stage from 725 a.m. EDT through 757 a.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 8.05 feet at 745 a.m. EDT. The Valley Creek at Valley Forge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 610 p.m. EDT through 858 p.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 7.77 feet at 700 p.m. EDT. Several roads were closed in Chester County due to flooding, including PA Route 926 and Westtown Road in Westtown Township. Creek Road was also closed by PennDot for a time due to flooding. Event precipitation totals included 3.01 inches in Modena, 2.24 inches in West Chester, 2.14 inches in Valley Forge, and 2.12 inches in Northbrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms tied to a surface front  dropped several inches of rain over northwest Pennsylvania the morning of the 27th. Particularly hit hard were Jefferson and adjacent Clearfield counties, were roads were made impassable by over four to six inches of rainfall. The local EMA Director stated there were 49 water rescues and 50 people were placed in shelters. The hardest hit areas include Punxsutawney, Sykesville, Stump Creek, Big Run. and Reynoldsville. Preliminary damage reports have a total of 347 homes and 34 businesses damaged by flood waters. Of those, nine homes were destroyed and three businesses were a total loss. Damage is already estimated to be about $3 million but could be upwards of $5 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county emergency manager reported that State Route 949 was closed from north of Munderf to Sigel due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that developed along a cold frontal boundary brought bands of showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours to Delaware and Chester Counties on the 12th. This caused flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.5 inches across central Delaware County and southern Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in southern Chester County. Event precipitation totals included 3.15 inches in West Grove, 2.86 inches in Landenburg, 2.55 inches in Nottingham and 2.36 inches in Unionville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms tied to a surface front  dropped several inches of rain over northwest Pennsylvania the morning of the 27th. Particularly hit hard were Jefferson and adjacent Clearfield counties, were roads were made impassable by over four to six inches of rainfall. The local EMA Director stated there were 49 water rescues and 50 people were placed in shelters. The hardest hit areas include Punxsutawney, Sykesville, Stump Creek, Big Run. and Reynoldsville. Preliminary damage reports have a total of 347 homes and 34 businesses damaged by flood waters. Of those, nine homes were destroyed and three businesses were a total loss. Damage is already estimated to be about $3 million but could be upwards of $5 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Department of Highways reported that State Route 322 at Soldier Run was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and also in parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of the Lehigh Valley, 6 to 8 inches in parts of the Poconos and around 8 inches in parts of the local Philadelphia area.  The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event. This event also helped establish back-to-back all-time monthly rainfall records in Philadelphia. The July 2013 precipitation total of 13.24 inches was a new monthly record for Philadelphia and came on the heels of a record breaking 10.56 inches falling in June. The current normal meteorological summer seasonal precipitation average for Philadelphia is 11.28 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in northeastern Lehigh County and affected Washington and Heidelberg Townships the most where Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches. Measured event precipitation totals included 2.09 inches in Slatington and 1.48 inches in Schnecksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant instability combined with modest lapse rates and abundant deep-layer moisture (PW) produced numerous thunderstorm clusters with locally heavy rain during the afternoon and evening hours across central PA. Although vertical wind shear profiles were not particularly strong, strong destabilization lead to robust updrafts which produced marginally severe hail and damaging winds/wet microbursts. Localized flash flooding occurred in Potter and McKean Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several thunderstorm clusters produced heavy rain and localized flash flooding in and around the Shinglehouse area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of the Lehigh Valley, Poconos and Philadelphia northwest suburbs during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Creeks running higher than normal led to the death of a 13-year-old boy in Philadelphia that afternoon.  The 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old brother jumped into the swollen Pennypack Creek near Roosevelt Boulevard (U.S. Route 1). They were swept by the swift current over a waterfall before an attempt could even be started to rescue them. One of the rescuers also had to be rescued. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 5.5 inches in sections of eastern Monroe, southern Lehigh and most of hardest hit Northampton County. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in eastern Monroe County in eastern sections of Smithfield and Middle Smithfield Townships. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 5 inches in the eastern parts of the townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant instability combined with modest lapse rates and abundant deep-layer moisture (PW) produced numerous thunderstorm clusters with locally heavy rain during the afternoon and evening hours across central PA. Although vertical wind shear profiles were not particularly strong, strong destabilization lead to robust updrafts which produced marginally severe hail and damaging winds/wet microbursts. Localized flash flooding occurred in Potter and McKean Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several thunderstorm clusters produced heavy rain and flash flooding across northeast McKean County. Road closures included RT 446, intersection of Newell Creek/Sartwell Roads, SR 155 in Turtlepoint, Taylor Brook Drive, Bell Run Road and Sun Valley Road near Eldred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that moved across southeast Pennsylvania during the day on the 10th caused renewed flooding in the area. Event precipitation totals averaged between 1.5 and 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain during the 10th led to flash flooding of some roadways and gaged steams and creeks in Montgomery County. The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington was above its 9 foot flood stage from 748 p.m. EDT through 1141 p.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 10.20 feet at 1000 p.m. EDT. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek at Schwenksville was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1138 a.m. EDT through 145 p.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 7.58 feet at 130 p.m. EDT. The river rose above its flood stage a second time from 1142 p.m. EDT on the 10th through 423 a.m. EDT on the 11th. The second crest was 7.79 feet at 230 a.m. EDT on the 11th. Event precipitation totals included 3.61 inches in North Wales, 3.33 inches in Hatfield, 2.99 inches in Kulpsville, 2.63 inches in Blue Bell, 2.45 inches in Harleysville, and 2.36 inches in Collegeville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of the Lehigh Valley, Poconos and Philadelphia northwest suburbs during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Creeks running higher than normal led to the death of a 13-year-old boy in Philadelphia that afternoon.  The 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old brother jumped into the swollen Pennypack Creek near Roosevelt Boulevard (U.S. Route 1). They were swept by the swift current over a waterfall before an attempt could even be started to rescue them. One of the rescuers also had to be rescued. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 5.5 inches in sections of eastern Monroe, southern Lehigh and most of hardest hit Northampton County. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains resulted in flash flooding in northeastern Northampton County.  Several home basements were flooded with two to five feet of water on Messinger Street in Bangor Borough as an underground creek rose and flooded. One family on Messenger Street was rescued. Two garages on the street were also damaged. Fuel oil leaked into the water. Flooding closed Messinger Road, Viaduct Road, South Main Street, and Rutt Road in the borough. No injuries were reported. Power was out to a number of homes for precautionary reasons also because water reached into the ground floor.  The flooding occurred because of an underground creek near the headwaters of Martins Creek.  Numerous streets were also flooded in Penn Argyl Borough.  Flooding waters also damaged a few homes in East Bangor Borough. The axis of heaviest rain extended from Penn Argyl and Washington Township northeastward through Upper Mount Bethel Township in Northampton County. Event precipitation totals included 3.54 inches in Nazareth and 2.07 inches in Bethlehem.  These municipalities were south of where the heaviest rain fell and Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 5 inches within the axis of heaviest rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of the Lehigh Valley, Poconos and Philadelphia northwest suburbs during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Creeks running higher than normal led to the death of a 13-year-old boy in Philadelphia that afternoon.  The 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old brother jumped into the swollen Pennypack Creek near Roosevelt Boulevard (U.S. Route 1). The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding across central and northern Montgomery County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.0 to 2.5 inches across most of this area. In Towamencin Township, a motorist had to be rescued from flood waters. Event precipitation totals included 3.33 inches in Royersford and 2.53 inches in Hatfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and also in parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of the Lehigh Valley, 6 to 8 inches in parts of the Poconos and around 8 inches in parts of the local Philadelphia area.  The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event. This event also helped establish back-to-back all-time monthly rainfall records in Philadelphia. The current normal meteorological summer seasonal precipitation average for Philadelphia is 11.28 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in southeastern Monroe County and affected Hamilton, Stroud, Smithfield and Middle Smithfield Townships as well as Stroudsburg and East Stroudsburg the hardest as Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 to 6 inches within parts of these municipalities. Measured event precipitation totals included 3.67 inches in East Stroudsburg, 2.92 inches in Middle Smithfield Township and 2.74 inches in Blakeslee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and also in parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of the Lehigh Valley, 6 to 8 inches in parts of the Poconos and around 8 inches in parts of the local Philadelphia area.  The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event. This event also helped establish back-to-back all-time monthly rainfall records in Philadelphia. The July 2013 precipitation total of 13.24 inches was a new monthly record for Philadelphia and came on the heels of a record breaking 10.56 inches falling in June. The current normal meteorological summer seasonal precipitation average for Philadelphia is 11.28 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused urban and poor drainage flash flooding along all of the municipalities that border the Delaware River.  Event precipitation totals included 8.26 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 1.84 inches in Center City.  The precipitation gradient was tremendous over the county as only 0.80 inches fell in Swarthmore and 0.40 inches fell in Havertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across eastern Pennsylvania. Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River during the early morning high tide cycles on the 23rd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 24th. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. Wyomissing Creek was quickly out of its banks. Flooding was reported at the Cambridge Commons Apartments Complex, with water reported in the maintenance building. Flooding was also reported on Pennsylvania State Route 12 approaching Reading. Event precipitation totals included 6.70 inches in Kutztown, 4.75 inches in Boyertown, 4.21 inches in Bernville, 2.29 inches in Fleetwood and 2.23 inches in Oley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across eastern Pennsylvania. Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River during the early morning high tide cycles on the 23rd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 24th. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. Several roads were reported to be flooded across Chester County. Event precipitation totals included 1.58 inches in West Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy thunderstorms caused localized urban and small stream flash flooding in and around the Johnstown area during the afternoon and evening . Many surrounding Townships and Boroughs were impacted, including the extreme northern portion of Somerset County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused a washout of Route 160 (Forest Hills Drive/9th Street) in Paint Township near Windber.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy thunderstorms caused localized urban and small stream flash flooding in and around the Johnstown area during the afternoon and evening . Many surrounding Townships and Boroughs were impacted, including the extreme northern portion of Somerset County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorms rains produced urbanized and small stream flash flooding in and around the city of Johnstown during the late afternoon and evening hours. Trained weather spotters reported over 2 inches in an hour. Approximately 25 roads were closed in the Johnstown area, including Eisenhower Blvd. and Ohio Street. Flooding impacted homes along Arbutus Avenue and Fulmer Road. Sams Run came out of its banks and caused flooding problems in Geistown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that moved across southeast Pennsylvania during the day on the 10th caused renewed flooding in the area. Event precipitation totals averaged between 1.5 and 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that fell during the 10th led to flash flooding along roadways and gaged creeks and streams in Delaware County. The Chester Creek at Chester had moderate flooding and was above its 8 foot flood stage from 636 p.m. EDT through 1049 p.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 10.93 feet at 845 p.m. EDT. The Crum Creek at Newtown Square was above its 6 foot flood stage from 518 p.m. EDT through 1022 p.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 9.34 feet at 700 p.m. EDT. Several roads were closed due to high water in Delaware County; including Westtown Road, Westtown-Thornton Road, and Creek Road. Event precipitation totals included 3.22 inches in Wayne and 1.37 inches in Chester Heights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across eastern Pennsylvania. Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River during the early morning high tide cycles on the 23rd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 24th. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. Several roads around Schwenksville were reported to be flooded out. Cars were submerged within flood waters in Pottstown. No serious injuries were reported. Event precipitation totals included 3.32 inches in Gilbertsville, 2.90 inches in Blue Bell, 2.69 inches in North Wales, 2.57 inches in Kulpsville, 2.37 inches in Hatfield and 2.33 inches in Pottstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave and convective low dropping southeast from lower Michigan produced heavy showers and thunderstorms over Somerset County. The upper-air disturbance was embedded within an anomalously moist northwest flow and tapped into a plume of monsoonal moisture that wrapped northeast from the Desert Southwest around the northern periphery of an expansive southern Plains upper ridge. While much of Somerset County received 1 inch of rain during the course of the day, two concentrated areas of locally heavy rain (2-4 inches) occurred in the northwest and southwest corners of the county. The intense rain rates combined with wet antecedent conditions produced flash flooding which eventually transitioned into areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Following a period of heavy rain and flash flooding earlier in the morning, a second area of heavy rain in Jenner Township and Boswell Borough lead to additional flash flooding and exacerbated ongoing inundation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that moved across southeast Pennsylvania during the day on the 10th caused renewed flooding in the area. Event precipitation totals averaged between 1.5 and 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that fell during the 10th led to flashing flooding of some roadways and gaged creeks and streams in Bucks County. The Neshaminy Creek at Langhorne was above its 9 foot flood stage from 1123 p.m. EDT on the 10th through 625 a.m. EDT on the 11th. It crested at 9.60 feet at 145 a.m. EDT on the 11th. The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek at Dublin was above its 5 foot flood stage from 802 p.m. EDT through 845 p.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 5.18 feet at 815 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 2.21 inches in Langhorne, 1.99 inches in Penndel, 1.51 inches in Pennsburg, and 1.33 inches in Quakertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across eastern Pennsylvania. Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River during the early morning high tide cycles on the 23rd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 24th. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused urban and poor drainage flash flooding. Several areas of significant flooding were reported on the Schuylkill Expressway. Significant flooding was also reported on Broad Street in South Philadelphia under Interstate 95, with vehicles trapped. The water level was reported to be nearly up to the car windows. Deep standing water occurred on Interstate 95. The heavy rain flooded sections of the 8th and Market PATCO Commuter rail line stop. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 242 a.m. EDT through 255 a.m. EDT on the 23rd. It crested at 7.25 feet at 245 a.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 1.50 inches in Northeast Philadelphia, 1.29 inches in Rockledge and 1.18 inches in Northwest Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm over northern Columbia County produced heavy rain and localized flash flooding during the early morning hours on the 2nd. The flooding was confined to the Sugarloaf Township/Benton area. Later that day, intense rainfall produced flash flooding in Northern Cambria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense heavy rainfall between 4-5 inches in less than an hour produced flash flooding in Northern Cambria. The bulk of the flooding was confined in Northern Cambria Borough and Susquehanna and Barr Townships. Deveaux Street and Route 219 North ��� both state routes - were closed temporarily due to flooding. Mosscreek Road in Barr Township received considerable debris and mud collection. The Northern Cambria Middle School reported significant flood damage and was closed for the week during the cleanup.  Numerous flooded basements were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves diving through a broad upper level trough brought rounds of showers and thunderstorms through the last several days of June. With a weakly capped atmosphere, a cold pool associated with two such upper level waves helped to spark two areas of convection in the afternoon on June 28th. There were numerous reports of wind damage across eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. In addition, training thunderstorms produced several areas of flooding, including some flash flooding across several counties in western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported that Pittsburgh Street in Scottdale is flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that developed along a cold frontal boundary brought bands of showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours to Delaware and Chester Counties on the 12th. This caused flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.5 inches across central Delaware County and southern Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and creeks in and around Upper Providence Township. Water rescues occurred within the township, but no serious injuries were reported. Event precipitation totals included 4.15 inches in Media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in Philadelphia and Delaware Counties and also in parts of the Poconos and Lehigh Valley. Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of the Lehigh Valley, 6 to 8 inches in parts of the Poconos and around 8 inches in parts of the local Philadelphia area.  The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event. This event also helped establish back-to-back all-time monthly rainfall records in Philadelphia. The July 2013 precipitation total of 13.24 inches was a new monthly record for Philadelphia and came on the heels of a record breaking 10.56 inches falling in June. The current normal meteorological summer seasonal precipitation average for Philadelphia is 11.28 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused urban and poor drainage flash flooding in Philadelphia. Multiple ramps of Interstate 95 around Broad Street were closed. A 21-year-old woman drowned after she accidentally drove into the Schuylkill River near Boathouse Road in Philadelphia. A 31-year-old male passenger managed to swim to safety. The river was running higher than average, but was not flooding at the time of the drowning. SEPTA Regional rail lines reported flooding on tracks within Philadelphia. The flooding rains caused portions of Terminal A at Philadelphia International Airport to lose power. Departure and arrival delays reached 90 minutes and seventeen flights were cancelled. Event precipitation totals included 8.26 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 1.84 inches in Center City.  The precipitation gradient was tremendous over Philadelphia as only 0.64 inches fell at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport.||A total of 8.02 inches of rain fell at the Philadelphia International Airport on the 28th. The amount not only established a new record daily maximum rainfall for that date, but was also the most rainfall on record for any calendar day in Philadelphia. The previous record was set on September 16, 1999 during Tropical Storm Floyd and was 6.63 inches.  This torrential downpour also helped establish a new July monthly rainfall record of 13.24 inches in Philadelphia. The previous record was 10.42 inches set in 1994.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves diving through a broad upper level trough brought rounds of showers and thunderstorms through the last several days of June. With a weakly capped atmosphere, a cold pool associated with two such upper level waves helped to spark two areas of convection in the afternoon on June 28th. There were numerous reports of wind damage across eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. In addition, training thunderstorms produced several areas of flooding, including some flash flooding across several counties in western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reported numerous roads closed in the city of Washington. Catfish was reported out of it's banks, stranding a car in high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported roads flooded and streams out of banks in Dawson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves diving through a broad upper level trough brought rounds of showers and thunderstorms through the last several days of June. With a weakly capped atmosphere, a cold pool associated with two such upper level waves helped to spark two areas of convection in the afternoon on June 28th. There were numerous reports of wind damage across eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. In addition, training thunderstorms produced several areas of flooding, including some flash flooding across several counties in western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported flooding in Grant Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding of the Starrucca and Shadigee creeks caused a house to collapse and fall into the Starrucca Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was occurring on the Shehawken Creek with many roads and properties flooded in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced some flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported flash flooding on Liberty Way.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave and convective low dropping southeast from lower Michigan produced heavy showers and thunderstorms over Somerset County. The upper-air disturbance was embedded within an anomalously moist northwest flow and tapped into a plume of monsoonal moisture that wrapped northeast from the Desert Southwest around the northern periphery of an expansive southern Plains upper ridge. While much of Somerset County received 1 inch of rain during the course of the day, two concentrated areas of locally heavy rain (2-4 inches) occurred in the northwest and southwest corners of the county. The intense rain rates combined with wet antecedent conditions produced flash flooding which eventually transitioned into areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized heavy rainfall of 3-4 inches in about 3 hours caused flash flooding in Jenner Township and Boswell Borough. The North Star School District was closed due to the flooding. Route 601 was closed in Jenners and several homes had flooded basements. One vehicle got stranded in moving water along Route 601 in the flood waters. Large boulders washed out onto the roadway on US 30 (Lincoln Highway) in the village of Jenners. Several roads were closed in Boswell Borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in Berks County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches in sections of the county.   Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. In fact, it was the wettest June on record in Philadelphia (10.56 inches)  and the 6th wettest June on record in Allentown (6.83 inches). On a county weighted average, June monthly precipitation ranged from 6.9 inches in Berks County to 10.4 inches in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of small creeks as well as roadway flooding in and around Bethel Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system acted on a moist and unstable airmasss to bring severe thunderstorms to northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Equinunk Creek was over its banks and flooding Equinunk Creek Road in several places. Two bridges were underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system acted on a moist and unstable airmasss to bring severe thunderstorms to northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Winterdale Road were washed out by flash flooding. Shoulders and guard rails of the road were gone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A retrograding upper level low continued to bring the threat for showers and thunderstorms on June 29th. However, with meager instability and shear, most storms were able to remain below severe levels, and only a few strong to severe wind gusts and toppled trees were reported. Despite this, a relatively stationary boundary did leave enough focus for some training thunderstorms that produced flooding over portions of Jefferson and Armstrong counties in Pennsylvania; two counties that had already experienced several days of heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reported flooding on River Road, East Branch Road, and Coolspring Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance produced showers and thunderstorms with heavy rainfall across western Pennsylvania and the northern West Virginia Panhandle. Flooding of roadways and areas of poor drainage was reported.  Significant flash flooding was reported across portions of Fayette county in Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coveland Creek was first reported out of its banks and debris was moving a bridge. From South Connellsville to Dunbar Borough, Dunbar Township and North Union a state of emergency was declared as flash flooding washed out roads, and damaged yards and homes across these areas. An elderly woman was evacuated from her home in North Union, where from 120 to 130 homes had water damage, and at least 14 homes were flooded by Dunbar Creek. Damage to township roads in North Union was estimated by officials to be one million dollars alone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fire Department reported flash flooding on Butler Street in Etna with over 2 feet of water running across road.

Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2 to 3 inches in this area. The White Clay Creek at Strickersville was above its 9.5 foot flood stage from 757 p.m. EDT through 910 p.m. EDT on the 28th. It crested at 9.75 feet at 845 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 2.47 inches in Landenburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms produced isolated wind damage in McKean County after midnight. A weak shortwave moved eastward across eastern KY during the predawn hours into the early morning, preceded by a field of large-scale lift and deep moisture transport focused into the lower Susquehanna Valley. Although storm motions were relatively quick, areas of training combined with 2+ precipitable water values, intense precipitation rates and seasonably high stream flows lead to flash flooding and road closures. In addition, low instability coupled with modest low-level shear produced a few supercell storm-structures and isolated damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy training thunderstorms produced areas of flash flooding during the early morning hours. Several homes had flooded basements. A water rescue was conducted in Sadsbury Township at Noble/Lower Valley Road due to a vehicle stuck in standing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in extreme southeast Pennsylvania primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches and this was mainly confined to Chester and Delaware Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Valley Creek at Valley Forge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 201 p.m. EDT through 417 p.m. EDT on the 18th. It crested at 7.49 feet at 345 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 2.70 inches in East Nantmeal Township and 1.78 inches in Honey Brook.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Washington Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe convective development shifted east of the Lake Erie region into northwest Pennsylvania, within a zone of broader vertical ascent extending downstream from an upper level wave migrating into the Great Lakes region. Isolated straight-line wind damage occurred around a supercell that moved across northern Warren into McKean County. Heavy thunderstorm rains also produced localized flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding and closed portions of US Route 6 in Columbus Township, SR 69 (Jackson Run Road) and SR 59 (Kinzua Road) in the northern part of the county. Warren Fire units were called for a water rescue on Brown Run Road as Brown Run came out of its banks and over-flowed the bridge. The flood waters also impacted one home on the south-side of Kinzua Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training bands of locally heavy rain impacted parts of the middle Susquehanna Valley during the late morning and early afternoon. A deep east-southeast flow from the Atlantic pulled high moisture into the region around an upper-level low rotating northward from MD/VA. Rainfall rates of 1-2/hour were common with localized rainfall rates as high as 4/hour. Several locations around the Lewisburg, Selinsgrove and Sunbury areas picked up between 2-3 inches of rain over a short duration. Urbanization combined with the intense rains lead to flash flooding along SR 11 and the closure of Reagan/Hamilton underpasses near Sunbury. Small streams including Bull Run and Turtle Creek also came out of their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain caused flash flooding around Lewisburg. Bull Run and Turtle Creek came out of their banks and flooded adjacent roads. The Lewisburg COOP observer recorded 3.25 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training bands of locally heavy rain impacted parts of the middle Susquehanna Valley during the late morning and early afternoon. A deep east-southeast flow from the Atlantic pulled high moisture into the region around an upper-level low rotating northward from MD/VA. Rainfall rates of 1-2/hour were common with localized rainfall rates as high as 4/hour. Several locations around the Lewisburg, Selinsgrove and Sunbury areas picked up between 2-3 inches of rain over a short duration. Urbanization combined with the intense rains lead to flash flooding along SR 11 and the closure of Reagan/Hamilton underpasses near Sunbury. Small streams including Bull Run and Turtle Creek also came out of their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused water to cover portions of SR 11 from Selinsgrove northward along the west-side of the Susquehanna River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCV and broader mid-level trough crossed the central Appalachians and triggered strong to severe thunderstorms from the central ridges into the Susquehanna River Valley during the afternoon and evening. Very high boundary layer moisture and humidity contributed to heavy rainfall/flash flooding and precipitation loading within consolidating convection. While the deep layer flow and shear were somewhat modest, ambient vertical vorticity just ahead of the MCV and low LCLs aided in the development of two weak, short-lived (EF1) tornadoes in Centre and Perry Counties. Deep moisture (PWAT) values around two inches along with relatively slow, south-to-north training cells and bands produced significant flash flooding, particularly in DuBois and Beech Creek which sustained extensive flood damages due localized 4-6+ inch rainfall amounts. Both towns were declared a State of Emergency. The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record. An 86-year old man was swept away and killed by the rising flood waters in Beech Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains produced flash flooding in the Centre region from Pine Grove Mills and State College through Bellefonte and Milesburg. The hardest hit area was from Milesburg northeast along Route 150 to the Blanchard/Beech Creek Area near the Centre/Clinton county line. Numerous roads were closed including Route 26 from Porter Road to Benner Pike in College Township, Jacksonville Road (Route 26) in Marion Township, Route 3005 (Fox Hollow Road) from Cricklewood Drive in Patton Township to Park Ave/Porter Road in College Township, Route 455 in Walker Township, Route 550 from Upper Gyp Road to Reynolds Lane in Benner Township and Route 26 at Walnut Ridge Road in Marion Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCV and broader mid-level trough crossed the central Appalachians and triggered strong to severe thunderstorms from the central ridges into the Susquehanna River Valley during the afternoon and evening. Very high boundary layer moisture and humidity contributed to heavy rainfall/flash flooding and precipitation loading within consolidating convection. While the deep layer flow and shear were somewhat modest, ambient vertical vorticity just ahead of the MCV and low LCLs aided in the development of two weak, short-lived (EF1) tornadoes in Centre and Perry Counties. Deep moisture (PWAT) values around two inches along with relatively slow, south-to-north training cells and bands produced significant flash flooding, particularly in DuBois and Beech Creek which sustained extensive flood damages due localized 4-6+ inch rainfall amounts. Both towns were declared a State of Emergency. The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record. An 86-year old man was swept away and killed by the rising flood waters in Beech Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the Danville area (Mahoning Township). Several secondary roads were closed due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCV and broader mid-level trough crossed the central Appalachians and triggered strong to severe thunderstorms from the central ridges into the Susquehanna River Valley during the afternoon and evening. Very high boundary layer moisture and humidity contributed to heavy rainfall/flash flooding and precipitation loading within consolidating convection. While the deep layer flow and shear were somewhat modest, ambient vertical vorticity just ahead of the MCV and low LCLs aided in the development of two weak, short-lived (EF1) tornadoes in Centre and Perry Counties. Deep moisture (PWAT) values around two inches along with relatively slow, south-to-north training cells and bands produced significant flash flooding, particularly in DuBois and Beech Creek which sustained extensive flood damages due localized 4-6+ inch rainfall amounts. Both towns were declared a State of Emergency. The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record. An 86-year old man was swept away and killed by the rising flood waters in Beech Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains of 4-6 inches in an hour caused significant flash flooding in the Beech Creek area. The flash flooding extended northeast along Route 150 into Mill Hall. The heavy rains and flood waters inundated the Beech Creek area, which resulted in a State of Emergency and Disaster Declaration due to numerous roads closed/damaged and covered in debris from flood waters. Many of the road closures and damage was confined in Beech Creek Township. More than 30 miles of roadway, including drainage culverts and bridges, were affected by the flooding. ||One home in the Beech Creek area was destroyed and another sustained major damage. An additional 14 homes also sustained minor damage. Flood-related damages totaled over 10 million dollars. ||An 86-year-old man was swept away by rising flood waters along Bald Eagle Creek while trying to rescue his ATV. His body was found two days later on Saturday, June 29, 2013 by kayakers. ||The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCV and broader mid-level trough crossed the central Appalachians and triggered strong to severe thunderstorms from the central ridges into the Susquehanna River Valley during the afternoon and evening. Very high boundary layer moisture and humidity contributed to heavy rainfall/flash flooding and precipitation loading within consolidating convection. While the deep layer flow and shear were somewhat modest, ambient vertical vorticity just ahead of the MCV and low LCLs aided in the development of two weak, short-lived (EF1) tornadoes in Centre and Perry Counties. Deep moisture (PWAT) values around two inches along with relatively slow, south-to-north training cells and bands produced significant flash flooding, particularly in DuBois and Beech Creek which sustained extensive flood damages due localized 4-6+ inch rainfall amounts. Both towns were declared a State of Emergency. The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record. An 86-year old man was swept away and killed by the rising flood waters in Beech Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains inundated the DuBois area with over 5 inches of rain in a 2-3 hour period from late morning into the early afternoon. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell at the city's sewage treatment plant, which was consistent with radar-derived storm total precipitation estimates.  This resulted in historic flash flooding and closed all roads coming into and going out of the DuBois area. A state of emergency and disaster declaration was issued for Clearfield County and the DuBois area in the wake of widespread flooding. Preliminary damages related to the flooding are estimated around $15 million dollars. ||The flash flooding closed dozens of roads in the northwestern portion of Clearfield County and the DuBois area. The road closures included Route 255 (East DuBois Avenue) from the intersection with McCracken Run Road in DuBois City to Penfield, Route 4003 (Mine Road) between the intersection of Route 410 (Shamokin Trail) and the intersection with Route 4002 (Stanley Bottom Road) in Brady Township, Route 3009 (McGees Mills Road) between the intersection with Buhite Road and the intersection with Grant Road in Brady Township, Dixon Avenue, Jared Street, East Maloney Road near the railroad tracks, Simpson Avenue, Platt Road, Clear Run Road and Pifer Street. DuBois City Manager John Suplizio said that the whole city was hit hard but the lower parts were devastated. Those areas include Chestnut Street, Dixon Avenue, Jared Street, The Flats, Pentz Run, Daly Street, Locust Street, Hamor Street, Sandy Street, DuBois Street and adjacent areas.||Sandy Lick Creek and Tannery Dam overflowed which contributed to the widespread flooding and road closures. The Sandy Township swift water rescue team along with other local fire departments performed over 30 rescues. More than 130 people were taken to the DuBois Area High School where a shelter was set up.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms over northern Ohio and southeast Ontario tracked eastward across central Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening. Moderate instability and  favorable winds aloft maintained the severe storms which produced damaging winds and excessive rainfall. Very wet antecedent conditions coupled with the heavy thunderstorm rains resulted in areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains flooded and closed portions of Route 36 and 219 near Mahaffey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A week after a flash flood even in eastern Erie County, another heavy rain event came through with 3 to 5 inches of rain. The hardest hit areas were Summit, McKean, and Greene Townships in eastern Erie County. The City of Erie also suffered some flash flooding as a major thruway was cut off by high water. Four hikers were rescued in a gorge as the creek rose quickly, but no injuries were reported. The rain event was caused by short wave trough over the region, with northwest Pennsylvania situated in the warm sector with dew points in the lower 60s. Some overrunning, training, and lift associated with the higher topography in the region supported high rainfall amounts which fell over an 18 hour period. Rainfall from the week before kept the soil conditions wet, and flash flood guidance was as low as 0.65 for 1 hour rainfall during the event. The observed rainfall rates were not notable, however one observer reported over 2/hr at one point when a heavier cell moved over Greene Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall measured between 4 and 5 inches feel over Greene, Summit, and McKean Townships in eastern Erie County on the 6th. This heavy rain, over saturated ground, produced widespread flooding. Elk Creek in McKean Township came out of it's banks and inundated a basement and garage at two different homes on Rick Road. Hamot Road was washed out on one side requiring road crews to make repairs. The water depth was estimated at a depth of three feet on some roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms over northern Ohio and southeast Ontario tracked eastward across central Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening. Moderate instability and  favorable winds aloft maintained the severe storms which produced damaging winds and excessive rainfall. Very wet antecedent conditions coupled with the heavy thunderstorm rains resulted in areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding around State College. A few vehicles were stranded in standing water on Atherton Street near the bus terminal. This section of Atherton Street was briefly impassable. Thompson Run came out of its banks and closed the eastbound lane of College Avenue in front of the Your Building Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCV and broader mid-level trough crossed the central Appalachians and triggered strong to severe thunderstorms from the central ridges into the Susquehanna River Valley during the afternoon and evening. Very high boundary layer moisture and humidity contributed to heavy rainfall/flash flooding and precipitation loading within consolidating convection. While the deep layer flow and shear were somewhat modest, ambient vertical vorticity just ahead of the MCV and low LCLs aided in the development of two weak, short-lived (EF1) tornadoes in Centre and Perry Counties. Deep moisture (PWAT) values around two inches along with relatively slow, south-to-north training cells and bands produced significant flash flooding, particularly in DuBois and Beech Creek which sustained extensive flood damages due localized 4-6+ inch rainfall amounts. Both towns were declared a State of Emergency. The Bald Eagle Creek at Beech Creek Station surged nearly 8 feet in 4 hours and crested just below major flood stage. The creek officially crested at 13.75 feet which was the sixth highest crest on record. An 86-year old man was swept away and killed by the rising flood waters in Beech Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused urbanized flash flooding around Harrisburg and Penbrook. Further north, flash flooding closed a section of Route 209 in Upper Paxton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornadic storm moved through Union City on the evening of the 28th. Heavy rain accompanied this storm with a 15 minute ASOS rain gage reading of 0.65. The storm total rain the river basin that Union City resides in was approximately 4. Significant flooding accompanied the tornado damage in Union City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Union City resides between two branches of the French Creek. The West Branch of the French Creek is located to the north and west of town and has a reservoir just before the confluence with the southern branch. The reservoir was constructed to retain excess runoff, mainly from spring snow melt. The reservoir water levels jumped over 30 feet as a result of the rain from this storm. Despite this, the southern branch of the French Creek, which runs through the southern part of town, came up quick and high. No gages are available on that tributary, but most of the flood damage was along this creek. The flooding that resulted was widespread through Union Township and the borough. Due to a road washout on Odell Street Ext. There were 7 rescues conducted with use of the fire truck ladder extended across the raging water. The flood damage was estimated over $100,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours to occur in southeast Pennsylvania during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 1.0 and 3.5 inches in many areas in and around the local Philadelphia area and marred traveling plans on this Labor Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flash flooding in central Bucks County affecting Bedminster, Plumstead and Tinicum Townships  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 4 inches in sections of those townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours to occur in southeast Pennsylvania during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 1.0 and 3.5 inches in many areas in and around the local Philadelphia area and marred traveling plans on this Labor Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Skywarn spotter reported that thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding along sections of Cobbs Creek bordering Delaware County.  While there are no established flood stages for gages along Cobbs Creek, it crested at 7.67 feet at Noon EDT on the 2nd at Lincoln Highway/City Avenue (U.S. Route 1) and at 13.72 feet at the Mount Moriah Cemetery at 215 p.m. EDT on the 2nd. Event precipitation totals included 1.89 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours to occur in southeast Pennsylvania during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 1.0 and 3.5 inches in many areas in and around the local Philadelphia area and marred traveling plans on this Labor Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding in eastern and southeastern parts of Philadelphia. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 1 to 2 inches within the city.  Event precipitation totals included 1.89 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours to occur in southeast Pennsylvania during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Event precipitation totals reached between 1.0 and 3.5 inches in many areas in and around the local Philadelphia area and marred traveling plans on this Labor Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding across central Delaware County with Springfield and Upper Darby Townships affected the hardest.  In Springfield Township, flash flooding along the Stony Creek backed into storm drains in the parking lot of BJ's Wholesalers on Woodland Avenue. The water reached up to five feet high and completely submerged some vehicles. About twenty water rescues were performed as fifty vehicles were affected in the parking lot.  Seven fire companies responded to the flooding. Specialized rescue boat water units were used to rescue people from their vehicles. Numerous roadways were flooded in the township and neighboring Upper Darby Township. One vehicle was swept into a flooded creek. The intersections of Normandy and Marshall Roads, Copley and Marshall Roads and Lansdowne Avenue and State Road were all flooded and closed for several hours. In Middletown Township, several water rescues occurred in the Lima area.  A Skywarn spotter also reported flooding along Cobbs Creek bordering Philadelphia.   Event precipitation totals included 3.59 inches in Swarthmore, 2.85 inches in Havertown, 2.00 inches in Drexel Hill and 1.89 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Allentown during the evening of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The second straight day of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused roadway and small creek flash flooding in Allentown and Whitehall Township. Numerous roadways were flooded with some water rescues from trapped vehicles. A child nearly was swept away in the flood waters before being rescued by an adult. Manhole covers popped. About 43 vehicles were badly damaged in the flooding in the West End of Allentown and several businesses were flooded. Flood damage in the area also occurred to homes, garages and basements. No serious injuries were reported. About 2200 people were sheltered in place at the Allentown Fair off of Liberty Street in the city because the entrances and exits to the fairground were flooded. The Zac Brown Band had to cut their concert short. Fair goers were able to leave later that evening.  Damage to the fair was limited to grass and gravel erosion. Elsewhere in the city, vehicles were trapped in flood waters on Sumner Avenue, 22nd and Allen Street, 13th and Liberty Street and 18th and Tilghman Street. About ten homes around 22nd and Allen Street had water in their basements and the electricity was turned off for precautionary reasons.  Event precipitation totals included 1.26 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trof helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours during the morning of the 9th in the Poconos and Monroe County in particular. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 6 inches in the southeastern two-thirds of Monroe County. This caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding. The runoff from the heavy rain caused the Delaware River water levels to be higher than average. The next day (the 10th) a 30-year-old man drowned in the river while tubing with about 10 other people off of Kingwood in Hunterdon County. They were tubing across the river toward Tinicum in Bucks County when he went into the river.  Investigators say he was about fifteen feet from the shoreline when he fell off the tube and went missing. Divers searching for the body over the next week were hampered by the high water levels and poor visibilities and additional heavy rain.
