His body was apparently found on August 31st on a small island in the Delaware River. Lower Makefield (Bucks County) police were called to a report of a body on an island one mile north of the Calhoun Street Bridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage as well as small stream flash flooding in Monroe County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3.5 and 6.0 inches in an axis from Chestnuthill and Tunkhannock Townships northeastward through Price and Middle Smithfield Townships. Measured event precipitation totals included 3.29 inches in Stroudsburg, 3.02 inches in Reeders, 2.57 inches in McMichaels and 2.52 inches in East Stroudsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm over northern Columbia County produced heavy rain and localized flash flooding during the early morning hours on the 2nd. The flooding was confined to the Sugarloaf Township/Benton area. Later that day, intense rainfall produced flash flooding in Northern Cambria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported in the Sugarloaf Township/Benton and Stillwater areas.  A washout was reported on Beech Glen Road which blocked one lane of traffic.  Agricultural flooding was also reported, and a pumpkin patch reported significant losses due to the high water.  A small mudslide and downed trees occurred along a section of State Route 239. This caused the road to be restricted to a single lane until approximately 0400 EDT while PA D.O.T. cleared the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and moist air mass for early September helped scattered thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening. Isolated flooding and wind damage were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 991 Call Center reported flash flooding on Verona Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and moist air mass for early September helped scattered thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening. Isolated flooding and wind damage were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Freeport Road Closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and moist air mass for early September helped scattered thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening. Isolated flooding and wind damage were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Low Grade Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and moist air mass for early September helped scattered thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening. Isolated flooding and wind damage were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported 4 feet of water along Railroad Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in the southeastern part of Berks County.  Event precipitation totals included 2.82 inches in Reading, 2.66 inches in Wyomissing, 2.39 inches in Mohnton, 2.28 inches in Wernersville and 2.27 inches in Sinking Spring.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in Chester County and then led to flooding along the east branch and the main stem of the Brandywine Creek that lasted into the night of the 13th. The heaviest precipitation for this event fell in Chester County.  About 30 vehicles became stuck in flood waters and five water rescues were performed. A mudslide occurred on the Pennsylvania Turnpike near mile marker 318 near Chester Springs. The Valley Creek at Valley Forge had major flooding and was above its 7 foot flood stage from 705 a.m. EDT through 214 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 12.82 feet at 945 a.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 6.53 inches in Coatesville, 4.24 inches in Chesterbrook, 4.15 inches in Downingtown, 3.73 inches in Tredyfrrin, 3.14 inches in Unionville and 2.65 inches in West Chester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave crossing the region helped support for the development of showers and thunderstorms a few of which became severe. However, the bigger threat was heavy rain, as there was plenty of low level moisture to support one to two inch an hour rain rates. Once cell in particular produced 3+ inches of rain as it slowly moved southward across Venango, Indiana, Westmoreland, and Armstrong counties in Pennsylvania and Garrett county in Maryland. The towns along the Kiskiminetas River; Apollo, Vandergrift, and Gilpin were hit particularly hard by flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused several roads to be closed in southern Armstrong County, including Route 66 from Ford City southward. 4 feet of water was over Route 66th in Apollo causing tractor trailers to get stuck. In addition, several residents on Glade Run Road had to evacuate their residences by boat. In total, over 200 homes sustained flood damage, mainly to basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of rain with embedded thunderstorms caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and upper Bucks County and poor drainage flooding in Philadelphia as well as brief minor flooding along the Frankford Creek on the 28th. The rain started during the morning of the 28th, fell at its heaviest around Noon EDT and ended during the early evening of the 28th. Rainfall amounts varied across east central and southeast Pennsylvania, but averaged between 1 and 3 inches in most places. The precipitation formed and rode along a stationary front over Pennsylvania and New Jersey. This boundary started to sag southward during the late afternoon and night as a low pressure system that formed along the boundary passed south of Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage and roadway flooding from Allentown southward in Lehigh County. The heavy rain fell so quickly that manhole covers were popping. Roadway flooding, stranded vehicles and water rescues in Allentown were reported on Mack Boulevard, Basin and Auburn Streets, Elmo Street, Mohawk Street and South 4th, 8th and 12th Streets.  Farther to the south, Pennsylvania State Route 309 was flooded and closed in Upper Saucon Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.91 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 1.64 inches in Orefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding, particularly in the northern half of Delaware County. The Blue Route (Interstate 476) was flooded. The runoff from the heavy rain also led to flooding along the main stem of the Brandywine Creek.  The Crum Creek at Newtown Square had moderate flooding and was above its 6 foot flood stage from 906 a.m. EDT through 158 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 9.40 feet at 1115 a.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 3.10 inches in Wayne, 2.50 inches in Newtown Square and 1.72 inches in Aston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of rain with embedded thunderstorms caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and upper Bucks County and poor drainage flooding in Philadelphia as well as brief minor flooding along the Frankford Creek on the 28th. The rain started during the morning of the 28th, fell at its heaviest around Noon EDT and ended during the early evening of the 28th. Rainfall amounts varied across east central and southeast Pennsylvania, but averaged between 1 and 3 inches in most places. The precipitation formed and rode along a stationary front over Pennsylvania and New Jersey. This boundary started to sag southward during the late afternoon and night as a low pressure system that formed along the boundary passed south of Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage and roadway flooding in Bethlehem. Flash flooding isolated forty homes around Pennsylvania State Route 412 in the city. Event precipitation totals included 2.91 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding, particularly in the lower half of Montgomery County. Emergency personnel responded to around 30 calls for assistance from motorists trapped in their flooded vehicles. In Norristown, four roadways (including Trooper Road and Van Buren Avenue) and underpasses were flooded and closed. A construction barge broke free on Stony Creek at two workers were rescued. in Hatboro, flooding along the Pennypack Creek reached into the parking lot of the Robert Bruce Apartments. Gulph Road was flooded in King of Prussia. The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington had major flooding and was above its 9 foot flood stage from 830 a..m. EDT through 313 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 12.35 feet at 1230 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 3.98 inches in West Norriton, 3.81 inches in Blue Bell, 3.56 inches in Fort Washington and 3.48 inches in North Wales.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of rain with embedded thunderstorms caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and upper Bucks County and poor drainage flooding in Philadelphia as well as brief minor flooding along the Frankford Creek on the 28th. The rain started during the morning of the 28th, fell at its heaviest around Noon EDT and ended during the early evening of the 28th. Rainfall amounts varied across east central and southeast Pennsylvania, but averaged between 1 and 3 inches in most places. The precipitation formed and rode along a stationary front over Pennsylvania and New Jersey. This boundary started to sag southward during the late afternoon and night as a low pressure system that formed along the boundary passed south of Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as roadway flooding in upper Bucks County in and around Quakertown. Flooding was reported along Pennsylvania State Route 309. Event precipitation totals included 1.60 inches in Quakertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in western Bucks County.  Vehicle rescues were performed in Southampton. The Little Neshaminy Creek at Neshaminy was above its 8 foot flood stage from 1029 a.m. EDT through 153 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 8.98 feet at Noon EDT. Event precipitation totals included 2.86 inches in Penndel, 2.17 inches in Warrington and 1.94 inches in Quakertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in Berks County and southeastern Pennsylvania on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 7.0 inches, highest in Chester and Montgomery Counties. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected sections of the Brandywine and Wissahickon basins.  Major flooding occurred along sections of the Wissahickon and Valley Creeks. Vehicle water rescues were performed in Chester, Montgomery and lower Bucks Counties. The AAA of Mid-Atlantic reported a 60 percent increase in assistance calls. Because the torrential rain coincided with the morning commute, traffic on some interstates were backed up for hours. SEPTA commuter regional rail lines experienced on average thirty minute system-wide delays through the morning.  Arrival delays to Philadelphia International Airport reached 90 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding as well as creek flooding within Philadelphia.  Flooding occurred along the Frankford, Pennypack and Wissahickon Creeks. A teenager was rescued from the Pennypack Creek in the Holmesburg section of the city. Extensive flooding snarled traffic along the Schuylkill Expressway. Lincoln Drive along the Wissahickon Creek was flooded in both directions and closed.  The Wissahickon Environmental Center Camp was cancelled because of flooding. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue had moderate flooding and was above its 7 foot flood stage twice from 820 a.m. EDT through 1011 a.m. EDT on the 13th. Its highest crest was 8.85 feet at 830 a.m. EDT. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge crested at 8.87 feet at 345 p.m. EDT.  The Wissahickon Creek at its mouth crested at 7.23 feet at 415 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 2.20 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport and 1.93 inches in Northeast Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms tied to a surface front  dropped several inches of rain over northwest Pennsylvania the morning of the 27th. Particularly hit hard were Jefferson and adjacent Clearfield counties, were roads were made impassable by over four to six inches of rainfall. The local EMA Director stated there were 49 water rescues and 50 people were placed in shelters. The hardest hit areas include Punxsutawney, Sykesville, Stump Creek, Big Run. and Reynoldsville. Preliminary damage reports have a total of 347 homes and 34 businesses damaged by flood waters. Of those, nine homes were destroyed and three businesses were a total loss. Damage is already estimated to be about $3 million but could be upwards of $5 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported that State Route 219 at Old Gray Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding at State Street and St Clair Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front and upper level trough pushed across the Upper Ohio Valley on July 10th producing widespread severe weather and flash flooding from eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, and western Pennsylvania. This included 3 separate tornadoes. One tornado occurred in Lawrence county, PA, with 2 additional tornadoes across portions of Tuscarawas and Carroll counties in Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Tropical Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in Berks County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches in sections of the county.   Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. In fact, it was the wettest June on record in Philadelphia (10.56 inches)  and the 6th wettest June on record in Allentown (6.83 inches). On a county weighted average, June monthly precipitation ranged from 6.9 inches in Berks County to 10.4 inches in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of small creeks (including Willow Creek) as well as roadway flooding (including Main Street) in Fleetwood. Event precipitation total in Fleetwood was 2.96 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training bands of locally heavy rain impacted parts of the middle Susquehanna Valley during the late morning and early afternoon. A deep east-southeast flow from the Atlantic pulled high moisture into the region around an upper-level low rotating northward from MD/VA. Rainfall rates of 1-2/hour were common with localized rainfall rates as high as 4/hour. Several locations around the Lewisburg, Selinsgrove and Sunbury areas picked up between 2-3 inches of rain over a short duration. Urbanization combined with the intense rains lead to flash flooding along SR 11 and the closure of Reagan/Hamilton underpasses near Sunbury. Small streams including Bull Run and Turtle Creek also came out of their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding closed the Reagan and Hamilton underpasses near Sunbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia in a hot and humid air mass with weak upper level winds. A few storms became severe, and heavy rainfall produced some flash flooding and areal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding with a swamped vehicle, as well as water flowing into a business.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm clusters across western Pennsylvania organized into bowing line segments as they moved east-southeast across the southern Alleghenies and Laurel Highlands during the late afternoon and early evening. The line of storms produced isolated wind damage and sub-severe hail. A more discrete thunderstorm cell just ahead of the main line of storms produced a brief, weak EF0 tornado in Somerset County. An area of locally heavy rain produced flash flooding in York County during the late evening, with areal flooding persisting into the early morning on 8/8.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains produced flash flooding across portions of southern York County during the late evening and early overnight hours. Spotter reports indicated  two inches of rain fell in about 1 hour. Street flooding was reported in Hanover. A water rescue was conducted at the intersection of Seven Valleys Road (State Route 616) and Maple Street in North Codorus Township. A motorist drove her car into Codorus Creek which has flooded over the road. Emergency responders were able to rescue both occupants of the stranded vehicle. This section of the road along Codorus Creek was closed for much of the night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm clusters associated with a passing cold front and upper level disturbance produced significant urban flooding around the Scranton metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was major urban flooding taking place with ditches and storm drains spilling over and flooding streets. Water was flowing into homes in some parts of the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm clusters associated with a passing cold front and upper level disturbance produced significant urban flooding around the Scranton metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major urban flooding was occurring in the Throop, Jessup, Archbald, Simpson and Jermyn areas. City streets and secondary roads were flooded with cars stuck in the water and water flowing into homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated and slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding in the South Hills of Pittsburgh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported 2 vehicles stuck in flash flooding of the I-376 exit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated and slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding in the South Hills of Pittsburgh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding at Swallow Hill Road and Greentree Road with one trapped stranded vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated and slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding in the South Hills of Pittsburgh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bower Hill Volunteer Fire department in Scott reported 27 water emergencies due to flash flooding in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated and slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding in the South Hills of Pittsburgh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a person trapped in vehicle form rising water near Carnegie. Numerous roads quickly flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash floding with water up to homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding on several portions Route 58.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding with 2 feet of water flowing across Route 322 between Brookville and Reynoldsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 2 feet of water flowing across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported water up to 2 feet flowing in portions of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported parts of Route 119 closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved slowly along a stalled boundary, and produced very heavy rain and flash flooding over Fayette county during the early morning of August 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Flash flooding west of Ohiopyle with water flowing over multiple roads and water in some homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved slowly along a stalled boundary, and produced very heavy rain and flash flooding over Fayette county during the early morning of August 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding in Dunbar with Gist Run and Dunbar Creek out of their banks. Water was over Arch Bridge road with debris and cars floating in town. Water was reported in the first floor of some residences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved slowly along a stalled boundary, and produced very heavy rain and flash flooding over Fayette county during the early morning of August 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding in Wharton Township, on Shaffer School Road and Nelson Road near Route 40. Water was reported in some homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved slowly along a stalled boundary, and produced very heavy rain and flash flooding over Fayette county during the early morning of August 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out a bridge over a culvert on Falbo Road in Perry Township. A driver was killed when he drove into the culvert after the bridge had been washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very narrow but intense band of heavy rain remained nearly stationary over downtown State College and produced localized flash flooding during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding prompted road closures due to high water including the eastbound lanes of College Avenue adjacent to Thompson Run in front of the Blaise Alexander auto dealership, Atherton Street from Park Avenue to College Avenue and Orchard Road between Park Avenue and Puddingtown Road. A few cars were stranded in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed well ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some of the thunderstorms were severe, and also produced flash flooding across much of northern Venango county in Pennsylvania, with some flooding in Tuscarawas county Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Buxton Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed well ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some of the thunderstorms were severe, and also produced flash flooding across much of northern Venango county in Pennsylvania, with some flooding in Tuscarawas county Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding with Route 8 closed in Cherry Tree Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system located over southern Ontario along with surface boundaries in the vicinity of northeast Pennsylvania resulted in severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an unstable airmass with severe thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall and flooding. A solitary, long lasting thunderstorm produced in excess of 6 of rain across northwest Susquehanna county. There was significant devastation to the road network, and a trailer park was seriously flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe flash flooding damaged several roads in the area, with significant flooding on County Route 267. Three to four other roads were destroyed and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system located over southern Ontario along with surface boundaries in the vicinity of northeast Pennsylvania resulted in severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an unstable airmass with severe thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall and flooding. A solitary, long lasting thunderstorm produced in excess of 6 of rain across northwest Susquehanna county. There was significant devastation to the road network, and a trailer park was seriously flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe flooding was occurring along County Route 267, rendering it impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system located over southern Ontario along with surface boundaries in the vicinity of northeast Pennsylvania resulted in severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an unstable airmass with severe thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall and flooding. A solitary, long lasting thunderstorm produced in excess of 6 of rain across northwest Susquehanna county. There was significant devastation to the road network, and a trailer park was seriously flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads in the northwest and central part of the county were inundated by flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms impacted the area during the late evening as a strong cold front moved across the region. In an environment characterized by 1.75 to 2 inch PWS, training/slow-moving thunderstorm cells with very heavy rain rates produced isolated flash flooding in Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in Earl Township. Locations that experienced flooding included Bareville, Hinkletown and New Holland. Flood waters closed several secondary roads in the affected areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms produced isolated flash flooding during the evening across the lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding and closed several roads across the county. High water forced several road closures from the west shore area to the Market Street bridge and Lemoyne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system located over southern Ontario along with surface boundaries in the vicinity of northeast Pennsylvania resulted in severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an unstable airmass with severe thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall and flooding. A solitary, long lasting thunderstorm produced in excess of 6 of rain across northwest Susquehanna county. There was significant devastation to the road network, and a trailer park was seriously flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe flash flooding forced the evacuation of a trailer court on Pamela Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms produced isolated flash flooding during the evening across the lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding and closed a section of SR 74 in Spring Township near Landisburg. Small stream and road flooding was also observed in Shermansdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread shower and thunderstorm activity developed across central PA in vicinity of a weak surface boundary as an upper level trough slowly tracked east across the region. Strong southerly flow aided deep moisture transport, sponsoring thunderstorms locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced significant flash flooding, which eventually transitioned into a long-duration flooding event as standing water and road closures persisted into 13 June 2014. The Franklin County EOC was partially activated due to the heavy rainfall. There were two water rescues for stranded vehicles in St. Thomas and Antrim Townships. All occupants in both vehicles were rescued safely. Lincoln Highway WB in St. Thomas Township was closed. The Peckman Bridge in St. Thomas Township is closed due to bridge damage. There were multiple homes flooded in the Red Run Park Subdivision in Washington Township. Flooding impacts in Montgomery Township included Welch Run Road, Ft Loudon Rd, Montgomery Church Road, Mercersburg Road, Hunter Rd, Two Top Rd Blairs Valley Rd, Shimbstown Rd and Punchbowl Intersection of Welch Run Rd. Multiple homes (single family dwellings) experienced flooding. Flooding impacts in Peters Township included the closure of Geibs and McDowell roads with up to 12 inches of standing water on most township roads. Flooding impacts in Antrim Township included closure of the following roads: Gitner Rd; 6700 block and 2800 block of Cold Smith Rd; Rabbit Road South off of Buchannan Trail West. Gilford Township Angle Road was completed submerged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain preceding a cold frontal passage caused flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in and around Philadelphia.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as around 3 inches in Chester County, most of which fell within two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1225 a.m. EDT through 1239 a.m. EDT on the 28th. It crested at 8.27 feet at 1230 a.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 1.43 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport and 1.37 inches in Wyndmoor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain preceding a cold frontal passage caused flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in and around Philadelphia.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as around 3 inches in Chester County, most of which fell within two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Elverson. A tributary to the North Branch of the French Creek flooded South Brick Lane. Flooding likely also occurred near the headwaters of the East Branch of the Conestoga River. A Skywarn spotter measured 2.6 inches in one hour in Elverson. Other event totals included 3.11 inches in Honey Brook, 2.56 inches in Warwick and 2.39 inches in Glenmoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread shower and thunderstorm activity developed across central PA in vicinity of a weak surface boundary as an upper level trough slowly tracked east across the region. Strong southerly flow aided deep moisture transport, sponsoring thunderstorms locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced significant flash flooding, which eventually transitioned into a long-duration flooding event as standing water and road closures persisted into the late evening. The Bedford County EOC was partially activated due to the heavy rainfall and severe storms. Flash flooding closed the following roads:  Route 4032 (Reynoldsdale Road) from the intersection of Route 56 to the intersection of Bob���s Creek Road in East Saint Clair Township; Route 4019 (Bobs Creek Road/Reynoldsdale Road/Imler Valley Road) from the intersection of Short |Cut Road in East Saint Clair Township to the Blair County Line in Kimmel Township; Route 4017 (Pine Grove Church Road/Indian Eve Road) from the intersection of Route 56 to the intersection of Reynoldsdale Road in East Saint Clair Township; Route 4016 (Bethel Hollow Road) from the intersection of Shaffer Mountain Road to the intersection of Route 96 in Napier Township; Route 2017 (Main Road/Diehl Road) in Bedford County is closed from the intersection of Main Road in Colerain Township to the intersection of Route 326 and Egolf Road in Snake Spring Township; Route 2014 (Main Road) in Bedford County is closed from the intersection of Main Road and Diehl |Road and the intersection of Route 326 and Golf Road in Colerain Township and Route 326 in Bedford County is closed from the intersection of Route 2014 SH to the intersection of Route 326 and Route 2017 in Colerain Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain preceding a cold frontal passage caused flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in and around Philadelphia.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as around 3 inches in Chester County, most of which fell within two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Pottstown. A water rescue occurred on College Drive near the Manatawny Creek.  Event precipitation totals included 2.28 inches in Perkiomen, 1.95 inches in Collegeville, 1.87 inches in Harlesville and 1.55 inches in Pottstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread shower and thunderstorm activity developed across central PA in vicinity of a weak surface boundary as an upper level trough slowly tracked east across the region. Strong southerly flow aided deep moisture transport, sponsoring thunderstorms locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding during the late evening and into the overnight period on 12-13 June 2014. The flooding closed roads including portions of SR 62, SR 6 and SR 59. Other secondary road closures included but were not limited to Dutchman Road in Mead Township and Chapman Dam Road near Clarendon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread shower and thunderstorm activity developed across central PA in vicinity of a weak surface boundary as an upper level trough slowly tracked east across the region. Strong southerly flow aided deep moisture transport, sponsoring thunderstorms locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produce flash flooding and closed Palo Alto Road near Wellersburg in extreme southeast Somerset County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Salisbury Township. This caused numerous flooded roads as well as a couple of road washouts. Sections of the Trout Creek and Black River flooded. Event precipitation totals included 1.57 inches in Breinigsville, 1.39 inches in Macungie and 1.31 inches at the Allentown Queen City Airport. Most of this rain fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist boundary layer coupled with strong heating/instability resulted in heavy showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon. PW values near 2 inches were pooled ahead of a cold front that approached the area from the lower Great Lakes region. The high moisture content of the airmass in place along with some training and interaction with topography promoted intense rainfall rates and excessive rainfall amounts - which lead to localized flash flooding over portions of southeast PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in the Lancaster areas of Eden Heights and Rossmere. Flood waters impacted homes on Carlton Drive/Rockford Lane and closed a section of the Lititz Pike at Keller Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist boundary layer coupled with strong heating/instability resulted in heavy showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon. PW values near 2 inches were pooled ahead of a cold front that approached the area from the lower Great Lakes region. The high moisture content of the airmass in place along with some training and interaction with topography promoted intense rainfall rates and excessive rainfall amounts - which lead to localized flash flooding over portions of southeast PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding near Red Lion and Craley. Flood waters damaged and closed West Broadway and South Main Street in Red Lion. Bull Run came out of its banks and flooded Bull Run Road near Craley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in Center City Philadelphia.  Storm drains could not keep up with the run-off near Thomas Jefferson University Hospital at the intersection of 12th and Chestnut Streets. Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport and 1.86 inches in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of weak low pressure around the Northern Great Lakes and an upper level disturbance passing over portions of eastern Pennsylvania produced scattered strong thunderstorms with heavy rainfall that resulted in areas of flash flooding and poor drainage flooding from the late evening of the 21st into the early morning of the 22nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to around 4 inches across portions of eastern Pennsylvania, especially in Northampton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in Northampton County. Road closures were reported in Forks Township and Belfast. A sinkhole developed at the intersection of Freemansburg Avenue and Emrick Boulevard in Bethlehem Township. Entire event precipitation totals included 4.12 inches in Nazareth, 3.56 inches in Palmer Township, 3.22 inches in Plainfield Township, 2.47 inches in Martins Creek, and 2.05 inches in Bethlehem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of cold fronts triggered scattered thunderstorms over southeast PA during the afternoon on 5-6 September 2014. Deep moisture combined with strong instability and relatively slow storm motions/training to produce torrential rains and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding and prompted water rescues near Kinzers and Gap.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms that formed near a stalled frontal boundary along the Pennsylvania border caused flooding in Chester County overnight on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding as well as smaller creek flash flooding in Downingtown.  In Downingtown, flash flooding occurred along Green Street. One vehicle was stalled in the flood waters.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3.5 inches in central Chester County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in Berks County during the early evening of the 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused roadway and creek flash flooding in western Reading and Wyomissing around the Wyomissing Creek. Vehicles were stranded in flood waters near the Spring Street subway in Reading. Event precipitation totals included 2.69 inches in Wyomissing and 2.62 inches in Reading.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and small creeks in Reading.  Several motorists were stranded within the flood waters. Spring Street was flooded and closed. The subway was submerged. Other roadways that were flooded included the Warren Street Bypass (Pennsylvania State Route 12). Event precipitation totals included 2.07 inches within Reading and 2.05 inches at the Reading Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nocturnal convective complex brought training thunderstorms to north-central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours. A localized 3-5 inches of rain fell over a 8-10 hour period which resulted in significant flash flooding in Elk and northern Clearfield Counties. Flash flooding, to a lesser extent, also occurred in adjacent Warren and Cameron Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding caused several road closures and flooded basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nocturnal convective complex brought training thunderstorms to north-central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours. A localized 3-5 inches of rain fell over a 8-10 hour period which resulted in significant flash flooding in Elk and northern Clearfield Counties. Flash flooding, to a lesser extent, also occurred in adjacent Warren and Cameron Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused significant life-threatening flash flooding in central Elk County focused on the Borough of Ridgway. Major flooding occurred on the Clarion River at Ridgway, where the river crested at 21.67 feet - second highest crest on record. The flooding was life-threatening with numerous water rescues and evacuations in Elk County. A flash flood emergency was declared for Elk County during the height of the flash flooding. Elk County was declared a disaster area after flooding caused significant damage to homes and businesses. Multiple roads were closed due to high water including portions of Routes 120, 219, 255, 948, 1009, 2003, 2007 and 3002. Approximately 25 homes and up to 10 commercial buildings sustained first floor flooding. Ridgway Borough evacuated approximately 100 people from a high rise apartment at 101 North Mill Avenue to Central Fire Hall. Saint Leos Church School was evacuated.  Other schools throughout the county conducted early dismissals. Other areas impacted by the flooding included St. Mary's, Johnsonburg, Byrnedale, James City, Wilcox, Weedville, Kersey and Elbon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nocturnal convective complex brought training thunderstorms to north-central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours. A localized 3-5 inches of rain fell over a 8-10 hour period which resulted in significant flash flooding in Elk and northern Clearfield Counties. Flash flooding, to a lesser extent, also occurred in adjacent Warren and Cameron Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding caused several road closures and flooded basements. The Penfield Elementary School was evacuated due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller creeks in Muhlenberg Township. Two vehicles were trapped in flood waters on North Fifth Street Highway near the Plaza 222 Shopping Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller creeks in and around Wyomissing. At least one vehicle was stranded in flood waters on State Hill Road near Bern Road in Wyomissing. Event precipitation total was 2.20 inches in Wyomissing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours also caused flash flooding of roadways and small creeks in New Hanover Township. Flooding was reported along North Charlotte Street and Kleman Road near the Minister Creek. Event precipitation totals included 3.65 inches in Pottstown, 3.19 inches in Gilbertsville and 2.34 inches at the Pottstown Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of small creeks and poor drainage flooding in Lehigh County. In Allentown, heavy flooding was reported on Lehigh Street and around the intersection of U.S. Route 22 and MacArthur Road. In Emmaus, flood waters from the Leibert Creek inundated Indian Creek Road.  Event precipitation totals included 3.31 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 1.80 inches in Schnecksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville. The creek crested at 4.33 feet at 645 p.m. EDT on the 13th. Event precipitation totals included 2.95 inches in East Greenville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused poor drain flash flooding in eastern Northampton County. A water rescue was performed in Palmer Township on South 25th Street at the Easton High School.  Event precipitation totals included 3.62 inches in Forks Township, 3.34 inches in Martins Creek, 3.31 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 2.55 inches in Glendon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain preceding a cold frontal passage caused flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania in and around Philadelphia.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as around 3 inches in Chester County, most of which fell within two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Upper Providence Township in the Mingo Creek Basin. Roboda Boulevard and Springer Town Road were flooded and closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.28 inches in Perkiomen, 1.95 inches in Collegeville, 1.87 inches in Harlesville and 1.55 inches in Pottstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm coupled with wet antecedent conditions caused isolated flash flooding in Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding in eastern Chester County centered on East and West Whiteland Townships. In the Exton section of West Whiteland Township, flash flooding along the Valley Creek spilled onto parts of South Whitford Road and Commerce Drive. Dopper Radar storm total estimates reached between 1 and 2 inches in the county, most of which fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in Bristol Township. Numerous roadways were flooded near the Delaware River and included Radcliffe Street, Farragut Street and Wilson Street.  Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport, 2.01 inches in Warrington, 1.96 inches in Newtown and 1.92 inches in Jamison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Pennypack Creek. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage from 852 p.m. EDT through 910 p.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 7.43 feet at 9 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport and 1.86 inches in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding on the campus of the Lower Bucks Hospital in Bristol Township. Flood waters started to cascade from the parking lots into the hospital's staircases. No patients had to be evacuated. Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport, 2.01 inches in Warrington, 1.96 inches in Newtown and 1.92 inches in Jamison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms moved over portions of northwest Pennsylvania form June 16th through the 18th. A line of training thunderstorms on the evening of the 18th produced radar estimated rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches over portions of Crawford County. Hail and strong winds also occurred with these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two portions of RT 173 was washed out when the Little Sugar Creek came out of it's banks in two separate locations. The washouts occurred on Bell Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary focused slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain in south Philadelphia and caused urban flash flooding during the evening commute. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 inches in the southern sections of the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in southern Philadelphia. Water was waist high in both directions on Interstate 95 at the Broad Street Tunnel. Numerous vehicles were stranded. Precipitation total was 2.56 inches at the Philadelphia International, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused two water rescues involving occupied vehicles in Norristown. One vehicle was stuck on U.S. Route 202/Markley Street. Three persons were rescued from that vehicle unharmed. A second vehicle was trapped in flood waters at the intersection of East Lafayette Street and Walnut Street. One person was rescued unharmed. The precipitation event total in Norristown was 2.13 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Tannery Run along East Butler Avenue in Ambler Borough. The borough police station was also flooded. The precipitation event total in Ambler Borough was 2.84 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Wissahickon Creek which resulted in the closure of Locust Street.  The precipitation event total in Ambler Borough was 2.84 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Wissahickon Creek. The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington (Upper Dublin Township) crested at 10.23 feet at 815 p.m. EDT on the 9th. Event precipitation totals included 2.84 inches in Ambler, 2.51 inches in Blue Bell and 1.73 inches in Fort Washington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along the Tacony Creek. The Tookany Creek Parkway was closed in Cheltenham Township between Jenkintown Road and Central Avenue. Roadways were also flooded in Elkins Park and Abington. Event precipitation totals included 2.51 inches in Blue Bell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across Eastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 13th. This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across the Philadelphia northwest suburbs from the afternoon of the 12th into the early morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation amounts averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and Montgomery County that afternoon and early evening. In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow, fresh water runoff and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the overnight high tide cycle on the 13th along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and small creeks in Upper Pottsgrove Township. Flooding was reported along Pine Ford Road at Pennsylvania State Route 100 near the headwaters of Sprogels Run and a tributary of the Manatawny Creek. Event precipitation totals included 3.65 inches in Pottstown, 3.19 inches in Gilbertsville and 2.34 inches at the Pottstown Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 845 p.m. EDT through 925 p.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 8.71 feet at 9 p.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia Airport and 1.86 inches in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved slowly along a stalled boundary, and produced very heavy rain and flash flooding over Fayette county during the early morning of August 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported water in homes and water flowing across roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and far southeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were a couple of corridors of very heavy rain: one across the lower Lehigh Valley, a second across central Montgomery and Bucks Counties and the third and heaviest along the Delaware River in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. In this last band, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the other two bands, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 1.5 and 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in south central Lehigh County. Several roadways were flooded in Allentown, South Whitehall Township, Emmaus and Upper Saucon Township.  Vehicles stalled trying to cross the flood waters.  In Allentown, this included one vehicle that became stuck in flood waters under a railroad bridge on South 8th Street. Flooded roadways included Walbert Avenue and Cedar Crest Boulevard in South Whitehall Township and Lehigh Street in Emmaus.  Event precipitation totals included 1.57 inches in Breinigsville, 1.39 inches in Macungie and 1.31 inches at the Allentown Queen City Airport. Most of this rain fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm moist air ahead of a slow moving cold front supported storms with torrential rain June 23rd through midday on the 25th. Numerous thunderstorms produced rainfall amounts around 1 to 2 inches during that time. For areas that saw training thunderstorms rainfall amounts exceeded 4 inches. Heavy rain and floods the week before had kept grounds saturated in many areas, so this additional rainfall was sufficient to cause flash floods.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of storms moved over the Titusville area in southeast Crawford County PA on the night of the 25th. At the Titusville Water Works 3.28 inches of rain was measured. |Route #27 was being closed due to high water right outside the city limits. Basement flooding was reported throughout Titusville and the surrounding area.  Debris in the Oil Creek caused a three inch natural gas pipeline to rupture along Superior Street at the bridge and was repaired by National Fuel Gas Company. Several residents were in need of being rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of cold fronts triggered scattered thunderstorms over southeast PA during the afternoon on 5-6 September 2014. Deep moisture combined with strong instability and relatively slow storm motions/training to produce torrential rains and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains and flash flooding closed SR 441 in Washington Borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level wave moving along a stalled front initiated thunderstorms that produced flash flooding and 2 weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported a vehicle caught in flash flooding with a driver rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused drainage and smaller creek flash flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of the 9th. Event totals where flash flooding occurred reached between two and three inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused a water rescue from a trapped vehicle along the Mill Creek at the intersection of Old Gulph and Williamson Roads in Lower Merion Township.  The single occupant was safely rescued by fire department personnel. The precipitation event total in Lower Merion Township was 2.13 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding closing Snyder Drive in New Sewickley Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Route 356 closed from Labell Vue Drive to Orr Avenue due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front the afternoon of the 18th, with localized flash flooding also occurring into the early morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 6 to 10 inches of water flowing across Route 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front the afternoon of the 18th, with localized flash flooding also occurring into the early morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported flash flooding on Streets Run Road, with numerous stuck vehicles closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front the afternoon of the 18th, with localized flash flooding also occurring into the early morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding with water running into a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported a landslide due to flash flooding along Days Run Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 991 Call Center reported Saxonburg Road closed due to flash flooding near the West Deer Fire Department.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported a bridge washed out with water into some homes along Metz Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported the Locust Street Trailer Court being evacuated due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding from Markle Road to Spring Hollow Road, and Bowman Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported debris from flash flooding on the Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad tracks from previous flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front the afternoon of the 18th, with localized flash flooding also occurring into the early morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on State Route 65 near Sewickley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front the afternoon of the 18th, with localized flash flooding also occurring into the early morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported portions of Route 62 in President Township due to flash flooding causing a mud slide with debris on the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding on Route 173 south of Grove City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding in and around Vandergrift and Apollo Township with some roads washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding on many roadways as well as water into basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported flash flooding on multiple roads in and around Ellwood City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding with 2 to 3 feet of water along parts of Canal Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported Slippery Rock Creek is out of it's banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding reported along Elbrook Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call center reported flash flooding along South Leechburg Hill Road through the intersection of Route 356. One vehicle was standed in high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding from Soap Run Road to Hickernell Road and South Tower Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding along Little Deer Creek with water running into homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Hollowview Road and Aley Hill Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Midvale Road and Foxwood Road under at least 2 feet of water due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported multiple roads closed with a mud slide in and around Darlington to Big Beaver. A mud slide closed Route 551, and some homes were evacuated due to flooding in Darlington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reports Blazer Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
