EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Flooding along Pittsburgh Street and Colfax Street from Springdale to Cheswick. Water was reported in the Sheetz on Pittsburgh Street in Cheswick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding with water quickly flowing over Sample Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported flash flooding with water quickly flowing over Route 51, with some debris from a land slide as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with heavy rainfall developed along a wavy frontal boundary across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania and produced numerous reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Route 981 washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms were widespread across Western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia on the 23rd, ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some thunderstorms were severe, with isolated flash flooding as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported South Mill Street closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms were widespread across Western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia on the 23rd, ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some thunderstorms were severe, with isolated flash flooding as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding with a mobile home park being evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused flash flooding across sections of the Poconos during the evening of the 31st. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded three inches across central Monroe County and also in southwest Carbon County where the heaviest rain fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Mahoning Township. Flooding was reported along State Route 443 near the Mahoning Creek and 84 Lumber. Event precipitation totals included 3.52 inches in Lehighton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across central Pennsylvania as an area of low pressure traveled along a stationary frontal boundary that was draped across the area.  A flash flood occurred in Schuylkill County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several homes and a bank were flooded on Center and Progress Avenues in Schuylkill Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered storms produced isolated wind damage and one report of sub-severe hail (nickel-sized) across central Pennsylvania.  Torrential downpours led to flash flooding across Lebanon and Schuylkill Counties where over 3 of rain fell in a short period of time (from 19-22 UTC).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to road closures  on East Main Street (422) and Chestnut Street.  One vehicle was in the water at Mill Street and Penn Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill pushed up the Ohio Valley and across southern Pennsylvania on June 20th, 2015. A line of thunderstorms pushed across the Laurel Highlands during the afternoon, with several discrete rotating cells developing ahead of the line over the Lower Susquehanna Valley. The event ended with a bow echo pushing across southern Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall brought Sugar Run Creek out of its banks.  The Cross Keys Trailer Park in Allegheny Township was evacuated due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weak disturbances embedded within a broad upper level trough over the central Appalachians produced clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The convective environment was favorable for organized storms as forecast soundings showed strong deep layer shear and veering wind profile with height. The severe storms resulted in numerous reports of wind damage along with marginal hail and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 209 was closed because of flooding, caused by severe weather moving through the area of Blythe Township. The Schuylkill River rose out of its banks between New Philadelphia and the village of Cumbola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weak disturbances embedded within a broad upper level trough over the central Appalachians produced clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The convective environment was favorable for organized storms as forecast soundings showed strong deep layer shear and veering wind profile with height. The severe storms resulted in numerous reports of wind damage along with marginal hail and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall resulting in flooding in the Lairdsville area.  Mill Lane was reported to be flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of an approaching upper trough on the 18th. With precipitable water values over 1.50 inches...some storms produced heavy rain which caused some flash flooding in Allegheny county, PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported that Washington Avenue is flooded in the 1000 block. Water was reported to be up to the car doors with several vehicles stuck. In addition, the ramps to Interstate 79 on Nobelstown Road were flooded and a small landslide was reported on the I-79 northbound ramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of overnight showers and thunderstorms caused some typical poor drainage flooding in eastern Pennsylvania as well as flash flooding in Northampton County before dawn on June 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in Bethlehem Township.  One water rescue was performed. Through the early morning, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 2.5 inches in central Northampton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of convection formed ahead of an approaching frontal system on the afternoon of June 8th, 2015. Discrete rotating supercells formed ahead of the main line of storms, and one such cell produced an EF-0 tornado in Northumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain (over 4 inches in 2 hours) brought flash flooding to the area.  A family was evacuated from a home in the 600 block of Shippensburg Road (Route 533) in North Newton Township.  Flooding was reported at the Laughlin Mill in Newville.  Flash flooding was also reported in the Orrstown area and in Shippensburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Flash flood was observed in the Carlisle area of Cumberland County.  Several water rescues were noted, include one on Lincoln Street.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reports of more then 1 foot of water flowed onto the parking lot of businesses at the intersection of Clay, North Bedford and North Hanover Streets in Carlisle.  Two vehicles were stranded in the high waters, and one person was rescued by boat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slowly westward moving thunderstorms that formed along a backdoor cold front caused flash flooding in parts of Northampton and Upper Bucks Counties during the evening of the 15th.  Reported event precipitation totals reached 2 to 3 inches. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in south central Northampton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller creeks in central and southern Northampton County. The heaviest rain fell in a northwest to southeast axis across the county from eastern East Allen Township through Lower Nazareth Township, Bethlehem Township, Lower Saucon Township and Williams Township. In Bethlehem, flash flooding forced the closure of Easton Avenue at Willow Park Road.  Flash flooding along the Nancy Run also washed out sections of Willow Park Road south through Walnut Street.  A large sink hole near a Pennsylvania Power and Light transmission tower on Clermont Street forced the evacuation of 25 to 30 families for a day. A home on Garrison Street had damage to its foundation and sidewalk. Wilson Avenue, near the Lehigh River became a river itself. Other roadways near the Lehigh River were washed away.  In Easton, parts of Hope Road washed away. Event precipitation totals included 2.89 inches in Glendon and 2.21 inches in Easton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slowly westward moving thunderstorms that formed along a backdoor cold front caused flash flooding in parts of Northampton and Upper Bucks Counties during the evening of the 15th.  Reported event precipitation totals reached 2 to 3 inches. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in south central Northampton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the Monocacy Creek in Bethlehem. Parts of the Illick's Mill and locations behind the Hotel Bethlehem were flooded. Flood waters also reached into the bottom of the historic Tannery and Waterworks. Other parts of the historic downtown and northern neighborhoods also suffered from poor drainage flooding. The Monocacy Creek at the Illicks Mill Road gage reached its 4.5 foot flood stage at 837 p.m. EDT on the 15th and crested at 5.99 feet at 1045 p.m. EDT on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms formed along gust front and sea breeze front boundaries in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late evening of the 26th and had little movement before they dissipated early on the 27th. Consequently, very heavy rain fell along the Montgomery and Chester County border and flash flooding occurred. The heavy rain began between 930 p.m. and 1030 p.m. EDT on the 26th. The rain ended between 1 a.m. and 2 a.m. EDT on the 27th.  Reported event precipitation totals reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in and around Collegeville. Roadways were flooded and some flood waters went into the basements of homes. A mesonet site in Collegeville had an event total of 3.81 inches of rain. A mesonet site in nearby Eagleville had an event total of 2.04 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, multiple thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and Poconos on the afternoon and evening of the 30th. The flash flooding in the Poconos persisted into July 1st. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches in the Lehigh Valley and five inches in the Poconos.||The heavy rain on the 30th culminated a very wet month of June across Eastern Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania as a whole.  The June monthly precipitation total of 7.59 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport was the 5th wettest June on record and the 8.88 June monthly precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was the 3rd wettest June on record.  The June precipitation total of 6.22 inches in Reading (Berks County), was 2.44 inches wetter than normal and the June precipitation total of 8.77 inches in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), was 4.39 inches wetter than normal. For the state of Pennsylvania, it was the second wettest June on record (8.20 inches) dating back to 1895.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, torrential downpours caused flash flooding in Coplay Borough. Several roadways were flooded with vehicles trapped in flood waters. A water rescue occurred on Catherine Street.  Doppler radar storm total estimates reached around two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, multiple thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and Poconos on the afternoon and evening of the 30th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, torrential downpours caused flash flooding in Northampton Borough as the Dry Run flooded.  On Banks Street, about 12 to 14 homes were flooded. Gasoline was also released into the flood waters. Flash flooding extended to East 8th Street where one home suffered structural damage and two people were trapped inside. The family was displaced and assisted by the Red Cross. Doppler radar storm total estimates reached around two inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in and around Pheonixville.  A mesonet site within Phoenixville had an event total of 3.50 inches of rain.

The June precipitation total of 6.22 inches in Reading (Berks County), was 2.44 inches wetter than normal and the June precipitation total of 8.77 inches in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), was 4.39 inches wetter than normal. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage locations in central Carbon County from around Lehighton northeast through parts of Penn Forest and Towamensing Townships to the Monroe County border. Event precipitation totals include 3.57 inches in Lehighton and 3.19 inches in Jim Thorpe and 2.28 inches in Albrightsville. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached nearly 5 inches along the Monroe County border in the Pohopoco Creek drainage basin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a wavy frontal boundary across parts of eastern Ohio and much of southwest Pennsylvania the afternoon of the 14th into the early morning of the 15th. Some of these storms were severe, but most produced very heavy rainfall, with local reports of near 4 inches of rain for the event. This brought flash flooding to portions of southwest Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 991 Call Center reported Park Hill Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Residual flash flooding from thunderstorms on June 30th continued overnight into July 1st in Monroe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in central Monroe County lasted into the early morning of July 1st. Hardest hit were Chestnuthill and Pocono Townships. The Monroe County Office of Emergency Management urged motorists to stay off the road. In Chestnuthill Township, the Pohopoco Creek flooded near Camp Jaycee. Merwinesburg Road was closed from Pennsylvania State Route 115 to Jonas Road. Ziegler Road was also closed near Jonas Road. In Pocono Township, southbound Pennsylvania State Route 611 along the Pocono Creek and near the intersection with Pennsylvania State Route 715 in Tannersville was flooded. There were mud slides in the area also. Farther south along the same creek, Warner Road (a partial wash-out) and Pennsylvania State Route 611 were also closed because of flooding. In Polk Township, Dotters Corner Road (near Dotters Creek) near Pennsylvania State Route 534 was flooded and closed. Event precipitation totals included 4.63 inches in Pocono Pines, 3.84 inches in Pocono Summit, 2.78 inches in Saylorsburg and 2.71 inches in McMichaels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm brought torrential rains and a report of an earth slide near Shawville, in Clearfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flash flooding and an earth slide near the intersection of Stiner Road and Shawville Croft Highway, Route 879.  Both lanes of the road was closed for a time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of Thursday, August 20th a strong thunderstorm brought torrential rains /up to 5���/ to portions of Adams, Cumberland and York Counties.  Biglerville in Adams County was hard hit, with several water rescues and structures flooded in a short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water Rescues and residential flooding was reported in Biglerville on East York Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of convection formed ahead of an approaching frontal system on the afternoon of June 8th, 2015. Discrete rotating supercells formed ahead of the main line of storms, and one such cell produced an EF-0 tornado in Northumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall brought flash flooding to the Millerstown area.  The local fire company performed 2 water rescues, 1 from a house and 1 from a motorist that tried to drive through a flooded road.  Eight flooded basements with as much as 7 feet of water in them was reported.  Roads flooded included North Market Street at Apple Street and Sunbury Path and Locust Alley.  Sunbury Path at Mill Race Road and Raccoon Valley Road west of the borough alsh had farm fields flood across the roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of convection formed ahead of an approaching frontal system on the afternoon of June 8th, 2015. Discrete rotating supercells formed ahead of the main line of storms, and one such cell produced an EF-0 tornado in Northumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain (over 4 inches in 2 hours) brought flash flooding to the area.  A family was evacuated from a home in the 600 block of Shippensburg Road (Route 533) in North Newton Township.  Flooding was reported at the Laughlin Mill in Newville.  Flash flooding was also reported in the Orrstown area and in Shippensburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving storm system brought a warm front north across the region...quickly followed by a cold front. While some gusty winds were reported, the only severe weather was a weak EF0 tornado that occurred in the warm sector behind the warm front. Isolated flash flooding also occurred with the training of rain showers ahead of the cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding with Wildwood Road at County lane closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving storm system brought a warm front north across the region...quickly followed by a cold front. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding with water moving across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave moving across the region in southwest flow brought showers and thunderstorms, some of which were severe to western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported approximately two feet of water was over the road at the intersection of Old William Penn Route 22 and School Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave moving across the region in southwest flow brought showers and thunderstorms, some of which were severe to western Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported flooding along Evergreen Avenue in Millvale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of an approaching upper trough on the 18th. With precipitable water values over 1.50 inches...some storms produced heavy rain which caused some flash flooding in Allegheny county, PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local 911 center reported that Bunola River Road was flooded in Forward Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of an approaching upper trough on the 18th. With precipitable water values over 1.50 inches...some storms produced heavy rain which caused some flash flooding in Allegheny county, PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local 911 call center reported that the creek next to Robb Hollow Road was out of it's banks, flooding part of the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms were widespread across Western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia on the 23rd, ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some thunderstorms were severe, with isolated flash flooding as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported water flowing over Route 910.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms were widespread across Western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia on the 23rd, ahead of a slow moving cold front. Some thunderstorms were severe, with isolated flash flooding as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Department of Highways reported a mud slide due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front coupled with a warm, moist airmass triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across southeastern Pennsylvania and into central and southern New Jersey during the late evening of the 20th through the early morning of the 21st. The thunderstorms were accompanied by heavy rainfall, leading to areas of flash flooding. Doppler radar estimates, as well as actual storm total measurements, ranged from around 2 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in southern Bucks County. Event precipitation totals included 2.61 inches in Penndel, 2.57 inches in Langhorne, 2.55 inches in Richboro, 2.42 inches in Bensalem, and 2.32 inches in Warminster. Much of this rain fell within a very short time period of about one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front coupled with a warm, moist airmass triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across southeastern Pennsylvania and into central and southern New Jersey during the late evening of the 20th through the early morning of the 21st. The thunderstorms were accompanied by heavy rainfall, leading to areas of flash flooding. Doppler radar estimates, as well as actual storm total measurements, ranged from around 2 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in lower Montgomery County. Localized flooding on area roadways was reported in Abington Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.87 inches in North Wales, 2.75 inches in Kulpsville, 2.61 inches in Glenside, and 2.54 inches in Hatfield. Much of this rain fell within a very short time period, including 2.30 inches of the reported rainfall at North Wales falling in just 50 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a wavy frontal boundary across parts of eastern Ohio and much of southwest Pennsylvania the afternoon of the 14th into the early morning of the 15th. Some of these storms were severe, but most produced very heavy rainfall, with local reports of near 4 inches of rain for the event. This brought flash flooding to portions of southwest Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding with Willett Road and Streets Run Road closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of a passing shortwave late on the 13th. The thunderstorms produced heavy rain over Allegheny and Westmoreland counties, with flash flooding reported near Leechburgh and Vandergrift.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reported that several vehicles were stranded on Route 356 at South Leechburg Hill. In addition, flooding was being reported at Allegheny Ludlum.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow boundaries from convection earlier in the day helped to spark additional thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening on the 9th ahead of an approaching cold front. Where the boundaries collided, thunderstorms with very heavy rain materialized, with rates approaching 2 inches per hour based on radar estimates and spotter reports. Convection started over Etna and Shaler, in northern Allegheny county and propogated northward toward Monaca, Ambridge, and Aliquippa in Beaver county. Several road closures were reported with several feet of water on roadways in both locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local 911 center reported that Route 989 was closed due to flash flooding near Economy.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local 911 reported that Franklin Avenue is closed due to flash flooding in Aliquippa.

Also, a landslide was reported on Middle Road and sewage was backing up into flooded homes on Morgan Avenue.

Six cars were reported to be stuck in water, which was half way up the doors. Also, there was water flowing into the Goss Gas building. In addition, the intersection of Maple and Glenn Avenues was reported to be flooded with a partial roadway collapse.

Convection started over Etna and Shaler, in northern Allegheny county and propogated northward toward Monaca, Ambridge, and Aliquippa in Beaver county. Several road closures were reported with several feet of water on roadways in both locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local 911 reported numerous roads closed around Bell Acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into Eastern Pennsylvania on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell right along the Delaware River in the local Philadelphia area where estimates and actual rainfall amounts exceeded four inches. This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rain during the evening of the 10th caused flash flooding and deep ponding of water on roadways and poor drainage areas in and around Eddystone Borough in southeastern Delaware County. The calendar day event precipitation total at nearby Philadelphia International Airport was 4.76 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into Eastern Pennsylvania on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell right along the Delaware River in the local Philadelphia area where estimates and actual rainfall amounts exceeded four inches. This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to poor drainage flooding, the Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 159 p.m. EDT through 219 p.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 7.18 feet at 215 p.m. EDT.  Lincoln Drive had about a foot of water on the roadway. Event precipitation totals in Philadelphia included 4.77 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport, 3.56 inches in Port Richmond, 2.72 inches at Temple University, and 2.17 inches in Wyndmoor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, multiple thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and Poconos on the afternoon and evening of the 30th. The flash flooding in the Poconos persisted into July 1st. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches in the Lehigh Valley and five inches in the Poconos.||The heavy rain on the 30th culminated a very wet month of June across Eastern Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania as a whole.  The June monthly precipitation total of 7.59 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport was the 5th wettest June on record and the 8.88 June monthly precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was the 3rd wettest June on record.  The June precipitation total of 6.22 inches in Reading (Berks County), was 2.44 inches wetter than normal and the June precipitation total of 8.77 inches in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), was 4.39 inches wetter than normal. For the state of Pennsylvania, it was the second wettest June on record (8.20 inches) dating back to 1895.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in central Monroe County that lasted into the overnight of the 30th. Hardest hit were Chestnuthill and Pocono Townships. The Monroe County Office of Emergency Management urged motorists to stay off the road. In Chestnuthill Township, the Pohopoco Creek flooded near Camp Jaycee. Merwinesburg Road was closed from Pennsylvania State Route 115 to Jonas Road.  Ziegler Road was also closed near Jonas Road. In Pocono Township, southbound Pennsylvania State Route 611 along the Pocono Creek and near the intersection with Pennsylvania State Route 715 in Tannersville was flooded. There were mud slides in the area also. Farther south along the same creek, Warner Road (a partial wash-out) and Pennsylvania State Route 611 were also closed because of flooding. In Polk Township, Dotters Corner Road (near Dotters Creek) near Pennsylvania State Route 534 was flooded and closed.  Event precipitation totals included 4.63 inches in Pocono Pines, 3.84 inches in Pocono Summit, 2.78 inches in Saylorsburg and 2.71 inches in McMichaels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southeast Pennsylvania during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of southeastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and in Northampton County.  Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Pottstown. Cars were stalled in high waters. A couple of water rescues were performed on High Street (State Route 4031) and College Drive near the Manatawny Creek was closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.34 inches in Pottstown, 2.33 inches in Collegeville, 2.20 inches in Palm and 2.13 inches in Limerick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms formed along gust front and sea breeze front boundaries in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late evening of the 26th and had little movement before they dissipated early on the 27th. Consequently, very heavy rain fell along the Montgomery and Chester County border and flash flooding occurred. The heavy rain began between 930 p.m. and 1030 p.m. EDT on the 26th. The rain ended between 1 a.m. and 2 a.m. EDT on the 27th.  Reported event precipitation totals reached 3 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours also caused flash flooding in southern Montgomery County mainly in Upper Merion Township. In Upper Merion Township, a mud slide caused the closure of Balligomingo Road between Front Street and Portland Road. In the King of Prussia area of the township, numerous roadways were flooded. The Schuylkill Expressway (Interstate 76) was badly flooded with traffic either halted or barely able to get through as the heaviest rain occurred. Event precipitation totals included 2.61 inches in King Of Prussia and 1.98 inches in Bala Cynwyd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Finger Lakes region of New York State helped trigger a cluster of showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rain that moved over the Poconos mainly during the evening of the 26th. The heaviest rain fell over eastern parts of Carbon County and southwestern parts of Monroe County.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 5 inches in eastern Carbon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Repeated showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams and roadways in Penn Forest and Kidder Townships.  Roadway flooding was reported in Penn Forest Township. Precipitation event totals included 3.36 inches in Albrightsville, 3.22 inches in Meckesville and 2.76 inches in Christmans.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southeast Pennsylvania during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of southeastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and in Northampton County.  Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain also caused flash flooding in parts of northern Northampton County in Upper Nazareth Township, Bushkill Township and Wind Gap.  In Bushkill Township, flash flooding filled basements with up to six feet of water along Jacob Court. Douglasville Road was flooded along the Bushkill Creek. State Park Road was also flooded and closed. In Water Gap, one water rescue was performed after a vehicle became stuck in a creek.  In Plainfield Township, both Sullivan Trail and Bangor Road were closed. Event precipitation totals included 3.18 inches in Lower Nazareth Township and  2.29 inches in Nazareth. In Plainfield Township, the two day precipitation total was 4.69 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southeast Pennsylvania during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of southeastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and in Northampton County.  Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Amity Gardens section of Amity Township.  Event precipitation totals included 2.65 inches in Boyertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front developed a line of strong thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 30th in Eastern Pennsylvania.   This line of thunderstorms dropped around an inch to inch and a half of rain in one hour in parts of Berks County and the Lehigh Valley. This caused isolated urban area flash flooding as well as general poor drainage flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused urban flash flooding in Reading. There were several water rescues from trapped vehicles on North 6th and North 8th Streets between Oley and Elm Streets. Basement flooding also occurred at Reading City Hall.  Event precipitation totals included 1.41 inches in Reading and 1.40 inches in Wyomissing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms that formed in the warm sector of the Susquehanna Valley and moved through southeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and first half of the evening on the 9th. It produced wind damage along its leading edge and then some flash flooding during the evening of the 9th in extreme southeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in lower Montgomery County mainly in Lower and Upper Merion Townships. Vehicles were stuck in flash flood waters on North Gulph Road, City Avenue and Haverford Avenue.  Event precipitation totals included 1.52 inches in Blue Bell, most of which fell in an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms that formed in the warm sector of the Susquehanna Valley and moved through southeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and first half of the evening on the 9th. It produced wind damage along its leading edge and then some flash flooding during the evening of the 9th in extreme southeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Frankford Creek.  The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue reached its 7 foot flood stage at 854 p.m. EDT on the 9th, crested at 7.23 feet at 859 p.m. EDT on the 9th and was back within bankfull at 904 p.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms that formed in the warm sector of the Susquehanna Valley and moved through southeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and first half of the evening on the 9th. It produced wind damage along its leading edge and then some flash flooding during the evening of the 9th in extreme southeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in southern and western Philadelphia.  SEPTA Trolley Service on routes 10, 11, 13, 34 and 36 were suspended due to flooding.  The on ramp to Interstate 95 at Penn's Landing was flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front provided the focus for concentrated thunderstorms across the Northern Tier counties in Pennsylvania. Rainfall estimates of 2 to 3 inches fell in a very short period of time, causing localized flash flooding in the area. Estimated damages to roads and other public and private infrastructure was estimated at 3 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported torrential rainfall of 2 to 4 inches in less than 90 minutes on this day. This led to widespread flash flooding of rural roads, and in the local towns and villages over a small part of central Bradford county. Water was a few feet deep on some village streets, and rushing flood waters also destroyed culverts on several area roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southeast Pennsylvania during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of southeastern Berks, northwest Montgomery and in Northampton County.  Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in southern Northampton County in the city of Bethlehem, Bethlehem Township and Palmer Township. In Bethlehem, East Market and Jenning Streets as well as East Boulevard were closed. In Bethlehem Township, a bus became stuck in flash flood waters. Stranded passengers were rescued from the bus. The Nancy Run Creek flooded within the township across Willow Park Road. The bridge over the creek at the intersection of Willow Park Road and Carter Road was flooded and closed.  In addition, Butztown Road was also closed. In Palmer Township, 25th Street was closed due to flash flooding and a couple of water rescues were performed. Event precipitation totals included 3.18 inches in Lower Nazareth Township and  2.29 inches in Nazareth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, multiple thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Lehigh Valley and Poconos on the afternoon and evening of the 30th. The flash flooding in the Poconos persisted into July 1st. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches in the Lehigh Valley and five inches in the Poconos.||The heavy rain on the 30th culminated a very wet month of June across Eastern Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania as a whole.  The June monthly precipitation total of 7.59 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport was the 5th wettest June on record and the 8.88 June monthly precipitation total at the Philadelphia International Airport was the 3rd wettest June on record.  The June precipitation total of 6.22 inches in Reading (Berks County), was 2.44 inches wetter than normal and the June precipitation total of 8.77 inches in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), was 4.39 inches wetter than normal. For the state of Pennsylvania, it was the second wettest June on record (8.20 inches) dating back to 1895.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brodhead Creek near Anamolink was above its 8 foot flood stage from 858 p.m. EDT through 1030 p.m. EDT on the 30th. It crested at 8.13 feet at 930 p.m. Pennsylvania State Route 447 which is located along the creek was flooded and remained closed into the overnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front slowly moving north through Pennsylvania triggered widely scattered showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain mainly during the evening of the 6th. The thunderstorms with the heaviest rain affected central Delaware County and upper Bucks County. In the latter flash flooding occurred as Doppler Radar storm total estimates approached 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain called flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as flooding of roadways in Upper Bucks County from Perkasie east into Nockamixon and Tinicum Townships. Water was crossing roadways in Perkasie. One cooperative weather observer in Perkasie reported 2.05 inches of rain within two hours. Doppler Radar storm total estimates neared 4 inches farther to the east close to Lake Nockamixon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal boundary was present over the region on the 8th. This allowed for the development of showers and thunderstorms. Heavy rainfall along with strong to severe thunderstorms occurred formed as instability grew in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to flash flooding with rocks and debris washing up on to roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal boundary was present over the region on the 8th. This allowed for the development of showers and thunderstorms. Heavy rainfall along with strong to severe thunderstorms occurred formed as instability grew in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads closed due to flash flooding with some debris washed into roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure led to the development of afternoon and evening showers and thunderstorms which became severe in spots and produced locally heavy rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An underpass of interstate 95 at Station ave flooded rapidly. A SEPTA bus became stuck in the flood waters. Water also led to flooding in Cornwall Apartments.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure led to the development of afternoon and evening showers and thunderstorms which became severe in spots and produced locally heavy rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Frankford and Pennypack creeks rapidly rose above flood stage for a short interval, quickly receding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Most electric outlets reported thousands of power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three Feet of water covered parts of State Street in Mertztown.  Water Rescues were necessary.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Most electric outlets reported thousands of power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flooding was reported on several roadways in and near downtown Bethlehem.  The southbound side of Pennsylvania Route 378 was closed between 3rd Avenue and 8th Avenue.  Vehicles were stranded on Route 378. A basement was flooded on the 1600 Broadway along with water rescues at 33rd and Lehigh streets. Motorists were also stranded due to flood waters in Lower Macungie twp and in Allentown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Most electric outlets reported thousands of power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rose quickly from heavy rain and flowed over several roadways in Bushkill Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in Eastern Pennsylvania late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Most electric outlets reported thousands of power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Frankford Creek reached its flood stage of 7 feet at 2240EST.  The Pennypack Creek reached its flood stage of 7 feet at 2320EST.  Numerous roadways were reported flooded from urban runoff. Interstate 76 was closed between Girard and Montgomery drive exits along with part of Lincoln Drive. Numerous reports were sent into Philadelphia police for water rescue requests. Lincoln Drive in Fairmount Park was also closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved southeast across eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania the afternoon and evening of the 28th. While some wind damage was reported, more significant flash flooding occurred over portions of Allegheny and Fayette counties in Pennsylvania, with the widespread flash flooding across Bullskin Township in Fayette county, including the town of Connellsville. Between 75 to 100 homes sustained damage from flood waters in Bullskin Township, including 29 single family homes with major damage, 8 mobile homes destroyed, a bridge destroyed, and 3 to 4 bridges suffering major structural damage. 50 people were evacuated, with damage estimates in the millions of dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported flash flooding on Washington BLVD, and elsewhere in the Highland Park area.  Water was quickly rising to the tops of cars, with one woman rescued from her vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level shortwave provided the support for shower and thunderstorm development in the afternoon on the 29th. Thunderstorms with heavy rain passed over Allegheny county, where over 2 inches of rain fell in an hour based on local observations. Flash flooding was reported in several locations throughout the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local emergency manager reported that Lebanon-Church Road at Clairton Road is closed due to flooding; Lebanon Road has been damaged due to flooding. Also, several roads were closed in Dravosburg due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the remnants of tropical storm Bonnie moved northward into the region and interacted with a frontal boundary over the region. This resulted in several rounds of heavy rain on the night of the 29th and the early morning of the 30th. Rainfall totals ranged from 3.09 inches at the GOES gauge at Pohopoco Creek to 2.3 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia ASOS. Other totals included 1 inch near Deer Lake and 2 inches near Bensalem.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Frankford gauge rose above flood stage and reached 7.6 feet by 8z on the 30th the value quickly fell below flood stage by 815z.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from the remnants of tropical storm Bonnie moved northward into the region and interacted with a frontal boundary over the region. This resulted in several rounds of heavy rain on the night of the 29th and the early morning of the 30th. Rainfall totals ranged from 3.09 inches at the GOES gauge at Pohopoco Creek to 2.3 inches at the Northeast Philadelphia ASOS. Other totals included 1 inch near Deer Lake and 2 inches near Bensalem.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pennypack gauge rose just above flood stage to 7.42 feet at 815Z. It was below flood stage by 830Z. A man jumped into the high waters during the overnight hours to rescue a dog. The man was swept away by the current and found dead at 9:30 am according to Law Enforcement and Media reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very moist and unstable conditions were across the region on the backside of an upper level ridge. Scattered thunderstorms developed in the afternoon with isolated damage and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported the Sugar Creek Ambulance Station flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Circulation around an offshore flow produced showers and thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours on the 23rd. Some of these thunderstorms produced gusty winds, pea-sized hail, and heavy rain which resulted in roadway flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Circulation around an offshore flow produced showers and thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours on the 23rd. Some of these thunderstorms produced gusty winds, pea-sized hail, and heavy rain which resulted in roadway flooding in a few locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed along a weak boundary the afternoon of the 14th. A weak EFU tornado occurred in Belmont county, Ohio, while isolated flash flooding was reported in Fayette county in Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fire Department reported Washington Run overflowed with flash flooding bringing water into a business for a time, with limited damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered slow moving thunderstorms developed the evening of the 2nd ahead of a cold front. One of these storms produced isolated flash flooding in Westmoreland county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported numerous roads flooded from Jeannette to Harrison City and South Greensburg. Some manhole covers were dislodged with tributaries of Brush Creek out of their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse moving along a wavy frontal boundary produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall the morning of the 3rd. Some roads were closed due to flash flooding in Beaver county, while radar estimated nearly 4 inches of rain fell in 2 hours northeast of Ligonier in Westmoreland county. This produced flooding of roads, with one bridge washed out, as well as a water recuse from a home and a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flash flooding northeast of Ligonier with multiple roads closed due to flash flooding. The water rescue team was deployed to help a woman evacuate a home surrounded by water in Ligonier, with a water rescue from a stranded car on SR 711. A bridge was also washed out on Clifford Woods Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms developed as a cold front moved east under deepening low pressure moving into the Great Lakes the afternoon and evening of the 16th. Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported State Route 40 washed out near Atlas Crossing Road, and a miniature golf course flooded off Nell Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms developed as a cold front moved east under deepening low pressure moving into the Great Lakes the afternoon and evening of the 16th. Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported roadway flooding into cars at Park Manor BLVD and Sutherland Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms developed as a cold front moved east under deepening low pressure moving into the Great Lakes the afternoon and evening of the 16th. Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding on McMichael Road at Campbells Run Road.

As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a hillside near Ross Park Mall washed into driveway.

As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a bridge completely flooded on MT. Royal BLVD near Elfinwild Road.

Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported State Route 65 closed at 4th Street due to flash flooding.

As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported Laird Road closed due to a creek flooding.

Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding on Washington BLVD before the Highland park Bridge. Barriers are down and road is closed.

Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused a mudslide onto Streets Run Road.

Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water cutting into and underneath Air Shaft Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a large hole opened in Tin Can Hollow Road due to flash flooding.

As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported flash flooding on Tyrol BLVD.

Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding along State Route 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm brought flash flooding to a small area in southern Bedford County on the evening of June 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Black Valley Road closed with 18 inches of water on the road.  Several streams reported out of their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms developed as a cold front moved east under deepening low pressure moving into the Great Lakes the afternoon and evening of the 16th. Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flash flooding along Shaffer Run Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms developed as a cold front moved east under deepening low pressure moving into the Great Lakes the afternoon and evening of the 16th. Wind damage was reported over eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia, as well as an EF0 tornado in Fayette county, Pennsylvania, and another EF0 in Monongalia county, West Virginia. As the cold front laid out across the region in the evening, training thunderstorms produced flash flooding and flooding in some areas, with Uniontown in Fayette county, Pennsylvania being hardest hit by Red Stone creek coming out of it's banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 36 was reported washed out north of Leeper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse moving along a wavy frontal boundary produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall the morning of the 3rd. Some roads were closed due to flash flooding in Beaver county, while radar estimated nearly 4 inches of rain fell in 2 hours northeast of Ligonier in Westmoreland county. This produced flooding of roads, with one bridge washed out, as well as a water recuse from a home and a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty NWS employee reported Chapel Road closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse moving along a wavy frontal boundary produced scattered thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall the morning of the 3rd. Some roads were closed due to flash flooding in Beaver county, while radar estimated nearly 4 inches of rain fell in 2 hours northeast of Ligonier in Westmoreland county. This produced flooding of roads, with one bridge washed out, as well as a water recuse from a home and a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported roads closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small, but potent thunderstorm developed over Clearfield County just north of the town of Clearfield just before 22:00Z Thursday June 2nd, 2016.  The storm moved little and by 23Z was producing very heavy rain. The storm sat over the Clearfield-Lawrence County Airport (KFIG) where 5.16��� of rain fell essentially 3 hours.||Initially Flood Advisories were issued (2316Z), but as the storm sat in one spot, the advisory was upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning at 0038Z.  ||Significant flooding was reported near the town of Clearfield, with three homes flooded, and according to Clearfield County EMA 21 people were rescued from their homes and taken to a shelter. Fortunately there were no reports of serious injuries. Hardest hit areas were near Route 879 and Industrial Road, and multiple streets in downtown Clearfield including Turnpike, Nichols and Merrill Street.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small, but potent thunderstorm developed over Clearfield County just north of the town of Clearfield just before 22:00Z Thursday June 2nd, 2016.  The storm moved ittle and intensified, and by 23Z was producing very heavy rain. The storm sat over the Clearfield-Lawrence County Airport (KFIG) where 5.16��� of rain fell essentially 3 hours.||Initially Flood Advisories were issued (2316Z), but as the storm sat in one spot, the advisory was upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning at 0038Z.  ||Significant flooding was reported near the town of Clearfield, with three homes flooded, and according to Clearfield County EMA 21 people were rescued from their homes and taken to a shelter.  ||Shortly after midnight a house on West Front Street exploded when the owners tried to turn their power back on. Four residents of the home suffered unknown injuries.||Hardest hit areas were near Route 879 and Industrial Road (see fig 2), and multiple streets in downtown Clearfield including Turnpike, Nichols and Merrill Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level shortwave provided the support for shower and thunderstorm development in the afternoon on the 29th. Thunderstorms with heavy rain passed over Allegheny county, where over 2 inches of rain fell in an hour based on local observations. Flash flooding was reported in several locations throughout the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported several roads closed due to flooding including Forest Avenue in Homestead and the intersection of Mifflin and Lebanon roads near Hays, where cars were abandoned due to high water. Also, there was a mudslide at the corner of Forest Ave and West 8th Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms rolled off Lake Erie into lakeshore Erie County Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of August 10th. High rainfall rates produced a flash flood over Erie and Mill Creek between 1 am and 4 am.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shortly after midnight on the 10th a cluster of thunderstorms moved over lakeshore Erie County. The storm peaked right over the city of Erie and Millcreek around 1240 am with rainfall rates measured at 6 per hour. This excessive rainfall overwhelmed storm drainage and resulted in flash flooding primarily in the Millcreek area. The initial rainfall resulted in some standing water. As the runoff collected in low spots it resulted in 20-30 vehicles flooded and floating a little after 2 am. The Walnut Creek saw a rapid rise resulting in the need to sandbag the region to prevent inundation into homes. The hardest hit areas were West 12th Street and Lakefront Drive. On Lakefront drive pumps were needed to drain flooded roads and basements of 3 to 4 feet of water. Manhole covers were reported to have been lifted from the pressure in the storm drainage systems. Storm total measured rainfall amounts of 5.5 at local fire departments. The ERI airport spotter reported 3 in 30 minutes during the peak of the storm with 5.24 storm total rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms crossed the metropolitan areas of Northeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening. Rainfall amounts between 3 and 6 inches over a span from 90 minutes to 2 hours were common in many areas. These intense rainfall rates led to areas of urban and small stream flash flooding throughout Lackawanna county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant small stream flash flooding and street flooding occurred in and around Moscow. Roaring Brook washed over Brook Road near Route 690 for more than an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought moderate to heavy rains across much of central and north-central Pennsylvania during the overnight hours between October 20th and 21st. A very narrow band of intense rainfall developed over central Pennsylvania and extended into the higher terrain of Bradford county where 5 to 8 inches of rain fell within a 3 to 6 hour time span. Flash flooding closed roads in several townships with some damage to bridges and culverts in the area. The Tunkhannock Creek in Monroeton exceeded flood stage by over 2 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several small streams and creeks out of their banks flooding roads in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought moderate to heavy rains across much of central and north-central Pennsylvania during the overnight hours between October 20th and 21st. A very narrow band of intense rainfall developed over central Pennsylvania and extended into the higher terrain of Bradford county where 5 to 8 inches of rain fell within a 3 to 6 hour time span. Flash flooding closed roads in several townships with some damage to bridges and culverts in the area. The Tunkhannock Creek in Monroeton exceeded flood stage by over 2 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of streams and creeks created flooded roads across the area. Bridges and culverts along Route 414 had water problems.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought moderate to heavy rains across much of central and north-central Pennsylvania during the overnight hours between October 20th and 21st. A very narrow band of intense rainfall developed over central Pennsylvania and extended into the higher terrain of Bradford county where 5 to 8 inches of rain fell within a 3 to 6 hour time span. Flash flooding closed roads in several townships with some damage to bridges and culverts in the area. The Tunkhannock Creek in Monroeton exceeded flood stage by over 2 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in the area were flooded as heavy rainfall forced streams and creeks from their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving frontal system brought moderate to heavy rains across much of central and north-central Pennsylvania during the overnight hours between October 20th and 21st. A very narrow band of intense rainfall developed over central Pennsylvania and extended into the higher terrain of Bradford county where 5 to 8 inches of rain fell within a 3 to 6 hour time span. Flash flooding closed roads in several townships with some damage to bridges and culverts in the area. The Tunkhannock Creek in Monroeton exceeded flood stage by over 2 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain forced small streams and creeks from their banks, flooding several roads around Monroeton. A bridge was scoured along Route 414. Towanda Creek and Schrader Creek were the main tributaries causing flooding in the Borough. Flood water surrounded the Dandy Mini-Mart and closed the local airport.
