EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture advection in southwesterly flow increased throughout the day as a |longwave trough over the midwest deepened. A shortwave moving through the trough brought showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported flooding near intersection at Highway 403 and 22 in Strongstown. Route 56 was closed at United High School due to flooding and a landslide. Little Bush Creek was also reported to be out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and isolated storms moved across Pennsylvania as surface low pressure passed over western Ohio. The environment was moist and had moderate wind shear. Low levels had weak steerage flow that supported flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported near New Salem VFD. Flooding in McClellandtown hair salon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front positioned over Northeast Pennsylvania acted as the focus for several rounds of late night and early morning thunderstorm activity in the area. A deep moist environment was prime for the production of slow moving, heavy rainfall which contributed to several areas of localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed the Berwick Turnpike in Ridgebury Township. Evacuations of cars, homes and businesses was underway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front positioned over Northeast Pennsylvania acted as the focus for several rounds of late night and early morning thunderstorm activity in the area. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak upper level disturbances on the southern edge of the jet stream created areas of slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over the roadway on French Creek Road and Laddsburg Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting across Northeast Pennsylvania and Central New York was the focus for several rounds of thunderstorm activity within a very warm and humid airmass. Slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms contributed to several areas of minor flooding, along with, more serious flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding deposited rocks and mud over the road, blocking traffic for over an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed through the region during the mid afternoon hours. This front displaced a very warm and humid airmass, triggering widely scattered torrential rain producing thunderstorms. Some of these storms produced poor drainage and localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over Route 220, blocking traffic in both directions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across New York and became stationary over northeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon. Torrential rain producing thunderstorms formed within the tropical-like environment and moved slowly over the same areas. Flash flooding damaged property and washed out roads and bridges in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing throughout the village of New Albany, covering most roads and entering homes and businesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across New York and became stationary over northeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be rushing over U.S. Route 220 and Harney Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed east of Cleveland from a breeze off of Lake Erie near 17Z. Areas south and east of the line gave way to more storms as outflow boundaries converged. With high PWAT values (near 1.90) flash flooding became an issue with training storms. |Wet microbursts were also a concern with DCAPE values near 500kjg-1. The Weather Prediction Center had our region under a slight risk for excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported flooded intersection near Squaw Run Road/Field Club Road and at the intersection Fairview Road and Old Mill Road. An emergency manager also reported rushing water near Woodland Farms Road. Fox Chapel Stone Supply INC worker says the store took on 2 ft of water (WPXI reported). Aspinwall declared a state of emergency. The O'Hara Township manager reported that some homes may be total losses; said total infrastructure losses in the township added up to $1.3 million.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across New York and became stationary over northeast Pennsylvania during the late afternoon. Torrential rain producing thunderstorms formed within the tropical-like environment and moved slowly over the same areas. Flash flooding damaged property and washed out roads and bridges in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flooding closed SR 267 in Choconut Township near Murphy Corners Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rich tropical moisture remained across the Northeast region. Precipitable water values continued to be high at 1.90 to 2.00 inches. Morning soundings showed very little upper level flow. A static atmosphere prompted a risk for flooding; storms that developed tended to move very little. Isolated wet microbursts were a potential due to CAPE values over 2000 J/kg. Storms developed from outflow boundaries and light convergence aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported Nature Run Road and Route 381 was also flooded in Laghlintown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pittsburgh region continued to sit under an upper level ridge while tropical moisture lingered in the Northeast U.S. Sufficient instability allowed for a few strong storms to develop, causing tree damage. Localized flooding was the main concern due to a static atmosphere with light flow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local emergency manager reported that Washington Blvd was closed in both directions due to flooding at Allegheny River Blvd and Negley Run. The north side of the river, in Aspinwall, there was flooding at Delafield Ave (report via social media).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical-like air surging into Pennsylvania interacted with areas of weak low pressure which caused several rounds of heavy rain producing thunderstorms throughout the day. These storms moved across the same locations in the northeastern part of the State.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe flooding was reported in the New Albany Public Library. Approximately 1.5 feet of water was flowing through the structure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical-like air surging into Pennsylvania interacted with areas of weak low pressure which caused several rounds of heavy rain producing thunderstorms throughout the day. These storms moved across the same locations in the northeastern part of the State.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two bridges were damaged and closed by raging flood waters and debris striking the bridge decks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical-like air surging into Pennsylvania interacted with areas of weak low pressure which caused several rounds of heavy rain producing thunderstorms throughout the day. These storms moved across the same locations in the northeastern part of the State.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Serious flooding of low lying areas was occurring between Wyalusing-New Albany Road and the Susquehanna River. Flooding caused by overflow of an unnamed stream, and the Sugar Run creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical-like air surging into Pennsylvania interacted with areas of weak low pressure which caused several rounds of heavy rain producing thunderstorms throughout the day. These storms moved across the same locations in the northeastern part of the State.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved south across northern Ohio and northwest Pennsylvania on the evening of the 1st. The environment lacked shear and instability keeping the risk of severe weather low. However, the slow storm motions and residual warm moist air in the low levels made rainfall efficiencies high. During the afternoon some storms developed ahead of the approaching cold front, with rainfall rates estimated over 4��� per hour.  A slow moving cell formed near Kinsman extending to the dam at the Pymatuning Lake between 4 and 6 pm. Flash flooding resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Friday June 1, 2018  from 6:30 pm ��� 10:00 PM the Sugar Run in the Shenango River basin just south and downstream of the Pymatuning Dam flooded.  According to USGS records it was the second highest flow recorded at the Pymatuning Weir Gauge Station.  The highest flow was recorded on September 9, 2004 as a result of Hurricane Ivan.  However that high flow included input from the Pymatuning Dam.   During the June 1, 2018 event, the dam gates at 6:45 pm  before Sugar Run reached flood stage.   This event appears to be the worst flash flood on Sugar Run since the start of data collection in 1933.  In addition to the destruction of a park hiking bridge ($30,000 estimated replacement).  Residents in four private homes/cottages in the Douthette Allottment �� mile below the dam were evacuated and the structures received minor flood damage due to 4-8��� of water on the first floor.   A rain gauge at the Pymatuning Park Office recorded 1.66 inches of precipitation from as of 8 pm, however this gauge was sited north of the heaviest rainfall.   Anecdotal accounts reported 4-5 inches in rain gauges directly north east of Kinsman, OH in the watershed.  Doppler radar estimates of 1.5-3.5��� fell in the area, however radar estimates have a low bias due to the height of the radar beam at that location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hooversville Fire Dept Chief has reported they have a total of 5 streets under water, a total of 20 homes displaced due to flooding in Hooverville, Somerset County. Approximately, 47 people have been evacuated and have gotten placement either with other family members, in hotels, or the at shelter at Church Street and Clark Street. in Hooversville. Hooversville Fire Chief also advised the water is approx one house away from there station at this time.||Somerset County 911 is reporting that 35 persons are being evacuated in Benson Borough. The evacuees are will being going to a shelter being set up at St. Thomas Church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storm developed ahead of an approaching cold front on July 16, 2018. Neither CAPE nor shear were very impressive, but a couple of storms managed to produce wind damage across northwestern and north-central Pennsylvania.  Heavy rainfall brought flash flooding to portions of McKean and Potter Counties during the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding was reported across the Potter County.   In Bingham Township road closures included  Collins Hill Road in the area of Bingham Road and Windfall Road, Bingham Center Road at Bacon Road, and Bingham Center Road in the area of 218.  Pusher Siding Road was under 3 feet of water and approximately 1000 feet of the roadway was washed out.||In Genessee Township, Ellisburg Road between Main and Ridge roads was briefly  closed and water was approximately a foot deep. Ellisburg Road in the area of Dogtown Road had three homes under water, no injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed across the county as a result of floodwaters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and pulse thunderstorms developed in a very warm and humid airmass over central Pennsylvania. Anomalously high PWATs resulted in very heavy rainfall in some storms, and a few reports of wind damage were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding reported across the county with Pushersiding Road closed near Ulysses, Peet Brook Road flooded near Andrews Settlement,  Route 6 flooded west of Galeton, and Oswayo Creek flowing over Route 44 near Hebron.   West Pike reported 6.10 inches and 4.73 inches in Galeton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 4 inches of rain produced flash flooding.  PA Route 443 was closed due to flooding.  Bunker Hill Road in Halifix Township was damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pulse storms developed over the higher elevations of central Pennsylvania in a high CAPE, low shear environment. In an abnormally hot and humid airmass, these storms produced torrential rainfall and isolated reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding hit Blair County and the Altoona area that afternoon.   Approximately 100 homes and businesses suffered damage and Duncansville, Allegheny and Blair Townships made disaster declarations.   Multiple requests for evacuations were made during the event from residents.  A natural gas leak was reported at 210 Cambridge Drive in Allegheny Township.  Water rescues were performed at 10th Street at 8th Avenue in Duncansville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue occurred on South Lehigh Avenue. Park Road and Spain Road were closed due to flooding. North Tulpehocken Street was closed in Pine Grove Borough. State Route 209 was also closed both ways as a result of flooding. Little Manahoy Creek flooded onto South 3rd Street in Frackville. Flooding from Little Manahoy Creek impacted one home or more. Rain also washed out Gordon Mountain Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: State official reported flash flooding near Bailey Drive on Route 62. Route 62 was closed as water and debris was flowing over roadway. Several mudslides were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In an environment with weak winds aloft, an isolated thunderstorm developed over eastern sections of Allegheny county. This produced significant flash flooding along Route 51 and the Baldwin area. Numerous roads were closed with a video of a dumpster floating down State Route 51. Rainfall amounts ranged from 2.43 in Mount Oliver to a trace at Pittsburgh International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County official reported that Plummer School Road was closed due to high water. Also, three feet of water was reported in some homes in Hutchinson. A woman had to be rescued from her vehicle near Sutersville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed multiple roads including State Route 87 between Forksville and Dushore.

Multiple fire departments conducted water rescues. Approximately 25 homes along Dry Run Creek have been evacuated due to flooding. A shelter was established at Warrior Run Fire Department for the evacuees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of Sonestown and rural areas of southwestern Sullivan County.  Many evacuations were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms formed along a nearly stationary boundary that crept southeastward from the Great Lakes.  Precipitable water values of around 1.6 inches and weak steering flow along the boundary led to a few areas of training thunderstorms.  Rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 3.0 inches on already saturated ground led to several areas of flash flooding in Washington, Allegheny, and Westmoreland Counties.  The worst flooding was near Herminie, where up to 14 homes were impacted and a mobile home was shifted off of its foundation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported that the intersection of Route 51 and Lewis Run Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wet and unsettled weather pattern brought flash flooding to portions of central Pennsylvania from the 12th through the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Loyalsock Creek was over its banks and evacuations were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low amplitude, positively-tilted shortwave trough crossed the eastern Great Lakes/upper Ohio Valley region on October 2nd.  Showers and thunderstorms developed in a moist, unstable air mass across eastern Ohio, northwestern Pennsylvania, and northern West Virginia. Despite expansive early morning cloud cover, some clearing was observed, allowing for a substantial buildup of instability, while dewpoints in the mid to upper 60s illustrated the available moisture.  The crossing shortwave and associated mid-level jet resulted in 40 knots of deep layer shear and a wind profile which favored discrete cells. As a result, several supercells and tornadic signatures were observed.||A total of six tornadoes were observed in the Pittsburgh forecast area, with ratings ranging from EF-0 to EF-2.  The most significant damage was observed with a tornado that resulted in damage to homes and gravestones in the vicinity of Jefferson Cemetery in Jefferson County.  No deaths or injuries were reported from these tornadoes. Several reports of hail up to golf ball size were also received, as well as reports of straight-line wind damage.||In all, 14 tornadoes occurred in the state of Pennsylvania on this day.  The previous record number (since 1950) of tornadoes on an October day was four on October 5, 1979.  Overall, there are only three days with more Pennsylvania tornadoes recorded:  May 31st to early June 1st, 1998 (23 tornadoes), June 2nd, 1998 (22), and May 31st, 1985 (21).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported roadway flooding in the 1000 block of Washington Avenue in Scott Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped across Pennsylvania during the afternoon hours of October 4th.  A line of thunderstorms accompanied the front, dropping 1.0 to 1.5 inches of rain across urban portions of Allegheny and Westmoreland Counties in a short period of time.  Given the already wet conditions and ideal setup for runoff, several reports of flash flooding were received, including several water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported flash flooding and ongoing water rescues in the South Hills section of Allegheny County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and moist airmass was draped across Ohio on July 5th. Slow moving showers and thunderstorms developed along the afternoon lake breeze and outflow boundaries. With dewpoints in the mid 70s and precipitable water values around 2 inches the environment was favorable for torrential rain. Flash flooding was localized to northern Ohio and northwest Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding in Edinboro where the intersection of Route 99 and Old State Road and Springboro where Springboro Road and North Hickernell Road were impassable. In Hartstown water was running over Main Street and Adamsville Road. Numerous roads closed. Water estimated at 2 feet in portions of Edinboro University.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving through central New York triggered numerous thunderstorms across the area. A frontal boundary became stationary over northeast Pennsylvania during the afternoon. Thunderstorms moved very slowly along this boundary with several rounds of torrential rainfall occurring in the Scranton metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be rushing across roads and into residences along W. Swinick Drive in Dunmore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and excessively humid conditions beneath a weak area of high pressure led to the development of numerous thunderstorms around the region. These storms moved very slowly across the area due to light steering winds. Torrential rainfall fell in just a few hours, causing flash and urban flooding problems in a few areas of northern PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was overtopping and eroding a bridge on Bow Bridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall led to three areas of flash flooding during the evening hours on Wednesday June 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several road closure due to flash flooding /4 to 6 rain reported on East Swatara Drive/ in Beverly Heights in Swatara Township.  A water rescue was report at a residence surrounded by rushing water on Old Jonestown Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall led to three areas of flash flooding during the evening hours on Wednesday June 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains passed through multiple municipalities in Warren County causing road closures and other impacts. State Routes 6 and 27 are closed in various parts of the county. A vehicle slid into the ditch from the flood waters on State Route 27. The roadway also has a mudslide near Hickory Lane in Pittsfield Township. State Route 6 is closed in Youngstown Borough and is nearly impassable elsewhere in the county. Glade Water Rescue was dispatched for a water rescue on this road. A Command Post was set up at the Youngstown Fire Department. They were dispatched to rescue a group care home, on 29680 Route 6, that were unable to evacuate. The decision was made that it was safe enough for the residents stay in their home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 4.  Rainfall amounts of 1.0 to 1.5 inches fell in a short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in lane closures along Interstate 476 between Broomall and Villanova.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding from the afternoon of June 19 into the nighttime hours.  Rainfall amounts of 3 to near 6 inches were reported in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania.  Significant flash flooding occurred in Berks County, mainly in the Reading area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in the Reading, Wyomissing, Shillington and Kenhorst areas.  Several water rescues took place near the intersection of Lancaster Avenue and Morgantown Road in Reading.  The Reading Public Museum in West Reading was damaged by flood waters.  Trees were uprooted on and near the museum property, and a metal sculpture was washed away.  Several water rescues took place around the intersection of Park Road and Sunnyside Avenue in Wyomissing.  A sink hole developed on State Hill Road at Penn Avenue in Wyomissing.  Residents of the Cambridge Commons Apartments in Wyomissing were rescued from flood waters as deep as 6 feet.  Five individuals were rescues from flood waters at a convenience store on Museum Road in Wyomissing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated flash flooding occurred in Berks County during the early evening hours of June 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in parts of Earl Township, Amity Township and Oley Township.  Memorial Highway and Covered Bridge Road were completely inundated.  There was widespread roadway flooding in Earlville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Pennypack Creek in Northeast Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-stationary frontal boundary set up across Ohio and Pennsylvania on the 17th, and wavered about the region until it was kicked off to the east by a stronger frontal boundary late on the 20th.  Flooding and flash flooding remained a concern through the period given an ideal setup for training storms, as well as efficient rainfall production associated with observed high PWATs and deeper warm cloud depths.  Storm total rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches were not uncommon.  Flooding reports in southwest Pennsylvania were mainly limited to road and basement issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county emergency manager reported that one foot of water was running from Peters Creek on to Gill Hall Road, as well as State Route 51.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms formed in an unstable air mass on the 28th.  The storms took advantage of dry air aloft to create downburst conditions in a few cases, producing reports of wind damage in Allegheny, Lawrence, and Westmoreland Counties. Also, one to two inches of rain on already wet ground created flooding issues in portions of western Lawrence County. ||A lull in activity occurred during the night and into the following morning.  Later in the day, renewed instability, plus residual outflow boundaries from previous convection, helped to expand thunderstorm coverage during the evening of the 29th and into the early morning hours of the 30th ahead of a sagging cold front.   Steep lapse rates and dry air aloft supported many instances of thunderstorms with damaging wind.  Damage was mainly to trees, but there were a few instances of roof damage in Washington County.  Hail was much less widespread, but a few reports of dime to quarter sized hail were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 dispatcher reported that Cover Road was flooded near the railroad crossing.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 62 Flooded North of Tidioute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms were able to bloom during the afternoon hours as a shortwave trough crossed the region while convective temperatures were reached.  CAPE values of 1000-2000 J/kg were sufficient to induce updrafts capable of tapping dry air aloft to create a few instances of downbursts.  One particularly strong downburst occurred at the Quicksilver Golf Club in Washington County, where multiple trees were blown down and where 70 MPH wind was estimated. A couple instances of large hail were also reported in Allegheny County.  Merging/training thunderstorms also produced flash flooding that was localized to Lawrence County, where up to 1.5 inches of rain fell in a short time on saturated ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 dispatchers reported that the 100 block of Shenango Road was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving line of thunderstorms produced an area of heavy rainfall over Mercer County on the 5th.  Around 2 inches of rain fell in the space of a couple of hours.  This produced flash flooding in the area, including a few flooded roads and some reports of water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported that Stewart Avenue was flooded.

Merging/training thunderstorms also produced flash flooding that was localized to Lawrence County, where up to 1.5 inches of rain fell in a short time on saturated ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 dispatcher reported flooding on West State Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A front, which has been lingering north of our area, marched south on July 6th and brought damaging storms and widespread flooding.   Sufficiently strong mid-level flow supported damaging wind in some cases. However, the main impacts were from flash flooding.  This was supported by the presence of anomalously high precipitable water values, deep warm cloud depths, and sufficient instability and lift.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local 911 Call Center reported Route 51 and Crane Ave flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing shortwave trough and surface cold front brought scattered showers and thunderstorm on July 11th. Increasing shear, building instability, and mid-level dry resulted in a few strong storms across the area. Unseasonably high warm cloud depth created impressive rainfall rates, contributing to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local 911 Call Center reported numerous flooded areas. Mansfield Bridge and 5th Ave closed due to flooding in McKeesport. In Mount Vernon, a creek flooded a roadway near Boston Hollow Rd and Mansfield Rd. Near Lovedale, car was stuck near 1101 Happy Hollow Rd. In Wylie, a house was flooded at 157 Polk Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough crossed the Great Lakes on July 19th and then dove southward on the eastern flank of an upper ridge. The atmosphere was sufficiently unstable to allow isolated strong storms to develop. High moisture levels, with dewpoints in the 70s, also created an environment capable of producing heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local fire department reported multiple reports of flash flooding and water over roads in the Seneca area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped down across the region on the morning of July 21st. Convective initiation was aided by increased low-level moisture convergence along the front, as well as destabilization of the atmosphere due to daytime heating.  Convective inhibition was largely absent, and surface-based CAPE values exceeded 3000 J/kg over most of the region.  Shear was marginal, but the instability was sufficient to allow for strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging wind gusts.||A moist environment was also in place as surface dewpoints climbed into the 70s.  This, plus a flow pattern that was conducive to training thunderstorms, promoted flash flooding issues along a stalled boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local emergency manager reported that Universal Road was flooded. A vehicle was stuck in water.

Shear was marginal, but the instability was sufficient to allow for strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging wind gusts.||A moist environment was also in place as surface dewpoints climbed into the 70s.  This, plus a flow pattern that was conducive to training thunderstorms, promoted flash flooding issues along a stalled boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local county official reported numerous flooded roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Block Water Dam Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing shortwave trough and surface cold front brought scattered showers and thunderstorm on July 11th. Increasing shear, building instability, and mid-level dry resulted in a few strong storms across the area. Unseasonably high warm cloud depth created impressive rainfall rates, contributing to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous areas flooded. Portions of PA Route 88 (Library Rd.) were flooded. The intersections of Valley Drive and Millford Drive in Bethel Park were flooded. A road collapsed in front of Toole Autobody on McNeilly Rd in Baldwin Twp. The intersection of Glass Run Rd and Baldwin Rd flooded, with an empty vehicle reported to be floating down the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms were generated by an approaching shortwave. A prefrontal trough in the morning temporarily suppressed the potential for flooding. However, during the afternoon, storms were able to regenerate.  An overall weak flow pattern allowed some storms to move sufficiently slow to created isolated flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local 911 call center reported a vehicle stuck in a flooded road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 6.  Rainfall amounts of 2 to near 3 inches occurred in sections of Monroe County, Northampton County and Bucks County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain resulted in flash flooding and a mud slide along PA Route 611 in Stroud Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 6.  Rainfall amounts of 2 to near 3 inches occurred in sections of Monroe County, Northampton County and Bucks County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused roadway flooding in the Lahaska area.  Some roads became impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With very moist profiles and little wind shear, the primary concern for the day was heavy rainfall and localized flash flooding potential with thunderstorms. A flash flood watch was issued for a portion of our region, mainly the higher elevations. Deep warm cloud depths and slow moving storms promoted high rainfall rates. The 00Z sounding noted very high precipitable water values of 1.67 inches, which exceeded the 90th percentile for the date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Department of Highways said a landslide due to heavy rain across across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place at the intersection of Sassamansville Road and Kulps Road in Douglass Township.  Other water rescues in the township took place at the intersection of Swamp Creek Road and Schlegel Road, and at the intersection of Hoffmansville Road and Green Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and early evening of July 22.  Rainfall amounts of 1 to near 3 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped in flood waters in Salisbury Township, requiring a water rescue.  There were multiple reports of flooding along Interstate 78 in Salisbury Township and Allentown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and early evening of July 22.  Rainfall amounts of 1 to near 3 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Little Lehigh Creek in the Allentown area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and early evening of July 22.  Rainfall amounts of 1 to near 3 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Perkiomen Creek at East Greenville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor frontal boundary was moving slowly northeast to southeast across northwest Pennsylvania during the evening of July 19th. A line severe thunderstorms blew down trees across rural Crawford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storms with heavy rain fell across eastern Crawford County on the night and early morning of July 19 and 20th. The Oil Creek flooded Gresham Road in Hydetown with 3 to 4 feet of water, causing substantial damage to the blacktop.  One home had their back wall knocked down, and several others had water flooding their basements.  One person even had to be airlifted from their home. Other roadways that were closed in Crawford County due to damage sustained during the flood include Fish Flats Road/Sparta Street/Britton Road from Garland Street, in Centerville to White Road, in Rome Township; and Faunce Town Road from Washington Street in Troy Township to Maple Hill Road in Troy Township. A bridge on Foote Road was swept away by a tributary to the Oil Creek. Titusville Water Works reported 3.89��� of rain, though this gage was located south of the area of heaviest rain. Estimated rainfall was 4 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped in flood waters at the intersection of Reading Avenue and Trout Run Road in Douglass Township, and a water rescue was needed.  Another water rescue took place at the intersection of Farmington Avenue and Englesville Hill Road in Douglass Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place at the intersection of Fagleysville Road and Colonial Road in Upper Frederick Township.  Another water rescue took place on Snyder Road in Upper Frederick Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: PA Route 100 was closed in both directions near Bechtelsville due to flash flooding.  Some buildings in Bechtelsville took on water.  Campers were evacuated from the Lazy-K Campground near Bechtelsville.  Some tents and camping trailers were swept away by the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An excessively warm and humid airmass resided over northeastern Pennsylvania for several days. A weak surface boundary provided the focus for slow moving, conglomerated thunderstorms which produced several hours of locally heavy downpours. This resulted in excessive runoff to streams and drainage systems in the Kingston and Wilkes-Barre areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several city streets and roads were flooded by torrential rainfall overwhelming drainage infrastructure. Cars were stranded in flood waters with water up to the windows in some cases.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An excessively warm and humid airmass resided over northeastern Pennsylvania for several days. A weak surface boundary provided the focus for slow moving, conglomerated thunderstorms which produced several hours of locally heavy downpours. This resulted in excessive runoff to streams and drainage systems in the Kingston and Wilkes-Barre areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several residences in the area were reported to be flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place along Upper Pine Creek Road near Davis Road in West Pikeland Township.  Flash flooding occurred along Pickering Creek in West Pikeland Township with flood waters reaching Conestoga Road and Kimberton Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place along Kutztown Road near Fox Hollow Lane in Upper Hanover Township.  Other water rescues took place on Wasser Road near Ridge Way, and along Quakertown Avenue at Ott Road in Upper Hanover Township.  A water rescue took place on Washington Street near 3rd Street in Pennsburg.  Moderate flooding occurred along the Perkiomen Creek and its tributaries in Upper Hanover Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An excessively warm and humid airmass resided over northeastern Pennsylvania for several days. A weak surface boundary provided the focus for slow moving, conglomerated thunderstorms which produced several hours of locally heavy downpours. This resulted in excessive runoff to streams and drainage systems in the Kingston and Wilkes-Barre areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major urban flash flooding occurred in the Greater Wilkes-Barre area. Numerous roads were flooded, cars stranded, and reports of water up to the door of a police station. Homes and apartments in the area were taking on water. Sink holes had opened up on a few roads.

A weak surface boundary provided the focus for slow moving, conglomerated thunderstorms which produced several hours of locally heavy downpours. This resulted in excessive runoff to streams and drainage systems in the Kingston and Wilkes-Barre areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four feet of water was reported on roads between Welles Street and Hoyt Street. The first floor of an apartment building was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought 2 to around 5.5 inches of rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 11.  The heaviest of the rain fell in southeastern Berks County, northern Chester County and upper Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pregnant woman and her son were trapped in a car that flipped over after being swept against a guardrail on Grist Mill Road near Locust Road along the Ironstone Creek.  The two were trapped inside the vehicle, where they both perished. The rescue crew could not reach them until the water receded about 5 hours later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass, with little wind shear, continued to linger across the Ohio River Valley. Convection was anticipated with daytime heating under a weak trough.  A flash flood watch was expanded due to heavy rainfall the previous day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local 911 Call Center reported Route 58 near the railroad tracks closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass, with little wind shear, continued to linger across the Ohio River Valley. Convection was anticipated with daytime heating under a weak trough.  A flash flood watch was expanded due to heavy rainfall the previous day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local 911 Call Center reported West Jamestown Rd. flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass, with little wind shear, continued to linger across the Ohio River Valley. Convection was anticipated with daytime heating under a weak trough.  A flash flood watch was expanded due to heavy rainfall the previous day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local 911 Call Center reported Wise Road flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The previous days weather left southern Pennsylvania saturated. These antecedent conditions along with a stalled shortwave trough allowed for bands of rainfall to move through the Somerset and Bedford counties the evening of July 7th overnight into early July 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over the intersection of Rockdale and Mt. Davis roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of central Pennsylvania during the afternoon of August 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blair County experienced a deluge of heavy rain that has caused multiple incidents in several townships. An apartment complex at 1160 Municipal Drive in Allegheny Township was flooded with contact made with all residents and no evacuations reported. Also in Allegheny Township a fire has been reported at another apartment complex at 3111 Colonial Drive with an unknown number of apartments involved or persons displaced. No injuries reported. The Cross Keys Village at 418 Holstein Drive in Allegheny Township has been flooded with contact made with all residents within the trailer park. No evacuations reported. In Logan Township, a structure fire and multiple trees down have been reported. A shelter was set up a the Allegheny Township Fire Station. The Blair County''s EOC was not been activated, only a few local municipalities EOCs activated.||In addition, flooding was reported at the Sylvan Hills Golf Course in Hollidaysburg.  See https://www.wearecentralpa.com/news/local-news/stunning-video-drone-footage-of-flooded-sylvan-hills-golf-course-in-hollidaysburg/ .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of central Pennsylvania during the afternoon of August 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were trapped in high water at the McDonalds in Coal Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought flash flooding to portions of central Pennsylvania during the afternoon of August 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to a trained spotter a bridge was washed out and a road buckled at Logan Run Road near the intersection with Bowden Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought some flash flooding to portions of the area on the evening of August 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported and many roads were reported flooded in Smethport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist southeasterly wind flow interacted with a stationary boundary over southern NY, triggering clusters of slow moving thunderstorms across northeast PA. Locally heavy rainfall contributed to flash flooding in Luzerne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Berwick Highway was closed due to flash flooding. Motorists were stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads in and around Forks Township were flooded and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough remained in place over the region on August 5th.  Instability was sufficient for the generation of numerous showers and thunderstorms, especially north of Pittsburgh, but relatively low CAPE and shear levels kept storms sub-severe.  However,  a slow-moving storm with very heavy rainfall did create some minor flash flooding in portions of Mercer County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported flooding at the intersection of Lamor Road and Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Salford Station Road was closed due to flash flooding in Lower Frederick Township near PA Route 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 29.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches fell in a short amount of time, with some locally higher amounts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several water rescues took place in Bensalem Township, Bristol Township and Middletown Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 29. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were impassable due to flash flooding in Sumneytown (Marlborough Township).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals of 1.5 to 2.0 inches fell from Berks County into the Lehigh Valley on the evening of May 19.  There were locally higher rainfall amounts in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North 5th Street Highway was closed in Muhlenberg Township in the vicinity of Elizabeth Avenue due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on State Hill Road in Wyomissing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Interstate 95 in Philadelphia around Interchange 30.  The exit ramp became impassable due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough was in place across the eastern part of the country on August 2nd.  A weak shortwave moving through that upper system induced an inverted surface trough that slid slowly westward across southwest Pennsylvania through the day.  Storms initially formed to the northeast of Pittsburgh, with one storm causing wind damage in Jefferson County.  ||Thunderstorms then developed westward during the afternoon, following the surface trough.  Instability was sufficient for strong updrafts which produced a few more hail and wind damage reports.  A weak wind field prevented storms from becoming more organized, but that wind field also promoted slow storm motion, leading to a few roadway flash flooding reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county emergency manager reported that Route 31 was flooded in Donegal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 29.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches fell in a short amount of time, with some locally higher amounts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local fire department pulled a male teenager out of the flood swollen Mill Creek in Middletown Township.  The individual was kayaking with another male teenage when he fell out of the kayak.  The victim was pulled from the creek but later died at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia.  A law enforcement official indicated that the creek's high and fast moving water likely contributed to the victims death.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough remained in place over the region on August 5th.  Instability was sufficient for the generation of numerous showers and thunderstorms, especially north of Pittsburgh, but relatively low CAPE and shear levels kept storms sub-severe.  However,  a slow-moving storm with very heavy rainfall did create some minor flash flooding in portions of Mercer County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county 911 call center reported that Old Sharon Road was flooded near Sharon Mercer Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of weak mid-level shortwaves moved across the upper Ohio Valley during the afternoon hours.  The first storms formed near Interstate 80 around noon, with a broken line of convection then forming towards the southwest during the afternoon hours.||Instability and shear levels were sufficient to create an ideal environment for damaging wind gusts.  Many reports of tree and power line damage were received, along with a few instances of structural damage.  A roof was blown off of a house in Roscoe, and several structures were damaged by a storm at Sigel.  Flash flooding was also reported in Mercer County during the early evening, as a result of multiple thunderstorms moving over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County 911 officials reported flash flooding along North Good Hope Road.

Many reports of tree and power line damage were received, along with a few instances of structural damage.  A roof was blown off of a house in Roscoe, and several structures were damaged by a storm at Sigel.  Flash flooding was also reported in Mercer County during the early evening, as a result of multiple thunderstorms moving over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported water over Pennsylvania Route 58 near the Stone Arch Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The risk for severe storms continued May 29th as necessary ingredients stayed in place. An unstable/ buoyant atmosphere, wind shear to sustain updrafts, and large scale |ascension with a crossing shortwave were all present. With a stalled boundary, and precipitable water values pushing up to 2 inches, flash flooding was also a concern throughout the entire day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager reported that Becks Run Road was closed from Wagner Street to East Carson due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager reported that the vicinity of the 31st Street Bridge up through Herron Avenue was closed due to flooding. Route 28 was also closed and water rescues had to be performed due to 30 inches of water accumulating in one lane. A landslide was also reported near the 1800 Block of Spring Garden Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Urban flooding and isolated strong wind associated with thunderstorms occurred the night of September 1st (early morning September 2nd) as a shortwave passed across the Ohio River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 Call Center reported flooding at Route 65 and 4th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist southern flow along a quasi stationary boundary drifted eastward into the evening of May 9th, 2019. That brought areas of heavy rainfall which caused flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall caused flooding along Gilbert Hollow Road and caused debris to dam a  drain which led to the evacuation of 21 homes along Gilbert Hollow Road.  The rain and water subsided by 1144 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mid-level westerly flow of 45-70kts streamed over the Great Lakes/Upper Ohio Valley. A shortwave trough embedded within this zonal flow entered the region and moved eastward throughout the day, helping to provide forcing for ascent and strengthening of deep layer shear.  Mid-level westerly flow of 45 to 70 knots also streamed over the Great Lakes and the Upper Ohio Valley. Large hail was supported by mean layer CAPE of 1500 to 3000 J/kg and effective bulk shear of 35 to 50kts. Additionally, strong synoptic winds and steepening low-level lapse rates increased the severe wind threat.||With high precipitable water values of around 1.5 inches, training storms were also able to produce localized flooding.||The hail from this event was so severe that windows in homes broke and cars were damaged. A local car dealership said that from the time of the incident to the end of September they were booked with car repairs due to hail damage. Roughly, the damage from hail for this event cost at least 12 million dollars.||The town of Zelienople, PA was hit hard with rain, as a total of 4 to 5 inches accumulated in just a few hours. As a result, the Connoquenessing Creek rose throughout the night and crested at just over 15.3 feet on Wednesday morning, May 29th.  Based on historical crests, this was the 4th highest crest on record; records go back to the early 1920s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 Call Center reported that the 500 block of Delaware Avenue was flooded. A vehicle was stuck but managed to escape.

Large hail was supported by mean layer CAPE of 1500 to 3000 J/kg and effective bulk shear of 35 to 50kts. Additionally, strong synoptic winds and steepening low-level lapse rates increased the severe wind threat.||With high precipitable water values of around 1.5 inches, training storms were also able to produce localized flooding.||The hail from this event was so severe that windows in homes broke and cars were damaged. A local car dealership said that from the time of the incident to the end of September they were booked with car repairs due to hail damage. Roughly, the damage from hail for this event cost at least 12 million dollars.||The town of Zelienople, PA was hit hard with rain, as a total of 4 to 5 inches accumulated in just a few hours. As a result, the Connoquenessing Creek rose throughout the night and crested at just over 15.3 feet on Wednesday morning, May 29th.  Based on historical crests, this was the 4th highest crest on record; records go back to the early 1920s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 Call Center reported Blackwoods Road, Fezell Rd, Sterele School Rd, and Rochester Run Rd in New Sewickley Towsnship flooded.

Additionally, strong synoptic winds and steepening low-level lapse rates increased the severe wind threat.||With high precipitable water values of around 1.5 inches, training storms were also able to produce localized flooding.||The hail from this event was so severe that windows in homes broke and cars were damaged. A local car dealership said that from the time of the incident to the end of September they were booked with car repairs due to hail damage. Roughly, the damage from hail for this event cost at least 12 million dollars.||The town of Zelienople, PA was hit hard with rain, as a total of 4 to 5 inches accumulated in just a few hours. As a result, the Connoquenessing Creek rose throughout the night and crested at just over 15.3 feet on Wednesday morning, May 29th.  Based on historical crests, this was the 4th highest crest on record; records go back to the early 1920s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen reported flooding along Highway 224.

Mid-level westerly flow of 45 to 70 knots also streamed over the Great Lakes and the Upper Ohio Valley. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The risk for severe storms continued May 29th as necessary ingredients stayed in place. An unstable/ buoyant atmosphere, wind shear to sustain updrafts, and large scale |ascension with a crossing shortwave were all present. With a stalled boundary, and precipitable water values pushing up to 2 inches, flash flooding was also a concern throughout the entire day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 Call in Center reported Route 51 closed in both directions between Aliquippa and Hopewell Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved northeast through the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River valley, bringing a plume of deep moisture into Northeast Pennsylvania. Rain, with embedded bands of thunderstorms, developed ahead of the low pressure area during the day of 31 October. A widespread swath of 1 to 2 inches of rain fell throughout the region, with localized amounts in the 2.5 to 4 inch range. Some of this heavy rainfall fell in a short amount of time, producing several areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Floodwaters covered Route 414 with a mudslide also blocking the roadway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bailey Corners Road flooded with areas of the road completely washed away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania and northern New Jersey on the night of October 31.  Rainfall totals of 1.0 to 2.5 inches were common from Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and the Pocono Region in Pennsylvania into northwestern New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the West Branch of the Perkiomen Creek in Upper Hanover Township and Douglass Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the East Branch of the Brandywine Creek in West Bradford Township and East Bradford Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the West Branch of the Brandywine Creek in Honey Brook Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias brought high winds, heavy rain, several tornadoes, and coastal flooding to the mid-Atlantic region, becoming the most impactful tropical cyclone to impact most of the region since Sandy in 2012. Flash flooding as a result of heavy rain caused two direct deaths from this event...one in Lehigh County and the other in Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along Valley Creek in the Valley Forge area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred in Maidencreek Township.  Main Street in Blandon was closed at the railroad tracks.  US Route 222 was under water at Dries Road.  Willow Creek was out of its banks at a number of locations in the township.  A tributary of Willow Creek was also out of its banks and caused flooding on Cornerstone Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred in Muhlenberg Township and in Laureldale.  There were a number of water rescues in the area.  The intersection of Darby Avenue and 6th Avenue was under water.  PA Route 12 was closed between PA Route 61 and the 5th Street Highway.  Flooding occurred around the intersection of Hain Avenue and Laurel Run Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused a sinkhole to develop at the interchange between US Route 222 and PA Route 61 in Muhlenberg Township.  The sinkhole was approximately 20 feet in diameter and at least 8 feet deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were trapped in flood waters at the interchange between US 222/422 and State Hill Road in Wyomissing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred in Ontelaunee Township with at least one water rescue taking place.  Willow Creek was out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred in Fleetwood and in Richmond Township.  A water rescue took place at the intersection of Forest Street and West Spring Street in Fleetwood.  Sections of Main Street were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sections of Fairview Drive in Kutztown were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to Berks County during the early hours of August 2.  Rainfall totals as high as 4 to 6 inches fell in the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two vehicles were stranded in flood waters near the intersection of North Heidelberg Road and Fairway Drive in North Heidelberg Township.  At least two individuals were rescued from the vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of August 12.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on the Industrial Highway in Tinicum Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of August 12.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Lower Oxford Township were impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on August 13.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Broad Street was closed at Sandy Ridge Drive in Doylestown due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from an approaching weather system persisted for several hours. A locally enhanced line of thunderstorm activity triggered rapid and enhanced flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Branch of Towanda Creek was over its banks and flooding structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from an approaching weather system persisted for several hours. A locally enhanced line of thunderstorm activity triggered rapid and enhanced flooding in a few locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from an approaching weather system persisted for several hours. A locally enhanced line of thunderstorm activity triggered rapid and enhanced flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads are flooded around Litchfield with water encroaching into residential areas. Some roads were damaged and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing warm front promoted heavy rain and thunderstorms during the afternoon of March 28th. Substantial breaks in the clouds south of the boundary, along with substantial warm air advection, resulted in around 1500 J/kg of mean-layer CAPE,  and substantial (60kts+) effective shear was in place across the region. Hail growth increased into the evening as effective wind shear increased to 70kts over eastern Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Police were said to be responding on Brownsville Road, which was covered with water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two water rescues took place on South Union Avenue near Bartram Avenue in Lansdowne.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: South New Middletown Road was closed in Middletown Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough and its associated surface cold front advanced across the upper Midwest and Great Lakes on July 10th. Conditions were favorable for strong/ severe downburst winds. HREF models at the time suggested a period of 1500 MUCAPE across the western counties, steep low-level lapse rates, and surface delta theta-e values approaching 20K. Flooding was likely due low shear and PWAT values near 1.5-1.8 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported in north Union Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed during the heat of the early afternoon over northeastern Pennsylvania. Torrential rainfall, and slow moving storms produced localized flash flooding in Wyoming county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stony Brook rapidly overflowed its banks and flooded a road along Mehoopany Creek. Fast moving water was up to 3 feet deep in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locations hit by rain the evening of July 23rd were prime for possible flooding given development of rain earlier in the day. A marginal for excessive rainfall was in place as well given the 1.8 to 1.9 PWATS. A crossing trough created the development of thunderstorms and showers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local fire department reported flooding on Shannon Creek Road in New Florence and basement flooding in the city of Derry. A local citizen reported 4 inches of rain from 500PM 07/23/2020 to 500AM 07/24/2020.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias tracked from south to north across far eastern Pennsylvania during the morning and early afternoon of August 4, 2020. Heavy rain impacted the Susquehanna Valley, and there was one report of a tree down on a home in Lancaster County. Later that day, isolated storms developed ahead of an approaching cold front with one storm producing a report of a tree down in Blair County with a wind estimated at only 45-50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported across the area. A water rescue was performed at the 2400 block of Beaver Valley Pike in New Providence. Flooding blocked one lane of traffic on Route 283 near Route 30 eastbound. Flooding was reported 2 miles north of Ephrata. Flooding was reported on Route 897 in East Cocalico Township. In Lancaster flooding was reported along Steel Way and across Route 283 in Manheim Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On August 22nd, showers and thunderstorms developed near and south of a dewpoint gradient extending from Indiana, PA to New Philadelphia, OH.  Outflow from these storms allowed a few additional cells to develop over Allegheny County.  The slow-moving storms produced instances of wind damage and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streets Run was overflowing onto the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On August 22nd, showers and thunderstorms developed near and south of a dewpoint gradient extending from Indiana, PA to New Philadelphia, OH.  Outflow from these storms allowed a few additional cells to develop over Allegheny County.  The slow-moving storms produced instances of wind damage and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connor Road was flooded in Mount Lebanon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over central Pennsylvania, ahead of a weak mid-level shortwave, during the afternoon of August 7, 2020. A few of these storms produced wind damage, as well as flash flooding across Lancaster and York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding was reported across Lancaster and a small portion of York County.||A dozen water rescue calls were reported for areas including East Hempfield, East Lampeter, Manheim, Providence, Salisbury, Strasburg, Upper Leacock, West Earl and West Hempfield townships.||In addition to the water rescue calls, there were many reports of high water on roads across the Lancaster county, and some residential flooding.||Two rescue calls were  for vehicles in water, according to initial dispatch reports, one on Meadow View Drive in West Earl Township just before 4 p.m., and one in the area of East Main Street in Upper Leacock Township just after 4 p.m. ||A third water rescue call was reported in the 300 block of West Main Street in Upper Leacock Township just before 4:30 p.m.||Just before 5 p.m., more water rescue calls were reported: in the 1300 block of Marshall Avenue in Manheim Township; in the 500 block of Weaver Road in Strasburg Township; and at Independence Court and Greenfield Road in East Lampeter Township.||Others followed shortly, at Pennsy Road and Main Street in Providence Township; at Greenfield Road and railroad tracks in East Lampeter Township; at Strasburg Road and Old Strasburg Road in Salisbury Township; and at Lincoln Highway East and North Kinzer Road in Paradise Township.  High water was also reported at Old Harrisburg Pike and Spooky Nook Road in West Hempfield Township, and at Snapper Dam Road and Northside Drive in East Hempfield Township. ||Calls for high water on roadway later came from Bowman Road and Parker Drive in East Hempfield Township; Cardinal Road and North Elm Street in Lititz Borough; South 14th Street and Central Avenue in Columbia Borough; and Ruby Street and Froelich Avenue in Mountville Borough.||By 4:40 p.m. the list of calls for high water on roadway included Peace Road in West Earl Township; Church Street and Daryl Drive in East Hempfield Township; West Penn Grant Road and Marticville Road in Pequea Township; and Peach Bottom Road and Beaver Valley Pike in West Lampeter Township.||At 5pm a water rescue was reported at Arsenal Road and North George Stree 1 mile north of York in York County.|||Later reports came from Marticville Road and Goods Run in Pequea Township; Hollinger Road and Millwood Road in West Lampeter Township; Bachmantown Road and South Ronks Road in East Lampeter Township; Snakehill Road and Route 23 in Upper Leacock Township; and Running Pump Road in East Hempfield Township. ||Starting at about 5:30 p.m., high water on roadway reports came for Embassy Drive and Rohrerstown Road in East Hempfield Township; New Holland Avenue and East Ross Street in Lancaster City; and Pleasure Road and Deer Ford Drive in Manheim Township.||Just before 5:30 p.m., PPL's outage center showed 805 customers without power in Lancaster County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Narrow bands of heavy rainfall, north of a warm front, brought pockets of serious flash flooding and urban flooding to northeast Pennsylvania during the early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rainfall in a short amount of time caused flash flooding on numerous roads in Bridgewater Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Narrow bands of heavy rainfall, north of a warm front, brought pockets of serious flash flooding and urban flooding to northeast Pennsylvania during the early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rainfall caused severe road flooding throughout Hallstead.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved though northern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 24th. This sparked scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area. One particular cluster of storm cells over Luzerne county triggered excessive rainfall and areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall flooded a residence to the first floor in Kingston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved though northern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of the 24th. This sparked scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area. One particular cluster of storm cells over Luzerne county triggered excessive rainfall and areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous cars were submerged by flash flood waters throughout Kingston borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On August 28th, a weak crossing surface low and an advancing upper trough helped to create additional thunderstorms, which were also aided by deep tropical moisture from the remnants of Hurricane Laura. Two waves of thunderstorms occurred on this day.  The first, along a lingering frontal boundary, caused wind damage to a few areas north of Pittsburgh.  A second round of storms, resulting from the crossing shortwave and deeper moisture, mainly resulted in heavy rain across portions of southwest Pennsylvania.  Urban flash flooding occurred in Allegheny County, with several reports received.  At least two vehicles were reported to be stuck in flood water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of flooded basements were received from the West Mifflin area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain and embedded thunderstorms moved through Northeast Pennsylvania on the 4th associated with Tropical Storm Isaias. Widespread rainfall of 3 to 5 inches occurred across the region. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding inundated the basement and first floor of a home in Greentown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain and embedded thunderstorms moved through Northeast Pennsylvania on the 4th associated with Tropical Storm Isaias. Widespread rainfall of 3 to 5 inches occurred across the region. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding throughout Honesdale led to multiple road closures. Up to four homes were affected by significant flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain and embedded thunderstorms moved through Northeast Pennsylvania on the 4th associated with Tropical Storm Isaias. Widespread rainfall of 3 to 5 inches occurred across the region. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flood waters entered several residences in the Borough of Lackawaxen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An impulse riding along a west to east boundary stalled near the Mason-Dixon line produced severe thunderstorms and heavy rain across sections of extreme southeast Pennsylvania from late afternoon through the evening hours on August 7th. Strong winds knocked down trees, and torrential downpours on ground already saturated from the remnants of Hurricane Isaias produced flash flooding on many roadways and small streams in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on McCue Road at Woodview Road in London Grove Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias brought high winds, heavy rain, several tornadoes, and coastal flooding to the mid-Atlantic region, becoming the most impactful tropical cyclone to impact most of the region since Sandy in 2012. Flash flooding as a result of heavy rain caused two direct deaths from this event...one in Lehigh County and the other in Montgomery County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Bryn Mawr Avenue was closed near Mill Road in Radnor Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex storm system moved from the Lower Mississippi valley to lower Ontario during this time period. Warm and moist air surged northward from the Gulf of Mexico bringing rain and temperatures in the lower 50s. Rainfall on the order of 2 to 4 inches accompanied the storm system. The warmer air and windy conditions rapidly melted a substantial snowpack of 20 to 30 inches in the region. This, coupled with the heavy rainfall, contributed to rapid stream rises resulting in flash flooding, followed by flooding of the main river channels on Christmas Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rapidly rising in the area with one home flooded to the first floor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex storm system moved from the Lower Mississippi valley to lower Ontario during this time period. Warm and moist air surged northward from the Gulf of Mexico bringing rain and temperatures in the lower 50s. Rainfall on the order of 2 to 4 inches accompanied the storm system. The warmer air and windy conditions rapidly melted a substantial snowpack of 20 to 30 inches in the region. This, coupled with the heavy rainfall, contributed to rapid stream rises resulting in flash flooding, followed by flooding of the main river channels on Christmas Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding led to evacuations of residences along Bluegrass Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and thunderstorms impacted central Pennsylvania on June 4, 2020. Individual cells formed over the central mountains during the afternoon hours, with some displaying supercellular nature. Splitting cells were observed, and there were numerous hail and damaging wind reports. This activity continued into the evening hours, while a separate, diminishing convective line of storms pushed into central Pennsylvania from the west.  ||One Flash Flood was reported during the evening in Schuylkill County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall brought flash flooding to Pine Grove which resulted in several closed roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms were able to form along a boundary left by the passage of a decaying mesoscale convective system during the morning hours of the 27th.  Dry air aloft led to the development of sufficient downdraft CAPE, allowing a few instances of localized strong wind.  A few reports of flooding were received as well, as storms were able to train east-west along the boundary and create localized heavy rainfall totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be rushing across US 422 adjacent to the BP gas station on the east side of Shelocta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in a moderate CAPE/weak shear environment during the early evening hours of July 8, 2020. A multi-cell cluster produced wind damage in Sullivan County, and few pulse storms produced wind damage in the Susquehanna Valley.  ||Slow moving thunderstorms also brought isolated flash flooding to Somerset and York Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash Flooding was reported in downtown Somerset.  Water was blocking traffic on South Ankeny Road and West Garrett.
