EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Post-Tropical Cyclone Fred caused flash flooding in eastern Pennsylvania on the night of August 18-19, 2021.  There were rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinehurst Road in Bethlehem was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania on the night of September 8.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: PA Route 145 was closed in North Whitehall Township to the south of Laurys Station due to flooding.  There was a water rescue from a vehicle at Second Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania on the night of September 8.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a water rescue from a vehicle on Industrial Drive at Avenue B in Bethlehem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating helped fuel storms as they developed along a cold front that passed through Northeastern Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding and related damages in the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few roads were flooded along Equinunk Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating helped fuel storms as they developed along a cold front that passed through Northeastern Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding and related damages in the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads are covered with water in Galilee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable environment in Northeast Pennsylvania allowed for thunderstorms, triggered by a passing warm front, to become severe with torrential rainfall. These storms produced areas of flash flooding in Bradford county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 187 was flooded in several locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain producing thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front displacing warm and very humid air over Northeastern Pennsylvania. Torrential rainfall from consecutive rounds of thunderstorm activity produced areas of flash flooding and localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many streets flooded in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain producing thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front displacing warm and very humid air over Northeastern Pennsylvania. Torrential rainfall from consecutive rounds of thunderstorm activity produced areas of flash flooding and localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oak Street was flooding from Keyser Creek. Road is closed and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused flash flooding in the Pennsylvania counties of Monroe and Northampton on the night of August 22.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to 8 inches in the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gilbert Road in Gilbert was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warner Road was closed at PA Route 715 in Pocono Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Berks County with many road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was slowly moving northeast from IN through northern OH during the day of July 11th, 2021, lifting a warm front northward towards northwest PA. Showers and thunderstorms moved northeast across Erie County, PA for much of the daytime hours ahead of this front. An low echo centroid storm with intense rainfall rates around 1.5 per hour produce efficient heavy rainfall over an area with saturated soils from the showers during the morning and afternoon hours. PWAT values were near 1.8, with modest MUCAPE values generally 500 j/kg or less. This intense burst of rain dropped around 1.5 in a little over an hour in the Edinboro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported several road closures in and around Edinboro due to flooding. Reports of numerous flooded basements. Received video of a creek out of it's banks, with several inches of water flowing over Gibson Hill Road near Capp Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm, unstable airmass has been in place over the region for much of the week leading up to July 17th, 2021, with several rounds of rainfall during the week leading to saturated soils across northwest PA. Thunderstorms developed ahead of an eastward moving cold front, with low echo centroid storms providing efficient, heavy rainfall. Two storms tracked over far southeast Crawford county in PA, dropping over 2 of rainfall in a one to two hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Titusville Fire Department reported significant flash flooding in Titusville due to Church Run, and additional flooding in Hydetown due to Oil Creek. The majority of flooding reports were from downtown Titusville, where video shows rapidly flowing water through the streets up against buildings and businesses. One water rescue was reported, with several reports of flooded basements. Numerous roads were closed, with Franklin Street being the main road impacted by flowing water. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 2.5 fell just upstream of the city of Titusville in a one to two hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania on the night of September 8.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue from a vehicle took place near the intersection of Mauch Chunk Road and Quarry Street in North Whitehall Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of June 8.  Rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches were reported in the Brandywine Creek basin of Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Parkesburg and Sadsburyville.  There were numerous water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of June 8.  Rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches were reported in the Brandywine Creek basin of Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bridge over Harvey Run on Ring Road in Chadds Ford Township was overtopped by flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania on the night of September 8.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide occurred along one of the access roads to the Portland-Columbia Toll Bridge in Portland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north into Pennsylvania during the day and became stalled during the early evening across the northeastern part of the Commonwealth. Thunderstorms became aligned along the Wyoming Valley, and extended off to the east into the Lackawaxen Valley during the evening. Rainfall amounts between 2 to 3 inches fell in a very short amount of time over urban and moderately populated rural areas leading to several road closures, overtopped bridges and small stream flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water flowing through a residence in this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front slipped southward across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening hours of June 9, 2021, generating scattered showers and thunderstorms in a warm and humid airmass ahead of it. A few of these storms produced localized wind damage before dissipating after sunset.  One flash flood was reported in Schuylkill County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall brought flash flooding to the area. A heavily flooded road was reported on Pine Creek Drive near Orwigsburg.  On Green Tree Drive a bridge and the road was reported flooded.  Other roads were reported flooded in the Orwigsburg area.  Route 901 was washed out in North Manheim Township. North 23rd Street in Pottsville was washed out and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through Northeastern Pennsylvania, producing some showers and thunderstorms. Moisture was high in the atmosphere, and storms were very slow moving, resulting in areas of torrential rain and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of Lehigh Road was washed out along Roaring Brook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved through Northeastern Pennsylvania, producing some showers and thunderstorms. Moisture was high in the atmosphere, and storms were very slow moving, resulting in areas of torrential rain and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over multiple roads around the Trucksville area. Many roads experienced damage from shoulder washouts. Sutton Road was washed out in a few locations and remained closed for more than a day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-stationary boundary was in place over southwest Pennsylvania on May 24th.  Taking advantage of an abundance of moisture and upper shortwave support, showers and thunderstorms developed and tracked along the boundary.  A couple of flooding events occurred in the urbanized areas of Allegheny County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A female was rescued after her car became stuck in high water near the Verizon Building at 590 Union Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 12.  Rainfall totals up to 6 to 10 inches occurred in Northeast Philadelphia and in far lower Bucks County prompting the issuance of a Flash Flood Emergency.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread significant flooding occurred in Bensalem Township.  There were many road closures including parts of Interstate 95, US Route 13, Woodhaven Road and State Road.  Many individuals were trapped in vehicles by the flood waters, with numerous water rescues becoming necessary.  Flood waters reached houses including some along Allen Avenue, McKinley Avenue and Kings Avenue, where residents needed to be rescued from their homes.  The Lafayette Garden Apartments along US Route 13 at the Poquessing Creek were severely flooded with 80 to 100 units affected.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in southeastern Pennsylvania during the afternoon and early evening of July 2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding in North Philadelphia in the vicinity of North Broad Street from West Erie Avenue to West Allegheny Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place in Darby Township along Hook Road near Industrial Drive.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two vehicles were stranded in flood waters at the intersection of Madison Avenue and Tyler Avenue in Phoenixville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding around the Philadelphia Mills Mall with roads closed and a few vehicles stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 17.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place in Bensalem Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rainfall to the Lehigh Valley and to Bucks County during the afternoon and early evening of July 29.  As much as 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Palmerton became impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rainfall to the Lehigh Valley and to Bucks County during the afternoon and early evening of July 29.  As much as 2 to 3 inches of rain fell in parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters were rushing across River Road in Plumstead Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 12.  Rainfall totals up to 6 to 10 inches occurred in Northeast Philadelphia and in far lower Bucks County prompting the issuance of a Flash Flood Emergency.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread significant flooding occurred in Bristol Township.  There were many road closures including parts of US Route 13.  Many individuals were trapped in vehicles by the flood waters, with numerous water rescues becoming necessary including those along Walnut Avenue and along McKinley Street at Wilson Avenue.  Flood waters reached some buildings along US Route 13 in the Croyden section of the township.  Part of Dixon Avenue near Newportville Road was washed out, and residents needed to be evacuated from nearby homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 12.  Rainfall totals up to 6 to 10 inches occurred in Northeast Philadelphia and in far lower Bucks County prompting the issuance of a Flash Flood Emergency.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Vine Street Expressway in Center City Philadelphia became impassable due to flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread severe thunderstorms formed during the afternoon and evening within an environment of moderate CAPE and moderate shear. A shortwave moved across the Ohio Valley giving support for multiple rounds of convection, primarily in the form of multicell clusters and linear segments. Although damaging winds were the main impact, a few storms also created large hail.  Flash flooding was reported from slow moving thunderstorms in Lycoming and Tioga Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding brought multiple road closures along Muncy Creek in Muncy Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 17.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Pennypack Creek in Northeast Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and early evening of July 16, 2021, in a very warm, humid airmass just south of a stalled frontal boundary that was draped across northern Pennsylvania. A few of these storms produced wind damage, including a particularly tall cell that produced winds estimated by a NWS Survey Team to be 85 to 95 mph in a wet microburst near Haneyville in northern Clinton County. Flash flooding from heavy rains also occurred in Northumberland and Sullivan Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding on a small creek brought water across the road at Limestoneville Road and Church Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms develop during the early afternoon hours of July 17, 2021 across western Pennsylvania and in the Lower Susquehanna Valley in an anomalously humid airmass ahead of an approaching cold front. The storms over the Lower Susquehanna Valley developed on a weak boundary in a high CAPE environment, and produced sporadic wind damage before moving to the east. The storms over western Pennsylvania eventually congealed into a broken line that progressed eastward across central Pennsylvania and had imbedded regions of damaging winds and very heavy rain. One hail report was received from beneath a particularly tall cell that developed over Blue Mountain just west of Marysville in Perry County.  Flash flooding from these storms was reported across McKean, Dauphin and Tioga Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of several roads in the Port Allegheny area.  A building collapse was also reported from a wash out.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding with water covering roads in Forks and Elkland Townships.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minesite Road in Wescosville was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Post-Tropical Cyclone Fred caused flash flooding in eastern Pennsylvania on the night of August 18-19, 2021.  There were rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on First Avenue in Royersford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed during the afternoon and evening of the 12th in an environment of moderate CAPE and moderate shear southeast of a stationary front. Thunderstorms initially formed as single cells, then formed into multicell clusters later in the event over the Lower Susquehanna Valley.    Further north slower moving storms brought flooding around Mansfield in Tioga County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1935 EDT Tioga County is activating their EOC to an enhanced level due to flooding conditions throughout the county. Trailer park on Benedict Lane in Roseville is being evacuated, one foot of water and rising. Rt 660 in Delmar Township is flooded. Route 6 in Mansfield is flooding. Numerous roadways washed out and flooded. |At 2020 EDT Roseville area at 73 Benedict Road (in Mansfield) a Mobile Home Park is flooding, 10 residents are being evacuated to the Mansfield Fire Department. Route 549 and Route 6 in Roseville are underwater in multiple locations. Route 549 is passable, but has substantial debris on the roadway from the flooding. At 2246 EDT a total of 38 persons were evacuated from the Roseville area this evening. Route 549 remains closed. Route 6 has reopened. Route 287 has reopened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in a moderate CAPE, moderate shear environment just south of a warm front that was draped from northwest to southeast across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon of July 11, 2021. Several of the storms produced wind damage, and a few storms exhibited rotation near the warm front.   One slower moving thunderstorm brought urban flash flooding to Harrisburg.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in several cars stranded in water on Cameron Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread severe thunderstorms formed during the afternoon and evening within an environment of moderate CAPE and moderate shear. A shortwave moved across the Ohio Valley giving support for multiple rounds of convection, primarily in the form of multicell clusters and linear segments. Although damaging winds were the main impact, a few storms also created large hail.  Flash flooding was reported from slow moving thunderstorms in Lycoming and Tioga Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding with water across the roadway on State Route 287 in Delmar Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front, along with shortwave support, created the chance for thunderstorms across the region. Sufficient shear (40kts in the 0-6km layer), moderate to high instability (1500-2000 J/kg of CAPE), and dry mid-level air resulted in damaging winds and hail. Flash flooding occurred, mostly south of Pittsburgh, with training storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of flooding south and east of Pittsburgh, numerous vehicles were stuck. In Whitehall, intersection of Provost and Wayman flooded near Saw Mill Run. Widespread flooding was reported in West Mifflin. In Monroeville, near  I-376 East, a vehicle was stranded on ramp. A few streets were flooded in Swissvale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Post-Tropical Cyclone Fred caused flash flooding in eastern Pennsylvania on the night of August 18-19, 2021.  There were rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along the Frankford Creek in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While a shortwave trough moved south of the Ohio River Valley, isolated to scattered convection initiated in an area of low confluence north of Pittsburgh. As a result, slow moving heavy downpours ignited. Relief from rain didn't come for the city of Butler until outflow boundary collision.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sullivan Run in Butler, PA went out of its banks due to heavy rainfall. In a short amount of time, Butler County EMS and Media reported flooding at the intersection of West Jefferson and West Cunningham Street.  Flooding due to Sullivan Run also occurred at the intersection of West Brady Street and Hayes Ave; additional nearby streets also impacted. Multiple cars stuck and at least one basement was flooded. Pictures suggest at least 1 foot of water over the roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused flash flooding in the Pennsylvania counties of Monroe and Northampton on the night of August 22.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to 8 inches in the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicles were trapped in flood waters in Middle Smithfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong isolated storm created heavy downpours and tree damage to portions to Carnegie, PA June 8th. At the time of the storm, the region was still under a ridge. Day time heating and deep moisture created enough instability aloft to help thunderstorm development. Based off the radar, it looks like a shortwave over central Ohio, moving east towards I-70, helped make a non-severe storm become stronger. The road that received a flood report is prone to this hazard due to urban runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated heavy rain caused Washington Ave near Boden Ave to flood. A car was stuck in high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused flash flooding in the Pennsylvania counties of Monroe and Northampton on the night of August 22.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to 8 inches in the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fiddletown Road was closed due to flooding near Kunkletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 16th, a weak positively-tilted trough tracked from the Mississippi River Valley towards the Great Lakes today, while a surface front slowly sagged south from Lake Erie. Diurnal heating in an air mass with rich moisture plus increasing jet support yielded numerous thunderstorms, mainly favoring eastern Ohio and northwest Pennsylvania. Differential heating on the southern fringe of a thicker cloud deck and residual convective outflows provided the catalyst for development. Many reports of tree and power line damage were received. Also, multiple rounds of downpours during the day created flash flooding conditions in portions of Mercer and Venango Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crestview Drive near Reynold VFW was flooded.  Also, 20 feet of roadway washed out along SR-4014 near Reynolds Industrial Park Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of June 8.  Rainfall totals of 3 to 7 inches were reported in the Brandywine Creek basin of Chester County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Valley Township, Coatesville and South Coatesville.  There were numerous water rescues.  Minor flooding occurred along the West Branch of the Brandywine Creek in and around Coatesville and South Coatesville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the city of Philadelphia and nearby communities on the evening of June 14.  Rainfall totals were around 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place at the intersection of South Union Avenue and Park Place in Yeadon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along Frankford Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in South Philadelphia.  There were a few water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms formed ahead of a crossing cold front on July 17th.  An upper speed max rotating through an upper trough to the west provided support for lift through right entrance region jet dynamics. Sufficient instability and shear were present to allow storms to organize into clusters and line segments. There were scattered instances of tree damage, and also a report of flash flooding in Venango County due to downpours in the moisture-rich environment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pump Station Road was made impassable due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front remained to the north of the region on July 7th. An upper trough dug across the Great Lakes during the daytime hours as well. While better upper-level forcing remained to the north, return flow increased between this trough and the tropical system Elsa to the southeast. An abundant amount of moisture and warm air was thus funneled into our region.  Deep-layer shear was weak, but enough instability and dry air aloft was present to promote many instances of damaging wind gusts.  Damage to trees and power poles was fairly widespread, and there were a few instances of structural damage as well.  Planes were overturned by wind at Butler Airport, and Edgewood Borough declared a local state of emergency due to thunderstorm wind damage. ||Multiple rounds of thunderstorms also lead to flash flooding concerns in the urbanized areas of Allegheny County. Several instances of stuck vehicles were reported, and several homes were evacuated for a time in Bridgeville due to creek flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few roads were closed due to flooding in Squirrel Hill, with vehicles stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front remained to the north of the region on July 7th. An upper trough dug across the Great Lakes during the daytime hours as well. While better upper-level forcing remained to the north, return flow increased between this trough and the tropical system Elsa to the southeast. An abundant amount of moisture and warm air was thus funneled into our region.  Deep-layer shear was weak, but enough instability and dry air aloft was present to promote many instances of damaging wind gusts.  Damage to trees and power poles was fairly widespread, and there were a few instances of structural damage as well.  Planes were overturned by wind at Butler Airport, and Edgewood Borough declared a local state of emergency due to thunderstorm wind damage. ||Multiple rounds of thunderstorms also lead to flash flooding concerns in the urbanized areas of Allegheny County. Several instances of stuck vehicles were reported, and several homes were evacuated for a time in Bridgeville due to creek flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinewood and Lakeview Drive were both closed due to flooding, with over 2 feet of running water at the intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the Susquehanna Valley during the early evening hours of July 9, 2021, accompanied by scattered thunderstorms. There were wind damage reports along the path of a particularly impressive bow echo that developed over eastern Perry County and dropped southeastward across Dauphin, Lancaster and far southwestern Lebanon counties.  Further north, a band of heavy rain remained nearly stationary during the afternoon, producing flooding in the Mansfield area of Tioga County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding with reports of road closures and damage was reported across Richmond, Sullivan and Rutland Townships and in Mansfield Borough. No water rescues were reported. PA-549 was closed near Scouten Road. Sherman and North Academy Streets in Mansfield was closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in rising water on Station Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of mesoscale convective systems over the Great Lakes advanced into the Ohio River Valley throughout the day on August 12th and helped to create severe storms. Despite little effective shear, DCAPE was very high (between 1300-1400J/kg) and was enough to accelerate downdrafts, causing strong surface wind. Weak zonal flow also created an ideal situation for training storms to develop as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported by local 911 Call Center; flooding on Turner Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed along stationary frontal boundary that stretched east/west near I-70. The favorable environment, tall/skinny CAPE profiles and warm cloud|depths up to 4 km, helped drive more efficient rain rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 66 and Greensburg Road was flooded due to high flow from Poke Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed along stationary frontal boundary that stretched east/west near I-70. The favorable environment, tall/skinny CAPE profiles and warm cloud|depths up to 4 km, helped drive more efficient rain rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple areas flooded in the Finleyville/Library area. A water rescue was due near Lobb's Run Road.  Trax Farms in Finleyville had some flooded. Basements flooded in Peters/Union township. Piney Fork Road closed and flood at Greenman's Tunnel. Floodwaters closed Railroad Street and Airport Road as creeks spilled their banks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding has been reported in the city of Brookville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary, coupled with an extremely warm and humid environment, produced another day of slow moving, torrential downpour producing thunderstorms over Northeast Pennsylvania. Stripes of 1 to 3 inch rainfall occurred over several parts of the area. The greatest rain totals occurred over a large part of Bradford county where 3 to 5 inches accumulated in just a few ours. The region was again hit with major impacts from flash flooding of local creeks, streams and overwhelmed storm drainage systems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 220 was flooded and possibly washed away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed along stationary frontal boundary that stretched east/west near I-70. The favorable environment, tall/skinny CAPE profiles and warm cloud|depths up to 4 km, helped drive more efficient rain rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple areas flooded in Greensburg, roads included: Cemetery road and Hwy 119, Mt. Pleasant Road and Pellis Road, and Slate Run Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary, coupled with an extremely warm and humid environment, produced another day of slow moving, torrential downpour producing thunderstorms over Northeast Pennsylvania. Stripes of 1 to 3 inch rainfall occurred over several parts of the area. The greatest rain totals occurred over a large part of Bradford county where 3 to 5 inches accumulated in just a few ours. The region was again hit with major impacts from flash flooding of local creeks, streams and overwhelmed storm drainage systems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was surrounding homes near Gillett. Evacuation of residents was underway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of mesoscale convective systems over the Great Lakes advanced into the Ohio River Valley throughout the day on August 12th and helped to create severe storms. Despite little effective shear, DCAPE was very high (between 1300-1400J/kg) and was enough to accelerate downdrafts, causing strong surface wind. Weak zonal flow also created an ideal situation for training storms to develop as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in water on Washington Road near the Dairy Queen. Flooding along Saw Mill Run by the Parkway West ramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed the afternoon of the 13th as a result of a passing shortwave to the south and a slow moving trough located north of the Great Lakes. Just like the previous day, despite the fact that effective shear was slightly weak, DCAPE was ranging between 900 to 1000 J/kg. Also the ground was well saturated from storms the previous day, therefore a number of isolated areas were vulnerable to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lexington and Delafield Road closed due to 1 to 2 feet of water. St. Margaret Drive at the intersection of Freeport Rd closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed the afternoon of the 13th as a result of a passing shortwave to the south and a slow moving trough located north of the Great Lakes. Just like the previous day, despite the fact that effective shear was slightly weak, DCAPE was ranging between 900 to 1000 J/kg. Also the ground was well saturated from storms the previous day, therefore a number of isolated areas were vulnerable to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reports Cherry Run Creek out of its banks in Cornplanter Township. Bridge washed out. Route 8 also closed from Route 417 to intersection of Route 227.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 258 flooded between Sandy Lake and Greenville by Hadley Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding had caused a mudslide across Route 220 to the south of Ulster.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 220 near Ulster was reported to be washed out and partially collapsed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were closed due to severe flooding in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain producing thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front displacing warm and very humid air over Northeastern Pennsylvania. Torrential rainfall from consecutive rounds of thunderstorm activity produced areas of flash flooding and localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water is flooding Stevenson Hill Road. A washout is possible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave moved through Northeast Pennsylvania, triggering scattered thunderstorms. Several storms produced torrential rainfall which led to areas of flash flooding. A narrow band of rainfall totaling 2 to 4 inches stretched across the northeast quarter of the county. This rain fell in under 4 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge on Merry Go Round Road was washed out as a result of torrential rainfall and flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave moved through Northeast Pennsylvania, triggering scattered thunderstorms. Several storms produced torrential rainfall which led to areas of flash flooding. A narrow band of rainfall totaling 2 to 4 inches stretched across the northeast quarter of the county. This rain fell in under 4 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood water was flowing over a bridge on Route 467. Bridge was suspected of being severely scoured, or washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave moved through Northeast Pennsylvania, triggering scattered thunderstorms. Several storms produced torrential rainfall which led to areas of flash flooding. A narrow band of rainfall totaling 2 to 4 inches stretched across the northeast quarter of the county. This rain fell in under 4 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred on several rural roads in the area, including Collins Road, Town Road 730, Snyder Lane and Goody Hollow Road. Spaulding Hill Road was reported as impassable due to flood debris.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering mesoscale convective vortex over northwest Ohio that is acting as a trigger for developing thunderstorms on its eastern flank. 850-300mb mean steering flow, suggested at storm motion had the potential to slow down and create flash flooding in regions downstream (i.e. western PA).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooded roadways north of Butler, roads included: Hall Road, Mahood Road, Route 38, and Brady Street near Miler Avenue in the city of Butler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering mesoscale convective vortex over northwest Ohio that is acting as a trigger for developing thunderstorms on its eastern flank. 850-300mb mean steering flow, suggested at storm motion had the potential to slow down and create flash flooding in regions downstream (i.e. western PA).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported in Cranberry Township and Adams Township. Roads affected: Jane Street, Parkhill Road, Jackson Blvd. 2.07 inches of rain was measured in less than an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering mesoscale convective vortex over northwest Ohio that is acting as a trigger for developing thunderstorms on its eastern flank. 850-300mb mean steering flow, suggested at storm motion had the potential to slow down and create flash flooding in regions downstream (i.e. western PA).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooded along Greenglen Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A back building storm developed along the I-80 region and caused flash flooding to occur in isolated areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Businesses along Route 36 affected by flooding, including Dale Smith Campers Sale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak flow aloft and high PWATs (1.77 at PIT), which was just below daily records but in the upper 1-2% of observations at this time of year, created the ideal environment for flash flooding to occur in isolated regions of western PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple areas experienced flooded due to back building storm. Richey Run broke from its banks and flooded Route 208, Route 338 was closed between Ritts Station Road to Blairs Corners Road, and roadways near the county line was affected.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Post-Tropical Cyclone Fred caused flash flooding in eastern Pennsylvania on the night of August 18-19, 2021.  There were rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three water rescues took place in Paoli, one at the intersection of East Lancaster Avenue and Leopard Road, another at the intersection of Maple Avenue and Agnew Lane, and a final one at the intersection of Paoli Pike and Rustic Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level trough with strong mid-level flow and diurnal heating under a moist low-level airmass helped generate severe storms across the Ohio River Valley. Effective bulk shear was 30-40kts and supported storm organization. ML CAPE ranged from 1000-2000J/kg by mid-afternoon, steep lapse rates helped efficient downdraft acceleration.  ||Training storms also created localized flooding along a convergence axis from southeast Ohio to southwest PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 911 Call Center reported a road washed out near the intersection of Ridgewood Drive and Franklin Farms Rd near Chartiers Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level trough with strong mid-level flow and diurnal heating under a moist low-level airmass helped generate severe storms across the Ohio River Valley. Effective bulk shear was 30-40kts and supported storm organization. ML CAPE ranged from 1000-2000J/kg by mid-afternoon, steep lapse rates helped efficient downdraft acceleration.  ||Training storms also created localized flooding along a convergence axis from southeast Ohio to southwest PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple report of flooding in the Baldwin, Pleasant Hills, West Mifflin, and Whitehall. 911 Call Center reported flood West 5th Avenue in McKeesport. A Trained Spotter reported Route 51 through Pleasant Hills is closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Post-Tropical Cyclone Fred caused flash flooding in eastern Pennsylvania on the night of August 18-19, 2021.  There were rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coffeetown Road was closed at Orefield Road in South Whitehall Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Montgomery County with many road closures and vehicles stranded.  Numerous water rescues took place.  Many buildings and homes were flooded.  Most waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the Schuylkill River, Perkiomen Creek and Wissahickon Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Delaware County with numerous road closures.  Many creeks in the county overflowed their banks, including Chester Creek, Ridley Creek, Crum Creek and Cobbs Creek.

The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Lehigh County with many road closures.  There was flooding along numerous waterways in the county, including the Lehigh River and Little Lehigh Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Northampton County with many road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in lower Bucks County with many road closures and vehicles stranded.  There were numerous water rescues.  Most waterways in the county overflowed, including the Delaware River (with a highly unusual quick response to the runoff), Neshaminy Creek, Tohickon Creek and the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek.  Many buildings and homes were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Montgomery County with many road closures and vehicles stranded.  Numerous water rescues took place.  There were two flood related fatalities, one in Skippack and one in Bridgeport.  Many buildings and homes were flooded.  Most waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the Schuylkill River, Perkiomen Creek and Wissahickon Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in upper Bucks County with many road closures and vehicles stranded.  There were numerous water rescues.  One flood related fatality was reported in Milford Township.  Most waterways in the county overflowed, including the Delaware River (with a highly unusual quick response to the runoff), Neshaminy Creek, Tohickon Creek and the East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek.  Many buildings and homes were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Chester County with many road closures and vehicles stranded.  There was a flood related fatality in Downingtown.  Numerous waterways in the county flooded, including the Schuylkill River, the West Branch of the Brandywine Creek, the East Branch of the Brandywine Creek, White Clay Creek, Red Clay Creek, French Creek and Valley Creek.  There were many reports of water entering buildings and homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Philadelphia with many roadways closed.  Most of the waterways in the city overflowed their banks, including the Schuylkill River, Cobbs Creek, Wissahickon Creek, Frankford Creek and Pennypack Creek.  Many buildings were flooded, especially in the Manayunk section of the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Philadelphia with many roadways closed.  Most of the waterways in the city overflowed their banks, including the Schuylkill River, Cobbs Creek, Wissahickon Creek, Frankford Creek and Pennypack Creek.  Many buildings were flooded, especially in the Manayunk section of the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous road closures in the Stroudsburg and East Stroudsburg area due to flooding.  Sections of PA Route 191 and PA Route 447 were impassable.  Also, Interstate 80 was closed near the Delaware River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening line of showers and storms pushed into central Pennsylvania from the west during the afternoon of August 11, 2021. At the same time, discreet cells developed over the Lower Susquehanna Valley, well ahead of the main line. The greater Harrisburg area experienced multiple rounds of storms, generating localized flooding in many neighborhoods. Local rainfall data showed we received almost 2.5 inches, of which 1.4 and 1.65 inches fell in less than 30 minutes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding reported in downtown Harrisburg with reports of stranded vehicles.  One report specifically mentioned submerged vehicles on Market Street.||Video is available here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8DRmf5UiESA .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Henri brought rain and thunderstorms to the area.  One storm became stationary over the New Holland area of Lancaster County, where up to 5 of rain fell in a short time, producing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small streams out of their banks and flooding local roads.  Many roads closed and impassible.  Flash flooding reported on Gristmill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered storms developed in a warm, humid airmass to the south of a stalled frontal boundary over southern New York state during the late afternoon and early evening of August 27, 2021. A couple of these storms produced wind damage in the Lower Susquehanna Valley.  Flash flooding was also reported in Tioga County near Mansfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over the road near US 6 and Roseville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fred brought heavy rain and strong thunderstorms to central Pennsylvania, along with a handful of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous flooded roads reported around Williamsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fred brought heavy rain and strong thunderstorms to central Pennsylvania, along with a handful of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Morrisons Cove Herald reported a house foundation was washed away due to flooding leaving the structure unihabitable.   Road damage was also reported along Route 866.||From https://www.mcheraldonline.com/story/2021/08/26/news/flooding-in-williamsburg-a-familiar-scene/9107.html .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fred brought heavy rain and strong thunderstorms to central Pennsylvania, along with a handful of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of multiple cars stuck in flooded roadways. PA-462 was closed in both directions between Belmont Road and Eastern Boulevard in Springettsbury Township.||PennDOT cameras showed  Interstate 83 at Exit 19: PA-462 is flooded with several stranded cars (842 pm EDT).||Video of some of the flooding was found here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8Gm3007vk8 .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fred brought heavy rain and strong thunderstorms to central Pennsylvania, along with a handful of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues reported in Lancaster city, along with numerous flooded roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shield of moderate to heavy rainfall, associated with the remnants of tropical cyclone Ida, moved from the DelMarVa peninsula to New England. This rainfall on top of several weeks of abnormally wet weather led to areas of small stream and urban flash flooding in Northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding eroded and closed Sibley Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shield of moderate to heavy rainfall, associated with the remnants of tropical cyclone Ida, moved from the DelMarVa peninsula to New England. This rainfall on top of several weeks of abnormally wet weather led to areas of small stream and urban flash flooding in Northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding led to a road collapse of South Main Street near Earth Conservancy Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnant low pressure center of Hurricane Ida passed across West Virginia and the Central Appalachian Mountains from late August 31st through September 1st.  The abundant moisture associated with the low intersected a frontal zone which was nearly stalled in the area of the Ohio Valley.  Strong isentropic and frontogenetically-induced lift led to periods of heavy rain over much of southwestern Pennsylvania over the two-day period, both from thunderstorms ahead of the low and from a period of tropical rainfall during the morning of the 1st.  Rain tapered off by the afternoon as the remnants of Ida pulled towards the Mid-Atlantic coast.||The heaviest rainfall over the two-day period was observed in Westmoreland, Allegheny, and Washington Counties, with totals of 3 to 5 inches common. Lesser totals were noted to the north and south of this area, with areas near Interstate 80 mainly receiving a half-inch or less. The heavy rainfall resulted in widespread flooding of roads and streams, with several instances of evacuations noted.  Particularly hard hit were the municipalities of Millvale, Bridgeville, and Scott, all of which issued disaster declarations.  In Stowe Township, a school bus was trapped in flood waters, requiring the rescue of two adults and seven children.  Other rescues of trapped motorists were noted. Twenty-four residents had to be evacuated from an assisted living facility in Oakdale, where water up to 18 inches deep was observed across the town. ||Despite the heavy rain and numerous instances of flash and areal flooding, widespread river flooding was not observed after the rainfall ceased.  A dry slot near the Mason-Dixon Line on the morning of the 1st kept rainfall totals lower on the headwaters of the Monongahela River, allowing area reservoirs to mitigate the impact of the tropical rain downstream.  Thus, while short-term flooding was significant over a portion of the region, the overall event did not have the same impact as Gordon in 2018 or Frances/Ivan in 2014.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New Alexandria Road was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnant low pressure center of Hurricane Ida passed across West Virginia and the Central Appalachian Mountains from late August 31st through September 1st.  The abundant moisture associated with the low intersected a frontal zone which was nearly stalled in the area of the Ohio Valley.  Strong isentropic and frontogenetically-induced lift led to periods of heavy rain over much of southwestern Pennsylvania over the two-day period, both from thunderstorms ahead of the low and from a period of tropical rainfall during the morning of the 1st.  Rain tapered off by the afternoon as the remnants of Ida pulled towards the Mid-Atlantic coast.||The heaviest rainfall over the two-day period was observed in Westmoreland, Allegheny, and Washington Counties, with totals of 3 to 5 inches common. Lesser totals were noted to the north and south of this area, with areas near Interstate 80 mainly receiving a half-inch or less. The heavy rainfall resulted in widespread flooding of roads and streams, with several instances of evacuations noted.  Particularly hard hit were the municipalities of Millvale, Bridgeville, and Scott, all of which issued disaster declarations.  In Stowe Township, a school bus was trapped in flood waters, requiring the rescue of two adults and seven children.  Other rescues of trapped motorists were noted. Twenty-four residents had to be evacuated from an assisted living facility in Oakdale, where water up to 18 inches deep was observed across the town. ||Despite the heavy rain and numerous instances of flash and areal flooding, widespread river flooding was not observed after the rainfall ceased.  A dry slot near the Mason-Dixon Line on the morning of the 1st kept rainfall totals lower on the headwaters of the Monongahela River, allowing area reservoirs to mitigate the impact of the tropical rain downstream.  Thus, while short-term flooding was significant over a portion of the region, the overall event did not have the same impact as Gordon in 2018 or Frances/Ivan in 2014.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on South Carbon Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported across the county with many roads closed.  Roads affected by flooding include Route 3027 (Beavertown Road) from the intersection of Sugar Run Road to the intersection New Fording Road in Todd Township;  Route 103 from the intersection of Arrowhead Way to the intersection of Bilger Road in Shirley Township; Route 522 at the intersection of Keystone Road to the intersection of Aughwick Mills Road in Shirley Township;  Route 305 from the beginning of Route 305 to the intersection of Alexandria Pike in Porter Township; Route 3003 (Power Plant Road) from the Bedford County Line to the intersection of River Road in Hopewell Township; Route 2016 (Valley Street/Chester Furnace Road) from the intersection of Monroe Valley Road to the intersection of Clark Road in Cromwell Township; Route 522 at the intersection of Keystone Road to the intersection of Aughwick Mills Road in Shirley Township; Route 103 from the intersection of Arrowhead Way to the intersection of Bilger Road in Shirley Township; Route 4005 (Alexandria Pike/Pike Street) from the intersection of River road to the intersection of Berwick Forge Road in Porter Township; Route 3027 (Beavertown Road) from the intersection of Sugar Run Road to the intersection New Fording Road in Todd Township; Route 1017 (Martin Gap Road) from the intersection of Toner Camp Road to the intersection of Old Town Road in Miller Township; Route 1008 (Myton Road) from the intersection of 305 (Shavers Creek Road) to the intersection of Hughes Road in West Township; Route 3043 (Snyder Run Road) from the intersection of Snyder Run Road in Juniata Township to the intersection of Henderson Overlook in Smithfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large number of localized flooding events were reported. Two water rescues were reported in Lickdale and Bethel Townships.  Vehicle in flood waters reported at South Zellers Road and South Sheridan Road in Millcreek Township. No injuries were reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture from the Atlantic Ocean was fed into Northeast Pennsylvania by low pressure near New York City. This led to areas of moderate to heavy rainfall totaling between 3 to 5 inches of rain with locally higher amounts. This rainfall led to widespread flash flooding across the Endless Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift water rescues occurring in Damascus Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ogden Road was washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding all over the region with water rescues reported.  US 22 was closed in both directions in the Hollidaysburg area.   Approximately 80 homes were impacted by flooding in the Altoona area.  The Blair County Convention Center was opened as a shelter.  ||Major river flooding on the Frankstown Branch of the Juniata River in the Williamsburg area where the river crested at 16.55 feet on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding across the area.  Around 10:30 a.m., Dark Shade Drive and Seanor Roads in Paint Township were shut down to one lane of travel because of flooding. Gardner Road between Bicycle and Dunmyer roads in Quemahoning Township and Water Works Road near Days Inn in Somerset Borough were also closed. Portions of routes 2005, 669 and 2003 in Elk Lick Township also closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding and water rescues reported across Lancaster County.  Water rescues reported in and near Lancaster and Ephrata.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and storms developed in a warm, humid airmass with moderate CAPE and shear ahead of an approaching cold front on September 15, 2021. One particularly strong storm produced widespread wind damage in Centre County, with isolated reports of wind damage elsewhere.  Another storm brought flash flooding to Sullivan County near LaPorte.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Muncy Creek jumped its banks and flooded across Nordmont Road.   Conklin Run was also out of its banks and flowing over Lake Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding reported.  On the PA Turnpike flash flooding was reported at mile marker 135 with a large portion of the turnpike closed during the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Ohio Valley allowed southeast winds out ahead of the storm system to draw in deep Atlantic moisture across Eastern Pennsylvania. This combined with an upper level disturbance sweeping through the area produced widespread moderate to heavy rainfall. This rain came on the heels of a heavy rain day three days prior, making it easier for additional flash flooding to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was occurring across U.S. Route 6 to the east of Burlington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous flooding, with water rescues reported across Dauphin County.  Some areas that reported flash flooding include Hockensville Road and Hannover Street in South Hanover Township, areas near the Hershey Country Club at Derry Road, Richardson Road in Lower Swatara Township, Swatara Creek Park in South Hanover Township, McCorkle Road between Jacobs Creek and Church Road, Church Road between Laurie Avenue and Ney Road, Wood Road between Bullfrog Valley Road to Limeric, Eby Road from Meadow Lane to Royal Road, SR743 between Lingle Avenue and Bindnagle Road, Bachmanville Road between Meadow Road and Felty Mill Road.   A mobile home park near Highspire was also evacuated due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding with road closures reported across Cumberland County.  Some roads reported flooded include Steigerwalt Hollow Road and Lewisberry Road, Walnut Bottom Road in Carlisle between South West Street and South College Street, and PA114 in both directions between Poplar Road, Springers Lane and Old York Road in Fairview Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida produced widespread heavy rainfall across Pennsylvania. Additionally, thunderstorms were observed southeast Of I-81 and the PA Turnpike. One of these storms produced wind damage in Adams County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flash flooding reported across York County.  The NWS issued a Flash Flood Emergency at the request of the county when water rescues increased during the evening rush hour.  27 water rescues were reported. Tyler Run Creek at York College overflowed its banks, and several homes were submerged in water.  Several roads sustained damage from flooding, including Valley Road in Newberry Township, West College Avenue in West Manchester Township, Indian Rock Dam Road in West Manchester Township, Iron Ridge Road between Old Hanover Road and Route 116 in Heidelberg Township and West Canal Road in Paradise Township.  In Goldsboro, damage to Valley and Pines Roads was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnant low pressure center of Hurricane Ida passed across West Virginia and the Central Appalachian Mountains from late August 31st through September 1st.  The abundant moisture associated with the low intersected a frontal zone which was nearly stalled in the area of the Ohio Valley.  Strong isentropic and frontogenetically-induced lift led to periods of heavy rain over much of southwestern Pennsylvania over the two-day period, both from thunderstorms ahead of the low and from a period of tropical rainfall during the morning of the 1st.  Rain tapered off by the afternoon as the remnants of Ida pulled towards the Mid-Atlantic coast.||The heaviest rainfall over the two-day period was observed in Westmoreland, Allegheny, and Washington Counties, with totals of 3 to 5 inches common. Lesser totals were noted to the north and south of this area, with areas near Interstate 80 mainly receiving a half-inch or less. The heavy rainfall resulted in widespread flooding of roads and streams, with several instances of evacuations noted.  Particularly hard hit were the municipalities of Millvale, Bridgeville, and Scott, all of which issued disaster declarations.  In Stowe Township, a school bus was trapped in flood waters, requiring the rescue of two adults and seven children.  Other rescues of trapped motorists were noted. Twenty-four residents had to be evacuated from an assisted living facility in Oakdale, where water up to 18 inches deep was observed across the town. ||Despite the heavy rain and numerous instances of flash and areal flooding, widespread river flooding was not observed after the rainfall ceased.  A dry slot near the Mason-Dixon Line on the morning of the 1st kept rainfall totals lower on the headwaters of the Monongahela River, allowing area reservoirs to mitigate the impact of the tropical rain downstream.  Thus, while short-term flooding was significant over a portion of the region, the overall event did not have the same impact as Gordon in 2018 or Frances/Ivan in 2014.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On State Route 980, a car was stuck in the water up to its headlights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shield of moderate to heavy rainfall, associated with the remnants of tropical cyclone Ida, moved from the DelMarVa peninsula to New England. This rainfall on top of several weeks of abnormally wet weather led to areas of small stream and urban flash flooding in Northeast Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars reported to be stuck in water due to urban flash flooding near River Street and the Exit 3 off ramp of the Cross Valley Expressway.

Rain tapered off by the afternoon as the remnants of Ida pulled towards the Mid-Atlantic coast.||The heaviest rainfall over the two-day period was observed in Westmoreland, Allegheny, and Washington Counties, with totals of 3 to 5 inches common. Lesser totals were noted to the north and south of this area, with areas near Interstate 80 mainly receiving a half-inch or less. The heavy rainfall resulted in widespread flooding of roads and streams, with several instances of evacuations noted.  Particularly hard hit were the municipalities of Millvale, Bridgeville, and Scott, all of which issued disaster declarations.  In Stowe Township, a school bus was trapped in flood waters, requiring the rescue of two adults and seven children.  Other rescues of trapped motorists were noted. Twenty-four residents had to be evacuated from an assisted living facility in Oakdale, where water up to 18 inches deep was observed across the town. ||Despite the heavy rain and numerous instances of flash and areal flooding, widespread river flooding was not observed after the rainfall ceased.  A dry slot near the Mason-Dixon Line on the morning of the 1st kept rainfall totals lower on the headwaters of the Monongahela River, allowing area reservoirs to mitigate the impact of the tropical rain downstream.  Thus, while short-term flooding was significant over a portion of the region, the overall event did not have the same impact as Gordon in 2018 or Frances/Ivan in 2014.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooded roads occurred in Washington township, including North Washington Road, Pine Run Road, and Pine Run Church Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Delaware County with numerous road closures.  Many creeks in the county overflowed their banks, including Chester Creek, Ridley Creek, Crum Creek and Cobbs Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and evening of July 17.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Frankford Creek in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 12.  Rainfall totals up to 6 to 10 inches occurred in Northeast Philadelphia and in far lower Bucks County prompting the issuance of a Flash Flood Emergency.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread significant street flooding occurred in Northeast Philadelphia.  There were numerous road closures including Woodhaven Road near US Route 1.  Moderate flooding occurred along the Pennypack Creek.  A total of 18 residents were evacuated from the Sherwood Crossing Apartments along Red Lion Road due to flooding from Byberry Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 12.  Rainfall totals up to 6 to 10 inches occurred in Northeast Philadelphia and in far lower Bucks County prompting the issuance of a Flash Flood Emergency.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads in Tullytown became impassable.  There was a water rescue along Spencer Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain fell in parts of southeastern Pennsylvania on the evening of October 13.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Perkiomen Creek in Upper Hanover Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures and rainfall resulted in an ice jam on Penns Creek in the Millmont area of Union County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam on Penns Creek led to the rescue of several people Friday morning in the Millmont area of Union County. No injuries were reported after two people and a dog were rescued from a house surrounded by water of Penns Creek.||According to the Mifflinburg Hose Company Facebook page, crews were called to the 900 block of Canada Drive in Lewis Township, Union County just after 5:30 a.m. Friday.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 21st, a cold front extended southwestward from southern ON to far-northwestern OH. This front drifted southeastward through the early evening, when it became located in vicinity of the major axis of Lake Erie, west-central OH, and east-central IN. The front then moved little through the wee hours of the 22nd. A line of thunderstorms moved generally eastward across northwest PA during the early evening and generated isolated straight-line wind damage. The ambient environment consisted of moderate to strong effective bulk shear, MUCAPE, and DCAPE, respectively. Repeated thunderstorms training over the same areas of Erie and Crawford Counties in PA led to excessive rainfall and flash flooding. Total rainfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches were estimated by radar in these locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flood in Union City. Several homes evacuated in the area of North Main and Waterford Streets and South Main and Parade Streets in Union City. Academy Drive near the junior high and high school was washed out due to flooding. Reports of several basements and homes flooded. Radar estimated rainfall of 3 to 5 inches in far southeast Erie county. US-6 bridge abutment washed away due to flooding near King Road northeast of Elgin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving storms fired in the late afternoon and evening hours of May 14th in a pattern of high moisture, weak overall flow,  and weak vorticity advection.  The slow storm movement resulted in localized heavy rainfall.  One instance of flash flooding was noted in Washington County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused numerous roads to flood in Downtown Beallsville. Route 40 at Maiden Street in the center of town was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough brought storms to Northeastern Pennsylvania. An isolated, slow moving thunderstorm, caused areas of flash flooding near New Albany.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 220 in New Albany was flooded in several locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough brought storms to Northeastern Pennsylvania. An isolated, slow moving thunderstorm, caused areas of flash flooding near New Albany.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred on Lawrence and Front Streets in the Borough of New Albany.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm brought flash flooding to a small portion of Fulton County on the afternoon of August 21st.  Several roads reported high water and debris.||In Cambria County, road flooding occurred in East Taylor, Summerhill, and Middle Taylor. East Taylor and Middle Taylor townships declared local disaster declarations. Damage was to paved and unpaved roadways, streambeds, and vegetative areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding with water and debris over the roads was reported on Great Cove Road at Websters Mill and Big Cove Tannery Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm brought flash flooding to a small portion of Fulton County on the afternoon of August 21st.  Several roads reported high water and debris.||In Cambria County, road flooding occurred in East Taylor, Summerhill, and Middle Taylor. East Taylor and Middle Taylor townships declared local disaster declarations. Damage was to paved and unpaved roadways, streambeds, and vegetative areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road flooding was reported in the Cito area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms moved across this area of the Ohio Valley just ahead of an approaching cold front. While thunderstorms were generally moving fast enough to avoid flooding issues, some locations received multiple rounds of heavy rainfall as multiple convective segments moved across, and in some instances trained across the same area. This led to isolated flash flooding in Ohio and Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local call center reported numerous basements flooded in Beaver County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across the Pittsburgh region with the passage of a shortwave trough. Sufficient moisture and instability led to brief, isolated downpours. Some thunderstorm segments had a storm motion which resulted in places receiving a quick inch or more in less than an hour. This resulted in isolated flash flooding in the Pittsburgh metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced heavy rainfall of around an inch in around a half an hour across a portion of Carnegie. The Pittsburgh fire chief reported flash flooding along Washington Ave between Hope Hollow and Boden Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few rounds of thunderstorms on July 24th and 25th preceded a cold frontal passage.  High levels of instability, ample shear, and pre-frontal disturbances provided thunderstorm clusters producing widespread damaging wind gusts.  Many instances of tree and power line damage were noted, along with isolated instances of structural damage.  One of those instances of structural damage, a tree falling on to two trailers in Venango County, unfortunately led to the death of a 28 year old woman.  Flash flooding of urbanized areas of Allegheny County also occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with high rain rates resulted in one to two inches of rainfall in less than an hour. This resulted in a portion of highway 65 flash flooding by Broad Street in Leetsville with water rushing across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few rounds of thunderstorms on July 24th and 25th preceded a cold frontal passage.  High levels of instability, ample shear, and pre-frontal disturbances provided thunderstorm clusters producing widespread damaging wind gusts.  Many instances of tree and power line damage were noted, along with isolated instances of structural damage.  One of those instances of structural damage, a tree falling on to two trailers in Venango County, unfortunately led to the death of a 28 year old woman.  Flash flooding of urbanized areas of Allegheny County also occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with high rain rates resulted in around an inch of rainfall in less than thirty minutes across downtown Pittsburgh. Shingiss Rd  This resulted in flooding of the low lying portion of Shingiss St underneath the Crosstown Blvd / I570 on-ramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms trained along a nearly stationary boundary crossing into northwest Pennsylvania during the evening hours of September 4th, taking advantage of a moisture-laden air mass. Instances of road flooding were observed in Mercer and Venango Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple flooded roadways were reported in the area between Grove City and Sandy Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: East Barnard Street in West Chester was closed between South Matlack Street and South Franklin Street due to flooding.  South Adams Street in West Chester was closed between East Market Street and East Miner Street due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving eastward through the region brought heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the morning of September 6.  Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 5 inches in much of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along Frankford Creek in Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southeastern Pennsylvania during the early hours of June 9.  Rainfall amounts as high as 1.5 to 2.5 inches fell in a short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light rail service was disrupted in Darby due to high water on the tracks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving pulse storms created flash flooding conditions across the region. The storms developed in a very moist, buoyant environment where 2000-3000 J/kg SBCAPE and 1.7-1.9 inch PW values, supported very efficient rainfall rates. Shear profiles were weak from the low levels to 300mb and created a 'pulse-type' behavior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported by the beer distributer and surrounding businesses on Sand Hill Rd by Route 30. A pick up truck was reported trapped by water and a water rescue occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The leading edge of a trough initiated convection across the region during the early afternoon of August 29th. With little deep-layer wind shear available for quick storm motion, flash flooding occurred under warm, moist conditions (PWATs ranging 1.8 to 2.0 inches under prolonged southwest flow). A few storms were considered severe, knocking down trees, as updrafts escalated into cool, dry conditions aloft and created strong downdrafts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused multiple streets in Monaca proper to flood.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Washington Boulevard to begin flooding and it was closed as a result.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Officials reported numerous high water issues across Mahoning Township due to heavy rain. This resulted in multiple roads closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Humphreys Run to rise significantly and out of its banks. A couple feet of moving water flooded Route 130 by Nasters Food. Swift water rescue was performed by the food store. Video from the area showed multiple feet of water flowing around the business, parking lot, and surrounding area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Received reports of extensive flooding across Unity Township, with Marguerite Lake Rd being significantly effected. Roadways and housing were reported to be inundated with high water. Additionally, a high water rescued occurred on Marguerite Lake Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in the afternoon as a result of heating beneath an upper-level trough. Fairly steep mid-level lapse rates combined with surface heating resulted in CAPE increasing to near 1000 J/kg. Cells were generally quick-moving, but a multi-cell segment moving eastward was positioned just right such that localized flooding occurred in New Florence PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Route 711 in New Florence to become inundated with water and closed for flooding.
