EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front draped over the region provided the focus for slow moving thunderstorm activity over northeastern Pennsylvania. Localized areas of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall contributed to some small stream and creek flooding near the Delaware River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported water, rocks and gravel running across Twin Lakes Road near the Handsome Eddy Road intersection due to culvert being blown out by flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania from the late afternoon into the nighttime hours of June 26.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding around the Exton Square Mall in Exton with some water rescues taking place.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of June 27.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bristol Road in Bensalem Township became impassable due to flooding around Bensalem Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening of June 27.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were multiple water rescues from vehicles in Lower Moreland Township.  Widespread roadway flooding occurred in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania during the midday hours of June 16.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1.0 to 1.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along Pennypack Creek in Northeast Philadelphia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of June 23.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An access ramp from Interstate 476 to West MacDade Boulevard in Woodlyn was closed due to flooding near Crum Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in extreme southeastern Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and early evening of June 25.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1.5 to 3.0 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along Pennypack Creek in Northeast Philadelphia.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several road closures in Tatamy due to flooding.  At least one vehicle was stranded in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms during the afternoon and early evening of April 15 produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2.0 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Fountain Hill became impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms during the afternoon and early evening of April 15 produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2.0 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: PA Route 309 was closed due to flooding in Upper Saucon Township from Huckleberry Drive to West Hopewell Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms during the afternoon and early evening of April 15 produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2.0 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Lower Macungie Township became impassable due to flooding.  There was a water rescue from a stranded vehicle at Church Lane and Oak Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania from the late afternoon into the nighttime hours of June 26.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding lead to a water rescue on the US Route 30 eastbound ramp onto US Route 202 northbound in West Whiteland Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and storms pushed into south-central Pennsylvania from the southwest during the evening of July 15, 2023. Additional showers and storms developed farther to the northeast from the middle Susquehanna Valley northeastward into the Endless Mountains region. Sporadic wind damage was observed with both areas of storms, and the northeastern area of storms began training which led to flash flooding in portions of Lycoming County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from training thunderstorms led to flash flooding near Pennsdale, with a vehicle becoming stuck in water of unknown depth on Pond Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from training thunderstorms caused flash flooding in Washington Township, with a stretch of Route 44 near Elimsport becoming covered with water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 25.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2.0 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in West Pikeland Township with several roads becoming impassable.  Pickering Creek overflowed its banks resulting in roadway flooding around Jacques Circle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania from the late afternoon into the evening of July 15.  Rainfall totals were as high as 3 to 6 inches.  Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Upper Makefield Township in Bucks County, where several lives were lost.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Lower Makefield Township.  There were numerous road closures and water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm and humid airmass over central Pennsylvania with moderate CAPE and very little CIN ahead of an approaching cold front. A few of the storms produced sporadic wind damage, and the widespread nature of this activity allowed the event to evolve into a flash flooding threat as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall estimated around 3 inches led to the closure of Brush Valley Road between Schock and Tressler roads in Rockefeller Township due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall estimated around 3 inches led to the closure of Route 61 between Highland Avenue in Sunbury and Green Street in Upper Augusta Township due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to the washout of a roadway between Tuscarora Township and Mifflintown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall estimated around 3 inches caused flash flooding east of Sunbury, with emergency responders conducting a water rescue on Plum Creek Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in southeastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon of July 25.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2.0 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to major flooding occurred along the East Branch of the Brandywine Creek in West Bradford Township and East Bradford Township.  The flooding resulted in the closure of a section of US Route 322.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm and humid airmass over central Pennsylvania with moderate CAPE and very little CIN ahead of an approaching cold front. A few of the storms produced sporadic wind damage, and the widespread nature of this activity allowed the event to evolve into a flash flooding threat as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall led to flash flooding of roads, a park, and a residential area in Thompsontown. There was also damage to the local fire station that included the kitchen, restroom, a meeting room, and a truck bay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and early evening of July 9.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to around 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding and road closures occurred in Muhlenberg Township.  PA Route 12 was impassable and closed between PA Route 61 and North Fifth Street.  US Route 222 was under water at the PA Route 61 underpass.  A house collapsed on Mount Laurel Road along Laurel Run due to basement flooding and the eventual failure of the foundation.  The residents needed to be rescued as the house was surrounded by flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on the afternoon and early evening of July 9.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to around 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Manatawny Creek around Spangsville in Oley Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania on July 16.  Rainfall totals were as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped in flood waters at the intersection of Mine Lane Road and Division Street in Palmer Township, necessitating a water rescue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania on July 16.  Rainfall totals were as high as 3 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters reached the first floor of a house in Washington Township, causing a basement wall to collapse.  A bridge on Lower South Main Street in the township was severely damaged due to rushing flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania from the late afternoon into the evening of July 15.  Rainfall totals were as high as 3 to 6 inches.  Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Upper Makefield Township in Bucks County, where several lives were lost.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Upper Makefield Township, resulting in the loss of seven lives.  A reliable rain gauge located within the township indicated that 4.64 inches of rain fell during the event which lasted less than 2 hours.  Widespread roadway flooding occurred with many roads becoming impassable.  Numerous water rescues took place in the township.  The worst of the flooding occurred along Hough's Creek.  The creek rose rapidly and the rushing water carried away many vehicles, most along Taylorsville Road which parallels the Delaware Canal.  Eleven vehicles were reported to have been swept into the creek.  Eight individual were rescued from their vehicle and two from the creek.  Unfortunately, seven people perished either while trapped in their vehicle or while attempting to escape the flood waters.||The Taylorsville Road Bridge over Hough's Creek was structurally compromised.  PA Route 532 between Stonebridge Crossing Road and Wrightstown Road was damaged severely by the raging flood waters from Hough's Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training showers and thunderstorms formed in an anomalously high PWAT airmass over central Pennsylvania during the late evening of August 29 and continued into the early morning hours of August 30. Locally heavy rainfall in excess of 3 inches caused flash flooding across southern Clinton County, and wind damage was observed in Lycoming County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding led to the closure of several roads across Bald Eagle, Woodward, and Dunnstable townships in due to water and/or rock slides across roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in eastern Pennsylvania from the late afternoon into the nighttime hours of June 26.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along Chester Creek in Aston Township, Middletown Township and Brookhaven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a warm front during the morning of July 20th provided a moist and unstable air mass.  A strong, progressive upper trough tracked southeastward from the Great Lakes, with an associated cold front crossing during the evening hours. Mixed-layer CAPE of up to 2500 J/kg, strong deep shear, and steep low and mid-level lapse rates were supportive of severe weather.  Widespread reports of wind damage were received, mainly to trees.  Some isolated urban flash flooding also occurred in Beaver and Allegheny Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to have entered a basement in Greenville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms formed over northern Ohio during the evening of July 26th and raced across southwest Pennsylvania to the north of Pittsburgh, supported by a shortwave trough.  Many wind damage reports were received in the vicinity of the I-80 corridor, with isolated flash flooding as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed the intersection of Route 338 and Route 58.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain during the morning of July 9th helped to saturate the ground, and additional thunderstorms in an anomalously high moisture environment during the early evening hours created flash flooding.  Wayne and Shenango Townships in Lawrence County were particularly hard hit, with at least eight homes in these areas impacted by flooding. Many roads were also impacted. An isolated instance of wind damage was also noted in Beaver County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along Old Princetown Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be over Center Church Road at Hell Run.  A couple of ponds overflowed and temporarily merged into one.

Wayne and Shenango Townships in Lawrence County were particularly hard hit, with at least eight homes in these areas impacted by flooding. Many roads were also impacted. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain during the morning of July 9th helped to saturate the ground, and additional thunderstorms in an anomalously high moisture environment during the early evening hours created flash flooding.  Wayne and Shenango Townships in Lawrence County were particularly hard hit, with at least eight homes in these areas impacted by flooding. Many roads were also impacted. An isolated instance of wind damage was also noted in Beaver County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of rain fell in southwest Lawrence over a 3 hour period.  At least eight homes were impacted by flooding in Wayne and Shenango Townships. Numerous roads were closed in the area and several water rescues from houses and cars were performed by local firefighters. The most significant damage in Shenango Township occurred around Union Valley, Snake Run, and Lower Boyd School Roads, the latter of which was undermined, creating damage to the asphalt. Roads impacted in Wayne Township included Shenango Stop, Union Valley, Snake Run, Chewton-West Pittsburg, Fletcher Hill, Boyd School, Lower Boyd School, Old Pittsburgh, and Union Valley Roads. McKee Run was reported to overflow its banks.||The Lawrence County Commissioners issued a disaster declaration for the entire county, with the Shenango and Wayne Township supervisors adopting similar measures for their respective municipalities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of thunderstorms, first from a decaying morning mesoscale convective system and later forming on outflow from earlier activity, produced heavy rainfall on July 1st. Instability was not high, but precipitable water values of 1.8 to 2.0 inches supported efficient rainfall. Localized totals of 1.5 to 2.5 inches, locally higher, produced flash flooding in several areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Green Valley Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall during the previous day, plus during the morning of July 2nd, kept the ground saturated. An early afternoon break in rainfall was followed by additional thunderstorm development in western and central Ohio by late afternoon.  These storms took advantage of an environment containing 1500 J/kg of surface-based CAPE, along with marginal sufficient deep shear of 30 knots to create severe thunderstorms with a number of wind damage reports in Ohio.  Southwest Pennsylvania only saw isolated flash flooding in Allegheny County from this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several intersections were closed in Aspinwall, including Freeport Road and Center Avenue, Freeport Road and Delafield Road, and Delafield Road and 2nd Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorms developed along a cold front across the Central and Lower Great Lakes during the late evening and overnight hours of August 24-25, 2023. These thunderstorms were in an environment of strong to extreme instability, along with sufficient low-level and deep-layer wind shear for organized and rotating thunderstorms. This allowed storms that developed over Michigan to organize into a fast-moving cluster of thunderstorms that produced extensive wind damage and a number of tornadoes between southern Lower Michigan and southwestern Pennsylvania, and Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Allegheny County 911 reported several roads closed in McKeesport, West Mifflin, Clairton, Elizabeth, and White Oak due to flash flooding. These roads include Rebecca St/W 5th Ave, and W 5th Ave at the Mansfield Bridge in McKeesport,  Lovedale Rd/McKeeseport Rd in  Elizabeth township, Clairton Blvd in Pleasant Hills, Coal Valley Road in Jefferson Hills.

This allowed storms that developed over Michigan to organize into a fast-moving cluster of thunderstorms that produced extensive wind damage and a number of tornadoes between southern Lower Michigan and southwestern Pennsylvania, and Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Allegheny County 911 reported a vehicle stuck in water along Universal and Stotler Road. Also, the 500 block of Anderson Ave in Plum had one foot of water on the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving low pressure over Northeast Pennsylvania was the focus for a constant stream of heavy rain-producing thunderstorms during the overnight hours. A quick rainfall of 2.5 to 3.5 inches caused swollen streams and areas of flooding. Water washed out several roads and infiltrated a mobile home park near Hallstead, PA forcing several people from their homes in the middle of the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moving water, approximately 10 inches deep, was reported across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level shortwave trough moved across the northern Great Lakes with a belt of stronger flow moving through the southern Great Lakes.  Scattered thunderstorms|developed through midday into the afternoon.  Forecast soundings showed some low-level hodograph curvature. Supercells evolved ahead of the cold front and create a large hail and tornado threat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal system over northeastern Pennsylvania combined with a weak upper level disturbance to focus heavy rain producing thunderstorms over the area. Torrential downpours over just a couple of hours accumulated between 3 to 5 inches of rainfall in small stream basins above the large metropolitan area known as the Lackawanna-Wyoming Valley. Severe flash flooding resulted in many road and bridge washouts around the local region. Motorists were stranded on urban streets and the flooding resulted in the deaths of two people who attempted to evacuate their vehicle into rushing waters. Another four people were seriously injured when their vehicle crashed into the remnants of a washed out bridge. The perpetual thunderstorms and flooding also shut down the Luzerne County Fair. Overall damages to the region as a result of this severe flooding are estimated at around 20 million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads flooded in the area and multiple cars stuck in deep water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved north along the Atlantic Seaboard spreading steady and heavy rain into northeastern Pennsylvania during the overnight hours. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streets closed due to flooding with several vehicles stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall associated with the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby entered southern Pennsylvania prior to sunrise on August 9, 2024. A north-south band of heavy rainfall impacted areas just west of the Susquehanna River leading to flash flooding across Union and Lycoming counties. The community of Trout Run in Lycoming County had to be evacuated due to high water. There were also multiple water rescues and houses with extensive damage in Union County with this heavy rainfall band, with multiple people being forced from their homes. Union County reported 1 property destroyed, 4 properties with major damage, 38 properties with affected or minor damage, and $443,254 in roadway and municipal damages/expenses. Additional rainfall with Debby continued farther west, and produced locally heavy rainfall across the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in portions of eastern Potter and western Tioga counties, where heavy rainfall and topographic impacts allowed for water to rise rapidly in valley locations. There were 26 water rescues reported in Potter County near Harrison Valley with multiple roadways closed throughout the county and many homes being shifted off of their foundation. In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in the Harrison Valley area, with 26 people being rescued from flash flooding and dozens of houses shifted off of their foundation due to rapidly moving water. A Galeton firefighter was injured while attempting a water rescue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall associated with the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby entered southern Pennsylvania prior to sunrise on August 9, 2024. A north-south band of heavy rainfall impacted areas just west of the Susquehanna River leading to flash flooding across Union and Lycoming counties. The community of Trout Run in Lycoming County had to be evacuated due to high water. There were also multiple water rescues and houses with extensive damage in Union County with this heavy rainfall band, with multiple people being forced from their homes. Union County reported 1 property destroyed, 4 properties with major damage, 38 properties with affected or minor damage, and $443,254 in roadway and municipal damages/expenses. Additional rainfall with Debby continued farther west, and produced locally heavy rainfall across the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in portions of eastern Potter and western Tioga counties, where heavy rainfall and topographic impacts allowed for water to rise rapidly in valley locations. There were 26 water rescues reported in Potter County near Harrison Valley with multiple roadways closed throughout the county and many homes being shifted off of their foundation. In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in the town of Westfield, with numerous structures and vehicles being swept away. Many individuals and some rescuers were trapped by floodwaters. Rescue units came in from as far away as Bradford, PA and Jamestown, NY, and helicopters were used to rescue individuals from roof tops. One individual who reportedly waded into the water went missing and is believed to be deceased.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Localized convergence of thunderstorms created a small area of 1.5 to 2.5 inch rain totals in portions of Washington and Allegheny Counties on May 5th, creating a few isolated flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Main Street was reported to be completely flooding near the intersection of Robinson Street. A secondary report also suggested that multiple basements were flooded along the Main Street area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms around slowly-moving Middle Ohio Valley low pressure created isolated flooding concerns in Allegheny County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road closures were reported on McMillan, Morrow, and McLaughlin Run Roads due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system was the driving force of scattered storms across Northeast Pennsylvania. Warm and moist air contributed to several rounds of heavy rain producing thunderstorms over the northern tier counties. Rainfall amounts in a short period of time totalled between 2 and 3 inches leading to localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water is flowing over Route 467 in several locations along Johnson Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front helped to focus the remnants of tropical cyclone Beryl which brought steady rainfall and embedded thunderstorms to the region. A cold front then brought a second round of thunderstorms in the evening. Thunderstorms with intense rainfall produced narrow bands of 2-4 inches of rain around the area leading to isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported water over several roadways in New Albany.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing shortwave trough created areas of showers over southwest Pennsylvania during the morning of May 18th. Localized low-level convergence led to radar-estimated rain totals of 1.5 to 2.5 inches over portions of Allegheny County, creating some issues with road flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water was reported on Route 28 between the 31st Street Bridge and 40th Street Bridge exits.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This day, May 17th, will be remembered as one of the more unusual tornado days in southwest Pennsylvania. Although overall levels of instability were fairly low, enough of that parameter, plus shear, was concentrated in the 0 to 3 km layer to allow for the formation of low-topped supercells during the early to mid-afternoon hours. Interaction with a surface boundary allowed for tornadogenesis in a few of the storms as low-level streamwise vorticity was ingested into updrafts. Three of the tornadoes were fairly weak, at EF0 level, with one EF1 impacting areas within the Pittsburgh city limits, including the Pittsburgh Zoo. No straight-line wind or hail reports were received, as the storms were small and as the environment did not support those impacts. One isolated flood report was also received in Allegheny County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car with an occupant was submerged in flood water at the intersection of Vermont Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong mid-level trough and an associated frontal zone crossed through the|Mid-South and took aim on the OH Valley. Strong forcing associated the energy aloft coupled with a gradually destabilizing boundary layer out ahead it set the stage for areas of locally heavy showers and thunderstorms for several hours and prompted dangerous flash flooding. A flash flood emergency was issued for portions of Allegheny County when 4 to 5 inches of rain fell on the community of Oakdale, PA in less than 6 hours.  Elsewhere, flash flooding occurred along small tributaries with widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 1006 was flooded between Route 65 and Route 288.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong mid-level trough and an associated frontal zone crossed through the|Mid-South and took aim on the OH Valley. Strong forcing associated the energy aloft coupled with a gradually destabilizing boundary layer out ahead it set the stage for areas of locally heavy showers and thunderstorms for several hours and prompted dangerous flash flooding. A flash flood emergency was issued for portions of Allegheny County when 4 to 5 inches of rain fell on the community of Oakdale, PA in less than 6 hours.  Elsewhere, flash flooding occurred along small tributaries with widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple areas in Petrolia, PA flooded. Route 268 was impacted by a nearby creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of showers and thunderstorms prompted a widespread flash flood problems across the Ohio River Valley on April 2nd to April 3rd. The synoptic pattern across the CONUS was a slow moving and deep elongated trough over the Great Plains phasing with a ejecting trough over the Midwest that created an area of converging moisture over eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Overall, over a span of 4 days, four to five an half inches of rain fell across the region. Not only was small tributaries impact, but the main river reached moderate flood stage. ||Along with flooding, there was a brief period of severe storms that tracked along eastern Ohio on the evening of April 2nd. A number of tornadoes touched down and were surveyed. Special soundings released by PBZ and ILN depict effective instability over eastern Ohio (1200J/kg to 1700J/kg), effective low-level shear (+50kts), and low-level helicity (300m2/s2) for rotating updrafts just before storms tracked through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streams out of their banks in the Moon Township and Robinson area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Homes and businesses were impacted by high water. Oakdale Fire Department had water issues and equipment had to be move to higher ground.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads closed across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A well-organized upper shortwave trough crossing the western Great Lakes and Ohio River Valley and associated cold front crossed the region. Warm, moist conditions across the Ohio River Valley along with limited cloud coverage resulted in increasing instability (2000-3000 J/kg) over the course of the day.  This along with increasing vertical wind shear up to 40kts (effective) as the trough and front approached from the west brought conditions favorable for severe weather by late afternoon / early evening. Damaging wind was the main threat with a notable mid-level dry layer, however, tornadoes were also possible.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported along Benton Avenue.

The synoptic pattern across the CONUS was a slow moving and deep elongated trough over the Great Plains phasing with a ejecting trough over the Midwest that created an area of converging moisture over eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Overall, over a span of 4 days, four to five an half inches of rain fell across the region. Not only was small tributaries impact, but the main river reached moderate flood stage. ||Along with flooding, there was a brief period of severe storms that tracked along eastern Ohio on the evening of April 2nd. A number of tornadoes touched down and were surveyed. Special soundings released by PBZ and ILN depict effective instability over eastern Ohio (1200J/kg to 1700J/kg), effective low-level shear (+50kts), and low-level helicity (300m2/s2) for rotating updrafts just before storms tracked through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gilbert Road closed due to flooding along Clear Run.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Victory Road in Clinton Township experienced flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong mid-level trough and an associated frontal zone crossed through the|Mid-South and took aim on the OH Valley. Strong forcing associated the energy aloft coupled with a gradually destabilizing boundary layer out ahead it set the stage for areas of locally heavy showers and thunderstorms for several hours and prompted dangerous flash flooding. A flash flood emergency was issued for portions of Allegheny County when 4 to 5 inches of rain fell on the community of Oakdale, PA in less than 6 hours.  Elsewhere, flash flooding occurred along small tributaries with widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Houston Road closed between Beaver Dam Road and the PA Turnpike due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A well-organized upper shortwave trough crossing the western Great Lakes and Ohio River Valley and associated cold front crossed the region. Warm, moist conditions across the Ohio River Valley along with limited cloud coverage resulted in increasing instability (2000-3000 J/kg) over the course of the day.  This along with increasing vertical wind shear up to 40kts (effective) as the trough and front approached from the west brought conditions favorable for severe weather by late afternoon / early evening. Damaging wind was the main threat with a notable mid-level dry layer, however, tornadoes were also possible.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported near Roxian Theatre.

A flash flood emergency was issued for portions of Allegheny County when 4 to 5 inches of rain fell on the community of Oakdale, PA in less than 6 hours.  Elsewhere, flash flooding occurred along small tributaries with widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift water rescues being made along Buffalo Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of showers and thunderstorms prompted a widespread flash flood problems across the Ohio River Valley on April 2nd to April 3rd. The synoptic pattern across the CONUS was a slow moving and deep elongated trough over the Great Plains phasing with a ejecting trough over the Midwest that created an area of converging moisture over eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Overall, over a span of 4 days, four to five an half inches of rain fell across the region. Not only was small tributaries impact, but the main river reached moderate flood stage. ||Along with flooding, there was a brief period of severe storms that tracked along eastern Ohio on the evening of April 2nd. A number of tornadoes touched down and were surveyed. Special soundings released by PBZ and ILN depict effective instability over eastern Ohio (1200J/kg to 1700J/kg), effective low-level shear (+50kts), and low-level helicity (300m2/s2) for rotating updrafts just before storms tracked through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reis Run Road closed due to flooding along Lowries Run and Harts Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper-level shortwave provided the focus for convection to develop across northern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of June 20, 2024. High PWAT values near 2 resulted in locally heavy rainfall beneath these slow-moving storms. A report of 2.50 of rainfall in only 25 minutes contributed to localized flash flooding along the headwaters of Pine Creek in Potter County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported in the vicinity of the headwaters of Pine Creek near Cutler Summit and the village of Brookland in Potter County during the afternoon of June 20, 2024, following 2.50 of rain in only 25 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak disturbances tracked along the northern periphery of a strong upper ridge, triggering scattered thunderstorms. Many of the storms developed near a frontal boundary that was approaching the New York-Pennsylvania border. With heat, humidity and instability in place, some thunderstorms moved very slowly producing 1 to 2 inches of rainfall within an hour which contributed to flooding in the metropolitan areas surrounding Wilkes-Barre.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall caused streets and basements to flood near Pittston.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streets and roads were flooded in West Pittston. Several vehicles were stranded in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed ahead of an approaching cold front on June 26, 2024. Some of these storms became severe, producing sporadic wind damage and a few severe hail reports across central Pennsylvania. There was also some flash flooding reported across the northwest mountains in portions of Warren and McKean counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain associated with thunderstorms produced radar estimated 3-4 inches of rain, causing flash flooding with water running across the roadway at the intersection of South Carver Street and Lexington Avenue on the southeast side of Warren.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms slowly moved north across Fayette county as outflow prompted new development. Localized flash flooding was reported in and around Uniontown, PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads and houses flooded in Uniontown, PA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms slowly moved north across Fayette county as outflow prompted new development. Localized flash flooding was reported in and around Uniontown, PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US route 119 at West Main Street closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms slowly moved north across Fayette county as outflow prompted new development. Localized flash flooding was reported in and around Uniontown, PA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approaching central Pennsylvania in an environment of sufficient instability and shear allowed for thunderstorm formation during the late afternoon and evening hours, with multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms crossing the northern tier of Pennsylvania. The multiple rounds of heavy rainfall, coupled with local topography, allowed for flash flooding across hydrologically sensitive areas of Potter and Tioga counties. As thunderstorms progressed southward into the Lower Susquehanna Valley, they began to congeal into a line of thunderstorms producing more widespread wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall produced flash flooding along Fox Hill Road in Ulysses Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of portions of an apartment complex on King George Drive in Lower Paxton Township near the Colonial Park Mall resulted in persons being trapped and evacuated, and the partial collapse of a wall of one apartment building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance in the upper atmosphere slowly moved across the northern tier of Pennsylvania during the afternoon. This feature, along with a stationary frontal boundary at the surface over Northeast Pennsylvania triggered scattered to numerous thunderstorms during the heat of the day. These storms moved very slowly over the region producing torrential rainfall and causing localized flash flooding in Luzerne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over roads in West Nanticoke with several streets closed to traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Modest height falls as a slow moving shortwave trough crossed the region resulted in a few strong to severe storms ahead of a surface cold front. Strongest shear (25-30kts) was observed largely south of Pittsburgh allowing for more organized convection and a heightened severe threat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State officials reported flooded roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Debby moved through, producing damaging wind gusts with a few severe thunderstorms, and heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads around Landenberg were flooded to the point of being impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road in Toughkenamon was flooded with water approximately 1 foot deep. Picture shared through social media.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media shows multiple roads in Kennett Square were closed due to flash flooding. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough over the Great Lakes interacting with a quasi-stationary boundary over eastern Ohio and western PA spawned severe weather from mid afternoon through late evening. MLCAPE near 2000 J/kg along with a relatively strong, elongated shear profiles led to an environment for strong to severe winds and possible tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along Wayne Avenue, and the street was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep plume of tropical moisture had spread over Northeast Pennsylvania ahead of the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby. Prolonged torrential rains blanketed the region during the night and early morning hours before becoming enhanced by the approaching tropical remnants. This enhancement of rainfall led to widespread flash flooding in many parts of the region where roads and bridges were destroyed and washed away along with numerous impacted properties. Many swiftwater rescue teams were deployed to extricate stranded residents from their homes and vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An occupied vehicle was reported to be stranded in the roadway due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple water rescues were reported in Forks Township during the heaviest rain. Time estimated based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall associated with the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby entered southern Pennsylvania prior to sunrise on August 9, 2024. A north-south band of heavy rainfall impacted areas just west of the Susquehanna River leading to flash flooding across Union and Lycoming counties. The community of Trout Run in Lycoming County had to be evacuated due to high water. There were also multiple water rescues and houses with extensive damage in Union County with this heavy rainfall band, with multiple people being forced from their homes. Union County reported 1 property destroyed, 4 properties with major damage, 38 properties with affected or minor damage, and $443,254 in roadway and municipal damages/expenses. Additional rainfall with Debby continued farther west, and produced locally heavy rainfall across the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in portions of eastern Potter and western Tioga counties, where heavy rainfall and topographic impacts allowed for water to rise rapidly in valley locations. There were 26 water rescues reported in Potter County near Harrison Valley with multiple roadways closed throughout the county and many homes being shifted off of their foundation. In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along Maclay Street in Harrisburg led to the road being closed in both directions along with a vehicle becoming stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moving northward across central Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening hours of August 17th allowed for severe thunderstorms to develop across the northern tier of Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall in an environment with long, skinny CAPE and ample moisture produced flash flooding in central Pennsylvania where storms had minimal upper-level movement and moved slowly into the early morning hours of August 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding on Myton Road east of Petersburg, with water rapidly rising over the roadway and closing the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall associated with the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby entered southern Pennsylvania prior to sunrise on August 9, 2024. A north-south band of heavy rainfall impacted areas just west of the Susquehanna River leading to flash flooding across Union and Lycoming counties. The community of Trout Run in Lycoming County had to be evacuated due to high water. There were also multiple water rescues and houses with extensive damage in Union County with this heavy rainfall band, with multiple people being forced from their homes. Union County reported 1 property destroyed, 4 properties with major damage, 38 properties with affected or minor damage, and $443,254 in roadway and municipal damages/expenses. Additional rainfall with Debby continued farther west, and produced locally heavy rainfall across the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in portions of eastern Potter and western Tioga counties, where heavy rainfall and topographic impacts allowed for water to rise rapidly in valley locations. There were 26 water rescues reported in Potter County near Harrison Valley with multiple roadways closed throughout the county and many homes being shifted off of their foundation. In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding led to water rescues of nine people and pets at a residence on Devitt Camp Road in Gregg Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening hours of August 18, 2024 produced showers and thunderstorms, with some storms becoming severe across eastern Pennsylvania in an environment of ample CAPE and shear. Storms began to develop and allowed for multiple rounds of locally heavy rainfall in Lancaster County, causing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving thunderstorm with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding near the intersection of Hershey Avenue and Wabank Road southwest of Lancaster, stranding a car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front stationed across the western highlands with an approaching cold front allowed for thunderstorm formation across western Pennsylvania and continued into central Pennsylvania during the late morning and throughout the afternoon hours on August 31, 2024. Strong-to-severe thunderstorms across north-central Pennsylvania produced isolated instances of thunderstorm wind damage before a more linear complex of thunderstorms moved into southwestern Pennsylvania and produced more widespread thunderstorm wind damage. Multiple instances of heavy rainfall lead to flooding and flash flooding across portions of Somerset County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall caused flash flooding on Hayes Street southeast of Windber, where flood waters began entering homes and basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching MCV alongside a quasi-stationary boundary in an environment enhanced by an upper-level jet allowed for severe thunderstorms to begin firing up across western Pennsylvania during the afternoon hours of August 6, 2024. As thunderstorms continued to progress eastward during the evening hours, increasing instability allowed for more widespread severe thunderstorm wind damage into the Lower Susquehanna Valley with isolated instances of small-to-marginally severe hail and multiple rounds of heavy rainfall producing flooding in Lancaster County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported along Marticville Road near Hidden Acres in Pequea Township. A water rescue was performed, with one person being pulled from a vehicle after trying to drive through the water.

In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in multiple helicopter rescues for individuals trapped on their roofs on Woodlawn Drive and Mill Street in Westfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front progressed across Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening hours of August 29, 2024 with showers and thunderstorms producing flooding concerns into the morning of August 30, 2024. Thunderstorms initially fired across the western highlands of central Pennsylvania, producing isolated severe hail and damaging wind gusts along with flash flooding in urbanized areas of Somerset and Cambria counties. Later in the evening, thunderstorms began to form and train along the frontal boundary slowly sagging southward, producing thunderstorm wind damage across the Middle and Lower Susquehanna Valley. Training thunderstorms with little to no movement began producing considerable flash flooding in Juniata County with multiple roadway closures throughout the county and basement collapses in households. Flash flooding continued into Perry County where multiple roadway closures occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding, washing out the roadway on Route 333 between Port Royal and Thompsontown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall associated with the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby entered southern Pennsylvania prior to sunrise on August 9, 2024. A north-south band of heavy rainfall impacted areas just west of the Susquehanna River leading to flash flooding across Union and Lycoming counties. The community of Trout Run in Lycoming County had to be evacuated due to high water. There were also multiple water rescues and houses with extensive damage in Union County with this heavy rainfall band, with multiple people being forced from their homes. Union County reported 1 property destroyed, 4 properties with major damage, 38 properties with affected or minor damage, and $443,254 in roadway and municipal damages/expenses. Additional rainfall with Debby continued farther west, and produced locally heavy rainfall across the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in portions of eastern Potter and western Tioga counties, where heavy rainfall and topographic impacts allowed for water to rise rapidly in valley locations. There were 26 water rescues reported in Potter County near Harrison Valley with multiple roadways closed throughout the county and many homes being shifted off of their foundation. In Westfield (Tioga County) there were multiple water rescues made by boating and helicopter crews as houses were moved completely off of their foundations and carried downstream.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding led to several homes being dislodged by swift-moving water in Potter Brook. Multiple rescues of residents were required, as well as the rescue of two rescue personnel who were trapped by rising water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moving northward across central Pennsylvania during the late afternoon and evening hours of August 17th allowed for severe thunderstorms to develop across the northern tier of Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall in an environment with long, skinny CAPE and ample moisture produced flash flooding in central Pennsylvania where storms had minimal upper-level movement and moved slowly into the early morning hours of August 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced flash flooding on Charter Oak Road south of Pennsylvania Furnace with water rapidly rising over the roadway.

Flash flooding continued into Perry County where multiple roadway closures occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding south of Port Royal with water rapidly filling the first floor of a residence.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm with heavy rain produced flash flooding that produced rapidly rising water in the basements of multiple residences along Miller Hill Road northeast of Mexico.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving across central Pennsylvania during the afternoon and evening hours of August 18, 2024 produced showers and thunderstorms, with some storms becoming severe across eastern Pennsylvania in an environment of ample CAPE and shear. Storms began to develop and allowed for multiple rounds of locally heavy rainfall in Lancaster County, causing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving thunderstorm with heavy rainfall produced flash flooding on Marticville Road southwest of Baumgardner, resulting in two cars getting stranded in water with water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep plume of tropical moisture had spread over Northeast Pennsylvania ahead of the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby. Prolonged torrential rains blanketed the region during the night and early morning hours before becoming enhanced by the approaching tropical remnants. This enhancement of rainfall led to widespread flash flooding in many parts of the region where roads and bridges were destroyed and washed away along with numerous impacted properties. Many swiftwater rescue teams were deployed to extricate stranded residents from their homes and vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous homes and businesses were flooded including the Thompson Hose Company firehouse.
